Along with jazz and speakeasies, the 1920s were also the heyday of the American carousel. A prime example, restored to its jazz-era glory, now sits on the Brooklyn waterfront. Jane's Carousel (named for Jane Walentas, the artist who rescued and restored it) was built in 1922 by the Philadelphia Toboggan Company and installed in a park. Walentas -- whose husband, David, is largely responsible for the gentrification around the Manhattan Bridge -- found it at an auction in 1984 and spent 27 years bringing it back to life. Even as fancy carousels go, Jane's is especially elaborate, with hand-carved horses and detail work in platinum and gold leaf. The architect Jean Nouvel designed the acrylic box that shields riders from the elements and admits sunshine, creating a winter-garden effect when it's cold, with views of the bridges, Manhattan and the traffic on the water. ''What's exciting is to be right on the river, to have the tugboats and ferries going by,'' Walentas says. ''There's a playfulness about the whole thing.'' Number of horses: 48

RUBELL--Sidney, passed away on November 24, 2011 at the age of 97. He was predeceased in 1996 by his wife Jeannette. He is remembered with great love by daughters Marilyn Rubell and Elaine Gorlechen, son-in-law Norman Gorlechen, granddaughters Lisa Bernstein (husband Michael Bernstein) and Robin Borkowsky (husband David Borkowsky), great-grandchildren Ryan, Kyle and Skyler and longtime companion Ruth Abrams. Sidney Rubell was the founder of Sidney Rubell Company LLC, a real estate company that owns and manages residential and commercial properties in Manhattan. Family and friends will gather at 11am on Sunday, November 27, 2011 at Gutterman's Inc, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

IN honor of Miami Art Basel, which opens next weekend, the Christian Dior label asked the Berlin artist Anselm Reyle to design a collection of colorful accessories. Of his collaboration with the Avenue Montaigne fashion house, Mr. Reyle notes, ''As an artist, I have a fascination with dubious taste, so collaborating with Dior, a symbol of 'good' taste, was exciting.'' He didn't turn the house on its head, so much as on its side. The neon stitching on Dior's quilted cannage bag has been tilted to reflect the artist's fiddling with tradition. The limited-edition flats, totes and jewelry will be available at a Dior pop-up shop in Miami from Monday to Dec. 10, and then in select Dior boutiques come January. They might be camo, but don't expect to blend in. LILY MIESMER

LEVITAN--David M.,born December 25, 1915 in Tver, Lithuania, died November 21, 2011 at his home in Manhattan. He arrived in the U.S. at age 12, speaking no English; within twelve years, he had received degrees from Northwestern University and a Ph.D. from the University of Chicago, and later an LL.B. from Columbia University. He served in the National Youth Administration; as Special Assistant to the Chairman of the War Production Board; as Chief of the Property Control Division, Foreign Economic Administration; as Editor-in-Chief of the first United Nations Manual of Operations; as consultant, producer and host for the ABC broadcasts "On Trial and "Perspectives"; as professor and adjunct professor at the University of Chicago, Columbia University, and other institutions, and as partner at the law firm of Hahn & Hessen. Mr. Levitan authored dozens of law review articles, including a 1940 analysis of Presidential control of foreign relations, cited by Mr. Justice Douglas in U.S. v. Pink. He served on the Nassau County Board of Public Welfare and chaired the Roslyn Harbor Zoning Board for more than thirty years. Mr Levitan was predeceased by his beloved wife of 56 years, Judith Morley Levitan; his parents, Shlomo and Chana; brothers Albert Viton and Max Levitan, and sister Charlotte Turyn. He is survived by daughter Barbara Levitan (Monica Lord), and son Stuart D. Levitan.

JODAITIS--Ellen Rosenfeld, died at age 74 on November 1, 2011. She is survived by her daughter Nancy; her son George and his wife, Brenda; three grandchildren: Amber, Justin, and Jade; her sister Nancy Greener; and her former husband Peter. She received a B.A. from Bates, a PhD from the University of Connecticut and post-doctorate from Harvard. New York City found one of its greatest ambassadors in her. Ellen was loved by many and will be greatly missed!

LILKER--Dr. Martin, 87, of Brooklyn, New York and Boca Raton, Florida. Renowned Jewish educator, teacher and principal at Yeshiva University High Schools, headmaster at Ramaz Upper School, and principal at HAFTR High School. He is survived by his beloved wife Paula (Peshie) Lilker, loving children Bruce, Philip, and Lisa and their spouses Sandy Lilker, Molly Lilker and Michael Reich who were like children to him as well. He is also survived by loving grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Shiva will be observed through Thursday morning December 1st at 773 Hampton Rd, Woodmere, NY.

KRAUSS--Ronnie, of Irvington, NY passed away on November 21, 2011 after a long battle with Pancreatic Cancer. She is survived by her husband Paul Tobey, sons Eric and Brett and sister Ellen. Her strength of spirit and love of family will be remembered by all. Donations to the Lustgarten Foundation.

PLAUT--Joshua Andrew, 42, of Brooklyn, NY, died November 22 at Morristown Memorial Hospital, after succumbing to complications resulting from a snowstorm-related accident that occurred October 29 in Summit, NJ. Sharp, funny and unwaveringly loyal, Mr. Plaut was an associate in the law firm of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati in their New York office. He previously worked at Davis Polk & Wardwell in New York. He clerked for the Honorable Robert W. Sweet of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. Mr. Plaut was born on July 18, 1969. He was raised in Summit, NJ, where he graduated from Summit High School and excelled at lacrosse. At Yale University he majored in English, played lacrosse and graduated cum laude in 1991. He also served as managing editor of The New Journal, a current events magazine. He graduated from Columbia Law School in 2003 where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar and editor-in-chief of the Columbia Journal of Environmental Law. He was named a New York Rising Star by Law & Politics magazine in 2011. Mr. Plaut was an avid runner who completed three marathons, including the New York City Marathon. He is survived by his wife Leonore (Lena) Kim; his parents, Anne and Jonathan Plaut, of Summit, NJ; two brothers, David Lawrence Plaut, of Austin, TX and Jeffrey Benjamin Plaut, of Montclair, NJ; two sisters-in-law, Jane Webre, of Austin, TX and Amy Karas Plaut, of Montclair, NJ; and four nephews and a niece.

WRIGHTSON--Patricia Bowne, of Longboat Key, FL passed away on November 19, 2011. Patty was born on December 8, 1927 in Utica, NY to Thomas B. Bowne and Edith Clarke. She was the widow of George D. Wrightson, who died in 2004. Her first husband, David E. Rickenbacker, died in 1983. Patty was formerly of White River Junction, VT and Upper Montclair, NJ. Patty was a graduate of Abbot Academy, Andover, MA. She volunteered at the Longboat Key Arts Center and the Longboat Key Library. Patty was an active member of All Angels Episcopal Church and the Bird Key Yacht Club. She is survived by a son, D. Brian Rickenbacker, Lexington, KY, daughters Marcia F. Rickenbacker, Enfield, NH and Nancy C. Schindler, Thetford Center, VT, twelve grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in Longboat Key in the Spring. Memorial donations may be made to the Longboat Key Library, All Angels Church or the Sarasota Memorial Foundation.

WACHSBERGER--Clyde Phillip "Skip" 66, of Orient, New York, died at home on Sunday, November 20, 2011. Artist, writer, master gardener, and opera lover, his greatest gift was his capacity for caring friendship. Born in New York City, son of Robert and Helen Dreher Wachsberger, he attended Horace Mann School and Columbia University. After studying stage design at New York University and at the Central School of Speech and Drama, he painted sets for the Metropolitan Opera and for television before co-founding the firm Tromploy. Retired to Orient, he created a garden that has become a mecca for plant-lovers. He leaves his loving spouse, Charles Randall Dean; his loving sister Fredrica and sister-in-law Sylvia Newman; his loving brother William Wachsberger and sister-in-law Phyllis; his beloved nieces Robin Wachsberger and Jennifer Halladay; a community in Orient that feels his loss deeply, and many very devoted friends. Interment will be private; a memorial gathering will be announced.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the Harvard football team's 45-7 victory over Yale described incorrectly the events at halftime after the public-address announcer asked for a moment of silence for the victims of an accident outside the Yale Bowl before the game. Yale's band did indeed perform at halftime (as did Harvard's); the band did not remain quiet for the remainder of halftime. The article also misidentified the team that Harvard defeated the previous week to clinch the Ivy League title. It was Penn, not Princeton.

KENNEDY--Mary Brewster, of Cambridge and Tisbury, MA died in Cambridge, November 16, 2011 at 97. Graduate of Miss Hall's School and Smith College, Class of 1936. Only sister of the late Hon. Kingman Brewster, Jr. She is survived by her daughter, Lucy E. Collins, M.D. (Harry Davidow) of NYC and their family; three Kennedy stepsons: Duncan (Mopsy) of Cambridge, David (Nadia) of Montclair, NJ, Charles of San Diego and their families. A beautiful woman of discerning taste and progressive social values, she was a skilled interior designer and devoted matriarch to her "blended" family. Burial will be private. A memorial service is planned for the spring. Further information at: www.levinechapel.com.

ON Nov. 13, the celebrated modernist designer Eva Zeisel turned 105. She marked the occasion by publishing ''Prison Memoir,'' which details the 16 months she spent in a Soviet prison in the 1930s, during which time she tried to commit suicide by cutting her wrists with a copper wire pulled from a toilet. The Hungarian-born designer had been falsely accused of plotting to kill Stalin. She describes her Leningrad prison cell rather cheerily as ''a cupboard.'' ''I started to do gymnastics,'' she writes in the memoir, published this month in the literary journal A Public Space. ''I tried to stand on my head. This was rather easy in the cupboard because there is not too much room to fall.'' Brigid Hughes, the founding editor of A Public Space, visited Ms. Zeisel at her home in Rockland County earlier this year to work on editing. ''She's very, very sharp,'' said Ms. Hughes, who noted that even though Ms. Zeisel's vision and hearing were fading, she was still at work on new designs, including a little ceramic egg holder. STEPHEN HEYMAN

Broadway box offices enjoyed a hearty Thanksgiving last week, with 34 musicals and plays grossing a total of $28.1 million, an increase of 6 percent from the comparable holiday week last November when 39 shows were running. Earning more money from fewer shows is in part the result of a so-called dynamic pricing strategy among Broadway theater owners and producers to sell more premium price tickets for high-demand performances, including during holiday season.

For a period of time in the early 1960s, a young commercial photographer named William John Kennedy made a habit of shooting a couple of artists he had befriended in New York's gallery scene. He then filed the negatives away in a cardboard box, where they remained for almost 50 years. Now 81 and living in Miami Beach, Kennedy recently unearthed the archive: the artists were Robert Indiana and Andy Warhol, and the period was late 1962 to 1964, the years during which Indiana and Warhol were becoming household names. The photographs, which will be exhibited at the Scope Miami art show during Art Basel Miami Beach, include some of the only known shots of Indiana and Warhol with their iconic works: Indiana with his "Love" painting, Warhol with an acetate of Marilyn Monroe. Perhaps more remarkably, though, they capture the artists not fully formed but on the cusp of fame. "They were in their infancy," Kennedy said by phone from Miami. "But by the end, it would be a miracle if I could shoot one minute because Andy was constantly going to the telephone to answer calls."

David Dunlap writes and photographs for The City Room blog about his visit to the hilltop at the Cypress Hills Cemetery set aside for journalists who died without the means to buy burial sites of their own - so-called "friendless journalists." In 1874, a newspaper fraternity acquired 24 lots - room for 360 graves - in the cemetery, which sits on the Brooklyn-Queens border. Thirteen years later, the New York Press Club raised the money for a 38-foot obelisk to set the place apart, and, as Mr. Dunlap notes: "For a while thereafter, journalists were just dying to get into Cypress Hills." Read more at City Room ».

One measure I've been tracking lately is the German 5-year breakeven. That's the difference between the interest rate on ordinary German 5-year bonds and the interest rate on 5-year bonds that are indexed to inflation (as measured by the euro area harmonized CPI); because one bond is protected against inflation while the other isn't, the breakeven amounts to an implicit market forecast of inflation.

On Nov. 28, 1943, President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Britain and the Soviet leader Josef Stalin met in Tehran during World War II for the start of a four-day conference. It was the first meeting between the "Big Three" Allied leaders.News of the conference was not released until three days after its completion, when it was announced by Moscow radio. The Dec. 4 New York Times reported that "Moscow radio had not indicated the nature of political and military discussions that took place in the Iranian capital, but it was generally assumed they dealt with the coordination of military plans for the final assault on Nazi Germany and with the unification of political plans for making peace with Germany on the basis of 'unconditional surrender.'"

GROSSMAN--Richard L, 68, of West Hurley, NY, author, activist and legal historian, died of cancer on November 22, 2011. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Richard was a forward-thinking community organizer, dedicated civic strategist and bold, provocative writer who consistently challenged rule by the privileged few and the dominance of corporate influence in government and culture. Passionate about the environment, he founded and directed Environmentalists for Full Employment; was executive director of Greenpeace USA; co-founded and taught Stop the Poisoning Schools at the Highlander Center in Tennessee. He designed and taught activist public interest workshops on Rethinking the Corporation and Rethinking Strategy. In 2011 he co-founded the Sovereign People's Action Network and the current anti-fracking citizen's group, Frackbusters NY. Richard's books and influential pamphlets include Taking Care of Business: Citizenship and the Charter of Incorporation; On the Supreme Court; Defying Corporations, Defining Democracy; and Fear at Work,: Job Blackmail, Labor and the Environment. He is survived by his loving family members, including his wife Mary L. MacArthur, daughter Alyssa Grossman, brand new grandson, Milo Grossman, brothers Lawrence and Daniel, aunt Dr. Shirley Grossman, and many dear nieces, nephews, and cousins. A memorial service will be held on Saturday afternoon, December 10th at the Lifebridge Sanctuary, in Rosendale, NY.

EBay has been adding new technologies to its arsenal lately in an effort to overhaul its retail identity and better compete with rivals like Amazon. Included in the company's recent acquisitions are RedLaser, a bar-code scanning application; Milo, a price comparison tool; and GSI Commerce, a provider of online services that will help the company work with larger retailers. On Monday, the company announced the latest step in its strategy: the acquisition of Hunch, an online recommendation start-up based in New York. Hunch creates a profile of what it thinks a person will like based on information about that person's friends and activity from around the Web.

MORRIS--Margaret Wager, passed away peacefully on November 26, 2011. She was born on October 5, 1918 and grew up in Far Rockaway. After high school she attended Cooper Union as a fine arts major, from which she graduated in 1939. She met her husband, the late David Lionel Morris, at Cooper Union and together with him raised a family in Great Neck, NY, where they resided for many years. She is survived by her twin daughters and their husbands, Susan and Stephen Butterfass of Croton-on-Hudson, and Marion and Martin Bush of White Plains, and a son and his wife Richard and Vicki Morris of Ringoes, NJ. She was a devoted grandmother to Alexandra, Alison, Ariel, Dionne and Tamara; and great-grandmother to twins Athen and Geordy. She will be very fondly remembered and missed by her many friends as well. Marge was a great lover of the outdoors. She skied in the winter and hiked in the other seasons. She had a lifelong love for gardening, bird watching and, in particular, collecting, identifying and lecturing about edible wild plants and mushrooms. For many years she was a member and executive officer of the New York Mycological Society and other groups devoted to preserving nature. Donations in her memory can be made to The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art.

LISBON -- Spain's departing Socialist government granted a pardon on Friday to Alfredo Sáenz, chief executive of Banco Santander, commuting a three-month prison sentence and a temporary ban from working as a banker. Instead, Mr. Sáenz must pay a fine. The government's unexpected decision removes a source of the uncertainty surrounding the leadership of Santander, the largest bank in the euro zone by market valuation.

The green kayak of the fisherman, Etay Levy, 46, of Brooklyn, flipped over a little after 1 p.m., a spokesman for the New York Police Department said.

WASHINGTON -- The coverage was hard-hitting and shocking to some: members of Congress received special opportunities to get in on the ground floor of stock offerings and were actively trading in shares of companies ''whose prosperity they influence and whose conduct they help to regulate.'' Those words were not from this month's ''60 Minutes'' report raising questions about the Wall Street dealings of top lawmakers, or a new book exploring the same issue. They appeared in the 1968 exposé ''The Case Against Congress'' by the muckrakers Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson, who laid out dubious financial maneuvers by lawmakers seeking to enrich themselves using their powerful positions and inside knowledge.

8 P.M. (Ovation) FRIDA (2002) Julie Taymor directed this film about the Mexican painter Frida Kahlo: her life, work, politics and pain, both psychological and physical. The movie was nominated for six Academy Awards and won for makeup and original score. Salma Hayek, below, nominated for best actress for her portrayal of Kahlo, has said she pursued the role for eight years. Alfred Molina channels Kahlo's husband, Diego Rivera. ''Ms. Taymor's film, adapted by no fewer than four screenwriters from Hayden Herrera's biography, is as restless and determined as its subject, whose painful, promiscuous life has become, almost 50 years after her death, something of a pop-culture legend,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''But while Kahlo, at least in the account favored by Ms. Herrera and Ms. Taymor, refused to be constrained by her sex, social convention or disability, 'Frida' is corseted by the norms of high-toned, responsible filmmaking, ticking off important events in Kahlo's life without much insight or feeling.'' But, he added, ''when the movie manages to break free -- in bursts of color, imagination, music, sex and over-the-top theatricality -- it honors the artist's brave, anarchic spirit.'' 10:30 A.M. (Oxygen)I NOW PRONOUNCE YOU CHUCK & LARRY (2007) Chuck (Adam Sandler) and Larry (Kevin James) are heterosexual New York City firefighters who pose as gay partners for insurance purposes. Jessica Biel plays Alex, the object of Chuck's affection -- if only he could tell her he prefers girls.

Aging reporters know, long before they are gone, that they are already forgotten; their scoops and exclusives and front-page triumphs no more than historical footnotes. If that. The thought that a pauper's grave would be the coup de grace was too much to bear for journalists of the 19th century. In 1874, the newspaper fraternity took title to 24 lots - room for 360 graves - on a hilltop at the Cypress Hills Cemetery, straddling the Brooklyn-Queens line. The plot was intended for ''friendless journalists'' who had died without the means to buy burial sites of their own.

The wake to be held at Riverdale Funeral Home, on Tuesday, November 29th from 2-4pm and 6-9pm. The funeral, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church, Riverdale NY, on Wednesday, November 30th at 9:45am. I share a virtual neighborhood with a legion of Times reporters, editors and columnists who know more than I will ever know about business and economics. (Look! Right over there: a Nobel-prize-winning economist!) In this humbling company, on this intimidating matter, who am I to tell anyone what to think? And so my plan was, frankly, to avoid the subject. But while there are things a columnist can ignore (if Kim Kardashian ever features in this column, just shoot me), our failing economic ecosystem is not one of them. So for the past several weeks my airplane and bedside reading has consisted of sexy documents like ''A Roadmap for America's Future'' and ''The Way Forward'' and ''The Moment of Truth'' and ''Restoring America's Future'' and ''Living Within Our Means and Investing in the Future.'' I've also reached out to a few economists respected for the integrity of their science and their patience with economic illiterates.

Earlier this week we published an article about Google Apps, and Google's struggle to displace Microsoft Office and Sharepoint inside large corporations. While Google has worked without a large consulting partner, it should be said that several smaller consultancies are working to encourage companies to adopt Google's cloud-based office productivity software. Among these are Dito, SADA Systems, Appirio and Cloud Sherpas. Each offers a somewhat different approach. SADA is reselling both Microsoft and Google products. Appirio offers Google along with a broad range of other cloud services for business, like Salesforce.com. Dito is making much of moving companies to Google's Chromebooks, which are lightweight laptops built for cloud interactions. Cloud Sherpas is among the largest consultants stressing Apps, and it claims to have moved over 1 million people to Google Apps.

LOS ANGELES -- Despite much learned talk about the game-changing scientific discoveries in radioactivity it portrays, ''Radiance,'' a new drama by Alan Alda at the Geffen Playhouse here, doesn't emit much in the way of theatrical light. Certainly Mr. Alda, the amiable actor and besotted science buff, does his studious best to illuminate the challenges that Marie Curie, gracefully portrayed by Anna Gunn, faced in pursuing a career in the sciences at a time when it was virtually unheard of for women to take prominent roles in academic or public life. But his dramatization of Curie's personal and professional trials often feels like a talking diorama in a science museum, at least until it makes a sudden leap into juicy, gaslit melodrama in the second act.

Millions of Americans who got on a plane over the Thanksgiving holiday heard the admonition: ''Please power down your electronic devices for takeoff.'' And absolutely everyone obeyed. I know they did because no planes fell from the sky. No planes had to make an emergency landing because the avionics went haywire. No planes headed for Miami ended up in Anchorage. We were all made safe because we all turned off all our Kindles, iPads, iPhones, BlackBerrys and laptops, just as the Federal Aviation Administration told us to. Realistically speaking, I'm going to bet that a handful of people on each flight could not be bothered, or forgot to comply.

On Friday, after shoppers had battled one another for bargains that might not have existed, balletgoers of many ages gathered at the David H. Koch Theater for a more reliable holiday ritual. As New York City Ballet's ''Nutcracker'' began its annual run of performances there, the tree telescoped on cue, the seven-headed Mouse King was vanquished, snowflakes swirled, and flowers waltzed. The Christmas magic in George Balanchine's imperishable staging, as in Tchaikovsky's score, is built in, guaranteed. Balanchine's inclusion of real children helps to guarantee it. Students from the School of American Ballet are always impeccably rehearsed. The comic details of child behavior in the party scene call for minimal acting, and a strong performance, like that of the gallant Colby Clark as Herr Drosselmeier's nephew, can make a difference. But the seriousness with which all of the children approach their dancing, their mimicry of adult civility, isn't acting. The drama underlying the ballet's fantasy and shifts of scale is really happening: the passing on of tradition. As it was for Balanchine as a child in St. Petersburg, Russia.

LOS ANGELES -- A family film free-for-all over the holiday weekend ended with puppets doing cartwheels, elves wondering what went wrong and Martin Scorsese somewhere in between. Hollywood's five-day Thanksgiving sales period -- considered crucial to generating momentum through Christmas -- was not as bountiful as studio officials had hoped. Ticket sales totaled about $234 million, an 11 percent decline from the same stretch last year, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing data.

FLYNN--Amy Mazzola. Died when hit by an automobile while out for a walk after Thanksgiving dinner with her family on November 24, 2011. She was the wife of Terence "Tad" Flynn, mother of James Davis Flynn and Christina Pleasant Flynn; sister of Alison Mazzola; and daughter of Sylvia and John Mazzola. She attended the Brearley School as well as the School of American Ballet, and graduated with honors from Harvard College in 1985. Amy was Woody Allen's script girl at age 17 with Bea Arthur as her chaperone. Amy was a vice president of JPMorgan & Co until 1995. She was active with the School of American Ballet and other organizations. She was a member of the Board of Directors of the American Friends of the Paris Opera and Ballet, member of the Watch Hill Yacht Club (RI), the Misquamicut Club (RI) and Doubles in New York. She will be missed dearly by all who knew her. Her friends were many, her talents were abundant, and her storytelling was legendary. At Frank E Campbell 5 to 8pm on Monday Nov 28. Funeral service will be held on Tuesday, November 29th at 2 at St. Thomas church, 53rd and fifth Avenue, New York, NY.

Every Sunday morning for three decades, the Rev. Maurice Chase would drive to Los Angeles's most desperate neighborhood, where he would hand out crisp new one-dollar bills, along with a handshake and a blessing. Clad in a Notre Dame hat and red sweater over his clerical collar, ''Father Dollar Bill,'' as he was known, cut a hugely popular figure with Skid Row's homeless. Hundreds would gather each week to await his arrival, forming a line that sometimes stretched four blocks.

Retired Executive Vice President of Babaco Alarm Systems; former President of the Visiting Nurse Association of Oyster Bay. Served under General Patton in WWII. Received his BA from Adelphi University and MA from Hofstra University. Services and Interment private. Donations in memory of William E. Blatz to St. Francis Hospital Development Office, 100 Port Washington Blvd., Roslyn, NY 11576.

Born in Schenectady, she was a world traveler who explored Europe, Africa and Asia. Carol, the daughter of Walter Olszewski and Sophie Sajta, is survived by her loving daughter, Regina Schwartz.

It's a taboo of the digital era: using a cellphone in a darkened theater. Some performance spaces, like Carnegie Hall, politely flash a notice reminding patrons to turn off electronic devices, while others, like the Alamo Drafthouse cinema chain in Texas, go so far as to eject violators. One new hall near Seattle is turning that logic on its head by encouraging patrons to send texts and update their Twitter and Facebook accounts to their heart's content. The Tateuchi Center in Bellevue, Wash., is expected to open in 2014 with a policy of smartphone laissez-faire, as a bet that allowing technological engagement will draw younger audiences.

GOLD--Herbert Z. (1915-2011), adoring husband and father, and mensch to all who knew him, died in the early morning after Thanksgiving at the age of 96. Born in Brooklyn, Herb, graduated from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania, where he played piccolo in the marching band, and then from NYU Law School. He later joined his father's business building homes and apartment buildings in Rockville Centre and Hewlett Harbor. He was appointed redeveloper as a partner of the firm of Stackler, Frank and Gold to build and complete the Urban Renewal Program for the Village of Rockville Centre, New York, and other projects on Long Island. In 1941 he met Rita Weinstein and when he asked which street he should take to drive her home, she told him to take the long way, and they did: He was married to Rita for 67 years before her passing in 2008. Together, they raised their beautiful son Richard, who sadly passed at the age of 35. Herb was a generous benefactor to countless organizations and individuals throughout the world. He established the Rita Gold Early Childhood Centers at Columbia University's Teachers College and in Tel Aviv. Herb funded many scholarships for young Opera singers, as well as for underprivileged students making it possible for them to go on to higher education. He was also a generous donor to The New York City Opera, Julliard, and The Sarasota Opera. Herb lived life to the fullest, inspiring those around him to strive to fulfill their highest potential. He was a kind, soft-spoken man of keen intellect and quick wit. Herb was a philanthropist and active participant in Jewish causes in the US and Israel, and a caring and generous friend to so many. He has left all of us an extraordinary legacy of learning and commitment to service. He will always be in our hearts. He is survived by his brother Ronny and loving cousins in America and Israel. Services will be held graveside on Monday, 12 noon, at The Old Montifiore Cemetery, located off Springfield Blvd. in St. Albans, Queens, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

SCHAUBER--Edgar, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Rye Brook, NY passed away on November 26 after losing his battle with pneumonia. He was 87. Son of Millie and Morris Schauber, Ed was born June 17, 1924 in Brooklyn, New York. He graduated from Erasmus High School, and was an alumnus of Brooklyn College. He served in the OSS in WWII and spent his career as a leader in building and guiding Central Petroleum Corporation. With his wife, Lois, he enjoyed traveling, theater, the ballet, music, reading, golf, playing bridge, talking politics, telling jokes and watching the grass grow. He took pleasure in making charitable contributions to a number of organizations, including Ben Gurion University and United Jewish Federation. Ed lived a rich and full life. As a young man he marched in the May Day parade. As an older man, he enjoyed playing Monopoly with his grandchildren. He always told us that you have to give back and always lived with the thought what will they say when you're gone? He was a devoted husband, father and grandfather who enriched the lives of those he touched. Ed sometimes like to play the game what would you like to come back as?. He wanted to come back as a song-and-dance man. He couldn't, as those who lived with him know, carry a tune. He was, however, a very graceful dancer. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, Lois Schauber, of Boca Raton, his sons Marc Schauber, Paul Schauber and his wife, Cathy, his daughter, Nancy Schauber and her husband A. John Simmons, and his grandchildren, Michael, Kristin, Elizabeth, Carolyn, Molly, and Sarah. Ed made people smile wherever he went; he will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, please do something kind for someone less fortunate than yourself.

On Sunday night, the fashion collective Three as Four opened its highly anticipated exhibition "Insalaam Inshalom" at the Beit Ha'Ir Center for Urban Culture in Tel Aviv, bringing to fruition a project over two years in the making. Covering the walls of the four-story building in fabric printed with their spring collection's central motifs, which are made of a mix of Muslim and Jewish symbols, the designers Gabi Asfour, Adi Gil and Ange Donhauser invited 10 artists to show works that relate to the project's central notion: that Judaism and Islam can live side by side. "We've accumulated the energy of artists and performers who are like-minded," Asfour said. "We tried to balance things from all sides, though it's always difficult."

A place in the starting lineup is one of the N.B.A.'s most overrated currencies. In actuality it indicates nothing, other than that a given team prefers to have a particular player on the floor to complete a specific lineup. Sometimes the starting five consists of the top five players on the roster, but more often it is a group that has been configured to manage strength and weakness, balance starters and reserves, and create a meaningful product out of a roster of moving parts.

On July 2, 2002, two luxury barges idled in New York Harbor. One, the Queen Elizabeth 2, had just completed a transatlantic crossing from Southampton, England. The other, the first Maybach 62 sedan ever produced, had stowed away for the voyage in a glass box on the ship's sun deck. The box was eventually lifted, gingerly, by a cargo helicopter and set down on a nearby pier, from which the V-12-powered car departed for a news conference on Wall Street.

The father of modern-day foraging, René Redzepi, is not short on accolades. His Copenhagen restaurant, Noma, has earned best restaurant in the world in San Pellegrino's foodie poll two years in a row, his abstract dishes comparisons to the paintings of Cy Twombly. Behind the chef's famously free-form approach is a highly studious investigation into the culinary possibilities of foraged ingredients. The El Bulli and French Laundry veteran has set up a nonprofit called the Nordic Food Lab on a nearby houseboat to "create cornerstones for a new kind of cuisine," he says. The research lab, led by Lars Williams, a former Noma chef and an alum of New York's WD-50, has been experimenting with fermentation and umami for seven months, for instance. "It's a bridge between science and the cooking world, but not for the sake of science," Redzepi says. "For the sake of deliciousness." Go to interactive feature >>

The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts said on Tuesday that the pianist and composer Jason Moran has been appointed its new artistic adviser for jazz. Mr. Moran, 36, is the second person to hold that post, which had been vacant since the death last year of Billy Taylor, the venerable pianist and educator who began advising the Kennedy Center in 1994.

They don't call it the Scottish play for nothing: when a new National Theater of Scotland production of "Macbeth" comes to the Lincoln Center Festival in the summer it will have only one Scotsman composing its entire cast, thus lowering the risk if anyone says its title out loud. Alan Cumming, the "Good Wife" and "Cabaret" star (not to mention the voice of another great Scot, Gutsy Smurf), will perform every single role in the Shakespeare tragedy, including the regicidal schemer of its title and his devious, spot-obsessed wife (though we're especially intrigued to see what he does with the three witches). The production, to be directed by John Tiffany and Andy Goldberg, will originate in June at the Tramway in Glasgow, and then be presented at the Lincoln Center Festival in New York from July 5 through July 14.

The 100-some dresses Patrick Demarchelier photographed for "Dior Couture" (Rizzoli, $115) constitute a high-gloss tribute to the venerable fashion house. But the book is also a curiously timed retrospective of Dior's fallen creative director, John Galliano, who designed the bulk of what's included here. Demarchelier dusted off frocks by Dior and his successors, Yves Saint Laurent and Marc Bohan. (Gianfranco Ferré, who was creative director from 1989 to 1996, is left out.) The foreword is by Jeff Koons - a Dior fan, apparently - who sees the couture pieces as "reminiscent of a spider's web, mirroring nature."

Norman Mailer famously called Truman Capote the most perfect writer of his generation, saying of "Breakfast at Tiffany's'' that he would not change two words. The 1961 film that came out three years after the novel's publication of course changed many words, siphoning off the book's abiding spirit of melancholy. When I encountered it for the first time, years ago, just out of college, I felt a race of fury over the liberties and licenses Hollywood had taken in its rendering. Holly's profession is hardly glossed over in the novel, and her neighbor, the book's unnamed narrator, does not and cannot provide her with a happy ending. I'm interested in hearing from all of you, but especially from those who have just read the book for the first time, presumably after some familiarity with the iconic film.

The Republican presidential candidate Herman Cain, whose campaign had already been stung by accusations of sexual harassment, was confronted with allegations on Monday that he carried on a 13-year affair with an Atlanta businesswoman. Because the story broke while Mr. Cain was live on CNN's "The Situation Room," he responded to the allegations by the woman, Ginger White, before they had actually aired on the Fox affiliate in Atlanta, WAGA-TV. According to The Huffington Post, the allegations "didn't come up during Cain's first segment with anchor Wolf Blitzer. That's because Blitzer didn't know about them either when the two men sat down." During that first segment of three, CNN producers began to see posts to Twitter that mentioned the coming WAGA story. "While seated during a commercial break, Blitzer then asked Cain about the Atlanta report and the candidate acknowledged that his campaign had been contacted about it and would be willing to discuss it on air," Michael Calderone of The Huffington Post reported. [Huffington Post]

Presidential elections are predictable. At the national level, economic conditions - measures like the change in per-capita income in the year or so preceding the election - usually do a good job predicting the popular vote. At the state level, you can usually predict the outcome given the vote last time, after adjusting for the economy and the home states and regions of the candidates. At the level of individual voters, preferences are largely predictable from political ideology, degree of partisanship, and, again, recent economic conditions.

STUDLEY--George L.,81, died peacefully at home on Thursday, November 24, after a long illness. He is survived by Helen, his wife of 55 years, his son Jonathan, daughter Alexandra, two grandchildren, Luke and Annabel, his brother Julien and sister-in-law Jane Studley. Friends and family will be notified of memorial service to be held.
GILITOS--Domenick. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Domenick Gilitos, associated with The New York Times from September 1, 1963 until retiring on December 1, 1993.

MURPHY--James P.,80. died, on November 27, 2011, peacefully at home. He is survived by his beloved, wife of 55 years, Margaret. He is remembered with great love by his children and their spouses, Patricia, Jim and Linda, Michael, Matthew and Amy, Chris and Karen and Cathy and Juan and his grandchildren, James III, Andrew, Charlie, Julia, Lily, Billy, Ryan, Danny, Jack, James and Cate. He graduated from LaSalle Academy, Manhattan College and Fordham Law School, where he was a member of the law review. At his retirement, he was an Executive Vice President and Director of Public Policy for Fleet Financial Group. Previously he was the Executive Vice President of the New York State Bankers Association, was a Vice President at Chemical Bank, and was an associate at Shearman & Sterling. He served as the Chairman of the Board of Trustees for the City University of New York from 1980 to 1997. He was a member of the Board and a past Chairman of the Board of the Futures in Education Foundation of the Diocese Of Brooklyn and Queens. His particular love was his work with the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, where he served as member of the Board and a past President. Visitation will be at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY, at 81st Street on Wednesday, November 30th from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Thursday, December 1st, at 10:30 at the Church of Saint Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street, New York, NY, followed by interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to The Association for the Help of Retarded Children, 8 Maiden Lane, New York, NY 10038.

An article on Monday about movie ticket sales during the Thanksgiving holiday period misstated part of the title of a film that opened on Wednesday. It is ''My Week With Marilyn,'' not ''My Weekend With Marilyn.''

After proving to be a stable presence on broadcast television for more than 60 years, the Hallmark Hall of Fame is off to a rough start in its new home at ABC. That feel-good film franchise was dropped by CBS in May after a 16-year partnership, only to be picked up in July by ABC. But it seems that its audience forgot to change the channel. On Sunday ABC showed its first Hallmark movie, ''Mitch Albom's Have a Little Faith,'' which lost more than 50 percent of the total audience from last year's post-Thanksgiving Sunday presentation of ''November Christmas.'' That movie drew 13.5 million total viewers for CBS while ''Have a Little Faith'' managed only 6.5 million for ABC. Over all for the night, NBC dominated every ratings category with ''Sunday Night Football,'' as the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Kansas City Chiefs, 13-9. Final numbers were not available Monday.

OLD--Lloyd J. The staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) note with sadness the death of our esteemed colleague Lloyd J. Old, who was internationally recognized as one of the founders and standard bearers of the field of tumor immunology. His research over a period of more than 50 years has directly enabled the design and development of tumor-specific vaccines and targeted antibodies. He was dedicated to developing the field of immunology and was a devoted and selfless mentor to hundreds of young researchers. His vision and leadership brought basic and clinical investigators together, across institutional and international borders, to take tumor immunology from animal models into clinical research and the development of promising new cancer therapies. Dr. Old joined MSKCC in 1958, served as associate director of research from 1973 to 1983, and was named to the William E. Snee Chair in Cancer Immunology in 1983. In June 2011 he received the C. Chester Stock Award from MSKCC. Dr. Lloyd also served for 17 years as Director of the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research and for 30 years as Scientific Director of the Cancer Research Institute. He will be sorely missed by all his colleagues. We extend our sympathies to his family. Craig B. Thompson, MD President, Robert E. Wittes, MD Physician-in-Chief, Thomas J. Kelly, MD PhD Director, Sloan-Kettering Institute

Just in time for Thanksgiving, a major new study offers some hopeful news about fat and fate, as well as about the consequences of the choices we make. For the research, investigators tallied the results of dozens of studies about the effects of exercise on the so-called fat gene, which is believed to increase the risk that carriers will be overweight or obese by 12 percent or more. Scientists first identified this gene, called the ''fat mass and obesity-associated'' gene, or FTO gene, several years ago, and as it turns out, it's distressingly common. By most estimates, about 65 percent of people of European or African descent and perhaps 44 percent of Asians carry some version of the FTO gene.

Gawker Media on Monday named new editors for two of its most prominent sites, the flagship Gawker and the sports and men's lifestyle site Deadspin. Remy Stern, the editor of Gawker for nearly two years, will be replaced by A. J. Daulerio, who has edited Deadspin for the last three and a half years. Mr. Daulerio, in turn, will be replaced by the senior editor of Deadspin, Tommy Craggs. The moves will take effect on Jan. 1.

About an hour after AT&T announced its $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile in March on a Sunday afternoon, I got a call at home. It was Randall L. Stephenson, AT&T's chairman and chief executive. Mr. Stephenson, an affable man with a wry sense of humor, knew he would face a battle persuading regulators the deal should be approved. And with me. As I peppered him with questions about why the government would possibly allow the No. 2 and No. 4 telephone carriers to merge - a textbook example of creating a duopoly between AT&T and Verizon if there ever was one - he deftly stood his ground. He was convinced the deal would happen.

An article in some editions on Saturday about the similarity between the Jets' push for a playoff spot this season and the same situation last season misstated the winning percentage of the remaining six teams on the Jets' schedule. Before Sunday's games, the Jets' final opponents had a winning percentage of .410 (25-36), not . 373 (19-32).

Blood thinners and diabetes drugs cause most emergency hospital visits for drug reactions among people over 65 in the United States, a new study shows. Just four medications or medication groups -- used alone or together -- were responsible for two-thirds of emergency hospitalizations among older Americans, according to the report. At the top of the list was warfarin, also known as Coumadin, a blood thinner. It accounted for 33 percent of emergency hospital visits. Insulin injections were next on the list, accounting for 14 percent of emergency visits.

(HBO2) TOOTH FAIRY (2010) Dwayne Johnson plays Derek Thompson, a fading ice hockey star also known as the Tooth Fairy for his habit of knocking out opponents' teeth. But when he mocks the beliefs of his girlfriend's daughter, he is summoned to fairyland to be prosecuted as a dream killer. His punishment is two weeks of exchanging baby teeth for dollars while outfitted in wings and a pink tutu. Ashley Judd is Derek's beloved, and Julie Andrews is fairyland's chief executive. ''Like most family films nowadays, the movie squanders a lot of energy righteously huffing and puffing its message: let kids dream,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times.

NEW HAVEN - College students seeking jobs on Wall Street have always had hurdles to overcome - grueling applications, endless rounds of interviews and fierce competition for the relatively few available spots at top firms. This year's Wall Street hopefuls have had a new force to contend with: the wrath of their peers.

LANE--William, 57, Deputy Director of Social Work at Jacobi Medical Center and North Central Bronx Hospital, Director of the Employee Assistance Program, Private Practitioner, Educator, Mentor, Advocate, Innovator and friend to all. Bill, as he liked to be called, died of injuries sustained in a tragic accident on Friday, November 25. He attended Clark University and Columbia University School of Social Work, Class of 1978. Bill earned his CASAC and dedicated many years to working with patients in both his hospital based and private practice. Most recently he worked in partnership with New York City agencies to develop and implement an Emergency Preparedness curriculum with the goal of initiating a Social Work Disaster Response Team in the Bronx. Bill dedicated his life to enhancing the integrity of Social Work practice. Bill was a consummate nurturer and touched the lives of countless people and communities. He had a love and passion for sailing, cooking and spices, travel, and working with his hands on various creative and home projects. He was known for his integrity, commitment, loyalty and love for his friends and family. Survived by the love of his life, his wife Susan Wortman, his parents, Reverends Robert and Fidelia Lane, siblings Rebecca Keefe and Janet Armstrong, in-laws, nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Jacobi Medical Center Auxiliary, Inc 1400 Pelham Parkway S. Bronx, NY 10461 Nurses Residence 7 North.

We write with bad news about Violet, the red-tailed hawk whose child-rearing and leg problems were chronicled on City Room in the spring. Violet, mother of Pip, is now in danger of losing the banded leg that had plagued her even before the Hawk Cam started rolling on the 12th-floor window of New York University's Bobst Library.

How many basketball players in pickup games around New York City still have a killer two-handed set shot? Bob Gold does. He's 71 years old and has been playing for 40 years in a year-round weekly game in Greenwich Village that he calls the longest continuously running pickup game in the city.

Frederic Boyer, a veteran of the film-festival circuit who has most recently been in charge of the Directors' Fortnight at Cannes, will be the new artistic director of the Tribeca Film Festival, its organizers said on Monday. Mr. Boyer, 52, has been the artistic director and head of programming for Directors' Fortnight since 2009. He also is the artistic director of Les Arcs European Film Festival, held at Les Arcs ski resort in France, and ran the art-house video store Videosphere in Paris. Peter Scarlet, the Tribeca festival's last artistic director, resigned in 2009 when Geoffrey Gilmore, the longtime director of the Sundance Film Festival, was brought in as Tribeca's chief creative officer. ''This is a very creative festival,'' Mr. Boyer said in a telephone interview. ''They have a very open mind, and for them they wanted me maybe to bring some more European connections. I have some contacts they don't have, they have some contacts I don't have, and we will join our forces to do something very specific and very unusual. I have a lot to learn from the Tribeca Film Festival.'' The 11th annual festival is scheduled to run in New York April 18 to 29.

SABIN--Ruth, died November 25, 2011, in Mamaroneck, NY at the age of 89. Liz and Alix Sabin, Nancy Drooker and Sharon Oliver were at her bedside. Memorial gifts may be made to Wildlife Conservation Service: www.wcs.org. Condolences may be sent to: Liz Sabin, Sabin, Bermant & Gould, Four Times Square, 23d floor, New York, NY 10036.

The playwright Tony Kushner, below, has been named the recipient of a $100,000 award honoring artists and others for ''socially responsible work'' and challenges to authority, like Mr. Kushner's fight with City University of New York trustees last spring over an honorary degree that they temporarily withheld from him. The Puffin Foundation and the Nation Institute, a nonprofit media center with ties to The Nation, the left-leaning magazine, announced on Monday that Mr. Kushner, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of ''Angels in America'' and other plays, would receive the annual Puffin/Nation Prize for Creative Citizenship. The award citation credited Mr. Kushner's ''lifetime of artistic work and activism,'' but did not mention the CUNY furor explicitly. But Andy Breslau, president of the Nation Institute, said that ''Tony's refusal to submit to the mischaracterization of his statements on Israel at a moment of great public controversy struck the jury as not only commendable but also in keeping with his career-long commitment to the public responsibilities of the artist.'' CUNY trustees voted in May to shelve an honorary degree that one of its campuses, John Jay College, planned to award to Mr. Kushner after a CUNY trustee said Mr. Kushner had disparaged Israel in past comments, a characterization Mr. Kushner immediately denounced as slander. The executive committee of the board later reversed the decision. In a statement Mr. Kushner said, ''I was surprised -- shocked, even -- that I've been chosen to be the recipient of this year's Puffin/Nation Prize.'' Previous recipients include Cecile Richards, the president of Planned Parenthood Federation of America, and the human-rights activist Michael Ratner.

WIENER--Lou, zl, born 1926, died November 27, 2011. A longtime board member of the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College, he endowed RRC's Louis and Myra Wiener Chair in Contemporary Civilization. He is survived by his wife of more than 25 years, two daughters, three stepsons and 14 grandchildren. His memory surely will be a blessing.

FORSTMANN--Teddy. My first New York friend who shared his home with me when I first arrived. Great memories and I am very sad. My heartfelt sympathy to his two sons, his two brothers and his two sisters. James Hammond - Friend

Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas issued a public apology today to a high school student who was disciplined for posting a disparaging Twitter message about him while she was attending a youth program at the state Capitol. ''My staff overreacted to this tweet, and for that I apologize,'' said Governor Brownback, a Republican, in a statement posted on his Facebook page. ''Freedom of speech is among our treasured freedoms.''

FLYNN--Amy Mazzola. Amy's dedication, enthusiasm and love of the arts, especially ballet, made her a valued and beloved member of the Board of Trustees of the American Friends of the Paris Opera & Ballet. Her intelligence, humor and passion will be greatly missed. On behalf of the entire Board, our deepest sympathies go to the Flynn and Mazzola families. Board of Trustees, American Friends of the Paris Opera & Ballet Olivia Flatto, Chairman Marina de Brantes, Honorary Chairman Hal J. Witt, Director

Long-lost works by Walt Disney, below, are suddenly sprouting like the bits of a chopped-up broom brought magically to life. An early cartoon drawing by Disney, dating from the early 1920s before Mickey Mouse was a gleam in his eye, will be among the items for sale at a two-day auction in Reno, Nev., The Associated Press reported. The drawing, titled ''Fill Up My Can,'' depicts a cigar-smoking man in a derby hat and bears the prophetic if not rib-tickling caption, ''Develop your sense of humor and it will develop you.'' (Fans will also notice that Disney's autograph hasn't quite developed its signature flourish.) The drawing was owned by Disney's sister, Ruth, and is expected to sell for $35,000 to $50,000 at an auction that starts Tuesday at the Atlantic Casino Resort. On the other side of the Atlantic, an independent British film library says it has found one of the earliest animated shorts to feature Oswald the Lucky Rabbit, a Mickey-like prototype created by Disney and Ub Iwerks before the more famous mouse came to prominence. Reuters reported that an Oswald cartoon called ''Hungry Hobos'' was found in the collection of the Huntley Film Archives, which is cataloging 80,000 items in its inventory. The short is expected to sell for $30,000 to $40,000 at a Bonhams auction on Dec. 14 in Los Angeles.

Vasily Alekseyev, the Soviet super heavyweight lifter who won 2 Olympic gold medals and set 80 world records, reigning as the so-called world's strongest man in the 1970s, died Friday at a heart clinic in Badenhausen, Germany. He was 69. His death was announced by the Russian Weightlifting Federation, which said that Alekseyev, who lived in the western Russian city of Shakhty, had been treated at the clinic since early November.

FLYNN--Amy Mazzola. The entire School of American Ballet family mourns her sudden and tragic loss. SAB Alumna, benefit event chair and patron, Amy's lifelong devotion to ballet was an inspiration to everyone around her. We extend heartfelt sympathies to the Mazzola and Flynn families.
A listing of credits on Nov. 18 with a film review of ''Tyrannosaur'' misstated the surname of the movie's editor. She is Pia Di Ciaula, not de Ciaula.

Three years ago the dance critic Nancy Goldner brought out her ''Balanchine Variations,'' a paperback guide to 20 ballets by the choreographer George Balanchine (22 if you count the three parts of ''Jewels'' as individual ballets). Pocket-friendly, modest, undictatorial, with a bright but quiet voice, it touches on multiple aspects of ballet (music, drama, ballet classicism, spatial architecture and more), engaging readers in a manner so unassuming that they are effortlessly involved in critical thought by way of friendly conversation. Although I have never spoken with Ms. Goldner extensively, in her book she is a true companion: her writing leads us into her temperament and, often enough, her life.
MAXIM--Leslie M. Nov. 29, 1917-June 23, 1996. Your Birthday and Thanksgiving - Two Most Memorable Times. Missing You and Recalling Special Days of Yore. Your Loving Wife, Pearl

The people assigned to the front entrance at New Utrecht, a large high school in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, spent the first two months of the school year on alert for the sounds of a 1980s rock anthem: ''We're not gonna take it. No! We ain't gonna take it!'' The track plays when a chronic truant enters the building and swipes his identification card.

Newt Gingrich, who not long ago was urging his fellow Republican candidates to avoid tearing one another apart in pursuit of the party's presidential nomination, took a new approach on Monday by explicitly declaring: ''I don't claim to be the perfect candidate; I just claim to be a lot more conservative than Mitt Romney.'' With his candidacy on the rise, Mr. Gingrich opened a three-day campaign visit to South Carolina and warned Republicans to be suspicious of candidates who ''adopt radically different positions.'' It was a fresh glimpse into the sharpening tenor of the nominating fight as the first round of voting begins in five weeks.

GOODHUE--Stephen V.R. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York mourn the loss of our very close and dear friend, Stephen V. R. Goodhue. Steve was an extraordinarily dedicated member of the VNSNY Board since 1970, and was Chair of the VNSNY Board from 1978 to 1988. He served on the Executive, Finance, Audit, and Investment Committees, and was past Chair of the Board of Partners in Care, a VNSNY affiliate. Steve was deeply devoted to promoting VNSNY's mission, and he brought tremendous wisdom and humor to each Board meeting. Steve was respected and highly esteemed for his knowledge, judgment, and values. He could tackle any issue, no matter how complicated, with steadiness and both an historical and long-term perspective. But above all, Steve was a cherished friend to Staff and Board members. Steve's infectious love of life and playful sense of humor were admired by all. His natural charm was evident by the fact that he effortlessly befriended everyone in our office, and his visits were a highlight of any day. Steve was irreplaceable, and we shall miss him beyond what words can convey. Douglas D. Broadwater, Chair of the Board Carol Raphael, President & CEO

BECKERMAN--Alvin (Al), of Bedminster, NJ passed away on November 21, 2011 at the age of 82. Al was born in Elizabeth, New Jersey and grew up in the Bronx. Al was an award-winning advertising executive and noted artist. After graduating from Pratt Institute with a BFA in communications design, he rose through the ranks of a world-reknowned ad agency to become its Creative Director, winning hundreds of awards for marketing and design excellence. In 1975, he co-founded The Beckerman Group, a strategic marketing and design firm in Bernardsville that serviced Fortune 500 corporations throughout the country. Al also taught at Pratt Institute, Kean University and Sussex Community College. Throughout his life, Al pursued his love of art. As a boy, he won art contests and later studied at the famous Art Students League of New York as well as the National Academy of Design in New York. Al continued to create art almost daily over the course of his life. His passion to create encompassed every medium from watercolor to drawing to acrylics. He exhibited his paintings in prestigious galleries, museums, libraries, temples and art associations along the east coast. He had several one-man shows and his drawings and watercolors are in private collections throughout the country. Al was a Korean War veteran having served from 1951-1953. He is survived by his wife Ilene and their five children--Isabelle Edelman of Bridgewater, Lillie Bryen of Westfield, Michael Beckerman of Gladstone, Joe Beckerman of Livingston, Julie Levine of San Francisco, and ten grandchildren, as well as a sister, Anne Hyman of Queens, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.

CAMPBELL--William Isaac. 11/29/1926-5/7/2011 To all his friends and family: you should know that on his last day before he disappeared into thin air, he told me, "I have never been happier." That says it all. MTE - "The we of us." JVH

A Political Memo article on Monday about personal relationships among the Republican presidential candidates referred incorrectly to Newt Gingrich's tenure as speaker of the House of Representatives. It began in 1995, not in 1996.

The publisher of the Italian yellow pages directories, Seat Pagine Gialle, has missed a payment on its bonds and announced a tentative agreement to cancel the bonds and issue shares in the company instead. But that agreement may collapse because of a disagreement over how much stock will be issued. That sounds like a prime example of how bondholders could have protected themselves by buying credit-default swaps, which are supposed to assure that investors will not suffer if a creditor defaults.

Ohio State University hired Urban Meyer as its football coach Monday, giving him one of the richest contracts ever in college sports -- the latest indication that the big business of college football is undeterred by the nation's broader economic woes or by concern about the prominence of sports on campus. The contract includes $4 million in base salary, bonuses -- for everything from players' graduation rates to playing in a national championship, up to $700,000 annually -- and lump payments in 2014, 2016 and 2018. The deal is worth more than three times the $1.32 million that the university's president, E. Gordon Gee, made in 2010, according to The Chronicle of Higher Education.

WERKMEISTER--Janet Mary (Fillit) -- The Rockefeller University community notes with great sorrow the passing of Janet Werkmeister, beloved spouse of Howard Fillit, our dear friend and a former member of our faculty. Howard and Janet have been cherished members of our University family for more than a quarter-century. Janet was a caring and dedicated physician who embodied all that is good about the medical profession. She will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Howard, Marielle, Michael, and the entire family. Russell Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Barry Coller, Physician-in-Chief Bruce McEwen, Professor Sidney Strickland, Dean Marnie Imhoff, V.P. for Development The Rockefeller University

BRICKMAN--Theodore, cherished husband of 60 years to Laura, father of Peter (Laurie), Paul (Debbie), adored Papa of Jason, Tracy, Rebecca and Josh. Funeral Wednesday, 11am, Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY. Interment, 1pm, New Montefiore, West Babylon, NY. Rest In Peace Sweet Papa Ted.

With his country gearing up for a hotly contested presidential election early next year, the Senegalese singer and songwriter Youssou N'Dour, above, one of the biggest stars of the world music genre, is putting his career on hold to plunge into the political fray. It's not clear in what capacity -- as a candidate for public office or just lending his prestige and support to someone already in the running -- or for how long, but he made the announcement over the weekend and set a date to stop performing. ''From Jan. 2 onwards, I am freeing myself from all artistic engagements to enter the political arena,'' Mr. N'Dour, 52, said in a live broadcast on a television station he owns. During the broadcast he also announced the formation of his own political movement, one of several opposed to Senegal's president, the 85-year-old Abdoulaye Wade, who, after promising to step down, is seeking a third term, of seven years, in balloting scheduled for February. Mr. N'Dour, who won a Grammy Award in 2005 for his CD ''Egypt'' and has recorded with artists as diverse as Lou Reed and Neneh Cherry, has long been active in political causes, both at home and internationally.

GROSSMAN--Richard L, 68, of West Hurley, NY, author, activist and legal historian, died of cancer on November 22, 2011. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Richard was a forward-thinking community organizer, dedicated civic strategist and bold, provocative writer who consistently challenged rule by the privileged few and the dominance of corporate influence in government and culture. Passionate about the environment, he founded and directed Environmentalists for Full Employment; was executive director of Greenpeace USA; co-founded and taught Stop the Poisoning Schools at the Highlander Center in Tennessee. He designed and taught activist public interest workshops on Rethinking the Corporation and Rethinking Strategy. In 2011 he co-founded the Sovereign People's Action Network and the current anti-fracking citizen's group, Frackbusters NY. Richard's books and influential pamphlets include Taking Care of Business: Citizenship and the Charter of Incorporation; On the Supreme Court; Defying Corporations, Defining Democracy; and Fear at Work,: Job Blackmail, Labor and the Environment. He is survived by his loving family members, including his wife Mary L. MacArthur, daughter Alyssa Grossman, brand new grandson, Milo Grossman, brothers Lawrence and Daniel, aunt Dr. Shirley Grossman, and many dear nieces, nephews, and cousins. A memorial service will be held on Saturday afternoon, December 10th at the Lifebridge Sanctuary, in Rosendale, NY.

A dance review on Monday about ''George Balanchine's The Nutcracker,'' performed by New York City Ballet, referred incorrectly to the casting for a broadcast of the production scheduled for Dec. 13. Tiler Peck, who danced the role of Dewdrop in the performance reviewed, will in fact be in the cast for the broadcast, in the role of Marzipan.

Because of an editing error, a report in the Foreign Briefing column on Thursday about a ruling by British Columbia's Supreme Court that affirmed the constitutionality of a 121-year-old criminal ban on polygamy misstated the court's authority. It is British Columbia's intermediate court, not the highest court. (The highest is the Court of Appeal.)

8:28 p.m. | Updated A consortium of investors led by the private equity firm Silver Lake and Microsoft is one of several parties that will be submitting a plan to take a minority stake in Yahoo, according to people briefed on the matter.

Medical researchers are again in pursuit of a goal they had all but abandoned: curing AIDS. Until recently, the possibility seemed little more than wishful thinking. But the experiences of two patients now suggest to many scientists that it may be achievable.

About $200 million in customer money that vanished from MF Global is believed to have surfaced at JPMorgan Chase in Britain, according to people briefed on the matter. The discovery could be the most significant breakthrough in a monthlong hunt for the missing funds. During MF Global's last chaotic days, the brokerage firm overdrew an account at JPMorgan, according to another person who is close to the matter. Some investigators now believe the firm used customer funds to patch at least some of the hole, which would have been a significant breach of federal law.

"I never thought a program like this would apply to me and my kids." That's what parents in the Gates Chili school district outside  Rochester are telling Debbi Beauvais, who administers the school meals program there. In a front-page article on Wednesday, The Times reported that around Rochester and across the country, suburban poverty means that schools are finding themselves serving more free or low-cost lunches - and breakfasts. And last year, when the proportion of students who qualified for free or subsidized lunches in the Hickman Mills C-1 district of Kansas City, Mo., hit 80 percent, the school began offering a third meal after the end of classes, paid for by the state.

A few days ago, we posted an article by Thomas B. Edsall analyzing the arguments of Democratic strategists who suggest that the Democratic Party has lost its chance to win over a majority of the white working class and that party leaders should concentrate their efforts on other constituencies. The response was swift and fierce. Readers posted nearly five hundred comments. Edsall's column was picked up, dissected, lambasted and praised in dozens of blog posts and newspaper articles, with headlines like "Different Flavor Kool-Aid For Democrats," "Is Obama 'Abandoning' the White Working Class?" and "NY Times: Democrats Not Interested in Voters Who Work, Target Losers Instead" (thank you, Rush Limbaugh).

Gov. Andrew Cuomo campaigned vigorously against renewing the New York surtax on high earners, which expires at the end of the year, insisting against all evidence that it would drive the wealthy out of the state. On Wednesday, however, he acknowledged (on Fred Dicker's radio show) that he is thinking of redrawing New York's notoriously unfair tax code. And while he gave no indication that he was changing his position on the so-called millionaire's tax, he did not rule out increasing taxes on the rich as part of a general overhaul.

With the darker days and cold weather upon us, it is hard not to be drawn to the ray of sunshine that is Self Publish, Be Happy. The founder, Bruno Ceschel, a writer and lecturer in photography at Camberwell College of Arts, promises self-fulfillment through making your own photo books and enjoying the work of others. After several years working in traditional publishing, Ceschel is keen to celebrate the D.I.Y. attitude and energy of self-publishing, which, with the ease and affordability of digital photography, printing and distribution, is now accessible to all.

Sundance released its competition lineup on Wednesday - 58 films, culled from 4,042 full-length submissions, a 6 percent increase in submissions over last year. Brooks Barnes, writing for The Carpetbagger blog, notes that it can be hard to find themes among that much cacophony, but opts for: "Love and sex, not necessarily in that order. Bleak self-scrutiny. Quirk, sometimes in the extreme." On Monday, programmers will announce selections for the festival's Premieres program, the noncompetitive and more star-driven part of Sundance, where most sales to distributors are made. Sundance is scheduled to run Jan. 19 to Jan. 29. Read more, including a complete list of the 58 films, at The Carpetbagger »

A day when America's Federal Reserve has apparently decided to play John J. Pershing to the latest European crisis seems like as good a time as any to talk about that old warhorse, Western civilization - and particularly the debates kicked up by "Civilization: The West and the Rest," Niall Ferguson's latest tome. Though perhaps "debates" is too high-minded a word, since the most prominent argument has featured Pankaj Mishra accusing Ferguson (in a vituperous London Review of Books review) of being a neo-imperialist, "white's man burden"-toting Euro-chauvinist, followed by Ferguson threatening to sue Mishra for libel. But I did think this comment from Brad DeLong raised some interesting issues. He's objecting to the idea, raised by Ferguson's book and emphasized by Donald Kagan's Times review, that European colonialists did good as well as evil, and that the Western imperialist project has to be credited with positive legacies as well as with grave crimes. Finbarr O'Reilly is a Canadian photographer based in Africa for Reuters. A wall of sound does not even begin to describe the effect on the ears when the New York band A Place to Bury Strangers performs. From the pulsing floor, through your toes, and up your spinal column, everything in your body starts to tremble. By the time you remember to stuff some tissues your ears, your mind is already reeling from the cocktail of endless guitar rumble, thundering drums and hysterical visuals. If you are into this kind of experience, which I happen to be, A Place to Bury Strangers, fronted by Oliver Ackerman and backed by Dion Lunadon and Gavin Haag on bass and drums respectively, is a must-see. More than just a shock to the system, the trio's music is completely solid.

Nadine Ferber and Adair Ilyinsky, the co-owners of Tenoverten, the stylish TriBeCa nail salon, were inspired by client feedback when concocting the formula for their new polish collection, and since their client list is filled with fashion-world heavies who know their Peridot from their Bordeaux, the partners couldn't have asked for a better focus group. "People love certain aspects of different polishes," Ferber says, pointing out that some of her customers choose Essie because it lasts the longest, while others rave about Chanel's color choices. "It became about how to meld the best of everything into one product," Ilyinsky says. After months of research in the field, the duo nailed their first six shades, which are named after streets in downtown Manhattan. A bright blue polish called "Commerce" was inspired by the West Village street where Ferber's clothing boutique, Mick Margo, is located. "Church" is a burnt red alternative to Wicked (a popular Essie shade), and Reade, a metallic charcoal, was named for the salon's home base. With its five-free formula (no formaldehyde resin, camphor, formaldehyde, toluene or dibutyl phthalate) and easy-to-hold brush (the salon's technicians work from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m., so a little attention to ergonomic detail was in order), this new polish deserves a big hand.

Feeling a little like a cleanse, or perhaps just something a tad less heavy after all that holiday fare? Me too. Still, we all want something good for dinner, and I never really want to sacrifice flavor for virtue.This week's City Kitchen features an easy fish dish with sesame and ginger, designed with both health and pleasure in mind. Sesame, often used in nearly every cuisine, is considered quite healthful. It is rich in antioxidants, vitamins and minerals. Ginger, too, can make this claim, as well as other countless health-giving qualities. Thankfully, they taste good too, providing lots of flavor, especially for light, low-fat dishes. It's win-win.

Tea or coffee? Geek chic or glam adventurer? Sparkle or confetti? These are just some of the choices you get to make when playing Madewell's fun new fashion adventure video. Choose tea with the model Dree Hemingway and watch her swap a yarny sweater and glasses for a.) a white shirt and coral pencil skirt, or b.) denim shirt, sequined skirt and trapper hat. Opt for coffee with the stylist Marina Muñoz and help her dance her way out of pajamas into either a.) a strapless dress and peony-purple sweater, or b.) minty pants, plaid shirt and boyfriend blazer. You have five seconds to pick accessories, dress code and party decorations from there. "What makes the video so amazing is that you control it," says Madewell's head of design, Kin Ying Lee. "You choose every direction the video takes - from what pieces she wears to which party she goes to - the options are endless. It's completely addicting." Featuring user-directed technology developed by the interactive multimedia company Interlude, and directed by Nagi Sakai with music written and performed by Katie Herzig, the video makes its world premiere here on The Moment. I debated the Americans for Tax Reform impresario at the American Enterprise Institute last night (I'll link to the transcript whenever it becomes available), and since I spent the evening arguing that his Taxpayer Protection Pledge has failed to actually protect taxpayers I thought I'd say something nice about him this space. Like any good activist, Norquist is a monomaniac about his issue: Everything in American politics revolves around taxes, all good things flow from tax cuts, no deal that increases taxes can ever benefit America, etc. etc. As I said at AEI, I think this view is mistaken, and that focusing obsessively on tax rates has proven to be an insufficient and even counterproductive strategy for actually limiting the size and scope of government. (Steven Hayward elaborates a bit on this argument in his recent essay on conservatism's intellectual blind spots.) And worse, because taxpayers are liable for tomorrow's debts as well as today's tax rates, even the pledge's present success at keeping rates relatively low may look like a pyrrhic victory in the long run.

During the holidays there are essentially two types of people: those that relish in receiving and those who find greater joy in giving. The subjects of today's story fall primarily in the latter category. They're the people who make presents their most presentable by swapping traditional wrapping paper for more unconventional, economical and environmentally mindful materials. "Anything is better than a giant roll of unrecycleable metallic Santas," says the Bodkin designer Eviana Hartman, who paints brown paper with pastel watercolors and uses once-trashed treasures, like sheets of architectural blueprint, when making the perfect parcel. But it isn't all arts and crafts. "A really easy option is to give gifts in colorful, reusable tote bags, like Baggu," Hartman says.

DealBook explains some of the thinking behind the report that Facebook (no relation) may be planning an initial public offering in the spring to raise $10 billion, with a company valuation of $100 billion. In short, Steven M. Davidoff, the Deal Professor, writes, Facebook "just has too many shareholders." When a United States company has 500 or more shareholders of record it must soon begin filing reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including audited financial information. Facebook is likely to reach 500 in April 2012, he writes, and most companies conclude that "if they are going to be subject to much of the regulation that comes with being public, they might as well just go ahead with an I.P.O. and get the full benefits of being public."
