Last summer, Andreas Richter, a 28-year-old computer programmer who lives in Berlin, wanted to get rid of some stuff: clothes, DVDs, a set of drinking glasses. He didn't want to throw out the items -- still perfectly useful -- but he also didn't want to have to schedule pickups or use DHL for a couple of T-shirts. So instead, he got out his power tools and built a telephone-booth-sized structure that he called "Givebox" on his street in Mitte (Steinstrasse 37b). Since then, the project has taken on a more interactive aspect and has expanded to other locations and even other cities.

GELMAN--Marvin. Founder of Lighting Services Inc, whose company's products illuminate museums and display windows all over the world, died November 29, 2011, in Westport, CT, of complications from cancer. He was 84. A longtime Westport, CT resident, Mr. Gelman had a passion for boating and being on the water. He was a member of the Saugatuck River Sail and Power Squadron and former Commander of Coast Guard Auxiliary Flotilla 72 based in Norwalk, CT. Mr. Gelman was a member of the NY Section of the Illuminating Engineering Society (IESNY) since 1950. He began his career as the Lighting Director of NBC's Tonight Show with Steve Allen. While working at NBC, he met his future wife, Barbara Savini, a production assistant with the program. The two married in 1957. In 1958, he left the network to launch his own consulting firm Lighting Services Inc (LSI) which had a motto of "everything in lighting from design to installation". Within a few years, realizing that quality lighting equipment was not available in the field, Mr. Gelman changed focus and Lighting Services Inc became a full-fledged specialty manufacturer of accent and display lighting. Mr. Gelman told friends, "From day one we decided we wanted to be the best in the business." When Mr. Gelman walked into a room, the first thing he did was look up at the lights. His passion for lighting ran deep. He thrived in his role as an entrepreneur and innovator in his field, introducing the world to track, accent, and display lighting. Mr. Gelman enjoyed describing the start of LSI, "I started the company with $400". In the early years of Lighting Services Inc, Mr. Gelman's Accountant called him up and said, "Marv, you're not really making any money here, maybe you ought to "bag-it." Astonished at what the Accountant said, "Bag-It what? I refused to "bag-it", this is what I wanted to do --- Lighting. So I changed Accountants, I "bagged" them." He often said, "You have to do what you like, otherwise you waste your whole life." Installations at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, Hong Kong Museum of History and Walt Disney Theme Parks are among those lighted with LSI's fixtures, as are display windows at Tiffany's, Gucci, Bergdorf Goodman and other luxury retailers. Born March 27, 1927, in New York, Marvin was the son of the late Jack and Lena Gelman. During World War II, he received training in electrical engineering while serving in the US Navy. After graduating from New York University, he began graduate studies in stage design and lighting at Columbia University. As a husband, father, and grandfather he was generous and loving. The family enjoyed many years of happiness, laughter and traveling together. Mr. Gelman was predeceased by his wife, Barbara Savini Gelman, who died in 1997. He retired from Lighting Services Inc in 2000 after 42 years as founder and President. He is survived by his daughter, Gretchen Saccone of Monroe, CT; son and daughter-in-law, Daniel and Ellyn Gelman of Westport; his five grandchildren, Chris and Corey Saccone of Monroe and Keith, Dayna, and Craig Gelman of Westport. He is also survived by his sister Rene Gelman MD, of Brookline, MA. Memorial contributions may be made to the Education Trust at the International Association of Lighting Designers. http://www.iald.org/trust/ donatehome.asp IALD Education Trust The Merchandise Mart, Suite 9-104, 200 World Trade Center Chicago, IL 60654.

After resisting for a decade, the parent company of American Airlines announced Tuesday that it would now follow a strategy that the rest of the industry chose long ago: filing for bankruptcy protection so it can shed debt, cut labor costs and find a way back to profitability. American's parent, the AMR Corporation, was the last major domestic airline that had never sought Chapter 11 protection. Its main rivals, including Delta Air Lines and United Airlines, used the bankruptcy courts to reorganize their businesses in recent years and emerged as stronger, more profitable rivals.

Each of the past few seasons, Gary Kubiak's Texans have been on the verge of making their first playoff appearance but have been undone by inept defenses. Houston joined the league as an expansion team in 2002, and its defense has never been much good, struggling in various measures of efficiency. But the bottom fell out for the Texans in 2010, when they had one of the league's worst defensive seasons. PURLIA--Vaso Louis, M.D. Vaso Louis Purlia, M.D.,Orthopaedic Surgeon, Medical Director, United States Public Health Service Hospital Staten Island, born October 24, 1916 in Claypool Arizona died peacefully at home in his sleep at age 95, Sunday, November 27, 2011 at 2:10. Captain Purlia graduated from Medical School University of Belgrade on scholarship in former Yugoslavia. During WWII he was imprisoned by Germans and he and his first wife Koka were rescued with The Forgotten 500 Airmen. Upon his return to the United States he completed his residency in general and orthopaedic surgery. Dr. Purlia was a member of The American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons and a Life Member of Association of Military Surgeons of the United States, (Vasco L. Purlia Number 1925). Dr. Purlia spent his entire professional life in the United States Public Health Service. He was a chief of the Orthopaedic division Public Health Service Hospital on Staten Island and Medical Director until the hospital closing and his retirement in 1981. He received multiple recognitions and awards for his achievement in the Public Health Service and training of Doctors. He was predeceased by his son Mark and his first wife Koka. Surviving relatives are his brothers George Purlia age 97, Sam Purlia age 88, his wife, Radmila Sindicic and her son Michael Kashkin, his caretakers Maria Sindicic, Debbie Sindicic and numerous nieces, nephews, grand-nieces and grand-nephews. Family will receive friends on Wednesday from 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral service Thursday 10am at The Cathedral of St Sava, 20 West 26 Street, New York. Interment to follow at the Cedar Grove Cemetery.

4:30 p.m. | Updated Les Waters, an Obie-award winning director known for his work with Sarah Ruhl and other emerging playwrights, will become the new artistic director of the Actors Theater of Louisville on Jan. 9, officials at the Kentucky theater said on Tuesday. Mr. Waters, 59, has been the associate director of Berkeley Repertory Theater in California since 2003. Mr. Waters will be the fourth artistic director at the 48-year-old Actors Theater, which is best known for its annual Humana Festival of New American Plays. Mr. Waters succeeds Marc Masterson, who stepped down in May to become the artistic director at South Coast Repertory Theater in Costa Mesa, Calif.

8 P.M. (NBC) CHRISTMAS IN ROCKEFELLER CENTER 2011 In this 79th tree-lighting ceremony, Tony Bennett, Justin Bieber, Michael Bublé, Cee Lo Green, Faith Hill, Carole King, Katharine McPhee and Javier Colon will gather around a Norway spruce, above, that's 74 feet tall and 46 feet wide. The tree, donated by Nancy Keller of Mifflinville, Pa., will be covered with 30,000 LED lights and topped with a Swarovski crystal star through Jan. 7. Then it will be milled for lumber for Habitat for Humanity. The Rockettes will put a little kick into the festivities, presided over by Al Roker and Savannah Guthrie of NBC's ''Today'' show. A preview show begins at 7. 8 P.M. (HBO2) PINK SARIS As a young girl in rural India, Sampat Pal was married into a family that forced her to work hard and often beat her. But she fought back, eventually leaving her in-laws and championing the rights of beleaguered women in northern India. As the leader of the Gulabi Gang, a vigilante group distinguished by its bright pink saris, she has brought to light the issue of domestic abuse, which is prevalent in rural areas where many young married women are at the mercy of their husbands' families. ''Forget tradition,'' Ms. Pal says in this documentary by Kim Longinotto. ''Women won't suffer in silence. They won't keep quiet anymore.''

GOODHUE--Stephen V.R.,January 21, 1929 - November 27, 2011. Steve Goodhue, beloved husband of Judith R. Wiener, father of three: Stephen V.R. Goodhue, Jr. of Perth, Australia., Nora G. Cascella, of Ridgefield, CT and Jason T.Goodhue of Berwyn, PA, stepfather of four: Peter H. Wyman of New Canaan, CT, Michael B. Wyman, of Winnetka, IL. Timothy Wiener, of Reno, NV and Jill Berkman of Bethlehem, PA, grandfather of 13, and great-grandfather of five. He also leaves his older sister, Mrs. Gerrish (Phoebe) H. Milliken and his older brother John T. Goodhue. Steve died Sunday after a valiant year-long battle against acute leukemia. Born in New York City, educated at Phillips Academy, Andover and Harvard University, class of 1951, Steve followed his father into a career in banking, and spent 35 years at Manufacturers Hanover Bank. He retired as Sr. VP in charge of the bank's Wall Street Dept. He served as Chairman of the Board of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York from 1978 to 1988, he was a Director of the Westbury Savings and Loan Association and a trustee of Whitehall Mutual Funds. With a constant smile on his face and a twinkle in his eye, he went through life gathering friends, helping others, and relishing every waking moment. He will be profoundly missed by his countless friends and adoring family. A memorial service will be held at 3:00pm on Friday, December 2 at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice.

GOLDE--Lawrence George, died on November 25, 2011 at age 69 survived by his loving wife of 39 years, Abigail McMurray Golde, brother Robert of Rye, NY and 14 nieces and nephews. A graduate of Princeton and Harvard Law, Larry had a distinguished law career in New York City which included the 1984 recovery from East Germany of 49 works known as "The East German Pictures" of Bauhaus artist, Lyonel Feininger. The works are displayed at the Phillips Gallery in Washington. A dedicated community activist and preservationist, Larry served seven years as the president of The Society for Clinton Hill in historic brownstone Brooklyn. His tenacity and humility are an inspiration to all of us who mourn his loss. A graveside service will be held at the Saxton's River Cemetery in Vermont on December 3.

FRONT PAGE Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Tuesday with the continuation of an article about Ohio State's hiring of Urban Meyer as football coach misidentified the game and the year in which Meyer faced Jim Tressel when Meyer coached at Florida and Tressel was at Ohio State. Meyer won the Bowl Championship Series national title game against Ohio State in 2007, not the Fiesta Bowl in 2008. The caption also misidentified the coach Meyer succeeded at Ohio State. It was the interim coach Luke Fickell, who replaced Tressel in May after Tressel resigned in the wake of an N.C.A.A. investigation. Meyer did not succeed Tressel.

KURZMAN--Nancy White, died of Parkinson's on November 23, 2011. Widow of Peter Kurzman. Surviving siblings: James White, Kittanning, PA; Lourene Pilgram, St Joseph, MO; JoAnne Dzina, Dallas, TX. Brothers-in-law: Harold Kurzman, Naples, FL; Paul Kurzman, New York City. BS Penn State University, M.Ed. University of Pittsburgh. Career spent in education and public relations. Memorial Service: December .2, 2011, 1pm, First Baptist Church, 265 W. 79th St., NYC. Suggested memorial gifts: Solebury Friends Meeting, Solebury, PA or to a charity of your choice.

OLD--Lloyd, J. The Cancer Research Institute (CRI) grieves the passing of its founding scientific and medical director, Lloyd J. Old, M.D., the Father of Modern Tumor Immunology, who died from prostate cancer Monday morning at age 78. Lloyd was a pioneer with a distinguished scientific career, whose passionate belief that the immune system could be harnessed to control and eventually cure cancer inspired generations of tumor immunologists. From his numerous seminal contributions to our understanding of the immune system and its relationship to cancer, through forty years as director of CRI's scientific programs, to his visionary leadership in bringing together CRI and the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research (LICR) to form the CRI/LICR Cancer Vaccine Collaborative, a jointly directed global clinical trials network established in 2001 to accelerate development of therapeutic cancer vaccines, Dr. Old transformed the fields of immunology and tumor immunology and made possible many of today's advances in immune system-based treatment of cancer. Although his imprint on the Cancer Research Institute and on the future of cancer treatment is strong, and his legacy of vision and leadership lives on through our work and the work of thousands of scientists who have been touched by Dr. Old's scholarship, generosity, and support, we nevertheless will feel deeply the absence of this caring, considerate, and highly intelligent man for whom we have the profoundest respect and admiration. Our condolences go to Dr. Old's sister, Constance, nephews, Christopher and Albert, niece, Letitia, and to his closest colleagues and many friends. Board of Trustees, Scientific Advisory Council, and Staff, Cancer Research Institute

GOODHUE--Stephen V.R. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York mourn the loss of our very close and dear friend, Stephen V. R. Goodhue. Steve was an extraordinarily dedicated member of the VNSNY Board since 1970, and was Chair of the VNSNY Board from 1978 to 1988. He served on the Executive, Finance, Audit, and Investment Committees, and was past Chair of the Board of Partners in Care, a VNSNY affiliate. Steve was deeply devoted to promoting VNSNY's mission, and he brought tremendous wisdom and humor to each Board meeting. Steve was respected and highly esteemed for his knowledge, judgment, and values. He could tackle any issue, no matter how complicated, with steadiness and both an historical and long-term perspective. But above all, Steve was a cherished friend to Staff and Board members. Steve's infectious love of life and playful sense of humor were admired by all. His natural charm was evident by the fact that he effortlessly befriended everyone in our office, and his visits were a highlight of any day. Steve was irreplaceable, and we shall miss him beyond what words can convey. Douglas D. Broadwater, Chair of the Board Carol Raphael, President & CEO

MURPHY--James. The AHRC New York City Board of Directors, senior staff and membership mourn the passing of AHRC New York City Board Member, James P. Murphy, and extend sympathy to his beloved and bereaved family. Over the last 44 years, Mr. Murphy devoted his time, spirit and energy to AHRC New York City and NYSARC Inc. A past president of the New York City Chapter, Jim held various Board Officer positions over the years, and served on and chaired several Board Committees. He always seemed to be able to find common ground and bring people together to move forward in a positive direction. At the NYSARC State level, Jim was a member of the Board of Governors for several years, and was a member of NYSARC's Legal Committee. He was a parent advocate who spoke from the heart as only a parent can. But he also spoke with reason and logic, and as a gentleman was able to influence politicians and professionals in the field of developmental and intellectual disabilities, making him a figure that was well respected by Governors, legislators and government officials. In addition to his involvement with AHRC New York City, Jim was a retired Executive Vice President and Director of Public Policy of Fleet Financial Group. From 1980 to 1997 he was Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the City University of New York. He was Vice President of the American Irish Historical Society and Chairman of the advisory board of the CUNY Institute for Irish-American Studies at Lehman College. He served on the Board of Trustees of Mount Sinai Medical School and LaSalle Academy in Manhattan. In 2001, Jim was a recipient of the St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Award from the National Catholic Education Association for service to public and non-public education. Jim is survived by his wife, Marge, and children Cathy, Patricia, Christopher, James, Matthew and Michael, and grandchildren. His son, Michael resides in an AHRC group residence. Jim will be remembered by his "AHRC family" for giving of himself for over forty years and will be greatly missed. Dr. Melvin Gertner, President AHRC New York City Dr. Lorrie Henderson, Executive Director, AHRC New York City

MURPHY--James P.,80. died, on November 27, 2011, peacefully at home. He is survived by his beloved, wife of 55 years, Margaret. He is remembered with great love by his children and their spouses, Patricia, Jim and Linda, Michael, Matthew and Amy, Chris and Karen and Cathy and Juan and his grandchildren, James III, Andrew, Charlie, Julia, Lily, Billy, Ryan, Danny, Jack, James and Cate. He graduated from LaSalle Academy, Manhattan College and Fordham Law School, where he was a member of the law review. At his retirement, he was an Executive Vice President and Director of Public Policy for Fleet Financial Group. Previously he was the Executive Vice President of the New York State Bankers Association, was a Vice President at Chemical Bank, and was an associate at Shearman & Sterling. He served as the Chairman of the Board of Trustees for the City University of New York from 1980 to 1997. He was a member of the Board and a past Chairman of the Board of the Futures in Education Foundation of the Diocese Of Brooklyn and Queens. His particular love was his work with the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, where he served as member of the Board and a past President. Visitation will be at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY, at 81st Street on Wednesday, November 30th from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Thursday, December 1st, at 10:30 at the Church of Saint Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street, New York, NY, followed by interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to The Association for the Help of Retarded Children, 83 Maiden Lane, New York, NY 10038.

THE ARTS A picture caption on Tuesday with a critic's notebook article about the book ''More Balanchine Variations,'' by Nancy Goldner, misspelled the given name of a ballerina shown in a performance of Balanchine's ''Divertimento No. 15.'' She is Nichol Hlinka, not Nicole.

Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund manager convicted of insider trading, is set to report next week to a federal penitentiary in Ayer, Mass., to serve an 11-year sentence. But on Wednesday morning, his lawyers will head to court in a last-ditch attempt to delay Mr. Rajaratnam's incarceration, in what will most likely amount to a dress rehearsal for his forthcoming appeal. Before three federal appeals court judges in Lower Manhattan, Patricia A. Millett, a lawyer for Mr. Rajaratnam, will argue that the government violated his constitutional rights in its use of wiretaps and that he should be released on bail pending the outcome of his appeal.

They're coming to save you: though the reanimated corpses from George A. Romero's 1968 horror classic ''Night of the Living Dead'' are long since buried (and hopefully deceased this time), one original building remains from the shooting of that film, and its fans are fighting to preserve it. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported that in September, the Evans City Cemetery Association gave Gary Streiner one year to raise $50,000 to repair a run-down chapel in that Pennsylvania town -- a building that ''Living Dead'' aficionados may remember from the graveyard where Barbra is teased by her brother, Johnny, ''They're coming to get you.'' (No spoilers, but let's just say Johnny comes to regret that taunt.) Mr. Streiner, who is the brother of Russell Streiner, the actor who played Johnny in ''Night of the Living Dead,'' told The Post-Gazette that he had raised nearly $7,000 for the cause through an online campaign as well as sales of T-shirts, posters, customized zombie portraits and pieces of the chapel's decaying roof.

The movie awards season that leads a gilded path to the Oscars on Feb. 27 kicked off in earnest this week. On Monday the Gotham Independent Film Awards, long the curtain-raiser to the red-carpet hoopla, bestowed honors; two films, ''Beginners,'' an autobiographical, multigenerational story of family and love, and ''Tree of Life,'' Terence Malick's historical epic starring Brad Pitt, tied for the top prize, best feature. With a cast that includes Christopher Plummer and Ewan McGregor as father and son, ''Beginners,'' a low-budget indie released in June by Focus Features, also won for best ensemble over more high-profile films, including ''The Descendants,'' Alexander Payne's sweet yet barbed family drama. Felicity Jones, a young British actress, won best breakthrough for her performance in ''Like Crazy,'' a trans-Atlantic love story, and Dee Rees won the breakthrough director award for ''Pariah,'' a coming-of-age drama.

The Jimmy Stewart vehicle ''Harvey'' - and the Emmy Award winner Jim Parsons (''The Big Bang Theory'') - are coming back to Broadway this spring. Roundabout Theater Company confirmed plans on Tuesday to mount the first Broadway revival of ''Harvey'' since 1970, when Stewart reprised his performance as Elwood P. Dowd from the 1950 film (as well as from the 1940s Broadway production.) Mr. Parsons, who was previously reported to be in negotiations for the revival, will take on the role of Elwood, the genial eccentric who claims to see a six-foot-tall white rabbit named Harvey. He made a well-received Broadway debut last spring in a supporting role in ''The Normal Heart.''

Michael Hastings, a British playwright whose best-known work, ''Tom and Viv,'' about the first marriage of T. S. Eliot, created a cultural brouhaha over the appropriateness of fictionalizing the lives of real people, died on Nov. 19, at his home in London. He was 74. The cause was cancer, said Andrew Hewson, his agent.

WALKER--Julia Armour. The trustees, staff and dancers of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater mourn the passing of Julia Walker, our long-time Board member of 38 years. Our hearts go out to her husband Carter and her entire family. She will be sorely missed by us all.

In a rare show of bipartisan comity on the angrily contested issue of immigration, the House of Representatives on Tuesday passed a bill that tweaks the visa system to allow more highly skilled immigrants from India and China to become legal permanent residents. The bill, originally offered by Representatives Jason Chaffetz, a conservative freshman Republican from Utah, and Lamar Smith, a Texas Republican and chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, sailed through by a vote of 389 to 15. Joining as sponsors were several Democrats who are outspoken liberals on immigration, including Representatives Luis V. Gutierrez of Illinois and Zoe Lofgren of California.

The week before they abducted their eight children from a foster care center in Queens, Nephra and Shanel Payne stocked up at Costco on supplies and dry goods, like diapers and infant formula for Nefertiti, their 11-month-old daughter, graham crackers and her favorite drink, pear juice. They stashed family photos and important documents in a storage facility and crammed a basketball and a football -- essential for traveling with a Little League team's worth of boys -- into their car. They had just been told, they said, that New York City's child welfare agency was planning to put their children, who had been in foster care for nearly three years, up for adoption rather than reuniting them with their parents.

They don't call it the Scottish play for nothing: when a new National Theater of Scotland production of ''Macbeth'' comes to the Lincoln Center Festival in the summer it will have only one Scotsman composing its entire cast, thus lowering the risk if anyone says its title out loud. Alan Cumming, the ''Good Wife'' and ''Cabaret'' star (not to mention the voice of another great Scot, Gutsy Smurf), will perform every single role in the Shakespeare tragedy, including the regicidal schemer of its title and his devious, spot-obsessed wife (though we're especially intrigued to see what he does with the three witches). The production, to be directed by John Tiffany and Andy Goldberg, will originate in June at the Tramway in Glasgow, and then be presented at the Lincoln Center Festival in New York from July 5 through July 14. In an interview with The Guardian Mr. Cumming said this ''Macbeth'' had begun with an idea ''to swap the roles of Macbeth and Lady Macbeth, because there are so many things about gender, I thought it would be a really exciting idea to flip that.'' He added: ''So we did this reading like that, in New York, and Andy Goldberg had this idea I should just play all the parts.''

After MF Global discovered a nearly $1 billion shortfall in customer money in the early hours of Oct. 31, the brokerage firm lined up a last-ditch - but ultimately unsuccessful - effort to fill the hole, according to people briefed on the matter. At the time, the revelation of missing money was about to scuttle a last-minute deal to sell part of MF Global to another brokerage firm. MF Global executives scrambled to assemble money from a variety of sources, including its own accounts at banks and clearinghouses, said these people, who requested anonymity because investigations into the matter were incomplete.

The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts said on Tuesday that the pianist and composer Jason Moran has been appointed its new artistic adviser for jazz. Mr. Moran, 36, is the second person to hold that post, which had been vacant since the death last year of Billy Taylor, the venerable pianist and educator who began advising the Kennedy Center in 1994. The responsibilities of artistic adviser extend to the development of jazz programming at the Kennedy Center, which operates its own jazz club as well as a regular concert series. Among its signature offerings is the Mary Lou Williams Women in Jazz Festival, the 17th annual edition of which is scheduled to begin May 10.

An article on Tuesday about the Nuttall Ornithological Club misstated the name of a vulture specimen displayed at the Museum of Comparative Zoology at Harvard, where the club met this month. It is the cinereous vulture, not the Cisneros vulture.

A film review on Friday about ''Crazy Wisdom,'' a documentary about Chogyam Trungpa, a Tibetan who was instrumental in bringing Buddhism to the West, misstated the age of the young British woman he married. She was 16 at the time, not 15.

NATIONAL An article on Tuesday about the Supreme Court's decision to hear a case about varying sentences for offenses involving crack and powder cocaine misstated the nature of the disparity. Under a law that has since been amended, an offense involving crack cocaine was subject to the same sentence as one involving 100 times as much powder. The law did not give rise to sentences ''100 times as long.''

ENGEL--Marjorie, 76. A beacon of compassion and fairness, lifetime advocate of the potential of all children, and fashionable figure outfitted in signature black coat and slacks, Marge Engel died on November 23rd of lung cancer. Outspoken in gratitude for her wonderful life, she approached dying with equanimity and peace. A longtime preschool teacher, she enriched the lives of hundreds of young children. Marge's life was made extra special by eight grandchildren, Lauren and Jeremy, Hannah and Gabriel, Dylan and Lia, and Maya and Jade: the children of her sons, John and Peter, and their wives, Yung Yung and Cheryl; and of her niece and nephew, Nancy and Michael, and their spouses, Michael and Maria. All of us will forever miss her grace and unconditional love. Sister of the late Elizabeth (Bitsy) Greenfield, Marge is survived by her devoted brother, Robert Conner, and his wife, Ann; her ex-husband, Stephen Engel; cousins Judy Saccucci, Ruth Modlin, and Kim Dana Kupperman; and a legion of loyal and loving friends. A Memorial will be on Saturday, December 10, 5pm, New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Marge's name to a charity to be announced at the memorial.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Friday about the biologist Lynn Margulis referred incorrectly to cells, whose origin was the focus of her research. All cells in the human body except mature red blood cells have nuclei, not ''all the cells in the human body.'' And the obituary, using information from the family, also omitted the name of a survivor. Michael Alexander, a half-brother, survives her.

FRIDAY'S PUZZLE - The comedian Emo Philips once did a bit about using chocolate Easter bunnies as a diagnostic tool in psychotherapy. I don't remember exactly how it went, but to paraphrase, he was told that the first part he bit off would clue the therapist in to where his problem lies: if he bit off the ears first, for example, it meant that he was relatively normal; if he bit off the feet first, it meant he felt he wasn't getting anywhere in life. His reply: "What if I bite out the eyes and scream 'Stop staring at me!'?"

For someone like me, someone like her presents an existential problem. Conditioned as I am to peering under the surfaces of things and sussing out the dark truth, how am I to parse the enigma of transparency - the lack of discernible neuroses, the absence of characterological curveballs - that is Tory Burch? Despite her many roles as a ragingly successful business entrepreneur, divorced mother of three sons and devoted stepmother to three daughters, crack skier and tennis ace, adored friend, philanthropist, consummate hostess and general woman about town, she is disconcertingly all of a piece. There is - but how can this be? Can Dostoyevsky be all wrong? - no lurking secret self, no rattling skeletons. What you see, as God knows how many people have told me about her, ranging from her own mother to the society maven Billy Norwich, is what you get. And what you get, as far as I can tell, having spent some time with her and having talked to numerous people about her, is someone annoyingly close to perfect. Someone it would be nice to dislike, if she were only dislikable. Someone it's impossible not to envy, if only because her life seems sun drenched from the get-go, with a childhood that sounds near magical, spent climbing trees and romping with her brothers and the German shepherds her parents bred on a 35-acre gentleman's farm in Valley Forge, Pa., replete with tennis court and swimming pool.

Ralph Blumenthal, writing on The City Room blog, looks back nearly 40 years to when he was assigned by The Times to cover what, since the Stonewall uprising, had become an annual commemoration: a march of thousands that started in Sheridan Square in Greenwich Village, moved up Avenue of the Americas and ended in Central Park. The marchers chanted: "Out of the closet and into the streets!" Back in the office, Mr. Blumenthal was told how long to write: "Three quarters of a buck. About 75 percent of a column, 600 words if I was lucky. But, oh, I was cautioned, it was not the gay march, it was the homosexual march." Read more on City Room »

It's no longer news that the Merce Cunningham Dance Company is due to shut up shop at the end of 2011. But another, attached troupe has already given its farewell. The Cunningham company's Repertory Understudy Group ended with a season of six performances in the Cunningham studio over the last six days of November. Known as the RUGs, its four dancers were never quite a second company. The group, formalized in 1990, served as an apprentice program for the Cunningham company, with whose members its four dancers shared studios and took class.

Valuable trees and interesting fauna abounded, including a black crocodile and coconut-size baby raccoon mingling in dangerous proximity: what kind of omen is that?

An auction for a copy of Action Comics No. 1 from 1938 set a record Wednesday night. After 50 bids the closing price was $2,161,000 -- the most ever paid for a comic book -- to be the owner of the first appearance of Superman. (And that new owner's identity is currently secret.) The copy of the book was graded at 9.0 on a scale of 1 to 10, a full grade better than a copy of Action Comics No. 1 that sold for $1 million last year. Over at Gold Derby, Adam Waldowski takes a look at the strong competition for the best adapted screenplay Oscar. When it picked up a nod from the New York Film Critics Circle on Tuesday, "Moneyball," the adaptation of Michael Lewis's business-of-baseball best seller, got an early lead; it may also be helped by having recognizable writers in Aaron Sorkin and Steve Zaillian. On the other hand, Mr. Sorkin won an Oscar just last year, for "The Social Network," and Mr. Zaillian picked up one in 1993, for a little film called "Schindler's List." (He also adapted this year's "Girl With the Dragon Tattoo.") Who else is on deck?

But with the opening of several Michelin-starred hotel restaurants in Spain, travelers can experience cutting-edge cookery in places outside remote areas of the Basque Country or Catalonia. The chef Dani García runs Calima in the resort town of Marbella; and the twin chefs Sergio and Javier Torres run Dos Cielos in Barcelona. Both restaurants, part of the Melia hotel chain, are making Spain's new cuisine easier to reach (if not easier on the wallet).

JERUSALEM - Israel is still a journalistic heaven, but Israeli journalists have good reason to forget it these days. Yes, Israeli informality means that it's still relatively easy for reporters to call high officials on their cellphones at all hours. Yes, the country's smallness means that they can quickly reach its every corner. But last week the Knesset member Yariv Levin of the Likud Party cast a dark shadow on these advantages by getting a proposed amendment to Israel's libel law through a first vote.

The study of genomes is caught in a "data deluge," reports Andrew Pollack in Thursday's New York Times. Although DNA sequencing is becoming faster and cheaper, researchers are drowning in the amount of resulting data, which is expensive to store, transmit and analyze.

Four more dolphins washed up on the shores of the Gulf of Mexico this week. For coastal residents from Louisiana to Florida, the beached animals are a familair sight: hundreds of decomposing dolphin carcasses have turned up over the last two years.

The rapper Kanye West received the most nominations for the 54th Annual Grammy Awards during a ceremony broadcast on Wednesday night on CBS, but it was the pop stars Adele and Bruno Mars who dominated the Song of the Year, Record of the Year and Album of the Year nominations, The ArtsBeat blog reported. Adele, the British soul singer, received six nominations for her album "21," which included the hit "Rolling in the Deep." (Her singing voice has been temporarily silenced by vocal cord surgery, and it is not clear, The Los Angeles Times reported, whether Adele will have recovered sufficiently to perform when the awards are handed out on Feb. 12.) Mr. Mars also received six nominations, three for "Grenade," his song about unrequited love, and three for the album "Doowops and Hooligans." Mr. West was nominated seven times based on two albums - his complex solo set "My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy" and his collaboration with Jay-Z, "Watch the Throne." Both were left off the Album of the Year list, but were nominated for Rap Album of the Year. (The snub of MBDTF, as Mr. West's album is known, was certainly the hot topic on Twitter.)

On Dec. 1, 1959, representatives of 12 countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, signed a treaty in Washington, which designated Antarctica as a scientific preserve, free from military activity.The signatories included the seven nations to have claimed control over a part of Antarctica: Argentina, Australia, Britain, Chile, France, Norway and New Zealand. The treaty did not affect these claims though it did ban all future claims. The New York Times noted that overlapping claims by Britain, Argentina and Chile had caused tension and that many hoped the treaty would "ultimately permit the claims issue to die a natural death."

OLD--Lloyd, J. The Cancer Research Institute (CRI) grieves the passing of its founding scientific and medical director, Lloyd J. Old, M.D., the Father of Modern Tumor Immunology, who died from prostate cancer Monday morning at age 78. Lloyd was a pioneer with a distinguished scientific career, whose passionate belief that the immune system could be harnessed to control and eventually cure cancer inspired generations of tumor immunologists. From his numerous seminal contributions to our understanding of the immune system and its relationship to cancer, through forty years as director of CRI's scientific programs, to his visionary leadership in bringing together CRI and the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research (LICR) to form the CRI/LICR Cancer Vaccine Collaborative, a jointly directed global clinical trials network established in 2001 to accelerate development of therapeutic cancer vaccines, Dr. Old transformed the fields of immunology and tumor immunology and made possible many of today's advances in immune system-based treatment of cancer. Although his imprint on the Cancer Research Institute and on the future of cancer treatment is strong, and his legacy of vision and leadership lives on through our work and the work of thousands of scientists who have been touched by Dr. Old's scholarship, generosity, and support, we nevertheless will feel deeply the absence of this caring, considerate, and highly intelligent man for whom we have the profoundest respect and admiration. Our condolences go to Dr. Old's sister, Constance, nephews, Christopher and Albert, niece, Letitia, and to his closest colleagues and many friends. Board of Trustees, Scientific Advisory Council, and Staff, Cancer Research Institute

ROESER--Kirk G.,died on November 17th of cancer at age 68. He was a graduate of Brown University and a fellow of the Society of Actuaries. He began his career at Mutual of New York as a life actuary, then joined MONY Re as a casualty underwriter, later becoming a senior executive at North American Re. In 1983 he co-founded Gill & Roeser, a reinsurance intermediary which brought actuarial expertise to the design of reinsurance treaties. The business also encompassed mergers and acquisitions in the insurance industry. He was an avid sailor, competing several times in Olympic trials and in world and national championships. He is survived by his companion of many years, Sylvia Kouchinsky and her daughters, Carol and Mariana, his daughters Paige and Katy, a son Jamie and two grandchildren, Chase and Ethan.

In the latest twist in the multilegged tale of ''The Human Centipede 2 (Full Sequence),'' that shock horror film has now been banned in Australia, weeks after it made its premiere at the country's Brisbane International Film Festival. The ''Human Centipede'' sequel, the second entry in the Dutch director Tom Six's series about kidnapping victims who are forcibly sewn together to create a being with a continuous digestive tract, was refused a rating on Monday by Australia's Classification Review Board, its equivalent of the Motion Picture Association of America, The Brisbane Times reported. The board cited ''gratuitous, exploitative or offensive depictions of violence'' in the film as it reversed an earlier decision to give it an R18+ rating, which would restrict the movie to viewers 18 and older.

Instead, it sends computer disks containing the data, via FedEx.

The Apple iPad has been hailed as a savior for assisting children with autism spectrum disorder or other special needs. It was portrayed as a minor miracle in a recent segment on ''60 Minutes'' and has been found to help even the very young quickly learn. Anecdotally, teachers, parents and therapists describe the profound difference that apps for Apple and Android products have made in helping autistic children develop skills. IPad programs have provided a means of communicating for some children with autism who cannot speak or have language delays. Other apps help children learn to handle social situations that can be stressful, like crowds at malls. And many programs can help develop fine-motor skills, which promote functions like writing or manipulating small objects.

FRIEDMAN--Morton. Morton Friedman, bridge columnist, beloved husband of Evelyn (Chaikin) for 59 years, died Thursday, November 24, 2011. Born in Brooklyn October 13, 1922, he joined US Army Corps of Engineers and was stationed in the Pacific during WWII. He graduated from NYU with a Math teaching degree, then joined his brother's company Alphatype Corp. (symbol ALTP listed on OTC exchange) to become Vice-President of sales. Formerly of Baldwin, NY, Mort spent his retirement teaching bridge classes at colleges and community centers near his homes in Copake Lake, NY; Long Boat Key, FL; and Redding, CT. He wrote a column for papers in Florida, New York and Connecticut called: " 'Bridging' the Gap" and recently achieved Gold Life Master. Mort was also an avid guitar player, fisherman, skier and golfer. In addition to his wife, Mr. Friedman is survived by a daughter, Roberta Dixon of Ithaca, NY; son Glenn and his wife Pamela (Segal) of Redding, CT; six grandchildren: Ursula, Casey, Natanya, Lillian, Hadley, and Jacob; and two great-grandchildren, Nikita and Jackson. A son, Sy, predeceased Mr. Friedman.

It is $24 billion, not $240 billion.

6:09 p.m. | Updated The critically acclaimed Broadway musical ''The Book of Mormon'' has recouped its roughly $11.4 million capitalization after just nine months of performances, its producers said on Tuesday. ''Mormon'' is the first commercially successful musical from the 2010-11 season, which had an unusually large number of original musicals open, including the still-running ''Sister Act'' and ''Priscilla, Queen of the Desert'' and flops like ''Catch Me If You Can'' and ''Wonderland.''

While it is not quite as helpful as Apple's Siri personal assistant, Google has a voice-activated feature in its software that lets you search the Web by speaking your search terms out loud. Google Voice Search is available in its mobile apps for the iPhone, BlackBerry and Nokia S60v3 mobile phones. Depending on which version of the software is installed on the phone, Android users have their own options, including the Google Search widget, the Voice Actions app for Android or other apps from the Android Market. Google has voice search built into its Chrome Web browser for Windows, Mac OS X and Linux systems. To use it, you need to have a working microphone attached to the computer. To start, just click the microphone icon in Chrome's search box and speak your keywords aloud. Google has more on Chrome's voice search here. In addition to cutting down on keystrokes, searching by voice also comes in handy when you are not sure how to spell the thing you seek.

MURPHY--James P. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of James P. Murphy, who is remembered for his outstanding service and dedication to the University, its mission and its students. He served as chairperson of CUNY's Board of Trustees for more than 16 years, from 1980 to 1997. A great orchestra's glory lies partly in continuity, the passing of musical traditions among generations of longstanding members. And a good pension in the precarious world of the arts is one element that helps keep players ensconced in their chairs, ensuring that handoff of artistic heritage. The storied Philadelphia Orchestra had one of the better pension plans around. But now the orchestra, burdened by tens of millions of dollars in pension obligations it says it cannot afford, is using bankruptcy court to avoid paying for them.

NOON (Starz) THE TOURIST (2010) Johnny Depp tries on normal as a Wisconsin math teacher on a train in Italy who bumbles into Angelina Jolie as a mystery woman who combines lock-picking skills with off-the-shoulder gowns and intrigue. That leads to dinner, followed by bullets and boat chases on the canals of Venice. ''Stargazing is the only reason bonbons like 'The Tourist' are made, dreams of box office bonanzas aside,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Still, there's definitely some amusement in watching Ms. Jolie's character come to the rescue of Mr. Depp's, ''a role reversal the movie only flirts with,'' Ms. Dargis added. ''But oh how much more fun it would have been if Mr. Depp had really played the girl, eyeliner and all.''

The director of New York State's educational testing program resigned on Tuesday, according to education officials, the same day the state dropped a plan to extend the length of reading tests given in Grades 3 through 8 to nearly four hours. Principals received word of the plans to extend the length of the tests on Monday via e-mail, The Daily News reported. Some of them expressed outrage that young children would be asked to sit for such lengthy testing, and by the next day, officials had dropped the plan, saying it was a mistake to issue the order without first consulting principals.

3:02 p.m. | Updated In the jargon of digital music, the streaming service Spotify offers a ''lean-in'' experience, meaning that a user needs to know what to look for and must type in the names of the desired songs or artists. By comparison, Pandora is more ''lean back'': you just press play and let it go. Now Spotify, which arrived from Europe in July and has been growing rapidly, is adding features to let users lean back a bit. At an elaborate news conference in Manhattan on Wednesday, the company announced that it had opened up its technology to let software developers and media companies build apps that would work within the Spotify system.

Faced with a worsening financial climate, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Wednesday that he was contemplating whether to propose changes to the state tax code, and he did not rule out the possibility that he would seek to raise taxes on wealthy New Yorkers. In a pair of radio appearances, Mr. Cuomo offered no details on what he was considering. But he suggested that changing how the state taxed its residents and businesses could be a way to promote economic growth.

In response to ''Children of the Hyphens,'' (Thursday Styles, Nov. 24), more than 100 readers shared their experiences of living with a double-barreled name or the process they went through when deciding what name to take or keep when they married. Here is a sampling of those comments, as submitted to nytimes.com/fashion. We ended up giving the kids my last name (I'm the mother) because my extended family is much smaller than my husband's, with far fewer offspring to carry on the name. It came down to throwing out ''tradition'' as the default and instead considering how we can support both heritages in the long term (i.e., which surname needed the help to survive). I hope that one day this won't seem so radical to people -- that surnames will be considered rather than assumed.

Last week, I had a conversation with a man who runs his own trading firm. In the process of fuming about competition from Goldman Sachs, he said with resignation and exasperation: ''The fact that they were bailed out and can borrow for free - it's pretty sickening.'' Though the sentiment is commonplace these days, I later found myself thinking about his outrage. Here is someone who is in the thick of the business, trading every day, and he is being sickened by the inequities and corruption on Wall Street and utterly persuaded that nothing has changed in the years since the financial crisis of 2008.

11:54 a.m. | Updated Time Warner announced on Wednesday that it had selected the head of a digital advertising firm to run its Time Inc. magazine unit. The company said that Laura Lang, chief executive of Digitas, would take over the world's largest magazine company, which publishes 21 titles in the United States, including People, InStyle and Sports Illustrated. Time Inc. had been effectively without leadership for nine months after the troubled departure of its former chief executive, Jack Griffin, who clashed with a decades-old company culture.

6:03 p.m. | Updated In a rare attack by a playwright on a professional production of his own work, Stephen Adly Guirgis took to Facebook on Wednesday to assail the casting of two white actors as the Puerto Rican lead characters in the Hartford regional production of his play ''The ------------------------ With the Hat,'' which was a Tony Award nominee for best play. The Hispanic Organization of Latin Actors has also complained to the theater, TheaterWorks, noting that the production had casting calls in New York City, a training ground for many Hispanic actors. Mr. Guirgis, who had been discussing his concerns with the play's director, Tazewell Thompson, and executives at TheaterWorks over the last two weeks, said in an interview that he decided to make his concerns public because the TheaterWorks executives ''are in a position of accountability and yet refuse to take responsibility for mistakes in the casting.'' The production is scheduled to end on Sunday, but Mr. Guirgis decided it was still worth speaking up because he hoped other theaters would make the effort to cast Hispanic actors, when available, in the two lead roles.

Q. A friend sent a photo he says he shot with his phone. I see from the JPG's ''properties'' latitude and longitude are listed. Is there an easy way to determine the physical location from these data? A. Most digital cameras store information about a picture in the file's EXIF (exchangeable image file format) tag. This data can include details about the image, like the focal length or flash use and can contain location information if the camera or phone records it; photos with embedded GPS data are often referred to as ''geotagged.''

SANDRO, a French label synonymous with effortless Gallic chic, has opened its first store in the United States. GELMAN--Marvin. Founder of Lighting Services Inc, whose company's products illuminate museums and display windows all over the world, died November 29, 2011, in Westport, CT, of complications from cancer. He was 84. A longtime Westport, CT resident, Mr. Gelman had a passion for boating and being on the water. He was a member of the Saugatuck River Sail and Power Squadron and former Commander of Coast Guard Auxiliary Flotilla 72 based in Norwalk, CT. Mr. Gelman was a member of the NY Section of the Illuminating Engineering Society (IESNY) since 1950. He began his career as the Lighting Director of NBC's Tonight Show with Steve Allen. While working at NBC, he met his future wife, Barbara Savini, a production assistant with the program. The two married in 1957. In 1958, he left the network to launch his own consulting firm Lighting Services Inc (LSI) which had a motto of "everything in lighting from design to installation". Within a few years, realizing that quality lighting equipment was not available in the field, Mr. Gelman changed focus and Lighting Services Inc became a full-fledged specialty manufacturer of accent and display lighting. Mr. Gelman told friends, "From day one we decided we wanted to be the best in the business." When Mr. Gelman walked into a room, the first thing he did was look up at the lights. His passion for lighting ran deep. He thrived in his role as an entrepreneur and innovator in his field, introducing the world to track, accent, and display lighting. Mr. Gelman enjoyed describing the start of LSI, "I started the company with $400". In the early years of Lighting Services Inc, Mr. Gelman's Accountant called him up and said, "Marv, you're not really making any money here, maybe you ought to "bag-it." Astonished at what the Accountant said, "Bag-It what? I refused to "bag-it", this is what I wanted to do --- Lighting. So I changed Accountants, I "bagged" them." He often said, "You have to do what you like, otherwise you waste your whole life." Installations at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, Hong Kong Museum of History and Walt Disney Theme Parks are among those lighted with LSI's fixtures, as are display windows at Tiffany's, Gucci, Bergdorf Goodman and other luxury retailers. Born March 27, 1927, in New York, Marvin was the son of the late Jack and Lena Gelman. During World War II, he received training in electrical engineering while serving in the US Navy. After graduating from New York University, he began graduate studies in stage design and lighting at Columbia University. As a husband, father, and grandfather he was generous and loving. The family enjoyed many years of happiness, laughter and traveling together. Mr. Gelman was predeceased by his wife, Barbara Savini Gelman, who died in 1997. He retired from Lighting Services Inc in 2000 after 42 years as founder and President. He is survived by his daughter, Gretchen Saccone of Monroe, CT; son and daughter-in-law, Daniel and Ellyn Gelman of Westport; his five grandchildren, Chris and Corey Saccone of Monroe and Keith, Dayna, and Craig Gelman of Westport. He is also survived by his sister Rene Gelman MD, of Brookline, MA. Memorial contributions may be made to the Education Trust at the International Association of Lighting Designers. http://www.iald.org/trust/ donatehome.asp IALD Education Trust The Merchandise Mart, Suite 9-104, 200 World Trade Center Chicago, IL 60654.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra announced on Wednesday that the conductor Riccardo Chailly, widely thought to be a potential candidate to become its next music director, had canceled concert engagements for the next two months for health reasons, including two weeks as guest conductor in Boston. Wilford, the chairman and chief executive officer of Columbia Artists Management, which represents the conductor, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Chailly has had recent heart problems involving atrial fibrillation. Over the next two months, Mr. Wilford said, Mr. Chailly was to have conducted the annual year-end performances of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony by the Gewandhaus Orchestra in Leipzig, Germany, where he is the music director; concert performances of Strauss's opera ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' in Valencia, Spain; and two weeks with the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra in Munich.

SATURDAY'S PUZZLE - I don't know how you all feel, but I would like to suggest to the crossword community at large that the relative "fun" level of a crossword puzzle be measured in a new unit that I would like to call the Quarfoot. To my mind, if a given puzzle met or exceeded the amount of fun I personally have when I do one of David Quarfoot's puzzles, that extra fun could then be measured, like an index, in a relative number of Quarfeet. The greater the number of Quarfeet, the greater the solving fun. I realize that this measurement would have to be entirely subjective, and that that might strike some of you as unfair, but as a general policy, I'd have to say I really don't have any trouble with that. I like Mr. Quarfoot's puzzles, and it's entirely possible that I'm just losing my mind.

On Dec. 3, 1861, President Abraham Lincoln delivered his first Annual Message, the equivalent of our modern State of the Union. In the 19th century, presidents summarized progress at the end of the year rather than the beginning, which gives a little more perspective on things. The phrase "the State of the Union" dates from 1934, when Franklin D. Roosevelt used it for the first time. Nor was it spoken, as it has been, generally, since Woodrow Wilson chose to travel down Pennsylvania Avenue and deliver his message verbally in 1913. (Jimmy Carter sent his in in 1981, a confession that things had not gone so well.) Instead, Lincoln composed a long written document, and sent it to Congress.

I don't usually pay attention to people trying to be the first to, say, circumnavigate the world on a raft made of Wikki Stix. So while I had vaguely heard the name Diana Nyad, I never gave much thought to her or why she felt the need to swim very long distances. Until the magazine's photo department showed me some pictures that Catherine Opie had taken of Nyad after a failed attempt at swimming from Cuba to Miami. Then I became very interested.
Interesting things that Bits reporters and editors found on the Web. More here.

Celebrate the holiday season with T's cover star, Viggo Mortensen, as he speaks his mind in an in-depth interview with Zoë Heller. Inside, Miranda Kerr, Richard Thompson and Taissa Farmiga wear the latest fashions, Sarah Mower meets Her Highness and The Selby drops in on Copenhagen's Noma. Need shopping tips? Read our gift guide, which offers groupings of joy for the people on your list. When you're done, settle back and enjoy Will Self's take on whether hotels are new community centers, join Joan Juliet Buck as she reminisces about a Christmas in Venice, visit with the model Raquel Zimmermann as she returns to her roots in Brazil and meet the Gifted, the breakout talents of 2011, including Charlie Day and Tyler, the Creator.

Aptera, the would-be electric car manufacturer founded in 2006, which was best known for its aerodynamic 2e three-wheeler prototype, announced its dissolution Friday. The company cited an inability to raise private financing to match a $150 million conditional offer of federal financing.
Though not quite in the league of real estate, modeling and Wall Street, academic medicine is not immune to cutthroat behavior.
Yankees closer Mariano Rivera had surgery Friday to remove a polyp, or polyps, from his vocal cords at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan, said his agent, Fernando Cuza.
Herman Cain says he will have something to say about the future of his campaign on Saturday.

Evidence that the holiday season has truly begun: The Bloomingdale's soundtrack has switched from easy listening to "Jingle Bell Rock," "Silent Night" and other perennial yuletide favorites; and the in-store offering is following suit, with stacks of Christmas sweaters as far as the eye can see. As a first-time Bloomingdale's visitor, I must admit that the prospect of putting together a selection of seasonally appropriate outfits was daunting; back home in New Zealand, the largest department store is about a quarter of the size of the men's-wear section alone. The hurdles are self-evident: too many options, too much running around between the designers' in-shop shops, a plethora of mediums and larges but few smalls (petite men must buy more clothes, or something). On the flip side, the staff is attentive, the merchandising is worthy of a Milanese boutique's window, and the brands are spectacular. You'll find Polo Ralph Lauren sitting alongside Z Zegna, Salvatore Ferragamo and Ovadia & Sons. Just a stone's throw away are Gant Rugger, A.P.C. and Junya Watanabe, all sharing a corner in the contemporary department.

As thousands of Egyptians rallied in Cairo's Tahrir Square on Friday, some members of the crowd wore bandages over one eye. The demonstration was part of an ongoing campaign to draw attention to the dozens of protesters who sustained serious eye injuries last week, after being hit in the face with pellets or rubber bullets fired by police officers.
In this Sunday's Book Review, the editors choose their 100 notable books of 2011. The selections are drawn from all the books reviewed in our pages since last year's big winter issue.
The economics profession has been blamed for failing to predict the global financial crisis, much less prepare for it or resolve it.

Thursday brought dramatically high winds to Miami, but also more art. At 10 a.m., the New Art Dealers Alliance (NADA) Art Fair opened its door for preview at the Deauville Beach Resort. Since relocating to the beach a couple years back, NADA has gotten better and better with an influx of very young galleries like West Street and 47 Canal (where Josh Kline's three consumer-conceptual infusions - "Blue Listerine With Dentyne Ice," "Mountain Dew With Claratin-D" and "Red Bull With Vivarin" - were displayed on a pedestal in Bodum coffee presses). The Night Gallery, from Los Angeles, took advantage of the fair's hotel setting, luring collectors and company back to a boudoir (Room 1010) upholstered in black velvet and hung with artwork, all of which was for sale, naturally.
Behind the scenes at Angelo Pennetta’s photo shoot of Raquel Zimmermann in Brazil for T Magazine’s Holiday 2011 issue.
Updated 12:03 a.m. | A gunman killed two people - one on a crowded city bus - in Queens on Friday afternoon, the authorities said.
It's been a good week for memorable TimesTalk interviews.

Raquel Zimmermann's blond hair and blue eyes do not, for most people, immediately say Brazil. But the model who has been the face of brands like Lanvin, McQueen and Shiseido arrived on the fashion scene from Bom Retiro do Sul, a small town in the south of the country, where boatloads of German immigrants began arriving in the 1800s. (Zimmermann's hometown is not too far from that of Gisele Bündchen, and it's easy to imagine that the two women share a similar gene pool.) The region is so Teutonic, in fact, that her parents now live in a city called Novo Hamburgo, a Bavarian-seeming burg where many of the old buildings are made of timber.

The model Raquel Zimmermann recently visited the island of Fernando de Noronha in Brazil for a shoot with T. Here, she dishes about life in Brooklyn, her love for moqueca (a traditional fish stew) and what to play if you want to get her dancing.

Brian Frons, the ABC executive who angered legions of soap opera fans earlier this year by canceling "All My Children" and "One Life to Live," will leave the network next month when his contract expires.

As I wrote in an article on Friday, even those who are back at work are not necessarily doing so well: only 7 percent of those who lost jobs after the financial crisis have recovered their income and standard of living. What's more, the downturn and its aftermath have disproportionately hit people with less education. Even though the unemployment rates of high school dropouts and graduates have fallen from recent highs, they are still much higher than the rate for college graduates.
Young men showed no signs this fall of being shoved back into the cage of fashion conformity.
Two agreements prompt optimism as industry negotiators hope to reach a broad deal with workers early next year.

Cutting out cookie rings to expose the marmalade filling makes for very pretty linzer cookies. But if rolling out cookies isn't your thing, there is an easier way. Simply form the dough into logs instead of disks, and wrap it in plastic. Chill until quite firm, at least 6 hours or up to 5 days. Then unwrap the logs and use a sharp knife to slice off 3/16-inch-thick rounds of the dough. Bake as directed for in the recipe, then form sandwich cookies with the marmalade filling. Sprinkle with confectioners' sugar. Just as tasty, much quicker. You could even skip the marmalade. But I wouldn't.
Who: The hair mogul Frédéric Fekkai.

The stock market has been volatile, to say the least, for much of this year, as investors follow each bit of news about the finances of countries in the euro zone. Some investors, looking for an alternative, have started to consider Latin America, Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week -- quite a turn of events since the 1990s and early 2000s, when countries there were in dire financial straits.

The distribution of FICO credit scores showed little change from 2006 — before the financial crisis — to 2011. While some people’s credit scores declined during the economic crisis, many others’ scores remained high or actually improved, because they became more conservative in managing their finances.

Documentary-watchers, keep your eyes on "Project Nim" and "Bill Cunningham New York": both films made the cut for the Academy's documentary shortlist and today they were also named to the Producers Guild list of candidates. The stories of an ape experiment gone terribly awry and our own beloved street style photographer join "Senna," "The Union" and "Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest" on the Producers Guild shortlist. The latter three films did not make the cut for the Oscars.

At Seven Miami, now in its second edition, seven progressive galleries - Hales Gallery, Ronald Feldman Fine Arts, Postmasters Gallery, PPOW, Winkleman Gallery, BravinLee Programs and Pierogi - from New York, Los Angeles and London have banded together to prove that an art fair doesn't have to be a sardine-can-style trade show. "Art fairs are noise," says Postmasters' Magdalena Sawon. Unless a collector shops for names, "it's not easy to spot, take in and think about works on display. We want to slow it down a bit and bring back what seeing and buying art in galleries means."

In response to our article about military working dogs that get post-traumatic stress disorder and our post Thursday about bomb-sniffing dogs in Iraq, the writer and historian Chris Dickon pointed out that American military working dogs played an important role in World War II. In his book, The Foreign Burial of American War Dead, Mr. Dickon notes that 25 dogs were killed in Guam while serving alongside American troops. Those American-born and bred dogs were buried and reburied in three different locations and have been memorialized on plaques and in ceremonies, Mr. Dickon says.
Newt Gingrich may have The Union Leader of New Hampshire, but on Friday, Mitt Romney landed his own high-profile media endorsement - Ramesh Ponnuru, a senior editor at National Review.

Perhaps the fundamental challenge in analyzing this year's Republican nomination race is the unusual divergence between the popular support for the various candidates, as can be measured through opinion polls, and their support among the party establishment, as can be measured through endorsements.

The Trump name is again being attached to something: a Republican presidential debate scheduled for Dec. 27 in Des Moines, The Caucus blog reports. Mr. Trump is pairing up with Newsmax, the conservative magazine and news Web site, to moderate the debate, which will broadcast on the cable network Ion Television. Newsmax's invitation to the candidates begins: "We are pleased to cordially invite you to 'The Newsmax Ion Television 2012 Presidential Debate,' moderated by a truly great American, Mr. Donald J. Trump." Though presidential candidates may initially balk at the idea of appearing in a debate hosted by Mr. Trump - they may ultimately see it as an invitation they can't refuse. Read more »

The 1964 Pontiac Banshee prototype bears many attributes of a blue-chip collector car, yet blue-chip sale prices have eluded its owner, the longtime Pontiac collector Len Napoli. The one-of-a-kind concept was recently listed by Mr. Napoli on eBay at the buy-it-now price of $750,000.

This week's Your Money column discusses a new credit report from a company called CoreLogic, which includes all sorts of information about your financial life that is not captured by the reports from the traditional credit reporting agencies.

Buzunesh Deba enjoyed the South Bronx on Friday at a lot more leisurely pace than the last time she was there. Granted, that was during the New York City Marathon, where she was on the way to a second-place finish among the elite women. This time, she was savoring the praise and love of students and fans at a luncheon in her honor at Hostos Community College.

It didn't take long for Rich Cho, the Charlotte Bobcats' new general manager, to make a substantial mark on the future of the franchise. After years of the Bobcats toiling away on the fringe of playoff contention, Cho took one huge step toward a team reboot in his first weeks on the job by trading Stephen Jackson and Shaun Livingston for the right to select intriguing young big man Bismack Biyombo with the seventh pick in the 2011 draft. Biyombo - along with Kemba Walker, whom the Bobcats selected with the ninth pick - figures to be a substantial part of Charlotte's rebuilding future.
George Walker was sitting outside his brother's house, drinking beer with his buddies, as he has for decades on the block of brownstones in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, where he grew up.

I was as shocked as anyone to read the recent news that a sophomore at Emory University was arrested for getting paid to take the SAT exam for some students at Great Neck North High School. But it wasn't the crime that shocked me; it was that a person could be arrested for such a thing. When I was in high school, back in 1987, my best friend, Liz, came home from taking the SATs at the next town over and reported that during attendance, some anonymous administrator had called out the name of a boy we'd known since kindergarten, someone who was supposed to be sitting next to Liz. Just as she was about to call out, "Absent," a boy she'd never laid eyes on raised his hand casually.

Freeh took over as MF Global's Chapter 11 trustee. The departing directors are David P. Bolger, David Gelber, Eileen S. Fusco, Martin J.G. Glynn, Edward L. Goldberg, David I. Schamis and Robert S. Art handlers for Sotheby's, locked out of their jobs since August in an increasingly bitter union contract dispute with the auction house, have been both inventive and voluble in their protest tactics, traveling to London to picket auctions and even showing up at businesses owned by Sotheby's board members.

The 16-year-old Wolfsonian-Florida International University museum has become a favorite Miami Beach destination, thanks to its intriguing Mediterranean Revival architecture and consistently impressive exhibitions, the latest one of which - "Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity" - opened last week. Parenting, as so many have so famously said, isn't something we do alone. It takes a village, and in that village we sometimes find ourselves faced with, well, situations. Sticky situations. Dilemmas, of a perplexing ethical nature. Moments when we're not sure how to do right by our kids, other kids, our fellow parents, and the people around us.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg paid tribute on Friday to a close aide, Matthew P. Sapolin, his disabilities commissioner, who died of cancer on Tuesday at age 41. At a funeral at St. Patrick's Cathedral, the mayor praised Mr. Sapolin, who was blind from the age of 5 as a result of his cancer, as someone who refused to feel sorry for himself and who fought up until the end of his life to improve the lives of disabled New Yorkers.

Most attention on climate science is focused on the new and the provocative, while the picture of growing risk from rising levels of greenhouse gases is best delineated by decades of work that is old and not contentious. That makes for a bad fit between this scientific enterprise and the world of public opinion, policy and politics. It can also produce a chronic feeling of intellectual whiplash.

ORLANDO, Fla. - Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi has been engrossed in presidential politics since dropping out of college to work on Richard Nixon's second run for the White House in 1968. From county committees to the West Wing, he has been in the middle of Republican politics at every level.

The ingénue is an established category in Oscar's best actress race: the performer who comes out of nowhere, often with her first film, to charm and beguile audiences and Academy voters. Think Gabourey Sidibe in "Precious," Jennifer Lawrence in "Winter's Bone" and Carey Mulligan in "An Education."

High up in an apartment block in Toronto, Viggo Mortensen was padding around barefoot, cleaning up the kitchen after lunch and speaking, in his soft-voiced way, about his longing for immortality. "I'm not afraid of death," he said, wiping down a counter with a damp cloth, "but I resent it. I think it's unfair and irritating. Every time I see something beautiful, I not only want to return to it, but it makes me want to see other beautiful things. I know I'm not going to get to all the places I want to go. I'm not going to read all the books I want to read. I'm not going to revisit certain paintings as many times as I would like. There's a limit." He paused. "I mean, I understand limits are good for character and all that, but I would rather live forever."

Each year, the numbers get bigger. There are 42 million family caregivers now, a cohort that includes more than just adult children watching over their aged parents, although they predominate. Tens of millions of us are engaged in this hard, transformative task; this dance in which who leads and who follows changes by the minute; this time in life that can't be over quickly enough and that we want to last forever; this labor of love.
The job market seems to be getting better, and it is doing so in surprising areas. Jobs seem to be going to people with less education, and the number of long-term unemployed is coming down.

Since World War II, investors in American stocks have always made money during the third year of presidential terms. But with one month left, 2011 could be the first such year to see losses since 1939.

It has been hard much of this year for Western photojournalists to enter Yemen to cover the political turmoil of the Arab Spring. It took Samuel Aranda more than a month to find a safe way into the country, giving him plenty of time to ponder what it would be like working in the deeply divided nation, where hundreds have died in protests.

President Obama never expected to campaign for re-election on lowering the jobless rate to pre-recession levels; all he really needs is a trend in the right direction. He got that this morning with the announcement that unemployment had fallen to 8.6 percent from its sticky 9 percent level most of the year, and you can expect to hear about that drop from the president and his surrogates for some time. It's one of the best job reports in a long while.

There are many ways to measure the lucklessness of the Cleveland Browns. The team has suffered through freakishly botched fourth-quarter field goals in each of the last three games, losing two of them as a result. Peyton Hillis, arguably the team's best player, has come down with a severe case of the Madden Curse, and it seems likely that he will play for another team next season. During a trip to Indianapolis in September, the team showed up four hours later than expected after its plane got stuck in mud at the Cleveland airport.

Google's roughly $400 million acquisition of Admeld, the online display advertising company, automatically attracted government scrutiny because of its size, reports Claire Cain Miller of The New York Times. The Federal Trade Commission is investigating the search giant for antitrust violations. Read more »

For the first five years of my twin boys' lives, I visited our town's library each week, but only to scoop up heaps of picture books, diversions, when all else failed, that filled the time and calmed down their fighting. Now the boys are in kindergarten, learning to read, and so, in a way, am I again. On a recent Saturday, I let my sons page through books on their own in the children's area of the library while I finally wandered among the tall shelves of fiction, which is where I stumbled on Penelope Lively's "Moon Tiger," a Booker Prize winner in 1987. Just a few days earlier, I had heard the writer Moni Mohsin on NPR describe the book on a terrific weekly segment called "You Must Read This." So inspired had she been by the novel's ambitious, selfish, literary hero, Claudia Hampton, Mohsin, at age 22, had quit the "worthy, dreary job" she had accepted shortly after finishing university and jumped into a job at an upstart newspaper. "Like Claudia," she said, "I was determined to lead my life, not be led by it."
The Justice Department on Friday approved Google's roughly $400 million acquisition of Admeld, an online display advertising company.

One of the final topics that came up over the course of many sit-downs with Justin Vernon of Bon Iver when I was working on my magazine profile of him was the Grammy Awards. Or more precisely, his discomfort with them, and his incredulity that he'd ever be in contention for one.

The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday released its much-delayed and oft-revised air quality regulations for industrial boilers and incinerators. The proposal is a modest refashioning of boiler rules introduced earlier this year, which were themselves a major revision of a 2010 plan by the agency that drew heavy political and industry opposition.

With a snap in the air, the classic cocktail revival turns to traditional warmers like hot toddies. "In the old days, they'd warm the drink by putting a hot poker into the glass," said Matthew Piacentini, who owns the Beagle in the East Village, which just started serving what he calls "twilight toddies."

In a deal that could remake the boundaries of the cable and wireless industries, Verizon Wireless said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire wireless spectrum from three cable companies at a cost of $3.6 billion.

Come December and Chennai begins to hum with the start of the kutcheri (classical music concert) season, referred to in the city simply as  the "Season." It's one of the largest music festivals in the world, with more than 1,500 concerts over six weeks at various locations.
