T's Sally Singer discovered the work of Walter Martin and Paloma Muñoz, the artists who designed the T for our holiday issue, at the Museum of Art and Design, where a selection of their whimsical snow globes was on display as part of the group show "Otherwordly: Optical Delusions and Small Realities." Indeed, the duo known for fabricating and photographing miniwinters in glass seemed a perfect fit for the season at hand. Here, the artists talk about their favorite storms, their preferred presents and the resolutions that rarely get made in the new year.

Governor Andrew Cuomo's administration is considering whether to allow drilling companies to blast millions of gallons of water and other chemicals into underground shale formations in New York State to extract natural gas.  His Department of Conservation put out 2,000 pages of documents about this process, known as hydraulic fracturing or hydrofracking, in September, and wants all public comments by January 11.

A holiday tradition continues this weekend, when Le Parker Meridien hotel, 119 West 56th Street (between Sixth and Seventh Avenues) in Midtown West, will display gingerbread houses created by bakeries and restaurants across the city in its lobby. The exhibit, which runs through Jan. 6, is free but the public can vote for its favorite with a $1 ticket, to benefit City Harvest, sold at the concierge desk.

Writing to Santa is an iconic holiday tradition, and one of the few that I dislike. Sure, that carefully penned letter - Dear Santa, please bring me a pony - is cute, what with the backward letters and the lopsided picture of a sleigh and such. But why should Santa, whose gifts come from the goodness of his heart, be told what to give? And how can someone whose toys are made by elves in a workshop be expected to produce a Wii? Then, there's the obvious fact that a pony will never fit in the sleigh. (Please don't ask for a puppy.)

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

Britain's Office of Fair Trading is investigating Groupon's marketing policies, after the daily deals site racked up 48 advertising violations in 11 months, The Guardian reports. The regulatory agency, which oversees consumer protection and competition in Britain, began investigating Groupon in July. Read more »

For my Arts & Leisure essay on public space in New York, I talked to Alexander Garvin. At "Zoning the City," a recent conference held on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the city's landmark 1961 zoning resolution, Mr. Garvin, a veteran urban planner, kept hammering away at the notion that government should zone more - and more wisely -- for public space, as opposed to private development. Mr. Garvin is well known as a big fan of Paris, which Baron Haussmann largely demolished and redesigned for Napoleon III in the 19th century around grand boulevards, streets and pedestrian-friendly spaces. Paris today has become a museum city, for all its glories. Still, Mr. Garvin thinks Haussmann's priorities provide a lesson for New York.

The Bronx muralists whose work was used without permission to raise the street cred of a Fiat commercial starring Jennifer Lopez will be getting, at the very least, a free Fiat by way of compensation. The lawyer for the art collective, TATS Cru, said they would custom-paint the car and auction it for charity. Whether they would also get some money was not made clear, although the artists said they were satisfied with the resolution. Read more on Wheels »

The news and financial services giant Thomson Reuters announced a shakeup in its leadership late Thursday afternoon, Amy Chozick reported, replacing its chief executive, Thomas H. Glocer, after he had struggled to turn around the company in an increasingly competitive market. The Wall Street Journal put those declining fortunes starkly, quoting the projected 2011 breakdown of the $24 billion financial-data market by Burton-Taylor International Consulting: Thomson Reuters at 31.4 percent of the market, down from 37.4 percent in 2005; Bloomberg LP at 30.8 percent of the market, up from 25.1 percent in 2005.

In Friday's New York Times, Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton report that Google is developing a package delivery service geared toward near-instant gratification. The service would let people order items on the Web from nearby stores and receive them within a day.

The Bagger was lucky enough to interview Tilda Swinton the other night, for a TimesTalk, and sartorially and conversationally, she was a thrill, as always. Among La Swinton's revelations: she hates the theater; doesn't believe in the notion of fixed identity; prefers to think of herself as a "schizophrenic" writer-performer rather than an actor; and used to make a bundle betting on horses. (That's her Career Plan B.) Ms. Swinton also talked about her work in "We Need to Talk About Kevin," Lynne Ramsay's controversial adaptation of Lionel Shriver's novel about the mother of a son who goes on a Columbine-style rampage. In this clip, Ms. Swinton explains why she believes the film, which recently won the top prize at the London BFI Film Festival, is about more than the familiar facts of that story. "It's about the inside of someone's mind," she said. "If you go into the film expecting that, you are much more likely to have a good trip."

Verizon Wireless said Friday it had agreed to purchase spectrum licenses for $3.6 billion from a group of companies that included Comcast and Time Warner Cable, part of a push to meet growing consumer demand for wireless services.

Among Buckminster Fuller's visionary designs was the "Fly's Eye Dome," a prefabricated fiberglass structure that was meant to be mass-produced and energy-efficient. This 24-foot prototype of the dome, which is now part of the Craig Robins Collection, is on display during Art Basel Miami Beach and Design Miami at the Palm Lot, at 140 Northeast 39th Street in the Miami Design District, which Robins developed; the dome will ultimately be installed in a pedestrian plaza in the district. It's being shown along with a reconstruction, by the British architect Norman Foster, of the Dymaxion car, Fuller's "omnidirectional transport system," in the exhibition "Architecting the Future: Buckminster Fuller and Norman Foster," curated by Daniel Reiser and Elizabeth Thompson. Here's a time-lapse film that shows the dome's installation in Miami.

RIO DE JANEIRO - Not long ago a city bus drove me by Rocinha, a sprawling favela of 100,000 people in southern Rio with a global reputation for violence. From the safety of my seat I watched the chaos. Beauty parlors were packed. Young people on motorcycles crisscrossed the paths at shocking speeds. A group of school girls giggled as they took pictures with their phones of flirtatious boys strutting by. Funk and samba music blared out of the bars. I loved the scene, but I wasn't about to get off the bus for a walk.

If style, per Gore Vidal, is about not giving a damn, then one might say cybercriminals have lots of style. "DarkMarket" (Knopf, $27), the new book by the T contributor Misha Glenny, disturbingly catalogs the capabilities of these nefarious Internet trolls - imagine, as Glenny does, that they could not only clog your in-box and steal your financial identity but attack your government, cripple your power grid or disable your national banking system. Still, the most common illicit activity on the Interwebs -  pornography aside  -  seems to be some form of personal credit card fraud. In fact, Glenny's title, "DarkMarket," comes from the name of a Web site where thousands of hackers coordinated the cloning and selling of credit card numbers and pins, often culled from illegally placed "skimmers" in A.T.M.'s and card machines. The site was infiltrated by an F.B.I. agent and taken down in 2008, resulting in many arrests.

After a series of highly public missteps over a Fiat commercial featuring Jennifer Lopez, in which the entertainer was depicted cruising past a copyrighted graffiti mural in the Bronx, a settlement has been reached with local artists who claimed to have never granted permission for their mural to be used in the spot.

On the night of Dec. 5, don't be nervous if you spot a bishop, angel and devil sitting together in a pub in Prague. Saturday is the celebration of St. Mikulas (Nicholas) -- a Czech figure similar to Santa Claus -- and while primarily an evening for children, it still brings a smile of remembrance to adults' faces.

Mitt Romney is enduring a tough week. He now trails Newt Gingrich by 20 or more points in some state and national surveys. He had a testy interview with Brett Baier of Fox News, and then compounded the problem by complaining about Mr. Baier's questioning later. A candidate whose presence in the race probably helped Mr. Romney, Herman Cain, is now in jeopardy of dropping out. Both Democrats and Mr. Romney's opponents are putting out ads that hit Mr. Romney on what is perhaps his core vulnerability, his reputation for flip-flopping. Meanwhile, one of Mr. Romney's greatest strengths, his strong positioning in New Hampshire, is at least a bit less certain now following the endorsement of Newt Gingrich by the Manchester Union-Leader.

A part of Indian history is being auctioned off on December 13th in New York City when the late Elizabeth Taylor's legendary jewelry will be up for bidding at Christie's: the Taj Mahal diamond from 1627. Taylor received the stone, which is set as pendant, as a gift on her 40th birthday in 1972 from Richard Burton, whom she was married to at the time. Burton bought it from Cartier for 350,000 pounds, and Taylor had the jeweler replace its original silk chord with an adjustable diamond and ruby chain.

If you were leaving your home in a hurry in the event of a disaster, what items - irreplaceable because of their practical, sentimental or monetary value - would you make sure to include in your bag?

President announced Thursday that he was seeking additional federal money for efforts to prevent and treat AIDS in the United States and globally. In an address to activists, celebrities and lawmakers for the annual World AIDS Day, Mr. Obama said that he would seek $15 million more to support H.I.V. clinics in the United States and $35 million for state drug programs. For international efforts, he set a goal of nearly doubling, to six million, the number of infected people who will get antiretroviral AIDS drugs through a program that his predecessor, George W. Bush, started. Advocacy groups say contributions have suffered as perceptions have taken hold that the epidemic has been arrested. Mr. Obama acknowledged that while the rate of infection has declined elsewhere, in the United States it has remained steady. ''The president just put a powerful down payment toward the end of the AIDS crisis,'' Matthew Kavanagh, director of advocacy for Health GAP, an activist group, said in a statement. And the international group Doctors Without Borders hailed Mr. Obama's financing commitment as ''the shot in the arm that the global H.I.V./AIDS response needs right now,'' and called on Congress ''to turn this commitment into reality.''

MILLER--Charles D. Avery Dennison Corp. mourns the passing of Charles D. "Chuck" Miller, visionary business builder and civic leader, who died November 23, 2011 at the age of 83. In his 47-year association with Avery Dennison, Chuck was instrumental in transforming the company from a U.S.-based manufacturer into a global Fortune 500 market leader in pressure-sensitive labeling materials and office products. As chairman for 17 years and CEO for 21, he drove the company's growth with creativity, courage and confidence, and every aspect of the business -- from vision to strategy to execution to culture -- was shaped for the better by his passion and imagination. Corporate headquarters in Pasadena, California bears his name in recognition of his impact. Chuck translated the qualities that made him such an exceptional businessman into a deep commitment to civic leadership. Among the many roles he filled with distinction were: chairman of the board of the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce, director of numerous Southern California companies, chairman of United Way of Greater Los Angeles, and co-created with Peter Mullin the Mullin-Miller Million Dollar Match Fund to encourage giving to the United Way Pathways Out of Poverty Plan during the recent severe recession. He also supported a wide range of medical institutions, including Operation Walk, which provides total hip and knee replacements to the impoverished and which he personally nurtured from a local into an international organization. A lifelong lover of athletics, he was one of the first members of the organizing committee that brought the 1984 Olympic Games to Los Angeles, and helped establish the Los Angeles Sports Council and the Amateur Athletic Foundation of Los Angeles (today the LA84 Foundation). He provided extensive support to the U.S. Lacrosse and personally funded the women's varsity lacrosse program at Occidental College, which today is a national power in the sport. A deep believer in liberal arts education, Chuck was especially devoted to his alma mater, Johns Hopkins University. He served as university trustee and presidential counselor, endowing the Charles D. Miller Professorship in the humanities at the Zanvyl Krieger School of Arts and Sciences and creating the Vision Fund, a scholarship program for arts and sciences undergraduates and summer students of the Johns Hopkins Center for Talented Youth. In 1998, he received the Heritage Award in recognition of his outstanding service to Johns Hopkins. He also had a long association with Occidental College, serving as a trustee from 1977 to 1998 and continuing thereafter as a trustee emeritus. He remained an active businessman, civic leader and philanthropist after retiring from Avery Dennison. He invested in real estate and owned and operated a wine company, the noted Jackson Hole restaurant Koshu, and a highly successful stable of thoroughbred horses. At the time of his death, he was a member of the executive board of the Rose Bowl Legacy Campaign for the renovation and preservation of the Rose Bowl, a member of the advisory board of the Autry Museum of Western Heritage and a trustee of Southern California Public Radio. The company expresses its deepest condolences to his wife, Carolyn; his daughters Amanda Daly Miller, Candice Louise Miller, Katherine Ann Miller, Susie Cherrill Otten and Charlotte Juanita Miller; and his grandchildren Laura, David, Eric and John Otten, and Harper, Juliet and Zander Branch. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service is planned for December 12 at 11am at The Langham Huntington, 1401 South Oak Knoll Avenue, Pasadena, and a memorial website: CharlesDMiller.org, is now live. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to: Charles D. Miller Legacy Fund United Way of Greater Los Angeles, 1150 South Olive Street, Los Angeles, California 90015. UnitedWayLA.org and Charles D. Miller Rose Bowl Legacy Fund 505 East Colorado Blvd., Suite 201 Pasadena, CA, 91101. RoseBowlLegacy.org

THE SCRIPT ''I spent my life in the private sector. I've competed with companies around the world. I've learned something about how it is that economies grow. We're not going to balance the budget just by pretending that all they have to do is take out the waste. We're going to have to cut spending. And I'm in favor of cutting spending, capping federal spending as a percentage of G.D.P. at 20 percent or less, and having a balanced budget amendment. The right answer for America is to stop the growth of the federal government, and to start the growth of the private sector. I'm Mitt Romney, and I approve this message.''

An article about an auxiliary club of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art that has created a prize bringing together Bay Area artists, collectors and the museum, misspelled the given name of one of the most recent recipients of the Society for the Encouragement of Contemporary Art Award. An article on Tuesday about Iran's passage of a law to downgrade relations with Britain referred incorrectly to the comparative severity of sanctions against Iran by Britain and the United States over Iran's suspect nuclear program, one reason for the downgrade. While new sanctions imposed by Britain include a provision requiring the severing of all contacts with the Iranian Central Bank, as the articles stated, that provision brings Britain's sanctions into line with those already imposed by the United States. It did not make Britain's sanctions ''the most severe,'' nor was it a step that the United States had not taken. (The error was repeated in an article on Wednesday about the attack on the British Embassy in Tehran by Iranian protesters.)

YANNETT--Walter M. 82, principal of Syosset High School for fifteen years, passed away peacefully at home on November 27, 2011. Dr. Yannett served as Syosset High School principal from 1970 to 1985. He also was principal of Division Avenue High School in Levittown from 1965 to 1970. He held various positions at high schools in Bethpage, Baldwin and Floral Park, before becoming principal of Division Avenue. He taught for many years as an adjunct professor in the schools of education at St. John's University and Hofstra University. In 1986, he became an assistant dean in the School of Education at Hofstra. Born in 1929, Dr. Yannett was a long-time resident of Seaford. He received his B.S. degree in secondary education, magna cum laude, from Fordham University in 1951. He served in the U.S. Army from 1952 to 1954 and then began his career in education upon returning from being stationed in Okinawa, Japan. In 1964, he earned a PhD in counselor education from St. John's University. In his early years, he played drums in a small jazz band. His lifelong love of music, especially jazz, made him a strong supporter of the arts in public schools. In 1983, the Nassau County Music Educators Association named him "Administrator of the Year." He also was an avid golfer, playing many rounds with friends and family. His other sport's endeavors spanned the athletic spectrum, from coaching young children's basketball teams to serving for over four decades on various committees of the Nassau County Public High School Athletic Association (Section VIII). Walter's warm smile and gentle soul are what drew people to him; from his colleagues to new acquaintances to his family. He was devoted to his three grandchildren, each of whom he showered with love. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Elizabeth, of Seaford; a brother, Frank and sister-in-law Marie, both of Newton, PA; a daughter, Nancy, and her partner Elise Brokaw, both of Lincoln, VT; and a son, Bruce, daughter-in-law Karen, and three beloved grandchildren, Elise, Gregory and Amanda, all of Rye, NY. He is also survived by several nieces and nephews. Walter was predeceased by his sister, Elaine Agnelli. A private ceremony and burial took place earlier this week. Donations may be made to the Dr. Walter M. Yannett Memorial Fund, which will be used to provide an annual scholarship to a college-bound senior at Syosset High School. Donations should be made payable to Community Funds, Inc. and sent to New York Community Trust, 909 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022.

How imperfect a pairing it seems: the silent, still, small-scale, black-and-white photograph and the sonorous, tumultuous, extravagant and kaleidoscopic opera. And yet, Times archival pictures from the 1940s through the early 1970s (most by Sam Falk) reveal how perfectly these two media complemented one another. Photographers may not have been able to capture the sweep of a production in a single exposure. But they could record up close the hundreds of interstitial moments that yielded the splendor on stage: principals rehearsing incongruously in street clothes, musicians scrambling to locate their instruments, a lead soprano waiting backstage for a cue, the chorus in metal folding chairs.

PASADENA, Calif. -- Raymond Chandler famously described the winds here as ''those hot dry Santa Anas that come down through the mountain passes and curl your hair and make your nerves jump and your skin itch.'' With snapped oak trees, collapsing roofs and even a toppled gas station, the winds here on Thursday made the nerves leap, run and somersault.

Thursday's 11:30 a.m. session at the Bikram Yoga NYC studio in the Flatiron District began as usual: a handful of half-dressed students slowly flapped their elbows as they decelerated their breath and stared at themselves in the mirror. After paying $25 each, they began their mindful workouts in the 105-degree ''Torture Chamber,'' while outside on Fifth Avenue, pedestrians scurried past in coats. A few blocks away, on West 27th Street, about 30 pupils soon began the same breathing exercises, dripping with sweat in the 103-degree heat. But this class, labeled ''Traditional Hot Yoga'' and offered by the growing studio chain Yoga to the People, cost just $8.

When Bobby Davis sent an anonymous e-mail to Syracuse University in 2005, saying that the associate men's basketball coach Bernie Fine had molested him, the university asked its legal counsel to start an investigation. The subsequent decision by the university and its counsel -- Bond, Schoeneck & King -- not to contact the Onondaga County district attorney's office and the Syracuse police department during its four-month investigation has drawn criticism from experts who handle sexual abuse cases. Jeffrey J. Mueller of the risk consultancy firm Granite Intelligence, who is a former assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, said it was ''beyond egregious'' that the university and the law firm did not consult with law enforcement.

Often -- too often for polite company -- David Nalbandian could not be bothered. While other prime-time tennis players of his generation might have heard a troublesome question, exhaled and given a thoughtful response, Nalbandian has long specialized in the curt reply, with the hard set of his strong features and the tight fold of his arms forming an impressive barrier to further dialogue.

ROCKVILLE, Md. - Last week, when a former Boston Red Sox infielder faced accusations of insider trading, the Securities and Exchange Commission got credit for levying a $100,000 fine. The Department of Justice in May heralded a guilty plea from a one-time senior executive at the Nasdaq Stock Market who traded on secret information. And earlier this year, after a lawyer was accused of stealing insider tidbits, federal prosecutors in New Jersey boasted of the arrest. But in each case, the federal government was not the first to detect the potential fraud. Rather, the initial alarm bells were sounded by an obscure group of private-sector analysts stationed here in suburban Maryland.

LIEBOWITZ--Sidney, of Fort Lee, New Jersey, formerly of Riverdale, New York, passed peacefully on November 30, 2011 at age 90. After graduating High School he served as an Army Ranger during World War II in combat in both Africa and Italy and awarded a Purple Heart. He went on to a successful career in the fashion industry as a principal of Bon Dana Sportswear. Sid was predeceased by his wife Shirley in 2008 after over 60 years of marriage. He is survived by a loving and dedicated family of his sister Jean, his daughters Susan and Andrea, his sons-in-law Robert and Harold, his grandson Andrew and wife Hillary, his grandson Jason and his fiancee Fabiola, his granddaughters, Marisa and Rachel as well as his great-grandchildren, Zachary and Zoe. All who knew Sid loved and admired him. His memory will be cherished.

''Storytelling in Japanese Art,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a captivating combination of show and tell, read and look. Curatorially speaking, the exhibition takes us gently in hand and, through text panels, captions and diagrams, reveals the narrative side of Japanese art with memorable clarity. It has been organized by Masako Watanabe, a senior research associate in the Met's Asian art department, and while installed in the museum's Japanese permanent-collection galleries, it is a temporary show full of significant loans. Illuminating the tales played out in a lavish assortment of hand scrolls, hanging scrolls, screens and books, the exhibition, with its explications and elucidations, gives didacticism a good name. It deserves return visits, especially for its second rotation, starting Feb. 8, when, due to fragility, several hand scrolls will be wound to different scenes and five screens will be replaced by others.

And several retailers said that they would discount even more in December.

She moved to Charleston, SC, where she enjoyed tennis, bridge and working as a guide at Boone Hall Plantation. She is survived by her husband, David Ruley, of 34 years, two children Stephanie and Jack Ruley, and five siblings, and many nieces and nephews. CAMERON--Donald, Designer, artist, raconteur, connoisseur, consummate gentleman and beloved friend, passed away in Manhattan at the age of 87 on November 23, 2011. Born in Toronto on March 17, 1924, he immersed himself in the study of art before and after serving in the Canadian Army. In 1944, a serendipitous encounter with legendary designer Tommi Parzinger at the Museum of Modern Art in New York forever changed both their lives. The two became partners in business as well as life, and together they created Parzinger Originals, a furniture and interior design firm that catered to elite decorators and clients. Their creations continue to inspire and entice savvy dealers and collectors to this day. Like Parzinger, Donald also created extraordinary pieces for the fashionable Madison Avenue retailer Rena Rosenthal. A bold and original abstract painter, he was invited by Hilla Rebay to exhibit at the Museum of Non-Objective Painting, the precursor to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, in the late 1940s. Following Mr. Parzinger's death in 1981, Donald established his own namesake firm to serve select clients eager to avail themselves of his encyclopedic knowledge of modern design. In addition to being one of the great under-sung maestros of 20th-century design himself, he was a gracious and elegant host and a fixture in his Beekman Place neighborhood, renowned for his wit, warmth and dapper personal style. His life was an object lesson in generosity and gracious living. He is survived by two nieces, Donna Pytel of Canada and Marlene Lane of Northern California, and two nephews, Alex Cameron of Toronto and Robert Cameron of Vancouver.

LOTHRIDGE--Charles David, Born in Colony, NY on January 16, 1923. He was the son of Dr. William and Anna Lothridge. He attended Union College, Schenectady and joined the Army Air Force in 1943, stationed first in India as a classification and assignment officer and later in Morocco. Moving to New York City in 1946, he enrolled in the psychology department of Columbia University, receiving a PhD in 1951. He worked for American Airlines and Booze Allen and Hamilton before joining GE in 1959 where in Crotonville he designed training sessions, taught and programmed management courses. In 1972, he moved to the New York City office becoming manager of International Development and Training Programs. In 1978, served as manager for the European Area Division in Brussels. Retired in 1985, GE recalled him as international consultant. Charles moved to Bucks County, Pennsylvania in 1992 where he shared a home with longtime partner James A. McGirr. His remains will be interred in the family plot at Memory's Garden in Albany, NY.

A Federal judge on Wednesday dismissed a lawsuit against the Dallas Museum of Art involving a collection of some 1,400 works of art, including paintings by van Gogh, Renoir, and Pissarro. The collection was donated to the museum by Wendy Reves, the widow of Emery Reves, a writer and publisher who was a close friend of Winston Churchill. Ms. Reves, who died in 2007, and her husband lived in a villa in the south of France that was originally built for Coco Chanel.

The Miami Art Museum will be renamed the Jorge M. Perez Art Museum of Miami-Dade County after a $15 million gift from Mr. Perez, the museum announced Thursday. Mr. Perez, a developer of multifamily residences, had already given $5 million to the museum's capital campaign for its new downtown building, designed by Herzog & de Meuron and due to be completed in 2013. ''It makes it possible to move forward with great confidence about the building,'' Thomas Collins, the museum's director, said in a telephone interview. ''We can concentrate in the next two years on our endowment and in that way supporting our programs.''

POSNER--Patricia R.,died on November 28, survived by her husband, Robert Losada, her sister Elaine P. Cooper, and other loving family in Virginia and California, as well as many beloved friends. We will miss her kindness, humor, joie de vivre, and above all her devotion to family, friends, and to people and animals in need. Memorial celebration to be held at a later date. Contributions may be made to Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Foundation 425 E. 61st St., NYC 10016.

LEXINGTON, Ky. -- The St. John's players gathered for strength through the flashing lights and pounding bass rhythms of the Kentucky Wildcats' intimidating introductions. They faced the biggest challenge of the season in their first game on the road Thursday night, coming off a Nov. 26 loss to Northeastern to take on the No. 1-ranked Wildcats. The players were grouped in the locker room at the end of the night as well -- to console one another after the Wildcats routed them, 81-59, at Rupp Arena.

RUSSELL--Thomas, 69, of Denville, NJ, passed away suddenly on November 29th. Proud father of Thomas and Brian (Amy). Adoring PopPop to Kevin, Hannah and Sydney. Devoted brother to Eileen Russell and the late Mary Catherine Sculthorpe. Also survived by loving nephews, nieces, cousins and many friends. He will be remembered with love, humor and as a gentle soul.

Facing an increasingly worrisome budget outlook, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders are in negotiations to return to Albany for a special session later this month, an official briefed on the negotiations said on Thursday. Lawmakers would return to vote on ways to offset a shortfall caused by lower-than-expected tax collections, according to the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the negotiations were still in the early stages. In mid-November, Mr. Cuomo's budget office projected that the state would be short $350 million during the current fiscal year, which ends March 31.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has tried to keep up with its tech-inclined riders by posting helpful Twitter messages like how to get to the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, updating its Facebook page as reliably as some teenagers, and creating a contest to let riders vote on their favorite apps. But when it comes to its online auctions, the agency will never be confused with eBay.

8:30 p.m. | Updated A federal court has denied Raj Rajaratnam's request to remain free on bail while he appeals his insider-trading conviction, a ruling that forces the fallen hedge fund manager to report to prison on Monday.

1:26 p.m. | Updated Contract talks between New York City Opera and its two main unions broke down on Wednesday night shortly after midnight, leaving little immediate prospect of an agreement and raising the possibility of a strike by the orchestra and chorus.

The parents of one of the children who was killed in the so-called West Memphis Three murder case have asked the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to refuse Oscar consideration for the documentary ''Paradise Lost 3: Purgatory,'' saying that it celebrates the three defendants in that case. In a letter reported by The Associated Press, Todd and Dana Moore, whose 8-year-old son, Michael, was found murdered with two other boys in West Memphis, Ark., in 1993, told the academy that the defendants were ''unjustly able to enter into a plea agreement'' and obtain their freedom from prison because of ''public pressure that exploded due to gross misrepresentations of fact'' in the ''Paradise Lost'' films.

Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has been pummeled for a string of gaffes in the past few weeks. But at least he's being a good sport about it. A new television advertisement lampoons him for forgetting in a debate last month that the Department of Energy was one of the three federal agencies he would eliminate as president.

The On Baseball column on Nov. 22, about Detroit Tigers pitcher Justin Verlander's winning the American League Most Valuable Player Award, referred imprecisely to two pitchers who previously received votes for M.V.P. The Angels' Francisco Rodriguez and the Phillies' Brad Lidge, in 2008, were the last pitchers to receive first-place votes, not to receive votes.

Once again, the balcony is closed: Roger Ebert said Wednesday that a resuscitated version of his long-running television series ''At the Movies'' would be halted while he seeks new sponsors for the show. ''At the Movies,'' which was most famously hosted by Mr. Ebert and Gene Siskel in the 1970s, '80s and '90s, was canceled in 2010, then revived in January under the title ''Ebert Presents At the Movies'' and featuring film reviews by Christy Lemire of The Associated Press and Ignatiy Vishnevetsky, a writer for Mubi.com.

Adolfo Carrion Jr., the former Bronx borough president and White House official, who is now a federal housing official and is a potential candidate for city comptroller, has been fined $10,000 by the city's Conflicts of Interest Board for using an architect on a personal renovation project who was also involved in a large housing development that required his approval. The fine stems from events in 2006 and 2007, when Mr. Carrion, then in his second term as borough president, hired the architect, Hugo Subotovsky, to design a porch for his Victorian home on City Island in the Bronx. At the time, Mr. Subotovsky was the architect for Boricua Village, a proposed 679-unit complex in the Melrose neighborhood.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about the struggle to store, transmit and analyze the growing volume of data from gene sequencing misstated what W. Richard McCombie, the researcher pictured, was examining. It is a glass device known as a flow cell, to which the DNA from cells is attached; it does not contain cells themselves.

An article on Thursday about a new formula announced by the administrator of the fund set up by BP for victims of the 2010 oil spill along the Gulf Coast, which could result in significantly larger payments than had been offered to shrimp and crab fishermen, misstated the amount paid out of the fund so far. It is $5.74 billion, not $5.74 million.

Bruce Springsteen will be the keynote speaker at next year's South by Southwest Music and Media Conference and Festival, Mr. Springsteen and organizers of the event, which is based in Austin, Tex., jointly announced on Thursday. His participation is scheduled for March 15 at the conference's main space, the Austin Convention Center. By accepting the invitation, Mr. Springsteen, who last month also announced a world tour for 2012, his first live performances since 2009, joins a list of performers who include some of his youth's idols and several of his peers. Previous keynote speakers at SXSW include Johnny Cash, Carl Perkins and Smokey Robinson as well as Pete Townshend, Neil Young, Robert Plant and Lucinda Williams.

MOFFATT--Marston Michael, age 67, Professor Emeritus of Rutgers University, passed peacefully on Saturday, November 26, 2011. The beloved husband of Pamela, is also survived by two sons Alexander and Jacob, a sister Harriet and a host of other loving relatives and friends. Services will be held on Saturday, December 3, 2011 at the Fort Lincoln Funeral Home, 3401 Bladensburg Road, Brentwood, MD 20722 at 10am.

BRAUFMAN--Sidney, on Monday, November 28, 2011 of leukemia. He was 89. After a successful corporate career he became a professor, most recently in the Management Department of Baruch College, where he taught courses in Business & Society in addition to Labor/Management Relations. He was also active as an arbitrator. An avid tennis player, he was still on the court the day before he entered the hospital. He was a lifelong amateur vocalist who strummed along on his guitar when his busy schedule would permit. He is survived by his devoted wife Lee, and children Jill, Brad and Mark. He was also grandfather to three adoring grandchildren, Phoebe, Sophie and Brett. He will be missed by his family, friends, students and associates, who knew him to be unfailingly just, thoughtful, thorough, and wise.

LIEBOWITZ--Sidney. To Susan and Robert, Andrea and Harold, Andrew and Hillary, Jason and Fabiola, Marissa and Rachel and Zachary and Zoe. All of you lost a prince of princes. Certainly one of the best that we knew on this planet. He did more than touch our lives, he made them so much better and asked for nothing in return. Rest well Sidney. Both Shirley and you deserve it. With much love, Michael and Gwen.

Herman Cain acknowledged in a newspaper interview on Thursday giving an undisclosed amount of money to help support Ginger White, an Atlanta woman who came forward this week to say that she and Mr. Cain had had a 13-year extramarital affair that ended about eight months ago. Mr. Cain has repeatedly insisted that he was no more than a friend to Ms. White.

An article on Wednesday about the passage of a bill in the House of Representatives to make more permanent resident visas available to some highly skilled immigrants referred incorrectly to the congressional service of the bill's lead sponsor, Republican Representative Jason Chaffetz of Utah. He was first elected in 2008 and is now in his second term; he is not a freshman.

ALBERTUS--Alfred J.,age 84 of Stony Brook, NY (formerly of Brooklyn), on November 30, 2011. NYPD Detective 1st Grade. WW II Army Veteran. Beloved husband of Prudence (nee Silecchia). Loving father of Donna, Barbara, Carol, and Angela. Cherished grandfather of Elise, Michael, Ian and Christin. Reposing at The Branch Funeral Home, 190 East Main Street, Smithtown, NY 11787. www.branchfh.com

FREEDMAN--Norbert, died on November 30 at the age of 88. A native of Hamburg, Germany, he emigrated under the pressure of the Nazi regime, taking the trans-Siberian railroad and settling in Seattle in 1940. After graduating from the University of Washington, he moved to New York, where he received a doctorate in psychology from Columbia University. Despite his blindness, he established himself as a psychoanalyst and a professor of psychology at Downstate Medical Center. A past president of the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research (IPTAR) and author of numerous publications, he was passionately devoted to teaching, research, and collaborative work. He lost the mother of his children, Njuty Greenberg Freedman, forty years ago, but then married Joyce Davidson Beckett, with whom he shared thirty-three happy years. He leaves behind his wife Joyce, son Jeffrey, daughter Carol and her husband Lawrence Vogel, grandchildren Gabriella and Max, brother Ralph Freedman, nephews Mark and Jonathan and Joyces sons, David, Peter and Michael, their spouses and children. He had a gift for friendship and a wide circle of devoted friends who will miss him dearly. Funeral service Sunday, 10:30am at "The Riverside" 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Family will gather after burial at the Freedman residence from 4 to 8.

An article on Monday about the Jets' 28-24 victory over the Buffalo Bills misstated the yard line where the Jets took possession with 5 minutes 44 seconds remaining in the game and drove for the winning touchdown. It was the Jets' 18-yard line, not the Bills' 18.

Cannes. Toronto. Park City, Utah. If these cities can each be the home of a great film festival, then why not Montclair, N.J.? Isn't it entitled to a little bit of that cinematic luster, too? ''Is it entitled to it?'' Stephen Colbert, the late-night comedian and Montclair resident, asked rhetorically. ''I think every town is entitled to anything that they want to do.'' He added: ''Small communities that dream big like this, I think they should be encouraged to. Everything that people are willing to come together to work hard on and create, they can.''

One of the charts I prepared for my presentation at the G30 was intended to debunk the notion that we need some kind of special factor aside from the depressed economy to explain low business investment. On the x-axis of the figure below I show the ratio of actual GDP to the CBO estimate of potential GDP. On the vertical axis I show the ratio of nonresidential fixed investment - basically, business investment - to potential GDP. The blue dots show data from 1985 to 2007, during which there was a strong relationship: a depressed economy led to low business investment. The red dots show subsequent data; if anything, business investment has been stronger since the Great Recession began than you might have expected.

An unapologetic and defiant Herman Cain suspended his presidential campaign on Saturday, pledging that he "would not go away," even as he abandoned hope of winning the Republican nomination. You went to a holiday party but realize you didn't actually get much to eat. Or after having Christmas cookies for lunch you went to a play and you're starving, but none of the post-theater options really appeal. Solution: go home and make a fine bowl of pasta. Everything you need is in your pantry-pasta, olives, capers, garlic, anchovy, hot pepper, olive oil. So much better than take-out or a slice of so-so pizza, and ready in minutes. See how in this week's City Kitchen.

The ongoing argument about whether the Internet is a boon or a bust to civilization usually centers on the Web's abundance. With so much data and so many voices, we each have knowledge formerly hard-won by decades of specialization. With some new fact or temptation perpetually beckoning, we may be the superficial avatars of an A.D.D. culture.

8 P.M. (HBO) THE ADJUSTMENT BUREAU (2011) Matt Damon, his toothy grin hinting at a young Robert F. Kennedy, portrays David Norris, a Democratic Brooklyn son and a favorite in the New York race for the United States Senate. That is, until a damaging photo from his past does in his campaign, and he meets Elise (Emily Blunt, above with Mr. Damon), a dancer who innocently causes him to veer off the path that a team of mystery men have, unbeknownst to David, plotted for him. Their plan does not include Emily, or free will on David's part, for that matter. Now he must decide whether to give in to their machinations -- or reclaim his life. If George Nolfi, who directed this film and wrote the screenplay, based on a short story by Philip K. Dick, ''doesn't go deep in 'The Adjustment Bureau,' a drilling down to where it hurts (he would rather entertain than pain you), he skates on the gray-blue surfaces of his film with confidence,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''Along with his likable, confidently sexy leads and an excellent troika'' in John Slattery, Anthony Mackie and Terence Stamp, ''Mr. Nolfi keeps the film balanced between sincerity and self-conscious amusement, rarely faltering in tone. With their cool-cat hats and tailored suits, Mr. Mackie, Mr. Slattery and Mr. Stamp look as if they're on hiatus from Mr. Slattery's AMC show, 'Mad Men' (or extras in 'North by Northwest'). Like Mr. Damon and Ms. Blunt they can bring you into this world because Mr. Nolfi never takes his eye off the human stakes.'' 6 P.M. (Animal Planet) HERCULES SAVES CHRISTMAS Hercules, the pit bull star of ''Pit Boss,'' tries out his acting chops to play Santa's beloved pooch and the overseer of his naughty-or-nice list. His mission this Christmas Eve: to help Max, a 12-year-old orphan with flagging holiday cheer, get on Santa's good side and find some seasonal spirit along the way.

BERKLEY--Robert H.,91, June 10 1920-December 1st, 2011. Bob was a graduate of The University of Wisconsin class of 1941, where he met his late wife Barbara. He also attended the Harvard Graduate School of Business. Together, Bob and Bobbie traveled the world and shared great adventures at home and abroad. A remarkable gentleman, Bob was fiercely loyal and endearingly stubborn. During WWII, Bob served as an officer aboard the USS Mansfield, a destroyer in the Pacific, and, always attuned to the finer necessities of life, snuck an ice cream maker aboard the ship. In 1955 he founded Weave Corporation, a textile design and manufacturer, and led the company through his retirement in 1994. A founder of the Pascack Valley High School District, Bob served as school board president, and vice president of the New Jersey Association of School Boards for ten years, was a passionate member of his community, always politically engaged, and was firmly committed to a range of philanthropic causes. Adoring brother of Jane Kantor and Paul Berkley (d. 1957). Devoted husband of Barbara (d. 2001), father to Alison (d. 2006), and Roger, and most loved and loving grandfather of Kate, and Daniel and Sarah. A service will be held Sunday, December 4, 10am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NY, NY. Interment Temple B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to: University Of Wisconsin Foundation, US Bank Lockbox 78807, Milwaukee, WI 53278-0807

In a deal that could remake the boundaries of the cable and wireless industries, Verizon Wireless said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire wireless spectrum from three cable companies at a cost of $3.6 billion. The spectrum transfer, if approved by the government, will allow Verizon to further expand its wireless data networks. But perhaps just as important, a separate agreement announced Friday will enable the cable companies - Comcast, Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks - to market Verizon services and vice versa, foreshadowing the possibility of cable television, broadband, home phone and cellphone service someday appearing on a single monthly bill.

There are 101 N.C.A.A. trophies sitting in the Stanford Athletic Hall of Fame Room, none of them for women's soccer. Now the team is just one win away from its first College Cup after a 3-0 victory over Florida State (18-7-1) in Kennesaw, Ga., on Friday night.

-When the Prado completed the rehanging of its unparalleled Velazquez collection last year two works were conspicuously missing from the walls. But now, after several months of restoration work long urged by experts, the paintings, ''Philip III on Horseback'' from 1634-35 and ''Margaret of Austria on Horseback,'' created during the same years, have returned to the company of Velazquez's royal portraits. -The restoration, sponsored by Fundacion Iberdrola and undertaken by Rocio Davila, has not only removed dirt and darkening varnish - which the museum said created a ''veil'' that obscured the sense of pictorial recession in the paintings - but also removed strips that had been added to the left and right side of both portraits in the mid-18th century to make them the same size as other works in a series that Velazquez had painted. The strips undermined Velazquez's composition and the pigments in the strips darkened differently than the those in the original paintings, creating an effect that looked almost as if a broad shaft of light was pouring down on the subjects.

Art handlers for Sotheby's, locked out of their jobs since August in an increasingly bitter union contract dispute with the auction house, have been both inventive and voluble in their protest tactics, traveling to London to picket auctions and even showing up at businesses owned by Sotheby's board members. On Thursday night two of the art handlers interrupted a planning meeting attended by Diana L. Taylor, a Sotheby's board member and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's girlfriend, and demanded that she help end the lockout. Initially, Ms. Taylor seemed to ignore the interruption but then she leaned into her microphone and made her position known clearly, in stern tones.

SILVERSTEIN--Louis. The Council of School Supervisors and Administrators mourns the passing of Louis Silverstein, celebrated newspaper editor and designer, who died on December 1, 2011, at the age of 92. To Helen, Anne, Dan, Robert and James, our deepest sympathy. To Anne, our wholehearted gratitude for bringing "Mr. Lou" into our lives. He re-imagined The CSA News, turning it into an award-winning union newspaper. He worked side by side with you, his beloved daughter, until the end. What an honor for us to have had the designer of today's New York Times share with us, for nearly a decade, his genius, humor and wisdom. Aaron Rodgers may be having the quietest record-shattering season for an undefeated team in N.F.L. history. Rodgers's Packers are certainly getting attention with their 11-0 record and their bid to repeat as Super Bowl champions. He is also getting plenty of credit for their success. But his assault on the N.F.L. record book is receiving little notice, and his 2011 season is not getting enough credit for what it may be: not just a most-valuable-player-caliber effort, but the best season a quarterback has had.

ORLANDO, Fla. - The fight for control of the United States Senate will intensify next year, with Republicans trying to capture a majority by seizing upon the political headwinds facing Democrats. The pieces to the puzzle are nearly all in place, with one exception: Nebraska. There, Senator Ben Nelson, a Democrat, has yet to decide whether he will run for a third term or join several of his Democratic colleagues and retire. He has a campaign organization in place, but intends to make a final decision over the holidays.

FREEDMAN--Norbert. IPTAR mourns the loss of its past president Dr. Norbert Freedman whose intellectual and psychoanalytic vigor energized our organization. Ever a force for understanding, a man of generous spirit, a teacher, researcher, mentor and friend, Bert never turned from responsibility and never tired of our work. He was a pillar of IPTAR and the international psychoanalytic community. He touched the lives of countless analysands, supervisees, candidates, students and colleagues and the loss of his intellect, wisdom, work ethic, humor and friendship will never be replaced. He lived his life with great zest, relishing the many activities and people with whom he was involved. It is hard to imagine IPTAR or our lives without him.

Continued housing distress and rising prices for food and gas are weighing heavily on American families' finances as the holiday shopping season begins, a quarterly analysis shows. The CredAbility Consumer Distress Index, a measure of household financial stability, fell sharply in the third quarter, largely erasing improvements made over the prior three quarters. An uptick in late mortgage and rental payments and higher prices at the grocery store and gas pumps were the chief culprits.

The director Bartlett Sher and the actress Kelli O'Hara, who collaborated previously on the Tony Award-winning revival of ''South Pacific'' and the musical ''Light in the Piazza,'' will reunite for a developmental workshop in New York this month of their latest project, ''The Bridges of Madison County,'' a musical adaptation of the best-selling novel and hit film. The Broadway producers Jeffrey Richards, Stacey Mindich and Jerry Frankel confirmed on Thursday that they were holding the workshop; no plans for a full production have been announced. Ms. O'Hara, a Tony nominee for both shows with Mr. Sher as well as for ''The Pajama Game,'' will star as Francesca Johnson, an Iowa farm wife who has a brief love affair with a roaming photographer, Robert Kincaid. Meryl Streep and Clint Eastwood played those roles in the 1995 film version of the 1992 novel by Robert James Waller. No other casting for the workshop was disclosed.

Matthew P. Sapolin, the Bloomberg administration's disabilities commissioner, died of cancer on Tuesday. He was 41. Mr. Sapolin, whose death was confirmed by the mayor's office, had served as commissioner for the Mayor's Office for People With Disabilities since the post was created in 2006. In that role, he pushed to make New York City's building code more accommodating to people with disabilities, created a mentoring program and led an effort to freeze rents for some disabled New Yorkers.

If you qualify for pretax transit benefits, you'll probably see the perk shrink starting in January. The benefit allows employees to lower their federal tax bill by setting aside pretax money to pay for the cost of taking public transportation (or van pools, in less urban areas) to work. The cap, now $230 a month, was about half that amount until Congress increased it temporarily in 2009. The move put the transit benefit on par with a similar $230-a-month benefit available to help commuters pay for parking.

MILLER--Charles D. Avery Dennison Corp. mourns the passing of Charles D. "Chuck" Miller, visionary business builder and civic leader, who died November 23, 2011 at the age of 83. In his 47-year association with Avery Dennison, Chuck was instrumental in transforming the company from a U.S.-based manufacturer into a global Fortune 500 market leader in pressure-sensitive labeling materials and office products. As chairman for 17 years and CEO for 21, he drove the company's growth with creativity, courage and confidence, and every aspect of the business -- from vision to strategy to execution to culture -- was shaped for the better by his passion and imagination. Corporate headquarters in Pasadena, California bears his name in recognition of his impact. Chuck translated the qualities that made him such an exceptional businessman into a deep commitment to civic leadership. Among the many roles he filled with distinction were: chairman of the board of the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce, director of numerous Southern California companies, chairman of United Way of Greater Los Angeles, and co-created with Peter Mullin the Mullin-Miller Million Dollar Match Fund to encourage giving to the United Way Pathways Out of Poverty Plan during the recent severe recession. He also supported a wide range of medical institutions, including Operation Walk, which provides total hip and knee replacements to the impoverished and which he personally nurtured from a local into an international organization. A lifelong lover of athletics, he was one of the first members of the organizing committee that brought the 1984 Olympic Games to Los Angeles, and helped establish the Los Angeles Sports Council and the Amateur Athletic Foundation of Los Angeles (today the LA84 Foundation). He provided extensive support to the U.S. Lacrosse and personally funded the women's varsity lacrosse program at Occidental College, which today is a national power in the sport. A deep believer in liberal arts education, Chuck was especially devoted to his alma mater, Johns Hopkins University. He served as university trustee and presidential counselor, endowing the Charles D. Miller Professorship in the humanities at the Zanvyl Krieger School of Arts and Sciences and creating the Vision Fund, a scholarship program for arts and sciences undergraduates and summer students of the Johns Hopkins Center for Talented Youth. In 1998, he received the Heritage Award in recognition of his outstanding service to Johns Hopkins. He also had a long association with Occidental College, serving as a trustee from 1977 to 1998 and continuing thereafter as a trustee emeritus. He remained an active businessman, civic leader and philanthropist after retiring from Avery Dennison. He invested in real estate and owned and operated a wine company, the noted Jackson Hole restaurant Koshu, and a highly successful stable of thoroughbred horses. At the time of his death, he was a member of the executive board of the Rose Bowl Legacy Campaign for the renovation and preservation of the Rose Bowl, a member of the advisory board of the Autry Museum of Western Heritage and a trustee of Southern California Public Radio. The company expresses its deepest condolences to his wife, Carolyn; his daughters Amanda Daly Miller, Candice Louise Miller, Katherine Ann Miller, Susie Cherrill Otten and Charlotte Juanita Miller; and his grandchildren Laura, David, Eric and John Otten, and Harper, Juliet and Zander Branch. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service is planned for December 12 at 11am at The Langham Huntington, 1401 South Oak Knoll Avenue, Pasadena, and a memorial website: CharlesDMiller.org, is now live. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to: Charles D. Miller Legacy Fund United Way of Greater Los Angeles, 1150 South Olive Street, Los Angeles, California 90015. UnitedWayLA.org and Charles D. Miller Rose Bowl Legacy Fund 505 East Colorado Blvd., Suite 201 Pasadena, CA, 91101. RoseBowlLegacy.org

CAWLEY--William of Cape May Courthouse, died November 27, 2011. He was born August 23, 1933 in Queens, NY. Lt Col Cawley graduated from Regis HS in Manhattan, and held multiple degrees, including two MAs from St. John's in History and Philosophy. He held a lifelong passion for swimming, the outdoors and learning, and was seldom far from a book. In his youth he was a lifeguard at Jones Beach, and went on to two distinguished careers. The first in service of our country with the USAF 53rd Weather Reconnaissance Squadron, and the second as a teacher for several institutions, including Syosset HS in NY. Bill was predeceased by his parents, Paul and Beatrice Cawley; his brother, Jim Cawley; and Children Mary and Michelle. He is survived by his loving and dedicated wife of 55 years Charlene; his sister Peggy Cawley; his children, Shayne, Kathleen, Erin, William and Christina; his grandchildren, Michael, Daniel, John, Anna, Kristy, Colleen, Sean, Maggie, Chase and Christopher; great-grandchildren, Logan and Liam. In his memory, please submit donations to the Alzheimer's Association.

An article on the DealBook page on Friday, about a fraud task force at the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, erroneously attributed a distinction to a task force member, Laura Gansler. Ms. Gansler was a co-author, with Clara Bingham, of ''Class Action,'' on which the movie ''North Country'' was based; she was not the sole author.

An article on Wednesday about the tax debate in Congress described incorrectly the recipients of the payroll tax reduction that President Obama has proposed to extend in 2012. All working Americans who contribute to the Social Security system through payroll tax withholding receive the reduction; not all workers, as some are covered by other retirement programs. The article also misstated the year the reduction is in effect. It is this year, not last year.

Sócrates, the elegant midfielder and Renaissance man who served as captain of Brazil's 1982 World Cup team, died Sunday in São Paulo. He was 57. Two new surveys out this morning, from the Des Moines Register and NBC News, show Newt Gingrich with the polling lead for the Iowa Republican caucuses. Ashok Malik of Tehelka analyzes the costs and benefits of India's decision to allow foreign retailers to open stores in the country in an even-handed essay. He argues that many of the opponents of the policy change are trying to "scare Indians by raising the bogey of the foreigner." But he also points out that allowing foreign retailers will likely also put pressure on some domestic businesses and industries. "Every economic initiative is a mixed blessing," he writes. "Even if it expands the cake, there will still be some losers."

Marielle Anzelone, a botanist and urban ecologist who founded NYC Wildflower Week, has been reporting from a patch of forest in Inwood Hill Park in Upper Manhattan once a week, beginning on the first day of autumn, Sept. 23. In her last dispatch, she observed a blooming witch hazel shrub, a bright yellow counterpoint to the naked trees above. Read the full series at NYTimes.com/cityroom. First, snow in October. Now, at the end of November, unseasonable warmth. On Monday, it reaches 70 degrees in New York, a record for the day. The mugginess is unwelcome; the air feels thick and wooly. A musky, earthy scent hangs in the woods.

YANNETT--Walter M. 82, principal of Syosset High School for fifteen years, passed away peacefully at home on November 27, 2011. Dr. Yannett served as Syosset High School principal from 1970 to 1985. He also was principal of Division Avenue High School in Levittown from 1965 to 1970. He held various positions at high schools in Bethpage, Baldwin and Floral Park, before becoming principal of Division Avenue. He taught for many years as an adjunct professor in the schools of education at St. John's University and Hofstra University. In 1986, he became an assistant dean in the School of Education at Hofstra. Born in 1929, Dr. Yannett was a long-time resident of Seaford. He received his B.S. degree in secondary education, magna cum laude, from Fordham University in 1951. He served in the U.S. Army from 1952 to 1954 and then began his career in education upon returning from being stationed in Okinawa, Japan. In 1964, he earned a PhD in counselor education from St. John's University. In his early years, he played drums in a small jazz band. His lifelong love of music, especially jazz, made him a strong supporter of the arts in public schools. In 1983, the Nassau County Music Educators Association named him "Administrator of the Year." He also was an avid golfer, playing many rounds with friends and family. His other sport's endeavors spanned the athletic spectrum, from coaching young children's basketball teams to serving for over four decades on various committees of the Nassau County Public High School Athletic Association (Section VIII). Walter's warm smile and gentle soul are what drew people to him; from his colleagues to new acquaintances to his family. He was devoted to his three grandchildren, each of whom he showered with love. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Elizabeth, of Seaford; a brother, Frank and sister-in-law Marie, both of Newton, PA; a daughter, Nancy, and her partner Elise Brokaw, both of Lincoln, VT; and a son, Bruce, daughter-in-law Karen, and three beloved grandchildren, Elise, Gregory and Amanda, all of Rye, NY. He is also survived by several nieces and nephews. Walter was predeceased by his sister, Elaine Agnelli. A private ceremony and burial took place earlier this week. Donations may be made to the Dr. Walter M. Yannett Memorial Fund, which will be used to provide an annual scholarship to a college-bound senior at Syosset High School. Donations should be made payable to Community Funds, Inc. and sent to New York Community Trust, 909 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022.

PORTNOY--Theodora Preiss, NYC native, Miami Beach resident, a breast cancer survivor died from complications from a stroke. A noted NYC and East Hampton art dealer for over 20 years, former board member of the Cornell Museum at Rollins College and an art historian her Theo Portnoy Gallery championed American craft as fine art to the public and art critics. Graduated from Fieldston attended Russell Sage College and graduated from Sarah Lawrence. A long time resident of Scarsdale and Amagansett, NY, is survived by her son, Eli of Miami Beach and granddaughter Anna Lilly of Eugene, Oregon. Her husband Samuel and daughter Lois both died of cancer in '06.

A review on Nov. 6 about ''Blue Nights,'' Joan Didion's account of her daughter, Quintana Roo Dunne, misstated the time that passed between the death of Didion's husband, John Gregory Dunne, and that of Quintana herself. It was some 20 months, not three years. (John Gregory Dunne died in December 2003 and Quintana in August 2005.)

Suspecting that California regulators may be exerting unlawful influence over the agencies that determine federal fuel-economy standards, Representative Darrell Issa has begun an inquiry into the practices of the California Air Resources Board, or CARB, the agency charged with setting pollution standards for the state. He is also seeking information from automakers to aid his investigation.

When the first Nobel Prizes were presented on Dec. 10, 1901, the award for economics wasn't one of them. The original five were for achievements in physics, chemistry, medicine and literature, and in pursuit of peace. The sixth, formally known as the ''the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel,'' was established by Sweden's central bank and first granted in 1969. Like the prizes in physics and chemistry, this one is awarded by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. The initial laureates were Ragnar Frisch and Jan Tinbergen. The prizes include a medal, a personal diploma and a cash award, now 10 million kronor -- almost $1.5 million at current exchange rates. JEFF SOMMER

STEIN--Kathleen Ellen. Born June 9, 1944 in Chicago. Died November 13, 2011, age 67, from a fall while hiking in the Delaware Water Gap. Stein lived in New York City most of her life. Preceded in death by mother Margaret Bruce Stein and father Benjamin F. Stein, M.D., of Sarasota, Fla. Survived by longtime companion Douglas Stein of New York City, sister Julia Long (Randy) of Weekie Wachee, Fla., and brother John F. Stein (Beth) of Nashville, TN, niece Kim Long and nephews Jonathan Long (Jaime) and Tyler Stein. Stein received a B.A. from Bard College with extensive PhD work at Rutgers University, where she taught literature and writing. She began her journalism career covering rock music for Circus, Creem and others before joining Omni magazine as a founding editor and writer. Former Omni editor and friend Keith Ferrell writes, Stein, during her long tenureat Omni, became one of the very best writers on science, and particularly neuroscience, in the country. Her stewardship of the magazine's legendary interviews is the prime reason they are legendary. She followed science with the assiduousness of a good reporter, and pursued its explication for general audiences with the enthusiasm of an evangelist. A widely published science and technology writer, Stein wrote for the New York Times, Biotechnology Newswatch and UPI, among others. Her book, The Genius Engine, on the complex role of the prefrontal cortex of the human brain was published in 2007. It received praise as a laudable work. A tremendous effort brought out with natural ease and Stein for her ability to present technical information in understandable terms, without being pedantic or overly simple. In addition to her love of writing, reading and good conversation, Stein was an avid hiker and accomplished sailor. There will be a memorial service at a later date. The family requests memorial donations be made to The Nature Conservancy, Bard College English Department or Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation (JDRF).

Michelle Trebow, 59: I have dysphagia, which is an illness of the esophagus. It is progressive and irreversible. Eventually I won't be able to swallow at all and will require a feeding tube. Everyone in my family is gone, so I had been totally alone in my illness. But then I met Danny at our assisted-living facility in May. He had just been transferred here from hospice, and the first time we looked into one another's eyes, our souls locked. I love Danny's quietness and his acceptance of the situation we are in. We decided to get married and vowed to take care of each other to the end. The facility director wanted to throw a party. She took me shopping -- we found a prom dress on sale -- and she did my makeup and hair. We married on July 2, 2011, and all of the residents came. Some even cried during the ceremony, and everyone danced afterward. It was the most beautiful day of my life. I'd been married before, but this was different. I realized, it does not matter when you meet the love of your life -- all that matters is that I got to meet him. Danny Clauson, 53: The very first moment I saw Michelle, I thought, I'm going to marry that woman. I was bowled over by her beauty. And then I fell in love with her spirit. Less than a month later, I asked her to spend the rest of my life with me. I've lived a hard life: I've been married before, but it did not end well. Since then, I've been homeless and am now dying from liver cirrhosis due to hepatitis C. I've suffered a lot and was ready to give up. But ever since I met Michelle, I wake up happy.

The Russian carrier Vladivostok Airlines (vladivostokair.us) plans to start flying between Siberia and the United States in July, the only direct service between the two regions. The new route, Anchorage-Petropavlovsk, a four-hour flight across the Pacific, connects Alaska to an urban hub on the otherwise wild Kamchatka Peninsula. The carrier picks up where Alaska Airlines left off in the late 1990s, when it discontinued flights between Alaska and Russia's Far East.

FREEDMAN--Norbert, died on November 30 at the age of 88. A native of Hamburg, Germany, he emigrated under the pressure of the Nazi regime, taking the trans-Siberian railroad and settling in Seattle in 1940. After graduating from the University of Washington, he moved to New York, where he received a doctorate in psychology from Columbia University. Despite his blindness, he established himself as a psychoanalyst and a professor of psychology at Downstate Medical Center. A past president of the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research (IPTAR) and author of numerous publications, he was passionately devoted to teaching, research, and collaborative work. He lost the mother of his children, Njuty Greenberg Freedman, forty years ago, but then married Joyce Davidson Beckett, with whom he shared thirty-three happy years. He leaves behind his wife Joyce, son Jeffrey, daughter Carol and her husband Lawrence Vogel, grandchildren Gabriella and Max, brother Ralph Freedman, nephews Mark and Jonathan and Joyces sons, David, Peter and Michael, their spouses and children. He had a gift for friendship and a wide circle of devoted friends who will miss him dearly. Funeral service Sunday, 10:30am at "The Riverside" 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Family will gather after burial at the Freedman residence from 4 to 8.

Barry Llewellyn, a founding member of the popular Jamaican harmony trio the Heptones, died on Nov. 23 in St. Andrew, Jamaica. He was 63 and lived in Brooklyn. The cause was pneumonia, said his wife, Monica.

Are hotels really the new community centers? The incorrigible Will Self checks out the scene and discovers it's not so bad. The on dit is that metropolitan hotels are now the favored working, socializing and culture-consuming loci of the mediatized professional. But hey, let's not just surf the zeitgeist. Let's hang 10 on the breaking wave of the future: hotels are what neophytes term ''glocal'' phenomena, in that they seamlessly elide down-home verities - a rumpus room for colleagues and pals - with worldwide utilities. However, no longer is it a case of ''All work and no play make Jack a dull boy. . . .'' - we're not talking about wintering over in the Rockies and trying a little ax play here, oh, no. Rather, the aim is to strike out for the known, check into a hotel in your own immediate environs, and then reorient your usual pursuits around this novel situation. In the interests of assaying the plausibility of this lifestyle, I took the tube six stops from my house in Stockwell, south London, strolled across Leicester Square and entered the unhallowed portals of the newish W Hotel.

The Prototype column last Sunday, about the inventor of a prosthetic device intended to ease phantom limb pain, misstated the location of the former Walter Reed Army Medical Center. It was in Washington, D.C., not in Virginia.

Who could pass up something billed as ''the fattiest pastry in all of Europe''? That's how the kouign-amann, a specialty of Brittany in France, was described to me when I visited the region this summer. Kouign-amann (pronounced kween ah-MON and derived from the Breton words for butter and cake) is something like a croissant but with extra layers of salted butter baked between the sheets, and a crispy coating of caramelized sugar.

Here's a sampling of readers' comments on Neil Genzlinger's column about how current situation comedies don't stack up against those of the past. ''I loved this column on the end of comedy. As a writer of 'M*A*S*H,' 'Cheers' and 'Frasier,' I must agree. We strove for a lot more than most of today's current shows -- and found other ways to convey penis jokes. Our feeling was always that anybody in junior high could make a penis joke. But to do it artfully, that takes a real writer.''

THE soaring Beekman Tower Hotel, at First Avenue and 49th Street, was an out-of-place landmark for years, until the United Nations went up. These days its dramatic Art Deco profile is not quite as prominent, a streamlined orange brick shaft built in 1928 as Panhellenic House, a residence for college women. The 61-year-old developer was Emily Eaton Hepburn, a real estate novice who created one of New York's most distinctive skyscrapers. Emily Eaton graduated from St. Lawrence University, class of 1887. After her marriage to Barton Hepburn, a banker and lawyer, she energetically promoted women's suffrage and projects like the re-creation of Theodore Roosevelt's house on East 20th Street. She was a key supporter of the City History Club, established to give children an appreciation of New York's colonial heritage.

At a press conference Thursday in Tokyo, the Toyota Motor Corporation and the BMW Group jointly announced they would collaborate on specific advanced powertrain technologies. The effort would initially be focused on research in lithium-ion batteries. Additionally, BMW was contracted to supply 1.6-liter and 2-liter 4-cylinder diesel engines to Toyota Motor Europe.

DIAMOND--Paulette Abraham, 89, born in Brooklyn, NY and long time resident of Queens. Passed away at home, surrounded by family and loved ones, November 26, 2011. Devoted high school teacher of English and reading. Predeceased by her cherished husband Frank, and brother Herbert Abraham. Beloved mother of David and Janet. An energetic woman of intelligence, warmth, generosity and integrity. Donations may be made to the UJA. Forever in our hearts.

The father of modern-day foraging, René Redzepi, is not short on accolades. His Copenhagen restaurant, Noma, has earned best restaurant in the world in San Pellegrino's foodie poll two years in a row, his abstract dishes comparisons to the paintings of Cy Twombly. Behind the chef's famously free-form approach is a highly studious investigation into the culinary possibilities of foraged ingredients. The El Bulli and French Laundry veteran has set up a nonprofit called the Nordic Food Lab on a nearby houseboat to ''create cornerstones for a new kind of cuisine,'' he says. The research lab, led by Lars Williams, a former Noma chef and an alum of New York's WD-50, has been experimenting with fermentation and umami for seven months, for instance. ''It's a bridge between science and the cooking world, but not for the sake of science,'' Redzepi says. ''For the sake of deliciousness.''

To the Sports Editor Re ''Syracuse Fires Fine After Latest Allegations,'' Nov. 28: Absorbing the initial effect of a child or adult coming forward to disclose sexual abuse is extremely difficult. Often, it is met with denial, skepticism or anger, complicating a horrific situation for the victim.

Since Olivier Theyskens exudes an edgy romanticism with his poetic long hair, he has always seemed like a Belgian goth. At the end of the last century, when he was a 21-year-old prodigy, he made clothes with a hint of darkness and dressed Madonna in a long frock coat for the 1998 Academy Awards. Now, at age 34, he is making cool clothes for his own generation, creating a 21st-century version of American sportswear as designer for his own Theyskens' Theory label and for the giant Theory company, which is under the umbrella of the Japan-based Fast Retailing group.

DESKEY--Michael, an architect engaged in large-scale projects of New York City firms, died on February 15, 2011, in Manhattan. He was 82. The elder son of Donald Deskey, innovative industrial designer, and Mary Campbell Douthett, pianist, Michael Deskey was born and raised in NYC, going to school first at Dalton and later at the Lawrenceville School in New Jersey. He was educated further at Yale and M.I.T., with a year of construction work between so that forever after he could talk to engineers and recognize subpar concrete testing. At Harrison & Abramovitz, Architects, in NYC from 1959, he designed laboratories for Brandeis University and New York State at Albany as well as the underground concourse and extension of Rockefeller Center west of Sixth Avenue and the U.N. International School in NYC. He also supervised the construction of the new McGraw-Hill building and the U.N. Library. In 1975 he grew a beard and soon after moved to Wauwatosa, Wisconsin, as the resident architect on the state medical college's education complex. Later he supervised additions to Southern Ocean County Hospital, Manahawkin, NJ, and the construction of headquarters for Philip Morris and Equitable Life Assurance, NYC, and managed the building of a U.S. Army Corps of Engineers research facility in Hanover, NH. His last project was supervising the construction of the American Museum of the Moving Image in NYC. Mr. Deskey was a skilled amateur photographer and electronics wizard and a punster. He wrote for "Films in Review" and twice fooled the panel on "To Tell the Truth." He was articulate, erudite; a lover of cats, women, movies, animation, symphonic music, midcentury modern design, the Vignelli map, Manhattan, a good pot roast, language, Helvetica, the books of John P. Marquand, and crosswords. He had an encyclopedic mind and a dry wit; he was a stickler for detail and beloved for his eccentricity. His brother, D. Stephen Deskey, and his nephews, Derek and Dennis, survive him, as do his last cats, Chloe and Samantha. He is sorely missed by his friends.

SIMNER--Marvin E. 84, passed away suddenly on December 1, 2011. Cherished husband for over 50 years of Tina Simner, proud father of Rick, and adoring grandfather of Daisy and Linus. Originally from New York, Marvin resided in Rancho Santa Fe, CA. Owner, and partner with his wife, of Commodore Corporation. A devoted friend, Marvin will be remembered for his humor and lust for life. We will miss him everyday. A service will be held at El Camino Memorial in San Diego on Sunday, December 4th at 2pm.
