The Dispatch essay on Nov. 27, about a Jewish family's online debate over making a donation to support Palestinian refugees, misidentified the event that prompted a cousin to write a series of emotional e-mails to family members. It was Israel's 2006 war with Hezbollah, not its 2009 war with Hamas.

In a world where even ''man caves'' - the dimly lit redoubts where men are left to tinker and socialize with other men - are falling prey to D.I.Y. home improvement television shows, two men on the South Shore of Long Island have found shelter for their creature comforts in the most unlikely of places. ''This, I think, is a bit more functional than a man cave,'' says Ed Palace, 50, settling into the director's chair inside the garden shed adjacent to his home in Brookhaven, N.Y., a leafy hamlet on eastern Long Island. ''A man cave is where you go and watch TV or porn or a ballgame. I can use this for storing my tools and potting supplies - stuff that I wouldn't bring in the house.''

MICHEELS--Ina M.,passed away peacefully at home in Newton, MA on November 27, 2011 surrounded by family. She was born in the Netherlands, in Amersfoort in 1927 and also lived in Amsterdam. She came with her mother, Mily Polak, to the New York City area in 1938, at age 11. She was married to Louis J. Micheels, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst for 61 years until his death in 2008. She attended high school at the Putney School in Vermont, and graduated from Russell Sage College in 1948. Following college she worked as a photographer in a studio that specialized in fashion photography in New York City. Above all she was a family person a dedicated and loving wife to Louis and mother to Ronald and Elizabeth. She lived for 52 years in Westport, CT and then moved to Newton, MA for the last six years or her life. She enjoyed activities including sculpture, photography, competitive sailing with her husband, gardening, visiting art museums and galleries, attending classical music performances, and playing with her four grandchildren. She also loved spending time in her second home on Martha's Vineyard where she enjoyed family and friends and the beautiful landscape. She is survived by her son Ronald, her daughter Elizabeth, their spouses Ann and David, and their children Graham, Erik, Lia and Wyn.

8:30 P.M. (Cinemax) CEDAR RAPIDS (2011) The skyscrapers and his sparkling hotel swimming pool in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, signify the big time to Tim Lippe (Ed Helms, above center), a 34-year-old insurance salesman and naïf arriving from Brown Valley, Wis., for a convention. An orphan, he has sought fatherly advice from his boss (Stephen Root) and something less maternal from his seventh-grade teacher (Sigourney Weaver). Soon he's trapped between the forces of his suite mate, Ronald Wilkes (Isiah Whitlock Jr.), a man of reason, and of Dean Ziegler (John C. Reilly), the gathering's vulgar center of attention. Then there's Joan Ostrowski-Fox (Anne Heche), the melancholy party girl who tugs at his heartstrings. But what Tim has really come for is the Two Diamonds Award, which he is meant to bring back to Brown Valley at whatever cost. ''Part of what's satisfying about 'Cedar Rapids,' which was directed by Miguel Arteta ('The Good Girl') from a smart, generous script by Phil Johnston, is that it takes both Tim and his joy seriously, and without self-congratulatory winks and nudges,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''Tim is funny, with his Ken-doll hair and sweater vests, wide-eyed wonder and fear ('There's an Afro-American man standing in my room,' he says with dismay on meeting a suite mate), but he only looks like a punch line.'' She added: ''It's a modest journey of a modest man that Mr. Arteta smartly doesn't inflate.'' Joan may call him Insurance Man, a kind of superhero, ''but Tim isn't super anything (though he proves heroic), and what makes 'Cedar Rapids' a low-wattage pleasure is its insistence that his ordinariness -- with his decency and sense of wonder -- is pretty extraordinary.'' 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Ms. Amanpour interviews the Republican presidential candidate Rick Santorum and Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, about his 30 years in Congress and his decision not to run for re-election. Angelina Jolie discusses her directorial film debut, ''In the Land of Blood and Honey,'' about the war in Bosnia during the 1990s.

Over the 26 years they've spent growing up in the Marais, the identical twins Alex and Victor Carril have earned a reputation for street brawling - with each other - in their picturesque Paris neighborhood. When the director Pascal-Alex Vincent caught wind (as all locals eventually do) of these ''hot twins who fight,'' he cast them in his short film ''Bebe Requin,'' which competed at Cannes in 2005, and later as the leads in ''Donne-Moi la Main,'' a movie inspired by their bellicose proclivities. As villains in this month's ''Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows,'' the twins will undoubtedly earn even wider recognition. But until then they keep busy making hip-hop music videos and working on their fashion line, Is Not Dead. And they both hold court nightly in the cafes near their family home on the Place du Marche Sainte-Catherine. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Argentina kept alive its chances of winning its first Davis Cup with a clear-cut victory over Spain in doubles on Saturday. David Nalbandian and Eduardo Schwank defeated Feliciano López and Fernando Verdasco, 6-4, 6-2, 6-3, in a two-and-a-half-hour match in Seville. The Argentines took control early in the second set, breaking their Spanish opponents twice to go ahead, 4-0. Spain leads the best-of-five Davis Cup finals, 2-1, on the strength of singles victories by Rafael Nadal and David Ferrer on Friday. The concluding singles matches will be played Sunday. ''It was not our best day, especially not mine,'' López said after the doubles match. More coverage at nytimes.com/sports.

Francesca Bonato's accessories line, Hacienda Montaecristo, was born of necessity. When she and her husband, the model Nicolas Malleville, opened their hotel, Coqui Coqui, in Tulum, Mexico, 10 years ago, ''Calvin Klein didn't sell linens here,'' she says. So the couple made their own, working with local weavers for everything from towels to uniforms. Along the way, she fell in love with the traditional shawl called the rebozo, which she and her partner, Jacopo Janniello Ravagnan, use for their bags, sandles and jewelry. ''We're inspired by the synchronicity of the colonial and local traditions,'' she says, ''by the romanticism of Mexico.''

They're called ninja miners not for their stealth but for the ubiquitous green panning bowls they sling over their backs. Even in outer Mongolia, where they lawlessly pan for gold, the resemblance to the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles is unmistakable. For years, they have furtively worked at abandoned commercial mines and on the edges of active mining sites, sleeping in canvas tents and laboring for 12 hours a day. But the 21st-century gold rush has pushed them into national parks, encroaching on the border with Siberia. Environmentalists say the ninjas are destroying pristine rivers and grasslands with their mining methods, which involve cyanide and mercury. Even the ninjas, many of them out-of-work herders, recognize the damage, but they say there is no other way to earn a livelihood in rural Mongolia. The mining can be dangerous, difficult and cold: at the snow-covered sites where the ninja miners work, temperatures can drop below minus-50. But for the potential of $20 a day, the ninjas have little choice but to pan for gold. total population of mongolia: 2,754,685 population density of mongolia: 4.3 people per square mile

Andrew Dermont In ''Me and My Man Shed'' (Page 66), Andrew Dermont, the director of online media at Big Think, stumbles upon a family friend's masculine hideaway. In addition to his journalism, Dermont, a Wesleyan graduate, has something of an entrepreneurial streak: in 2009, he and his roommate revived the Tammany Hall era's beefsteak feasts with a biannual festival in Brooklyn. (The event is now sponsored by McSorley's Ale.)

For someone like me, someone like her presents an existential problem. Conditioned as I am to peering under the surfaces of things and sussing out the dark truth, how am I to parse the enigma of transparency - the lack of discernible neuroses, the absence of characterological curveballs - that is Tory Burch? Despite her many roles as a ragingly successful business entrepreneur, divorced mother of three sons and devoted stepmother to three daughters, crack skier and tennis ace, adored friend, philanthropist, consummate hostess and general woman about town, she is disconcertingly all of a piece. There is - but how can this be? Can Dostoyevsky be all wrong? - no lurking secret self, no rattling skeletons. What you see, as God knows how many people have told me about her, ranging from her own mother to the society maven Billy Norwich, is what you get. And what you get, as far as I can tell, having spent some time with her and having talked to numerous people about her, is someone annoyingly close to perfect. Someone it would be nice to dislike, if she were only dislikable. Someone it's impossible not to envy, if only because her life seems sun drenched from the get-go, with a childhood that sounds near magical, spent climbing trees and romping with her brothers and the German shepherds her parents bred on a 35-acre gentleman's farm in Valley Forge, Pa., replete with tennis court and swimming pool. But here I am sitting with her at lunch in early October at one of her favorite haunts - Kelly and Ping on Greene Street in SoHo - and what I can't help noticing immediately is that she really listens, not like a person pretending to be interested until she gets the chance to talk but like someone who's actually intrigued by what you have to say. Right now, for instance, we are discussing the ordeal of clinical depression - one of my favorite subjects. My sense is that bleakness is not a component of Burch's inner landscape (indeed, her sister-in-law Patty Isen tells me that she's ''not that kind of person''), but all the same she seems compassionate, tells me about a dear friend of hers who suffers from the disease. For a moment or two I forget that I am here to interview her, rather than vice versa.

DISCUSSING the Ching-a-Ling Nomads motorcycle club does not usually require mention of teddy bears or Lego sets or Hannah Montana dress-up dolls, but then again this is the first year the outlaw biker club has become involved in a holiday toy drive run by the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Epiphany, on East 206th Street in the Bronx. ''Our goal is to collect 140 gifts -- that's double what they took in last year,'' said Willie Ching-a-Ling, a club member, who, following the Ching-a-Ling tradition, adopts the group's name while speaking to the press. ''We've changed over the years. We've gotten into that socially conscious thing.''

Survived by his loving wife of 63 years, Jacqueline and their two daughters, Iane Deutsch (Steven), and Stacee Bernstein (Jeffrey), and grandchildren Allie Ammerman (Matthew), Jennifer Rifkin (Adam), Benjamin Bernstein and Ryan Bernstein and his great-grandchildren Rylan and Bryce Ammerman.

SILVERSTEIN--Louis. The Council of School Supervisors and Administrators mourns the passing of Louis Silverstein, celebrated newspaper editor and designer, who died on December 1, 2011, at the age of 92. To Helen, Anne, Dan, Robert and James, our deepest sympathy. To Anne, our wholehearted gratitude for bringing "Mr. Lou" into our lives. He re-imagined The CSA News, turning it into an award-winning union newspaper. He worked side by side with you, his beloved daughter, until the end. What an honor for us to have had the designer of today's New York Times share with us, for nearly a decade, his genius, humor and wisdom. We honor the memory of a great New York Times assistant managing editor and art director and we honor his beloved family.

This past summer I drove across the country interviewing people who had lost their jobs since 2007 - since the housing market disintegrated, since Lehman Brothers evaporated, since layoffs subsumed the work force. I asked for details about the climactic phone call, the conference room, the look of the sky out the window, the security escort, the drive home: all the particulars of the experience. I met a mortgage broker who, one morning, learned he had been laid off when he found the door to his office building padlocked. I met an H.R. executive who had laid off a couple of hundred people before she herself was laid off. I met a husband who was laid off two weeks after his wife announced she was pregnant. I met a wife who laid off her husband.

VOXMAN--Himie, director of the University of Iowa School of Music, 1954-1980, died November 22 in Iowa City, IA. He was 99. Voxman is best known throughout the United States and Europe for his innumerable music publications, selling millions of volumes in the past 60 years. For decades his compilations and editions have formed the standard texts for aspiring and advanced wind musicians. His archival research in European libraries has brought to light an invaluable list of previously unpublished 18th and 19th century wind solo and chamber works. In 2000 Voxman became the first American to receive a Lifetime Achievement Award from the International Clarinet Association. He continued mentoring students and performing into his late 90's. His last published work was completed when he was 93. An event to celebrate Voxman's unique contributions will take place in Iowa City in the near future. More information may be found at: www.clas.uiowa.edu/faculty/ memorials/voxman.shtml.

Forget the less-is-more trend - tis the season to load it on. And in the makeup artist James Kaliardos's capable hands, full makeup looks glamorous, not glitzy. ''I went with a tough, sexy look inspired by Jodie Foster and Debbie Harry,'' Kaliardos says. ''It's the idea you can go rock 'n' roll for holiday and not always be glitter-crazed.'' Leaving skin practically bare (''Just a touch of Armani Luminous Silk Foundation in the center zone of the face, minimal powder and a hint of contour under the cheekbones''), he focused on serious eyes and lips. After dabbing concealer onto lids, he used M.A.C.'s 213 fluff brush to apply Nars Lhasa, a chic gray shadow, to the top lid, and Nars Underworld Duo Eyeshadow under the lower lashes. ''Really feel your shape and bones so you get subtle contour and an emphasis on the crease of the lid,'' Kaliardos advises. He curled lashes and added a lick of inky Givenchy Phenomen'Eyes mascara. For the festive red lip, he used Nars Velvet Matte Lip Pencil in Dragon Girl. ''It's so easy to draw on and fill in,'' he says. ''Apply, and into the night you go!'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The N.H.L. board of governors meets Monday and Tuesday in Pebble Beach, Calif., with two major items on the agenda: realignment and the collective bargaining agreement that expires in September. Realignment has big implications, with two proposals under consideration by the owners and their representatives. One would preserve the two-conference, six-division setup that has been in place since 1998-99. Winnipeg, now in the Eastern Conference's Southeast Division, would move to the West's Northwest Division, and either Detroit or Columbus would move to the East.

The ring, a birthday present, is an austere hunk of gold with an ice rink of diamonds finished off by a flat piece of carved jade - a phoenix, according to a Chinese artist who spied the ring during a dinner party in Beijing. I gazed wondrously at the design so as not to appear rude but thought: phoenix, schmeenix. The ring was given to me by someone I love, and I can still see his creased, anxious face the night I opened the box. It was designed by David Webb, a name that had personal associations for me of New York; some borrowed from Vogue and W in the '70s, others from those bird cages of rapture, the ''women's pages'' in newspapers, where praise for Webb's jewels was constant and vaguely haughty. Some years later, in the '90s, if I happened to be in the vicinity of 57th Street and Park Avenue, I would glance toward the David Webb shop, a fortress marked by a sleek nameplate, and think the place was somehow equal to a private bank or club. Which just goes to show you what a myth New York is, or as Truman Capote called it, ''a diamond iceberg.'' It would be years, and the gift of a ring, before I would be able to appreciate the remarkable genius of David Webb.

GERTENBACH--Robert F.,passed away peacefully on Tuesday, November 22, 2011 at the age of 88. He is survived by his loving wife Carol, two children Steve and Gail, daughter-in-law, Jennifer and two grandchildren Nicole and Ryan. A true patriot, he served with distinction in WWII (Pacific theater) as a lead bombardier in the 9th bomb group of the US Army Air Corp. His reverence for education propelled him in business as he was a CPA and a lawyer. He held various executive positions including Vice President of the Better Business Bureau and President of the Council for Tobacco Research. His gregarious nature and zest for life made him a friend to many. He will be deeply missed by all. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Fisher House Foundation, Inc. 111 Rockville Pike, Suite 420, Rockville, MD 20850-5168 (888)294-8560 or visit: www.fisherhouse.org/donate. Cremation will be private.

The purpose of a ''holiday'' magazine is, invariably, to talk about gifts: those we want, those we give, those we dream about in abstract and lustful ways. And this issue contains an extraordinary number of all of the above. Jane Herman and Ethel Park's selection of presents (Page 103) is as delightful and diverse as one could hope for. Their strategy for those on your list? Give a small bundle of items that, taken together, provide charming commentary on the personality of the giftee. They love canary yellow diamonds (hello, Rihanna!) with a crane-shaped bedside lamp, sandals for the beach with a jigsaw puzzle and stormproof matches (monsoon insurance!), local green eggs and Dutch eco magazines. It's an adorable and adult spin on a Christmas stocking. (In the course of their shopping, they unearthed and juxtaposed a vast number of cool items; visit our Web site for even more.) Of course, when we talk about gifts, we also look beyond the wrapping paper. There is the gift of great writing: we are delighted to share a part of Emmanuel Carrère's ''Lives Other Than My Own'' (Page 117), his meditation on loss in the wake of the Asian tsunami of 2004, and to publish Joan Juliet Buck's memoir of a Christmas spent in Venice, fitfully and miserably, with her parents and Peter O'Toole (Page 140). There is also the gift of discovery: Sebastian Kim and Jacob Brown's portfolio, on Page 147, of the breakout talents of 2011 (including Tyler, the Creator and Charlie Day) is terrific fun.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Secrets of the Spiral,'' Nov. 24: My high school coach, Ken Keuffel, who championed single-wing football as a coach at Wabash College for six seasons and at Lawrenceville School for 21 years, had a simple technique for instructing developing passers how to grip a football.
A first look at spring suggests a delightful duality: Do you reveal or conceal? The choice is as plain as black and white.
Um, how did you get into this? I was the guy who made fake IDs in college. I like looking at things and figuring out how they're made.

SHORTLY before he died of cancer in January, the designer Charles Nolan made an unexpected request. He wanted his store in the meatpacking district to remain open, no matter what happened to his label. Mr. Nolan, who was 53, was a charming man who had a terrific run in the bridge sportswear market early in his career, as a designer for Bill Blass, Anne Klein and Ellen Tracy. Through the Fashion Institute of Technology, he was also a mentor to countless designers. Still, his signature label, founded in 2004, was not so well known that you would have imagined a long future for his homey little shop, where the racks of smart coats and sequined dresses were positioned beneath overflowing displays of family photos, sketches and a video projection of a fireplace.
An obituary last Sunday about Odumegwu Ojukwu, the Nigerian colonel who proclaimed the Republic of Biafra in 1967, misstated the name of a school he attended. It is Epsom College, not Epson.

Montserrat Figueras, the glamorous, powerfully emotive Catalan soprano who along with her husband, Jordi Savall, created ensembles that revitalized the performance of early music, died on Wednesday at her home in Bellaterra, Spain. She was 69. The cause was cancer, said Alia Vox, the record label she and Mr. Savall founded in 1998.

Photographed by Sophia Schorr-Kon, ''Balance: European Hardcore'' (Mark Batty Publisher, $40) catalogs the sweaty, fist-swinging hordes that mosh across the continent - including miners, teachers, luxury-car salesmen and Subway sandwich managers. The travel writer Pico Iyer outs his unhealthy - but not uncritical - obsession with Graham Greene in ''The Man Within My Head'' (Knopf, $26). (Iyer marvels at how Greene's grouchy book on Mexico, ''The Lawless Roads,'' could be ''so dyspeptic, so loveless, so savagely self-enclosed and blind.'')

High up in an apartment block in Toronto, Viggo Mortensen was padding around barefoot, cleaning up the kitchen after lunch and speaking, in his soft-voiced way, about his longing for immortality. ''I'm not afraid of death,'' he said, wiping down a counter with a damp cloth, ''but I resent it. I think it's unfair and irritating. Every time I see something beautiful, I not only want to return to it, but it makes me want to see other beautiful things. I know I'm not going to get to all the places I want to go. I'm not going to read all the books I want to read. I'm not going to revisit certain paintings as many times as I would like. There's a limit.'' He paused. ''I mean, I understand limits are good for character and all that, but I would rather live forever.'' Mortensen's combination of cheekbones and limpid-eyed sincerity has tended to inspire a slightly awestruck tone in journalists over the years. Some of their more breathless accounts of his chilled-out, barefoot demeanor have come perilously close to making him sound a bit of a pill: a parody of the soulful gypsy artiste, all flared nostrils and rippling Kant quotations. Happily, he is not really as oppressively soulful or as grandiose as such reports might suggest. He is earnest, God knows, and his pronouncements on life and art verge, occasionally, on the sententious. But he's not a preening nostril-flarer. What he brings to mind, more than anything, is your older brother's hippie friend from childhood - the one who played you your first Velvet Underground album and instructed you in Trotskyist politics. He has the same lank-haired seriousness, and - oddly enough - the same shyness. He also has, for what it's worth, one of the strangest and unsexiest laughs in America: a kind of abrupt, feminine cackle that is liable to make you jump if you're not expecting it.

Joseph Gordon-Levitt's star turns in ''50/50'' and ''Inception'' may have overshadowed the recent success of his online passion project, hitRECord.org. The Web site invites artists from all walks of life to collaborate with the actor, resulting in music, short films and, now, a picture book called ''The Tiny Book of Tiny Stories'' ($15). The sweetly amateurish story collection is the first in a trilogy of titles from It Books, part of the publishing giant HarperCollins. Here Gordon-Levitt, 30, explains why this book deal is not just a coup for his young company but also an object lesson in how it works. The book is made up of roughly 45 illustrated stories culled from about 8,600 online submissions. Why does it have a predigital, ziney feel even though it came from this newfangled Web concept? I think that has less to do with the methodology and more with my personal taste and also the taste of the artist named Wirrow, who started this ''Tiny Stories'' collaboration in 2010. Wirrow is this artist who lives in England. He never gives out his real name and he never shows his face. He prefers to sort of remain anonymous, although we became friends recently when I was shooting ''The Dark Knight Rises'' in London.

The red pant had a good, long run as fashion's best-loved bottom, but it's about time a new color came into favor. The top contender: green, and more specifically pale, mellow, minty green, introduced in the resort collections as a prelude to spring's more pastel-centric palette (only a few months away). This green's dustier renditions - as seen on the spring runway at Theyskens' Theory - act similar to a khaki or olive green and can be worn as easily. ''We treat it like a neutral,'' says Acne's Jonny Johansson, who did suede leggings in the softest jade hue. ''It's like our gray.'' From the Row, a pair of silk pants in the prettiest sea foam need nothing more than a bit of shine - jacket or jewels - to make them evening-appropriate. ''The mint would look great paired with any metallic, silver or gold,'' say the designers Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen about their elegant, Deco-esque pant. Now, that's refreshing. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

It may be too late to try Ferran Adrià's molecular gastronomy at El Bulli in Catalonia, which closed in July. But with the opening of several Michelin-starred hotel restaurants in Spain, travelers can experience cutting-edge cookery in places outside remote areas of the Basque Country or Catalonia. The chef Dani García runs Calima in the resort town of Marbella; and the twin chefs Sergio and Javier Torres run Dos Cielos in Barcelona. Both restaurants, part of the Melia hotel chain, are making Spain's new cuisine easier to reach (if not easier on the wallet). Martín Berasategui ( above), whose fame, in Spain, rivals that of Mr. Adrià, is bringing molecular gastronomy to Mexico with Passion, a restaurant at the all-inclusive Paradisus resort in Playa del Carmen, opening Dec. 12. ''I have personally selected and supervised the training of the executive chef, the sous chefs and the maître d', in addition to service staff,'' he said.

Buffeted by lackluster profits and turmoil in the global markets, Wall Street is bracing for one of the worst bonus seasons in recent memory. But in the alchemy of high finance, bankers are hoping to turn the slump to their advantage. Financial firms are preparing to dole out huge amounts of stock at depressed prices, the value of which could rise substantially in a few years.

Bar hopping with a bunch of gondoliers at Christmas wasn't Joan Juliet Buck's style. When I peered over the Gothic staircase at dawn on my fourth day in Venice to see that the lobby of the Hotel Danieli was under 14 inches of water, I sent up thanks for my very first acqua alta. It meant the bar was out of commission. The bar's armchairs, stools and tables were already stacked all the way up the staircase. Our tribe began each day in the bar at 10: Peter O'Toole; his wife, Sian Phillips; her mother, known to all as Mumgee; their daughters Kate and Pat with their nanny Elizabeth; two writers in love, Harry Craig and Shana Alexander; and Joyce and Jules Buck, my parents. They and the O'Tooles had a movie company called Keep Films, and they were as inseparable in play as in work.

BERKLEY--Robert H.,91, June 10 1920-December 1st, 2011. Bob was a graduate of The University of Wisconsin class of 1941, where he met his late wife Barbara. He also attended the Harvard Graduate School of Business. Together, Bob and Bobbie traveled the world and shared great adventures at home and abroad. A remarkable gentleman, Bob was fiercely loyal and endearingly stubborn. During WWII, Bob served as an officer aboard the USS Mansfield, a destroyer in the Pacific, and, always attuned to the finer necessities of life, snuck an ice cream maker aboard the ship. In 1955 he founded Weave Corporation, a textile design and manufacturer, and led the company through his retirement in 1994. A founder of the Pascack Valley High School District, Bob served as school board president, and vice president of the New Jersey Association of School Boards for ten years, was a passionate member of his community, always politically engaged, and was firmly committed to a range of philanthropic causes. Adoring brother of Jane Kantor and Paul Berkley (d. 1957). Devoted husband of Barbara (d. 2001), father to Alison (d. 2006), and Roger, and most loved and loving grandfather of Kate, and Daniel and Sarah. A service will be held Sunday, December 4, 10am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NY, NY. Interment Temple B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to: University Of Wisconsin Foundation, US Bank Lockbox 78807, Milwaukee, WI 53278-0807

After the wave, the author, a self-absorbed Frenchman filled with self-pity, experienced a life-changing emotion: empathy. The following excerpt is adapted from ''Lives Other Than My Own,'' which was published in September by Metropolitan Books. The night before the wave, I remember that Helene and I talked about separating. It wouldn't be complicated; we didn't live together, hadn't had a child and were even able to see ourselves remaining friends, and yet, it was sad. It was Christmas 2004. Here we were in our bungalow at the Hotel Eva Lanka, and we couldn't help remembering a different night, just after we'd met, a night we'd spent marveling that we had found each other and would never part and would grow old together, happy for the rest of our lives. We even talked about having a child, a little girl. We did have that little girl in the end, and we still trust that we'll live out our days together. But after the dazzling confidence of love at first sight came a complex, chaotic year, and what had at first seemed so certain to us (and still seems so now) no longer appeared at all certain or even desirable. Lying side by side, we couldn't bring ourselves to mention that first night. She went out on the terrace to smoke a cigarette. I waited for her, lying on the bed and thinking, If she comes back soon, if we make love, then perhaps we won't separate, perhaps we will grow old together after all. But she did not come back. She remained alone on the terrace and I fell asleep, sad, lonely, convinced that my life could get only worse and worse.

GODOWSKY--Leopold, III. Pianist, composer and teacher, Leopold Godowsky III (b. 1938) was the nephew of George and Ira Gershwin and grandson of the legendary pianist-composer, Leopold Godowsky. He studied piano with Wolfgang Rose (student of Arthur Schnabel and Walter Gieseking) and composition with Charles Shackford (student of Paul Hindemith). After graduating from Columbia College and Columbia Teachers College, Godowsky first worked in music publishing and then at Columbia Artists Management. He began concertizing in the U.S. and abroad while in his 20's. He performed the Gershwin "Concerto in F" at Alice Tully Hall on the occasion of George Gershwin's Centennial. He also taught piano privately and as a member of the faculty at Hartt College of Music. He composed chamber music for string quartet, brass quintet, wind quintet, saxophone quartet, harpsichord, and an oratorio for vocal quartet. He is survived by his immediate family, wife, Mary Milton; his daughter, Leila Listo; and sisters, Georgia Keidan, Alexis Gershwin and Nadia Natali Family will receive friends on December 12 from 5-7:30 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Leopold's memory to: Midori & Friends: 212-767-1300. www.midoriandfriends.org.

''I went with a tough, sexy look inspired by Jodie Foster and Debbie Harry,'' Kaliardos says. ''It's the idea you can go rock 'n' roll for holiday and not always be glitter-crazed.'' Leaving skin practically bare (''Just a touch of Armani Luminous Silk Foundation in the center zone of the face, minimal powder and a hint of contour under the cheekbones''), he focused on serious eyes and lips. After dabbing concealer onto lids, he used M.A.C.'s 213 fluff brush to apply Nars Lhasa, a chic gray shadow, to the top lid, and Nars Underworld Duo Eyeshadow under the lower lashes. ''Really feel your shape and bones so you get subtle contour and an emphasis on the crease of the lid,'' Kaliardos advises. He curled lashes and added a lick of inky Givenchy Phenomen'Eyes mascara. For the festive red lip, he used Nars Velvet Matte Lip Pencil in Dragon Girl. ''It's so easy to draw on and fill in,'' he says. ''Apply, and into the night you go

Packers (11-0) at Giants (6-5) Sunday, 4:15 p.m. Line: Packers by 7. Aaron Rodgers threw for 299 yards and 3 touchdowns in a winning effort a few weeks ago, but he was not satisfied with his performance. ''I didn't throw the ball very well,'' he said after the game, a 35-26 win over Tampa Bay on Nov. 20. ''I'm not trying to be ridiculously humble right now. I'm just frustrated.'' Rodgers's quotation shines a light on a major problem gripping the N.F.L.: ridiculous humility, the absurd self-denigration to which great players succumb when they avoid expressing satisfaction or joy at achieving anything short of seven straight Super Bowl championships. We have grown so used to hearing Tom Brady-types say ''we still have a lot of work to do'' after 38-20 victories that we fail to notice that it has transcended professionalism or constructive criticism, becoming a pantomime of masochistic self denial. With Rodgers at least addressing the ridiculous humility phenomenon and Charles Woodson acknowledging last month that an undefeated season is a desirable goal, the Packers now represent the vanguard of football honesty: the one team daring enough to occasionally express pride. Rodgers should throw for 400 yards against a Giants defense full of rookies and backups. He may still feel frustrated after the game. Imagine how Tom Coughlin will feel. Pick: Packers.

The couple lived and raised their family in Brooklyn and Fire Island where they still reside during the summer. One of New York City's hottest hair colorists, Frederic Fekkai's Reyad Fritas, can spin straw into gold. ''I see a lot of overprocessed, dry hair out there,'' he says. Not on his glossy girls, bien sur. ''We get their hair into amazing condition and give them color that sparkles.'' Fine examples: ''The most beautiful colors, to me, are the ones that respect a woman's natural base,'' Fritas says. ''Many women have bad color, and it's because they strayed too far from what works with their complexion.'' Uniform color is modern, he says, and he prefers warm shades to cool ones. ''I don't do her hair, but I love Vanessa Paradis's coppery cinnamon hue.'' He does do Heidi Klum's signature blond tresses. ''She's adventuresome, so it's fun to work with her.'' Freja Beha wins in the brunette stakes. ''Her color's very natural and always looks cool without being extreme.''

An article on Nov. 20 about biking in Tel Aviv misstated the official policy regarding bike riding on the street. Tel Aviv traffic laws require bicyclists to ride in the street if there are no marked bike paths, though Tel Aviv officials said the law is not enforced and cyclists are free to ride where they like. It is not the case that bicyclists are strictly forbidden to ride in the street and must share the sidewalks with pedestrians.

A duplex penthouse apartment overlooking Union Square, with an outdoor fireplace and an infinity pool on its more than 2,000 square feet of terrace space, was the biggest apartment sale of the week, at $11.5 million, according to city records. The sale reflects not only the continuing demand for ultraluxury penthouses, but also the resurgence of a building that had seen some rough early days. The three-bedroom 3,164-square-foot condominium had been under contract in spring 2008 when sales at the building, 15 Union Square West, were first announced. But the market collapsed that fall, the contract fell through, and transactions in the building stalled.

MARSHALL--Gordon. Born January 9, 1927 in Brooklyn to Belle Spiro and Max Moskowitz, died peacefully on November 29, 2011. Gordon graduated from the Bronx High School of Science; enlisted in the Navy at 17 serving in the medical corps from 1944 to 1946; earned a law degree from NYU in 1953; and is perhaps best known for the attempted development of David's Island in New Rochelle, managing Joel Harnett's 1977 NYC mayoral campaign, and service on the Business Council of Westchester Board Of Directors. His passions included theatre, public service, golf, and Yankee baseball. He is survived by brother Philip (wife Dorothy), children Claudia, Peter (wife Brenda), Andrew and Jennifer; grandchildren Jessica, David, and Jake; and fun loving nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Theatre Development Fund (tdf.org).

BONUS FEATURE | 'SELF-RELIANCE' FOR ZOMBIES, by Adam Sternbergh (with apologies to Quirk Classics Press) There is a time in every man's education when he arrive sat the conviction that envy is ignorance; that imitation is suicide; that he must take himself for better, for worse, as his portion; that though the wide universe is full of good, no kernel of nourishing corn can come to him but through his toil bestowed on that plot of ground given to him to till, and that he has suddenly developed a primal and unceasing appetite for brains.

An acquaintance at Goldman Sachs knows what he is about but worries what the outside world would make of his keeping a dinner-party journal. Actually, there are few things he takes more seriously than maintaining a log not just of his menus but also of his centerpieces, place settings (china, crystal, silver, linen), guests' food preferences and even their allergies. Not that he is trying to steal Pat Buckley's tiara or anything. ''Hostess books,'' as they're still sometimes called, may be a creaky social nicety associated with the kind of women who spent afternoons at Kenneth having their hair teased, but it's surprising how many people hang on to them out of sheer usefulness - for remembering that the paella was so dreadful it should be taken out of circulation, that the sweet peas merit a replay. It's a long way from the Bois de Boulogne and the Duchess of Windsor, but you do what you can.

MILLER--Charles D. Avery Dennison Corp. mourns the passing of Charles D. "Chuck" Miller, visionary business builder and civic leader, who died November 23, 2011 at the age of 83. In his 47-year association with Avery Dennison, Chuck was instrumental in transforming the company from a U.S.-based manufacturer into a global Fortune 500 market leader in pressure-sensitive labeling materials and office products. As chairman for 17 years and CEO for 21, he drove the company's growth with creativity, courage and confidence, and every aspect of the business -- from vision to strategy to execution to culture -- was shaped for the better by his passion and imagination. Corporate headquarters in Pasadena, California bears his name in recognition of his impact. Chuck translated the qualities that made him such an exceptional businessman into a deep commitment to civic leadership. Among the many roles he filled with distinction were: chairman of the board of the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce, director of numerous Southern California companies, chairman of United Way of Greater Los Angeles, and co-created with Peter Mullin the Mullin-Miller Million Dollar Match Fund to encourage giving to the United Way Pathways Out of Poverty Plan during the recent severe recession. He also supported a wide range of medical institutions, including Operation Walk, which provides total hip and knee replacements to the impoverished and which he personally nurtured from a local into an international organization. A lifelong lover of athletics, he was one of the first members of the organizing committee that brought the 1984 Olympic Games to Los Angeles, and helped establish the Los Angeles Sports Council and the Amateur Athletic Foundation of Los Angeles (today the LA84 Foundation). He provided extensive support to the U.S. Lacrosse and personally funded the women's varsity lacrosse program at Occidental College, which today is a national power in the sport. A deep believer in liberal arts education, Chuck was especially devoted to his alma mater, Johns Hopkins University. He served as university trustee and presidential counselor, endowing the Charles D. Miller Professorship in the humanities at the Zanvyl Krieger School of Arts and Sciences and creating the Vision Fund, a scholarship program for arts and sciences undergraduates and summer students of the Johns Hopkins Center for Talented Youth. In 1998, he received the Heritage Award in recognition of his outstanding service to Johns Hopkins. He also had a long association with Occidental College, serving as a trustee from 1977 to 1998 and continuing thereafter as a trustee emeritus. He remained an active businessman, civic leader and philanthropist after retiring from Avery Dennison. He invested in real estate and owned and operated a wine company, the noted Jackson Hole restaurant Koshu, and a highly successful stable of thoroughbred horses. At the time of his death, he was a member of the executive board of the Rose Bowl Legacy Campaign for the renovation and preservation of the Rose Bowl, a member of the advisory board of the Autry Museum of Western Heritage and a trustee of Southern California Public Radio. The company expresses its deepest condolences to his wife, Carolyn; his daughters Amanda Daly Miller, Candice Louise Miller, Katherine Ann Miller, Susie Cherrill Otten and Charlotte Juanita Miller; and his grandchildren Laura, David, Eric and John Otten, and Harper, Juliet and Zander Branch. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service is planned for December 12 at 11am at The Langham Huntington, 1401 South Oak Knoll Avenue, Pasadena, and a memorial website: CharlesDMiller.org, is now live. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to: Charles D. Miller Legacy Fund United Way of Greater Los Angeles, 1150 South Olive Street, Los Angeles, California 90015. UnitedWayLA.org and Charles D. Miller Rose Bowl Legacy Fund 505 East Colorado Blvd., Suite 201 Pasadena, CA, 91101. RoseBowlLegacy.org

The word ''sandal'' has Hellenic origins. So it makes sense that the Greek native Christina Martini chose the island of Crete for embarking on her first footwear line, Ancient Greek Sandals. ''Our idea was to make our sandals look like they were archaeological finds but with a modern twist,'' says Martini, who spent a number of years designing shoes at Balenciaga and Louis Vuitton before branching out on her own. With subtle nods to the goddesses - Persephone, Aphrodite and Athena - the sandals' vegetable-tanned leather and handmade construction will merit compliments of mythic proportions. Ancient Greek Sandals, $160-$255. Go to barneys.com.

The Mortgages column last Sunday, about applying for a mortgage with a co-borrower with poor credit, misstated the length of time that Tracy Becker, the president of a credit restoration company, suggested that borrowers should be ''hypervigilant'' about paying their bills on time to improve their credit scores. It was for at least a year, not for a few months.

An obituary last Sunday about Basil D'Oliveira, the South African cricket player, misstated Mr. D'Oliveira's age when he immigrated to England. He was in his late 20s, not ''well into his 30s.'' The obituary also misstated the first year the South African cricket team played an international match after South Africa canceled a visit by the English cricket team in 1968. It was 1991, not 1994. And it misstated the surname of the author of the book ''Basil D'Oliveira, Cricket and Conspiracy: The Untold Story.'' He is Peter Oborne, not Osborne.

A lifelong supporter of progressive causes and a proud father and grandfather, he is survived by his wife of 61 years, Bea, his daughters, Julie and Ronnie, sons-in-law Ronald and Steve and his four grandchildren: Sander, Vera, Raymond and Daniel. He will be interred at the South Florida VA National Cemetery in Lake Worth.

ROSENGARTEN--Lucille (Lucy). The officers and staff of Cohme, Inc wish to honor the vision and leadership of Lucy Rosengarten. Her compassion and unwavering dedication to helping others will be greatly missed.

BRAUFMAN--Sidney, on Monday, November 28, 2011 of leukemia. He was 89. After a successful corporate career he became a professor, most recently in the Management Department of Baruch College, where he taught courses in Business & Society in addition to Labor/Management Relations. He was also active as an arbitrator. An avid tennis player, he was still on the court the day before he entered the hospital. He was a lifelong amateur vocalist who strummed along on his guitar when his busy schedule would permit. He is survived by his devoted wife Lee, and children Jill, Brad and Mark. He was also grandfather to three adoring grandchildren, Phoebe, Sophie and Brett. He will be missed by his family, friends, students and associates, who knew him to be unfailingly just, thoughtful, thorough, and wise.

FREEDMAN--Norbert. IPTAR mourns the loss of its past president Dr. Norbert Freedman whose intellectual and psychoanalytic vigor energized our organization. Ever a force for understanding, a man of generous spirit, a teacher, researcher, mentor and friend, Bert never turned from responsibility and never tired of our work. He was a pillar of IPTAR and the international psychoanalytic community. He touched the lives of countless analysands, supervisees, candidates, students and colleagues and the loss of his intellect, wisdom, work ethic, humor and friendship will never be replaced. He lived his life with great zest, relishing the many activities and people with whom he was involved. It is hard to imagine IPTAR or our lives without him.

BUCKMAN--Thomas R.,on December 1, 2011 in New York City. Born May 3, 1923 in Reno, NV to Thomas and Jo (Damm) Buckman. Survived by his daughters Tina Buckman and Carol Buckman (Kevin Goddess) and long-time companion Lynn Carter, all of New York City and brother David Buckman (Diane) of Reno. Predeceased by wife Gunhild. WWII Navy veteran; Director of Libraries at University of Kansas and Northwestern; President of The Foundation Center 1971-91 and Engineering Information Foundation. Compassionate and generous, he loved New York City, the arts, books, travel and great restaurants. He will be deeply missed.

The 100-some dresses Patrick Demarchelier photographed for ''Dior Couture'' (Rizzoli, $115) constitute a high-gloss tribute to the venerable fashion house. But the book is also a curiously timed retrospective of Dior's fallen creative director, John Galliano, who designed the bulk of what's included here. Demarchelier dusted off frocks by Dior and his successors, Yves Saint Laurent and Marc Bohan. (Gianfranco Ferré, who was creative director from 1989 to 1996, is left out.) The foreword is by Jeff Koons -- a Dior fan, apparently -- who sees the couture pieces as ''reminiscent of a spider's web, mirroring nature.''

The Big City Book Club returned on Tuesday with a live online discussion of Truman Capote's 1958 novella, ''Breakfast at Tiffany's.'' Ginia Bellafante, the Big City columnist, debated the significance of Holly Golightly, the main character, with readers, as well as the relative merits of the book and the 1961 film adaptation starring Audrey Hepburn. The club will meet again on Jan. 10 to discuss ''A Walker in the City,'' by Alfred Kazin.

An article on Nov. 6 about the effect of the uprising in Egypt and its aftermath on tourism there misstated part of the history of the Library of Alexandria, built in the third century B.C. The library was burned during Caesar's siege in 48 B.C., though the amount of damage is unknown. It was not burned by the Romans in 30 B.C.

It was the 10th of May when a letter marked ''On Her Majesty's Service'' dropped through our letter box. I wasn't home, because, in one of life's rare strokes of serendipity, I was presiding over the selection committee for London's Newgen at the British Fashion Council, the panel that X-rays young designers for runway-worthiness. My husband thought he ought to call, anyway. ''Listen to this,'' he began, and as soon as I heard the words ''Dear madam, the prime minister has asked me to inform you . . .'' Jonathan Anderson's paisley-print pantsuit melted before me into a psychedelic fudge, ''. . . that Her Majesty may be graciously pleased to approve that you be appointed a Member of the British Empire (M.B.E.) in the 2011 Birthday Honors List.'' First thought: me? Second: my daddy, who is 90 this year, will be so happy! Third (blood draining from brain): what am I going to wear? That morning, as it happened, was 11 days since the wedding of Kate Middleton and Prince William. Like every other fashion journalist, blogger and tweeter, I had been busy entertaining myself by assessing the relative successes and hilarious faux pas of the royal wedding guests' attire. I had a number of theories about the emerging, Kate Middleton-triggered ''new formality''; the rights and wrongs of Samantha Cameron's bareheadedness in the Abbey; the Philip Treacy beige octopus on Princess Beatrice's forehead; Pippa's bottom; Carole Middleton's hosiery standards; and (oh, the agony!) David Beckham arriving with his Officer of the British Empire medal on the wrong lapel.

AMODEO--Larry, died peacefully at home on November 28. Best friend, business partner, and amateur radio operator, he will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences to his wife and his entire family. Agnes and Andy Bodony

LOTHRIDGE--Charles David, Born in Colony, NY on January 16, 1923. He was the son of Dr. William and Anna Lothridge. He attended Union College, Schenectady and joined the Army Air Force in 1943, stationed first in India as a classification and assignment officer and later in Morocco. Moving to New York City in 1946, he enrolled in the psychology department of Columbia University, receiving a PhD in 1951. He worked for American Airlines and Booze Allen and Hamilton before joining GE in 1959 where in Crotonville he designed training sessions, taught and programmed management courses. In 1972, he moved to the New York City office becoming manager of International Development and Training Programs. In 1978, served as manager for the European Area Division in Brussels. Retired in 1985, GE recalled him as international consultant. Charles moved to Bucks County, Pennsylvania in 1992 where he shared a home with longtime partner James A. McGirr. His remains will be interred in the family plot at Memory's Garden in Albany, NY.

Raquel Zimmermann's blond hair and blue eyes do not, for most people, immediately say Brazil. But the model who has been the face of brands like Lanvin, McQueen and Shiseido arrived on the fashion scene from Bom Retiro do Sul, a small town in the south of the country, where boatloads of German immigrants began arriving in the 1800s. (Zimmermann's hometown is not too far from that of Gisele Bundchen, and it's easy to imagine that the two women share a similar gene pool.) The region is so Teutonic, in fact, that her parents now live in a city called Novo Hamburgo, a Bavarian-seeming burg where many of the old buildings are made of timber. Because Zimmermann wasn't raised steeped in samba and coconut water, it came as a surprise when she suggested the Brazilian archipelago of Fernando de Noronha as the place she'd like to go to shoot resort wear. ''I figured it was probably time to start exploring my own country,'' says the lanky beauty, who has seen plenty of the rest of the world in her 13 years in front of the camera. About as close to Senegal as it is to Sao Paulo, Noronha is one of the few places on the planet that strikes the right balance between tourist destination and nature preserve, limiting visitors to about 700 a day and strictly overseeing development. It's a fact that was not lost on Zimmermann, whose obvious pride in her country and boundless curiosity - in her spare time she surfs, meditates and does yoga - was positively contagious. Over two days spent tooling around in dune buggies, the island's usual mode of transportation, she was hard to keep up with. She navigated across bumpy roads, took to the sea on a tiny fishing boat, hiked over treacherous terrain, chased after lizards, frolicked on hot, burning beaches and put away bowl after bowl of moqueca, the traditional Brazilian fish stew. And when she learned that there was a famous cave on the island called Buraco da Raquel, literally Raquel's hole, she squealed with delight: ''We have to go there!''

SCHLEIFER--Charles Baker, 99. Died November 28, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Florence Schleifer. Devoted and loving father of Dr. Lawrence M. Schleifer and Dr. Leonard S. Schleifer (Harriet), esteemed grandfather of Adam and David. Son of Jewish immigrants, raised in Brooklyn, NY, he won a scholarship to Cornell University and graduated in 1933. He survived the Great Depression as a sweater manufacturer and fought the Nazis as a codebreaker in WWII. He instilled in his children that, "education was the weapon to fight the world with." He played tennis and chess with great skill and loved fishing and pinochle. He believed that there is no wealth in life without health. Charles was a senior member of the Greatest Generation and will be dearly missed.

Prada shoes for $129 a pair, anyone? Louis Vuitton bags (real) for under $200? On an island where Brooks Brothers counts as a low-end brand, the Goodwill Embassy Boutique on Sunset Avenue stands out as a place where common people can not only shop, but also buy. Like other Goodwill stores, the one on Sunset Avenue in Palm Beach takes donations and sells them, but because of its donors -- Worth Avenue boutiques shedding last season's stock and wealthy, fashion-conscious Palm Beach residents thinning out their wardrobes -- this thrift shop is required rummaging for those with designer-label yearnings and a store-brand budget.

Lay of the Land Fernando de Noronha, 220 miles off the northeast coast of Brazil, remains one of the country's best-kept secrets, despite its cavalcade of superlatives: Unesco World Natural Heritage site, sea turtle and spinner dolphin sanctuary, Brazil's best surfing and diving, and world-class beaches that are shockingly empty. Perhaps that's because of the long list of rules? No beach construction, no condos or large hotels (only inns called pousadas), no sunscreen in certain tidal pools, no swimming with dolphins, no fishing in depths of less than 164 feet, no free lunch (daily environmental tax: about $25!). Whatever the reason, the ''Island of 'No' '' -- as locals joke -- is paradise found. Pousadas Pousada Maravilha A favorite of Brazilian celebrities, this intimate place isn't so much about the upscale bungalows as the triumphant views of the postcard-worthy Sueste Bay. BR-363, Sueste; 011-55-81-3619-0028; pousadamaravilha.com.br; bungalows from $590. Ecopousada Teju-Açu Penélope Cruz and Javier Bardem bedded down at this eco-leaning spot with 12 bungalows surrounding a jungly pool. Estrada de Alamoa, 011-55-81-3619-1277; pousadateju.com.br; doubles from $500. Pousada Triboju The huge rooms here are rich with recycled native hardwoods, and your breakfast can be served poolside. Rua Amaro Preto 133, Floresta Velha, 011-55-81-3619-1370; triboju.com.br; doubles from $600. Pousada Zé Maria Noronha's biggest personality runs this inn, where three of the bunglows and six of the standard rooms offer stunning sea views. Rua Nice Cordeiro 1; 011-55-81-3619-1258; pousadazemaria.com.br; doubles from about $490.

ROUTH--Rylee Ann, died on November 17, of cancer, at age 60. She was a graduate of Convent of the Sacred Heart, and Smith College. She began her career at Peat, Marwick, Mitchell, then joined TIAA. She moved to Charleston, SC, where she enjoyed tennis, bridge and working as a guide at Boone Hall Plantation. A duplex penthouse apartment overlooking Union Square, with an outdoor fireplace and an infinity pool on its more than 2,000 square feet of terrace space, was the biggest apartment sale of the week, at $11.5 million, according to city records. The sale reflects not only the continuing demand for ultraluxury penthouses, but also the resurgence of a building that had seen some rough early days. The three-bedroom 3,164-square-foot condominium had been under contract in spring 2008 when sales at the building, 15 Union Square West, were first announced. But the market collapsed that fall, the contract fell through, and transactions in the building stalled.

She was a designer learning the ropes at Levi's and Ralph Lauren. He was a photographer and drummer playing the Brooklyn music scene. They met after a concert, fell in love and started making clothes. Les Aperizes is Laurence Nguyen and Brian Tamborello's debut spring collection. And like their story, the couple's style is wildly romantic: preciously made petal-collar silk dresses, blouses detailed with hand-embroidered French knots and fluidly tailored trousers (all priced between $240 and $1,350). ''Before ever sketching, we like to talk about a woman as if we're writing a character and imagine what she wears throughout different times in her life,'' says Nguyen, who sees herself as the line's dreamer and Tamborello as its down-to-earth craftsman. Regarding the latter, the cut is slouchy sexy and thoughtfully undone. Tamborello says: ''We ask ourselves, 'Can we picture our clothes on every character? Will they age beautifully with her?' '' Stores like Barneys New York and Ikram in Chicago sure think so. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

DURING the height of the civil rights movement, the Old Fourth Ward neighborhood of Atlanta, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was born, lived and is buried, was a bustling hub of middle-class black life. But as Atlantans raced to the suburbs, this stretch of factories and shotgun houses east of downtown fell into decay. Now, the neighborhood is generating buzz again -- as a cradle of culinary and artistic innovation and as a symbol of gentrification, with a more racially mixed population. Named for a former voting district, the O4W (in Atlanta shorthand) is being recharged by a wave of new art galleries, nightclubs and restaurants. This summer, the area's largest building, a 2.1-million-square-foot former Sears, was sold to developers and is to be turned into an enormous mixed-use space by 2014. ROBBIE BROWN

Martin Boyce, an artist known for creating sculptural installations that pay homage to Modernist design, has won this year's prestigious Turner Prize. The winning entry from Mr. Boyce, 44, was an installation that looks like both an interior space and a municipal park, with trees crafted of geometric aluminum leaves along with a desk, based on a library table by the French modernist designer Jean Prouvé. The desk has letters scratched into its surface, as though they were the carvings of a naughty school child.
In 2010, N.H.L. enforcer Derek Boogaard signed a multimillion dollar contract with the New York Rangers. But, nobody predicted how far and how fast the Boogeyman would fall.

The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year legacy tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Year's Day 2012. This is the 21st in a series of graphite drawings that Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company's journey. This week's entry is from Champaign and Chicago.

New York City Opera announced on Monday that it was seeking the help of a federal mediator in a deadlock with the unions representing its chorus and orchestra. The company's management declared an impasse last Thursday when the two sides were unable to come to terms on new contracts. City Opera has reduced its budget by nearly two thirds and has moved out of its Lincoln Center home to save money. It is seeking to pay the chorus members and musicians for each rehearsal and performance, with reduced health benefits, while the unions want to be compensated by the week and are seeking stronger guarantees of employment.
N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman speaks with New York Times reporter John Branch on the role of fighting in hockey and the recent death of enforcer Derek Boogaard.

The photographer Stephanie Sinclair, who is known for her ability to connect with the subjects of her pictures, was able to bring even more than her usual empathy to her most recent assignment for the magazine, photographing the minimally conscious patient Chris Cox. That's because Sinclair's own mother suffered a brain injury in 2001. "When you share the experience of someone you love having a brain injury - of becoming a different person - there's an instant intimacy," Sinclair says. "My mom has recovered a lot more than Chris has, but I had to do a lot of the things they're doing."
Walmart’s Prime Time Smile kit includes a pre-treatment that claims to protect against tooth sensitivity.
How CTE could lead to dementia and other symptoms in athletes like Derek Boogaard

The guest of honor at Carolina Herrera's prefall presentation earlier today was none other than her black miniature poodle, Gaspar. "He has been here since this morning," Herrera said, "he's the star today." And the muse, apparently. Among the collection's multicolor tulle evening dresses, copper-colored sequin sheaths and the tortoiseshell-inspired metallic pencil skirts that Herrera called "lunch looks" was this: a springlike silk twill shirtdress with sweet sleeves featuring -- surprise! -- a whimsical poodle print on a royal blue ground. Fetching, indeed.

The casting director for the Hartford production of "The __________ With the Hat" said on Monday that she was not involved with the choice of two white actors to play the roles of two Puerto Rican characters in the play by Stephen Adly Guirgis, who last week went public with his concerns about that production's casting.

In its first few weeks on the air, "Rock Center With Brian Williams," the new NBC newsmagazine show, has tackled topics of major national import: starvation in Africa, cheating on standardized tests, child abuse in college football.

The Sundance Film Festival has announced its out-of-competition premieres lineup, The Carpetbagger blog reports, and the theme for this January is comedy, comedy and more comedy. Other highlights, Brooks Barnes writes: "Spike Lee makes his Sundance debut as a director. The former indie queen Parker Posey returns in a big role. Rashida Jones ("Parks and Recreation") tries her hand at screenwriting." Read more »

"I'm from that generation of artists who tries to think very hard about new sets of relationships between people and spaces and how people work with artwork," said the artist Liam Gillick, who was one of several artists in Miami's Design District this year exploring a relationship with a big fashion brand. Cross-disciplinary collaborations, often accompanied by pop-up stores, are the name of the game during Art Basel Miami Beach, with often brilliant - and on occasion, less-than-brilliant - results. This year's brilliant moments included Gillick and Pringle of Scotland; Beatriz Milhazes and Cartier; and Anselm Reyle and Dior.
Adrian Ellis, the executive director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, has told that organization's board he will step down in early January.

New Jersey's annual black bear hunt, which resumed last year after a five-year hiatus, began Monday morning and will continue until Saturday. About 6,400 people registered for this year's hunt, and based upon the 2010 success rate, officials predict that the hunters will bag around 450 bears.
Here are some fresh thoughts on the enduring and important questions surrounding  "climate sensitivity" -- how much warming will result from a substantial buildup of greenhouse gases.

Even as Judge Jed S. Rakoff of Federal District Court in Manhattan rejected the Securities and Exchange Commission's proposed settlement with Citigroup because he did not find it in the public interest, the agency's chairwoman, Mary L. Schapiro, sought to enhance the S.E.C.'s authority to impose higher financial penalties to deter securities violations.

"West of Memphis," a new documentary about the West Memphis Three murder case in Arkansas, will make its premiere out of competition at the 2012 Sundance Film Festival, the festival's organizers said on Monday. "West of Memphis" is directed by Amy Berg ("Deliver Us From Evil") and its producers include the "Lord of the Rings" director Peter Jackson, as well as Damien Echols, one of the three defendants in the case who was released from prison in August. The feature arrives on the heels of the "Paradise Lost" documentary series, produced by HBO and directed by Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofsky, that has also chronicled the case and has occasionally come into conflict with Ms. Berg's film over interview access with key figures in the case. Other out-of-competition premieres will include Stephen Frears's "Lay the Favorite," Spike Lee's "Red Hook Summer," and "Something From Nothing: The Art of Rap," a documentary directed by Ice-T. Brooks Barnes has the complete list of films at The Carpetbagger.

Spike Lee makes his Sundance debut as a director. The former indie queen Parker Posey returns in a big role. Rashida Jones ("Parks and Recreation") tries her hand at screenwriting. Comedy, comedy and more comedy.

The United States Artists, a nonprofit organization that gives annual no-strings-attached grants to artists, composers, writers and performers has announced this year's list of recipients who will receive grants of $50,000.

The new president of China's largest television network, the state-run organization known CCTV, drew fire over the weekend from Chinese press advocates and others online over comments urging journalists to drop their pretensions of professionalism and submit to being mouthpieces of the government.

When given any amount of momentum, Derrick Rose is an absolute terror. His foot speed dwarfs most opponents' neural reaction times. His ability to change directions quickly renders even the league's better individual defenders irrelevant. His adaptable arsenal of spins, dekes and crossovers can turn any man in front of him into a practice cone.

As many as 60,000 of the votes cast in New York State elections last year were voided because people unintentionally cast their ballots for more than one candidate, according to a study being released this week. The excess-voting was highest in predominantly black and Hispanic neighborhoods, including two Bronx election districts where 40 percent of the votes for governor were disqualified.

As Albany debates whether to raise taxes on the wealthy, there appears to be little conclusive evidence that the so-called millionaires' tax imposed in 2009 on individuals who make more than $200,000 drove New Yorkers out of state. The tax is scheduled to lapse on Dec. 31, but Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is negotiating revisions in the tax code with legislative leaders that would raise taxes on wealthier New Yorkers.

Stephen Starr, the Philadelphia restaurateur who also owns Buddakan and Morimoto in Manhattan, won the contract to create a restaurant in the newly renovated New-York Historical Society. The result, named Caffè Storico (Italian for "historic"), will open on Saturday.

Many ridiculous reasons have been given over the years for Saudi Arabia's de facto ban on women drivers (de facto because there is no formal law, but women cannot obtain licenses). If women drive, it's been said, they will lose their modesty and overcrowd the streets. In a sad Thelma and Louise meet Ishtar moment, it is also said that women who drive will find it easier to rebel against their husbands.

Thieves using card readers and hidden cameras stole more than $250,000 from 11 Chase A.T.M.'s near New York City's Union Square earlier this year, according to a recently unsealed indictment.

The Rangers are seeking the 2,500th victory in club history Monday night when they host the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden. They're also out for their sixth straight win, their eighth straight at home, and the 13th victory in their last 15 games over all. If they do win, they'll maintain their position as the team with the N.H.L.'s best overall winning percentage.

My article in Saturday's New York Times, "Oh, for the Good Old Days of Rude Cellphone Gabbers," stirred a vocal response among readers, many of whom decried the boorishness of cellphone users in all of its many forms in several hundred comments posted over the weekend. The piece was about people who use voice technologies like Siri in the new iPhone 4S to orally search for restaurants, dictate texts and schedule appointments while in public.

At Peggy Siegal's lunch for "The Help" on Friday, what is usually a highly managed affair went off-script, as we noted here, with Billie Jean King getting in on the act. She wasn't the only guest with something to say. Andre Leon Talley, the Vogue editor and king of pronouncements, played a lively role, commenting, from his seat, about the look of the film, set in the early 1960s, and praising the costume designer, Sharen Davis.

When the Boeing Company announced its far-reaching, precedent-setting agreement with the machinists' union last week, all the talk was about the ushering in of a new era of labor peace between a company and union that were long known for their horrendous labor relations record. That record included five strikes since 1977, among them a 58-day walkout in 2008 that cost Boeing $1.8 billion.

Jose Reyes began his Mets career with a single, batting ninth and leading off the third inning in an interleague game against the Texas Rangers on June 10, 2003. Eight years later, Reyes said goodbye with a single, too, beating out a bunt against the Cincinnati Reds in the first inning of the final game of the season, on Sept. 28, 2011.

Jim Gerritsen lives a far piece from New York City, in a remote part of northern Maine that what was once known as the Potato Empire. But there he was on Sunday - at age 56 making his first trip to the city - to speak at the Farmers March on Wall Street.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reacted cautiously but skeptically Monday to reports that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was considering raising taxes on the wealthy to help close a looming budget gap.

Monday's issue of The New Yorker contains a review of David Fincher's "The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo," more than two weeks before its release on Dec. 21. A presidential task force assigned to plot out a strategy for remediating the damage wrought to the Gulf Coast by the BP spill and other events has issued its final recommendations. A big question is how fines paid by BP and other money devoted to restoration efforts will be spent.

In a film by Tabitha Denholm, Tory Burch takes a heartfelt tour through the city she loves most. From JG Melon to the Frick and Lincoln Center, Burch's New York is all about "surprises and newness and evolution," she says. Inspiring and nostalgic, the short film makes its debut here on The Moment.

Fedoruk, 32 and now an assistant coach with the minor league Trenton Titans, engaged in more than 100 fights in his nine-year N.H.L. career. Off the ice, Fedoruk, like Boogaard, battled an addiction to prescription painkillers. He sustained a career-altering injury in a 2006 fight with Boogaard, but they later became teammates and close friends. (Questions are no longer being accepted for this feature.)

As my colleague Rachel Donadio reported, Italy's new government, hastily assembled after Silvio Berlusconi's departure, announced sweeping austerity measures Sunday night. The package of deep spending cuts and tax increases is intended, said Prime Minister Mario Monti, to "save Italy."

Dell announces the conclusion of its Android tablet experiment with the shutdown of the Dell Streak 7. The PC maker joins just about every other tech company in a distinguished list of failed and misbegotten tablet endeavors.

In a piece called "Protecting Friendships During the College Admissions Process," our college intern, Susannah Griffee, reviews the difficulties of simultaneously navigating both friendships and the college admissions process and provides practical tips for how to lessen stress and avoid tension. Students: What have your experiences been like? What suggestions do you have for how applicants can take care of their friendships? Read her post and join the conversation on our sister blog, The Choice.

As part of the Indian government's continuing efforts to rein in disparaging and defamatory content on the Internet, the telecommunications minister is meeting on Monday with top local officials from Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and Facebook to ask the companies to prescreen user content from India, the India Ink blog is reporting. The representatives from these companies are expected to tell the minister that the demand is impossible to meet given the volume of content coming from India, and that they cannot be responsible for judging that content. In addition to its efforts to force online services to control what goes up on the Internet, or over wireless connections, the government plans to set up its own unit to monitor information posted on Web sites and social media sites, India Ink reports. Read more »

With Herman Cain suspending his presidential campaign, the other campaigns are making a play for his supporters, particularly on the ground in Iowa. Much of the speculation is that Newt Gingrich stands to benefit the most as conservatives look for a viable candidate, but Cain supporters in the state say they are up for grabs.

Federal officials hope to crack down more effectively on operators of "multiple employer" health plans that have defrauded small businesses and their workers of hundreds of millions of dollars, often leaving them stuck with unpaid medical bills, according to new rules proposed Monday by the Obama administration under the health care legislation.

As I was working on my argument about political parody on "Saturday Night Live," I traveled to our nation's capital to see if the humor of our political elite was also suffering from malaise. Wednesday was the 18th annual Funniest Celebrity in Washington Contest, a benefit whose proceeds go to the Susan G. Komen for the Cure, which fights breast cancer. The evening featured a bipartisan bill of stand-up performances by politicians, journalists and lobbyists who all seem to agree on one thing: People from Washington are not funny.

For as few novels as Jane Austen published in a literary career that has long outlasted her brief 41 years, even fewer portraits of her are believed to have survived. In Monday's New York Times, Somini Sengupta reports on the Khan Academy, a program of math and science lessons developed by Salman Khan that has become a YouTube hit, attracting up to 3.5 million viewers a month. This fall, at least 36 schools across the country are using software to try out Mr. Khan's lessons in the classroom, combining traditional teaching with computer-based lessons and exercises.

Dev Anand wasn't a star. He was a philosophy. The 88-year-old actor, who died of cardiac arrest on December 4, symbolized six decades of Hindi cinema and a spirit that insisted that the show must go on. No matter that the films ceased to seduce or that viewers stopped showing up decades ago. Dev Anand continued to create and despite the mostly substandard quality of his output, he never lost his icon status or the affection of his audience and colleagues.

Tens of thousands of programmers, writers, accountants and other workers labor at home doing contract work for companies like Google, Hewlett-Packard and NBC. The computers they use contain software that takes snapshots of what they are doing six times an hour. The snooping occurs randomly, making it impossible for the computer user to game the system.

Thick smog prompts officials to cancel hundreds of flights and shut down some major highways in Beijing. The American Embassy describes current air quality there as "hazardous," and the official Xinhua news agency says the pollution is likely to reach "dangerous" levels. [Agence France-Presse]

John Thomas Financial, a brokerage firm in Manhattan, found its newest junior analyst in the most unlikely of places. Tracy Postert, an unemployed biomedical scientist, was spotted by the firm's chief market analyst while taking part in the Occupy Wall Street protests in Zuccotti Park. As far as shapes go, the Madison Mini Doctor bag from the all-American leather goods label Mark Cross is an interesting one -- extra-long strap, compact size, structured handles. It's a saddle bag (the company was established in 1845 as a source for saddles and harnesses) turned on its head. "We want all of our bags to reflect the brand's legacy and history," says the company president, Neal Fox, about its strategy and recent re-entry into the marketplace. "This one reflects an especially modern approach to classicism." At $1,495, it is a princely price to pay for timeless style. The only question is, where to wear it first, Los Angeles or Monaco?

On Monday Merce Cunningham will appear on screen in the first public showing of his final interview. It is 18 minutes long and unedited. The interview was filmed in June 2009, the month before his death. When his face first appears on screen - he was 90, had been largely confined to a wheelchair for some years, and in recent months had suffered various medical setbacks - you're aware of the depredations of age. Then he talks, and it's evident that the mind was still sharp, the interest in precise verbal articulation still alert, the passion for dance unrelenting. It is an exciting revelation of his unflagging intelligence.

Last week the parents of one of the victims asked the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to refuse to consider the film, saying it celebrated the defendants in that case. And now comes news that behind the scenes there has been friction with a second, newly announced documentary about the case, this one called "West of Memphis" and carrying the imprimatur of Peter Jackson, the "Lord of the Rings" director.
