Gaia, the ancient Greek earth goddess, is being sold to the highest bidder, but it's for a good cause. A collaboration between the Turkish home accessories company Gaia & Gino, the New York designer Harry Allen and Swarovski Elements has produced "The Goddess Adorned,"  an auction of 15 of Allen's shapely Gaia vases, which have been customized by a glittering list of celebrities in the worlds of fashion, design and style, including Ashley and Mary Kate Olsen for Elizabeth and James, Kenneth Jay Lane, Doo.Ri, Waris Ahluwalia and Allen himself. The vases will be auctioned online for two weeks starting Tuesday to benefit Housing Works, and will be on view at the Swarovski Crystallized concept store, at 499 Broadway in SoHo. The original vase, which was designed by Allen for Gaia & Gino but never produced, was always meant to be "dressed," with jewelry or ribbons, for instance. "I designed the vase to be transformed," Allen explains, citing Gaye Cevikel, Gaia & Gino's fashionable founder, as his inspiration. A number of samples of the vase were made, and Allen had the idea to auction them for charity.

We're one cord into an expected six-cord winter and starting the colder part of our year in the Maine woods off the grid with three kids and two cats from the New Jersey suburbs. It's the first time I have heated with wood, and I miss the simplicity of a thermostat connected to a furnace.

Forget that the regular-season overtime rules prevented the Cowboys from even touching the ball after regulation of a 19-13 loss at Arizona - that was merely karmic justice. Any coach that mismanages timeouts and field position as spectacularly as Dallas Coach Jason Garrett did in the final minutes deserves to lose. First, Garrett seemingly iced his own kicker by calling a timeout just before Dan Bailey's 49-yard field goal on what would have been the game's final play. (Bailey made the initial kick, but couldn't repeat it.) Analyzing timeout usage as it pertains to a kicker's rhythm is like analyzing how your day might have been different if you'd only brushed your teeth three minutes earlier. It's a fruitless practice that's all hindsight and presumption.

Newton has 13 rushing scores, breaking the N.F.L.'s single-season record for a quarterback. Rob Gronkowski scored three touchdowns in the Patriots' 31-24 victory over the Colts. He has 13 touchdown catches this year, tying Antonio Gates in 2004 and Vernon Davis in 2009 for the most by a tight end in a regular season. He originally was given three touchdown catches, which would have broken the mark, but one was changed to a lateral on which he ran 2 yards for a score.

As Current TV turns itself into a channel for liberal talk, it is turning away from its original source for news, a critically acclaimed documentary unit called ''Vanguard.'' In what was described by some as a cost-cutting move, the channel dismissed most of the staff of ''Vanguard'' last week, according to four people with knowledge of the changes. The channel will produce more ''Vanguard'' documentaries in the future, but by relying on freelance staff, the people said.

With the holiday shopping season in full swing, retailers are trying everything to get consumers into stores. Now consumers who visit any of the 27 open-air malls owned by DDR, the commercial real estate company, will be able to receive text messages offering deals from any one of the hundreds of retailers in each of those malls. The program, called ValuText, is based on a technology called geo-fencing, which allows retailers to send text messages to consumers in a specific geographic area. Placecast, the company that provides the geo-fencing technology, has worked with wireless carriers to offer the service.

Viewed as a bust after underperforming in Buffalo, Maybin has resuscitated his career with the Jets, so much so that Rex Ryan pleaded for No. 51 jerseys adorned with Maybin's nickname, Mayhem, to be sold at MetLife Stadium.

Fado, the Portuguese tradition of elegant, emotive songs filled with tragedy and longing, was named to Unesco's Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity list in late November. By happy coincidence the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music had scheduled two nights of fado that began Friday with a concert featuring the United States debut of Camané, 44, a major star in Portugal who is one of his generation's leading fado singers, or fadistas. At this concert fado's past was never far from its present. Camané performs in a genre dominated by women. Fado (which means ''fate'') was defined for decades by its greatest singer, Amália Rodrigues, who died in 1999. It was music forged in the clubs called fado houses in Lisbon, entwining Portuguese song with tinges of Arabic music and echoes of the Portuguese empire returning to that port city: from Angola, Brazil, Cape Verde and perhaps Macao. Fado became the national style of Portugal under the dictatorship that ended in 1974; although it was largely spurned during the 1970s, a younger generation embraced its musicality as the political taint receded.

ACKERMAN--Morton S. The American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra Board of Directors and Staff mourn the passing of our esteemed Board Treasurer Morton S. Ackerman. Mort was a founder of our organization along with his dear friends, Fredric Mann and Zubin Mehta. His commitment to AFIPO's mission was steadfast and he worked tirelessly to see that the IPO and its members had the financial underpinning and endowment of a world-class orchestra. His wise counsel, business acumen and involvement in AFIPO's national expansion will always be remembered. Our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Jacquelyn, sons James and Lawrence and the entire family. Zubin Mehta and Itzhak Perlman, Co-Chairmen David A. Hirsch, President Elaine Wolfensohn, Immediate Past President Lynn Syms, Past President Lauren Veronis, Chrm Exec Cmte and VP Sara Fabrikant, Charles I. Petschek, Judith Resnick, Marilyn Ziering, Richard Ziman, Vice-Presidents Suzanne K. Ponsot, Executive Director

Retailers eager for sales offered shoppers many options on the big shopping weekend. For Target, Black Friday began on Thanksgiving Thursday and occurred online as well as in stores, and for Wal-Mart, Cyber Monday expanded into Cyber Week. According to Experian Hitwise, the top 500 retailers had an increase in visits of 24 percent on Cyber Monday compared to last year. Total shopping visits in the four-day period from Friday through Monday reached 285.3 million, which averages out to 49,538 visits a minute for the top 10 retailers. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Remember when a prankster could make himself a general nuisance by calling your home phone and quickly hanging up? The equivalent of a prank call on Skype, the popular voice-over-Internet-Protocol service, can be much more than a nuisance. If you are logged in to Skype, a prankster - or thief or spy - can effectively track where you are and in some circumstances, what you do and even what you download, according to an experiment led by Keith Ross, a computer science professor at the Polytechnic Institute of New York University in Brooklyn.

It was the southwest corner, not the northwest.

INTERNATIONAL An article on Thursday about Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton's trip to Myanmar to measure the depth of the political and economic opening that the country's autocratic, military-dominated government has begun misspelled the name of a government spokesman. He is U Ye Htut, not U Yeh Tut.

Social game makers like Zynga have gotten hundreds of millions of people to play their games, but one of the big raps on FarmVille, CityVille and other Facebook time-wasters is that they're too shallow to appeal to hard-core players. A company called Rumble is part of a new wave of hard-core social games startups that are trying to change that. Founded by a group of executives from Electronic Arts, Activision and other traditional game companies, Rumble, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., says it has raised $15 million from Google's venture capital arm and Khosla Ventures.

(IFC) A PRAIRIE HOME COMPANION (2006) Robert Altman's final film, based on Garrison Keillor's long-running radio program of the same name, focuses on the folksy and none-too-fancy entertainment at the Fitzgerald Theater in St. Paul and the ordered chaos of the live performance. In the movie a Texas conglomerate takes over the show's radio station and dispatches a big shot known only as the Axeman (Tommy Lee Jones) to stop the production. The down-home show features the ribald antics of the singing cowboys Dusty and Lefty (Woody Harrelson and John C. Reilly) and the backstage dramatics of the capricious Lola Johnson (Lindsay Lohan). Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film ''a defiant celebration of imperfection, improvisation and accident.''

CIUFFREDA--Anthony R. died on Friday December 2, 2011. He was 93 years old. Born in Port Reading, NJ in 1918, he lived in Colonia, NJ since 1952. A career Chemical/ Metalurgical engineer, Mr Ciuffreda graduated Woodbridge High School class of 1936. He earned a B.S. degree in Chemical Engineering from Newark College of Engineering (NJIT, 1940); a M.S. degree in Metalurgy at Stevens Institute of Technology, and pursued Ph D research in Metal's Properties at Columbia University. Mr. Ciuffreda was first employed at the former Metal and Thermit Co. (Rahway, NJ) between 1940-1949 pursuing research into the development and application of thermit and its use in welding, shipbuilding, industry and armaments aiding the US war effort 1941-1945. Beginning in 1949 and for the next 35 years, Mr. Ciuffreda was then employed at Esso/Exxon Research and Engineering Comp. (Linden, Florham Park NJ). He retired heading their Materials Technology Division as Senior Engineering Associate in 1984. Throughout the 1950s, 60s and 1970s, Mr. Ciuffreda authored many multinational steel/materials specification studies in Europe (UK, Germany, France, Italy); in Japan, and elswhere globally. An expert in hydrogen corrosion/materials techology, he advised on the company's refineries in Peru, Libya, Saudi Arabia, and in Venezuella. His expertise extended into work in gas turbine, pressure vessel, coal gasification energy technology. A prodigeous researcher, Mr Ciuffreda served as chairman of the Metals Properties Council of ASTM; and he served on various metalurgy committies in the American Petroleum Institute for many years. The holder/co-holder of several patents, his work in metals corrosion led to progress in many anaytical areas in the refining industry ranging from plant breakdowns, to alloy development and metals treatment used world-wide to date. Possessing a formally trained bass/baritone voice, stage, solo, operatic singing was also a main part of his life. Mr. Ciuffreda performed musicals in New York and the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the 1950's. He will be remembered for lead vocals in musical productions of South Pacific, Oklahoma, and Most Happy Fella preformed by Community Players (Westfield NJ) and Showcase Players (Cedar Grove NJ) in the 1960's. As a noted church soloist in NJ, he lent his voice to performances of Handel's Messiah and the early days of the New Jersey Symphony, Newark NJ; he performed into his late 80's.

Gelb and his wife Jessica Siegel Gelb, Noah L. Gelb and his wife Wanyi Chow and Nathanial L. Gelb. Adored great grandfather of Maya, Madalyn and Ruben Gelb. Dear uncle of Michael Gelb and Peter Gelb. Gelb and Gail Kleven Gelb following the interment on Monday and on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm and also at the home of Alan L. Gelb and Karen Levine on Tuesday and Wednesday beginning at 5:30pm. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy in his memory may be made to the Cohen Hillel Academy, 6 Community Rd., Marblehead, MA 01945 or to Doctors without Borders, P.O. Box 5030, Hagerstown, MD 21741-5030.

Cuomo on how to restructure Brooklyn's failing hospitals misstated the name of a hospital where it was recommended that medical beds from the State University of New York-Downstate be moved. SINCLAIR--William Alan, died peacefully on December 3 at sunrise, after a courageous battle against cancer, at the too-young age of 60. Beloved husband of Susan Sinclair, devoted, one-of-a-kind father to daughter, Alex and son, Michael, and dear brother to Naomi Norman. Cherished son of Judith and Albert Schwartz (both deceased). Bill will be remembered for his quirky sense of humor, devotion to all things good and pure, his love of sports, the ocean, yoga. Memorial service to be held on Wednesday, December 7 at 6pm, Fairchild Sons, Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Research.

KAHR--Stephen Christopher, age 69, died suddenly at his home in Ajijic, Mexico, where he and his wife Patricia Kahr, have spent the winters since their retirement. "Chris" was born in New York City to Carolyn Burpee and Arthur Kahr. He practiced law in New York City for over 30 years. The couple lived and raised their family in Brooklyn and Fire Island where they still reside during the summer. In addition to his wife, a psychotherapist now teaching English to Mexicans in Ajijic, Chris is survived by their two sons, David Ivan and Adam Paul, his granddaughter Anina, and sister Dale Moses. Donations in Chris' memory may be sent to the Cruz Roja in Ajijic: www.cruzroja.com

SAUL--Franklin Robert. The Trustees and staff of The Children's Aid Society of New York mourn the passing of retired Board member Frank Saul. He served as Treasurer for twenty-five years through 2002 and was admired and respected by all. His formidable presence and expertise guided CAS through a time of exceptional growth. Frank was a generous and steadfast supporter of our work and was committed to helping underserved children and families. He will be missed by all who knew him. Mark M. Edmiston, Chairman Richard R. Buery, Jr., President and CEO

Bookstore owners everywhere have a lurking suspicion: that the customers who type into their smartphones while browsing in the store, and then leave, are planning to buy the books online later - probably at a steep discount from the bookstores' archrival, Amazon.com. Now a survey has confirmed that the practice, known among booksellers as showrooming, is not a figment of their imaginations. According to the survey, conducted in October by the Codex Group, a book market research and consulting company, 24 percent of people who said they had bought books from an online retailer in the last month also said they had seen the book in a brick-and-mortar bookstore first.

It was a weekend of Thanksgiving leftovers at the multiplex. With no new broad-audience movies arriving in theaters, ''The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn -- Part 1'' (Summit Entertainment) repeated as the No. 1 picture in North America for the third weekend, taking in an estimated $16.9 million for a new total of $247.3 million. ''The Muppets'' (Walt Disney) was second with about $11.2 million in ticket sales, bringing its two-week total to $56.1 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. ''Hugo,'' Martin Scorsese's 3-D family film, expanded into more theaters and placed third, taking in about $7.6 million for Paramount Pictures, lifting its two-week total to $25.2 million. The animated ''Arthur Christmas'' (Sony Pictures Entertainment) continued to disappoint in fourth place, selling about $7.4 million in tickets for a two-week total of $25.3 million. ''Happy Feet Two'' (Warner Brothers) chugged along in fifth place, taking in an estimated $6 million for a three-week total of $51.8 million.

In his 1979 book about America's first generation of astronauts, Tom Wolfe spoke of the quality they most prized, ''an uncritical willingness to face danger.'' They called it the right stuff, a phrase that became the book's title. The highest-flying heroes of the 1960s saw the right stuff in a seemingly unlikely man, Jim Rathmann, who owned a Chevy dealership near Cape Canaveral and who returned their admiration, leasing to them for very little money his muscular Corvettes.

George McGovern's impact on food policy could have been greater, but not through more effort on his part. The 1972 presidential candidate, now 89, was a bomber pilot at the end of World War II when the decision was made to distribute remaining medicine and food to Europeans before heading home. "We were feeding our former enemies two days after bombing them," he told me over breakfast last week, two days before falling and being hospitalized. "It was an unprecedented gesture of good will."

Marine stoicism is no longer expected from the kindergartners at schools on the Marine base at Camp Lejeune, N.C., who are waiting for Dad or Mom (women make up 11 percent of forces serving in Iraq and Afghanistan, and 40 percent of them have children) to come home. Instead, an impressive array of high-quality support services are available for children with parents at war. How much can any club or counseling do to help a child manage the hopes and fears and confusion that come with watching a parent get on that plane, or come home injured or changed (or not at all)? Maybe not much, but the military is trying. In 2008-9, it spent $6 million to train 420 school counselors and psychologists in methods for helping children affected by parents serving in wartime. Michael Winerip's recent article in The Times, "Lessons in Coping for Children of Deployed," is a reminder that not all sacrifices come from our troops.

We investigated complaints of brutal hate crimes in neighborhoods, vandalism at places of worship, bullying at schools, and discrimination in the workplace aimed primarily at those who traced their origins to South Asia and the Middle East, or those who practiced Islam, Sikhism and Hinduism.

Overview | What happened on Dec. 7, 1941? Why is the attack on Pearl Harbor such a historically important event? In this lesson, students learn about the 1941 attack by reading an archival Times article from the day after, and then either create a series of Twitter posts that document the attack and resulting declaration of war, or write a "Historic Headlines"-style summary and analysis of the event and its repercussions - and their connection to today.

The Toronto Raptors were a truly unfortunate team last season, plagued by performance deficiencies in virtually every facet of the game. Their league-worst defense turned the Air Canada Centre into a sanctuary for visiting teams, and the Raps' offense was only slightly less hospitable. Overall, Toronto managed the fifth-worst efficiency differential in the entire N.B.A. last year, a mark truly representative of their failings in some of the game's most crucial areas.

Whether it is because of its unusual triangular footprint or the fact that a sumptuous Yohji Yamamoto boutique occupied it previously, the new Marni space at 1 Gansevoort Street, (646) 532-6015, empty for many months, seemed destined for a special tenant. Indeed, Consuelo Castiglioni's quirky Marni Edition designs for women and men, as well as her children's collection, have enlivened the space and a sleepy stretch of the meatpacking district. Though there are Marni outposts in SoHo and on the Upper East Side, this is the first United States location for Marni Edition, a slightly less expensive line with prices that may still keep us waiting for Ms. Castiglioni's H&M debut in March.

The New York City Opera, which is moving out of Lincoln Center, said on Tuesday that it had found office space in Lower Manhattan. The company said it would move its administrative operation to 75 Broad Street on Dec. 16, taking residence in temporary quarters there before occupying 14,000 square feet of renovated space in March or April. The company is also renting 4,000 square feet of storage space in the building, partly for its archives.

Last month, Milwaukee introduced two public service announcements intended to stop parents and caregivers from bringing infants into their beds. In the wake of nine infant deaths associated with an "unsafe sleep environment" in 2011 (including one discovered on the day the new campaign was announced), two ads went up citywide on buses and billboards, each showing a young baby (one white, one black) asleep in an adult bed amid much soft bedding, with a butcher knife tucked in alongside. "Your baby sleeping with you can be just as dangerous," the ads say.

Change was never my friend, especially unscheduled change, a change that brought unexpected sadness, a sense of failure and an empty freedom.

Remember what we said about printed shoes this season? Now from Suno, the out-of-Africa label designed by Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty, come five pairs of supercolorful, print-happy sneakers. "By doing this we can further our company's mission to create jobs within Kenya, and by using excess fabric from past productions we can make darn cute shoes at a really attractive price," Osterweis says. Darn cute is right. These classic slip-ons and lace-ups not only have names like "clustered caviar" and "bandana flower," but their soles are made from recycled rubber, too. "And we're helping baby elephants," adds Beatty, noting that a portion of all of the shoes' proceeds will go to the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust in Kenya. Here's to walking the walk.

As the final installment in the story of the life and death of the hockey enforcer Derek Boogaard by The Times's John Branch rolls out Tuesday, the waiting begins. Waiting to see if the sport reacts to something that has laid out the devastating effects of fighting in painful detail. Waiting to see if fans will continue to cheer fights, knowing they are likely trading those players' brains for their entertainment. Waiting to see if pundits can still manage to proffer the absurd arguments about the violence preventing more violence.

The Bagger's colleagues Nicholas Kulish and Michael Cieply took a look at the production of "Cloud Atlas," the unusual globe-trotting film project that may also be remaking how movies are financed. Describing it as an "epic independent film" too risky for one Hollywood studio to underwrite altogether, they explain that much of the financing comes from China, Korea and Singapore. And they add, "In many ways, the producers are drawing a blueprint for a new era of genuinely international filmmaking." Read more »

In something of a trend, graphic designers are working more closely with the scientific community as it reaches out to be better understood by people both outside and within its ranks. Simon C. Page, a London-based graphic designer, is the latest example of what I like to call a sci-graphiste. Page, who has a degree in applied mathematics, has designed a series of 10 posters for the International Year of Chemistry. Not only does the subject resonate with him, Page says, but it's also "a bonus" that his work is "helping an industry which is struggling to be heard."

One crucial thing you need to understand about political journalists is that with some honorable exceptions, they don't know or care about actual policy. In a way, that makes sense -- the skills needed to cultivate contacts, to get the inside scoop on what's going on in Congressional scheming or campaign war rooms, are very different from the skills needed to interpret CBO spreadsheets. The problem, however, is that all too often political journalists mistake the theater of policy for reality (or don't care about the difference).

An independent panel said on Tuesday that Olympus had engaged in a scheme to cover up investment losses and it called the company's management "rotten to the core," Hiroko Tabuchi of The New York Times writes. If any premiere had the cinematic sweep and heft - and orchestration - of a John Williams score, it would have to be "War Horse" at Lincoln Center. The soundtrack was just one reason that the world premiere of "War Horse," Steven Spielberg's adaptation of the children's book-turned-theatrical hit felt grand.

The pop-up phenomenon may be old news in retail and restaurants, but temporary hotels is a concept just gaining ground (makeshift bedrooms in Kreuzberg or Nakameguro art galleries excepted). Today the Berlin-based Design Hotels group is staking the first big claim to the trend on the beach in Tulum, Mexico. The company's founder, Claus Sendlinger, who moved with his family to Tulum last year, is spearheading the opening of Papaya Playa, a spiffed-up campus of cabanas once belonging to three now-shuttered resorts on about a half mile of beachfront land.

The production of "Cloud Atlas," a film version of the David Mitchell novel that has a $100 million budget, is an example of how sophisticated filmmakers "are turning to a globe-straddling independent finance system for their most expensive projects," rather than American studios, Nicholas Kulish and Michael Cieply report. The talent connected to the project includes Andy and Lana Wachowski, the American-born team behind the "Matrix" movies, and Tom Hanks and Halle Berry. But investors from China, South Korea, Singapore and beyond contributed roughly $35 million, without which the film could not have been made. German subsidies account for $18 million more.

GRANAT--Virginia Dammann, died peacefully last Friday at 100 years old in her Stamford home surrounded by her daughter Susan Weil of Stamford and her son Robert Granat of San Diego. Born March 18, 1911 and raised in New York City, Mrs. Granat graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Vassar College in 1933.

LONDON - When Eventbrite, a San Francisco-based start-up that sells tickets online, decided to open its first international office, the founders turned to the East End of London. The British capital offered a thriving music and theater scene, a large work force of young, multilingual college graduates and easy access to both the Asian and North American markets. In October, the technology company moved into a converted jewelry workshop in Saffron Hill, a district that was notorious for crime in the 19th century and inspired Fagin's Den in ''Oliver Twist.''

Andrew M. Kramer, a lawyer who handled dozens of labor disputes for major corporations and helped old-line manufacturers figure out how to cope with crushing health care costs for retirees, died on Nov. 21 at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 67. The cause was cancer, said his law firm, Jones Day. .

DALLAS - Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman, in an effort to illustrate why he is not optimistic about trading for a good starting pitcher at the winter meetings, provided insight into the kind of dialogue he is having with other general managers. ''It's, 'Hey, take my older, expensive, over-the-hill guy for your young, better-performing guy,' '' Cashman said before adding his response to such proposals. '' 'Let me think about that and get back to you, buddy.' ''

COOPER--Rita Streich, died on December 2 at the age of 93. She was a native New Yorker taking in all of what the City had to offer; museums, theater, opera and dance. She was a Zionist who went to Palestine in the late 1930's coming back to the States during WWII but returning to Israel many times. She went to Hunter College and Bank Street College and worked in early childhood education. She ran the UN's World Organization of Early Education for many years during her retirement. She is predeceased by her partner, Stanley Rappeport, and brother Dr. Norman Cooper. She is survived by sister-in-law, Evelyn Cooper, nephew Jonathan and Dorota Cooper and cousin Beth Lawrence plus many loving cousins. We will miss her smile and her slow and steady pace.

A Hong Kong television station has been fined $38,600 for inaccurately reporting the death of Jiang Zemin, 85, a former top Chinese leader, according to a statement Monday by the Hong Kong Broadcasting Authority. The station, Asia Television Limited, known as ATV, reported on July 6 that Mr. Jiang had died. Several people with ties to China's top leaders have since said that Mr. Jiang fell seriously ill during that time and was hospitalized, but did not die. The broadcasting authority cited the station for inaccurate news reporting, ''late correction of factual errors,'' and for taking ''an irresponsible approach'' to the inquiry.

SPORTS Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Syracuse University's handling of the sexual abuse allegations against the men's basketball assistant coach Bernie Fine misstated the year a telephone conversation between Bobby Davis, one of three men who say they were abused by Fine, and Fine's wife, Laurie, took place and was recorded. It was 2002, not 2003.

GALLEON-INSPIRED BOOK Turney Duff, a former trader at the Galleon Group, has signed with Crown Business, a division of Random House, to write a memoir about his career on Wall Street and time spent working for Raj Rajaratnam, the head of Galleon who was found guilty of insider trading and entered prison on Monday. Mr. Duff is writing ''The Buy Side,'' which Crown describes as ''a journey through the trading underworld as well as a look at after-hours Wall Street.'' The deal is said to be worth more than $250,000, according to a report in PublishersMarketplace. PETER LATTMAN

South Korea said Monday that it would resume sending aid to North Korea through Unicef, the United Nations children's agency, which it had halted more than a year ago amid tensions over the sinking of a South Korean warship. The government said it would send $5.7 million for medicine, vaccines and nutritional supplements for malnourished North Korean children. The announcement followed appeals from United Nations and aid groups.

David Denby, rule breaker? That is exactly what the folks at Sony are saying about that film critic at The New Yorker. As the Bagger's pal Anne Thompson reports at Indiewire, Mr. Denby broke an industry embargo by publishing his review of David Fincher's ''Girl With the Dragon Tattoo'' in this week's issue of The New Yorker. Other critics had agreed not to write about it until closer to the movie's much-awaited Dec. 21 release date. At 2 a.m. on Sunday Sony sent critics a missive begging them to stick to the terms set by the studio and singling out Mr. Denby for his apparent violation; Scott Rudin, the bigwig producer of ''Dragon Tattoo,'' followed up by sending Mr. Denby a tersely worded e-mail. (Digital communication means less phone-throwing.) While the rest of us were having brunch and doing laundry, Mr. Denby then politely responded to explain himself. You can read the entire back-and-forth here.

Having been burned by artists who proved too controversial, the National Football League has chosen a halftime performer for Super Bowl XLVI with a nice, safe, biblically inspired name. Well, not exactly. Madonna, the singer and multi-hyphenate whose resume includes such albums as ''Like a Virgin,'' ''Erotica'' and ''Hard Candy,'' the documentary ''Truth or Dare'' and a coffee-table photography book modestly (for her) titled ''Sex,'' will perform at the halftime show of the Super Bowl, which will be on Feb. 5 at the Lucas Oil Stadium in Indianapolis. The announcement was made during NBC's ''Sunday Night Football'' broadcast of a game between the Detroit Lions and the New Orleans Saints, confirming reports that emerged in October that the N.F.L. was in discussions with Madonna.
VIDEO ''The Role of Youth.'' The filmmaker Matt Wolf and the writer Jon Savage reflect on the history of youth in times of crisis. www.nytimes.com/opinion

W hat's next? If we had a supercomputer that could predict the future, we would tell you. Then again, if the past is any guide, the predictions would certainly be wrong. This special issue takes a many-faceted look at a set of technologies that are changing the world in more ways than could ever have been foreseen. Some things are clear already: The world of innovation is undergoing tectonic shifts, and the future is likely to look less like Silicon Valley, more like China and Africa. Beyond that? As Theodor Holm Nelson points out in the essay that concludes this issue, we are definitely headed somewhere: ''A wall? A cliff? A new dawn? We must choose wisely, as if we could.''

Those who complain that the Christmas season starts earlier and earlier each year might find solace in hearing how Filipinos traditionally celebrate the season - theirs can stretch from as early as September to late January. ''We have the longest Christmas season, and we go all-out,'' said Aurora Aquino, a Filipino-born fashion designer. ''Christmas is a very big deal for Filipinos.''

HSU--Samuel, a concert pianist and professor of music at Philadelphia Biblical University, was struck and killed by a car on the morning of December 1. Professor Hsu, 64, completed his Ph.D. in historical musicology at the University of California at Santa Barbara in 1972 with a dissertation on Debussy. In 2003 Hsu's book "Claude Debussy As I Knew Him" and Other Writings by Arthur Hartmann was published by the University of Rochester Press. The book was hailed by the London Times Literary Supplement as "intriguing and meticulously produced" and has been reissued in paperback. Hsu, born in Shanghai, received his early training in piano at the Shanghai Conservatory as one of twenty prodigies chosen from hundreds for a pilot prodigy class. At 17 he made his debut with the Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra. In the United States he studied with Rosina Lhevinne at the Juilliard School. He was her last full-time student. Hsu performed for twenty years with the distinguished violinist Xiao-Fu Zhou in hundreds of highly acclaimed recitals throughout the world. Professor Hsu is survived by his brothers Timothy and Andrew Hui.

WAITH--Eldridge Eddie, born January 13, 1918 in New York City, died on December 3, 2011. He joined the New York City Police Department in 1942 and went on to serve 30 years. Waith served every rank up to and including Assistant Chief Inspector. He then went on to serve as Commissioner of Public Safety in the U.S. Virgin Islands. He is survived by his wife Elsie Waith, children: Mariann and Linda, grandchildren: Nicholas and Matthew, sister Gloria and other relatives and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church, 2860 Webb Ave, Bronx, NY 10468. Mass on Wednesday at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church at 10am and burial at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY.

-As many as 60,000 of the votes cast in New York State elections last year were voided because people unintentionally cast their ballots for more than one candidate, according to a study being released this week. The excess-voting was highest in predominantly black and Hispanic neighborhoods, including two Bronx election districts where 40 percent of the votes for governor were disqualified. -The study, by the Brennan Center for Justice at the New York University Law School, blamed software used with new electronic optical-scan voting machines as well as ambiguous instructions for disenfranchising tens of thousands of voters. The old mechanical lever-operated machines did not allow votes for more than one candidate for the same office.

He is a sophomore, not a freshman. (The headline also erroneously referred to him as one of two ''freshmen'' who played a key role in the win.)

Adrian Ellis, the executive director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, has told that organization's board he will step down in early January. ''I'm coming up on five years,'' he said in an interview. ''I've had an absolute blast. Maybe I'm sort of restless.''

Martin, her mother and two sisters, A funeral service will be held on Saturday, December 10th at 2.00pm in St. Augustine's Church in Croton-on-Hudson. JAMISON--Herbert L.,Jr died peacefully in his sleep after a long illness at Greenwich Hospital on December 2, 2011. Born November 18, 1924 in NYC, Bert spent most of his life in Rye, NY and Vero Beach, FL. A graduate of Edgemont School, Scarsdale and Stony Brook School at Stony Brook, Long Island Bert received his M.B.A. degree in insurance from the graduate division of Wharton School of Finance at the University of Pennsylvania, where he was president of the M.B.A. club. After serving as an officer in the Navel Reserves in the South Pacific during World War II, he completed his studies at Wesleyan University receiving an honors degree in economics in 1947. In 1949 Bert joined Herbert L. Jamison & Co, the insurance brokerage founded by his father in 1938 spearheading the company's group and pension divisions. He went on to receive his Chartered Life Underwriter designation (1952) and in 1960 took over as Managing Partner of the firm. After developing the company into one of the largest and most respected independent insurance brokerages in the industry, Bert retired in 1992. Outside of work he volunteered his time and talents to a wide array of organizations. A "Life Member" of the American Yacht Club in Rye, Bert served as Commodore and Trustee while compiling an extensive successful competitive sailing record. While in office he instituted a 'more dynamic approach' to better serve the membership and improved budget controls that are still in place. Bert served as governor and was president of The Union League Club of New York City; he was a Director of the National Association of Insurance Brokers and a Governor of The Apawamis Club in Rye. Bert taught Sunday school at the Rye Presbyterian Church and later served as Deacon and Trustee. In 1977 Bert was unanimously appointed to fill a post on the Rye City Council and served on the Planning Commission, Board of Assessment Review, Retirement Plan Study Committee and Campaign Finance Chairman. Bert was a founding member of the Rye Arts Center and served with the Rye United Fund. He was a trustee for ten years and head of the insurance committee at The Osborn Rye, NY. Bert belonged to The Moorings Club, Vero Beach, FL and was a former member of the Riomar Country Club in Vero Beach, FL, and the New York Yacht Club in NYC. An avid sailor all his life, Bert enjoyed tennis, paddle tennis, swimming and golf In addition to Cristine Walker Jamison, his loving wife of 64 years, Bert is survived by sons Herbert L. III, wife Barbara and Mark R., wife Beth, grandchildren Jessica, Lauren, Jeffrey, Cristy and Walker, step grandson Kyle Ranson, sister Grace Wellever, brother Richard and (pre-deceased) by sister Eileen Reynolds. Bert was a role model to his family and enjoyed socializing with his friends. He will be missed by all. A Memorial service will be held at the Rye Presbyterian Church Wednesday, December 14, 2011, 1pm. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Rye Presbyterian Church, 880 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY.

''West of Memphis,'' a new documentary about the West Memphis Three murder case in Arkansas, will make its premiere out of competition at the 2012 Sundance Film Festival, the festival's organizers said on Monday. ''West of Memphis'' is directed by Amy Berg (''Deliver Us From Evil''). Its producers include the ''Lord of the Rings'' director Peter Jackson, as well as Damien Echols, one of the three defendants, who were teenagers in 1994 when they were convicted of killing three 8-year-old boys in West Memphis, Ark. The three defendants were released from prison in August. The feature arrives on the heels of the ''Paradise Lost'' documentary series, produced by HBO and directed by Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofsky, that has also chronicled the case and has occasionally come into conflict with Ms. Berg's film over interview access with key figures in the case. Other out-of-competition premieres will include Stephen Frears's ''Lay the Favorite,'' Spike Lee's ''Red Hook Summer'' and ''Something From Nothing: The Art of Rap,'' a documentary directed by Ice-T.

11:25 p.m. | Updated On Monday, Mitt Romney embraced one of President Obama's signature proposals - another one-year extension of a cut in payroll taxes, after just weeks ago deriding the idea as ''little Band-Aids'' that offered only a temporary fix. ''I would like to see the payroll tax cut extended just because I know that working families are really feeling the pinch right now - middle-class Americans are having a hard time,'' Mr. Romney said Monday on Michael Medved's conservative radio talk show.

The film critic David Denby reportedly broke an industry embargo by publishing his review of David Fincher's ''Girl With the Dragon Tattoo'' in this week's issue of The New Yorker, and Sony, the studio releasing the film, is not happy. Other critics had agreed not to write about the film until closer to its Dec. 21 release date. At 2 a.m. on Sunday, Sony sent critics a message reminding them to stick to the terms the studio set and singling out Mr. Denby; Scott Rudin, the producer of ''Dragon Tattoo,'' followed up by sending Mr. Denby a terse e-mail. In Mr. Rudin's view Sony feared that Mr. Denby's early review would force other publications to publish their critiques too far in advance of the movie's opening, and Mr. Denby broke his word to the studio. According to a transcript of the e-mail exchange online at IndieWire, Mr. Denby said his early review had less to do with any code of conduct than with the year-end pileup of quality movies, and The New Yorker's abbreviated production schedule. He liked the movie, calling it a ''bleak but mesmerizing piece of filmmaking.'' That the review is positive is immaterial, Mr. Rudin said, adding that Mr. Denby would be disinvited to advance screenings of any of his movies, including another long-awaited title, ''Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close.''

NEW YORK An article on Saturday about comments that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made about two of the most sensitive issues in New York City education -- class size and teachers' salaries -- misstated the given name of the president of the United Federation of Teachers. Martin Boyce, an artist known for creating sculptural installations that pay homage to Modernist design, has won this year's prestigious Turner Prize. The winning entry from Mr. Boyce, 44, was an installation that looks like both an interior space and a municipal park, with trees crafted of geometric aluminum leaves along with a desk, based on a library table by the French modernist designer Jean Prouve. The desk has letters scratched into its surface, as though they were the carvings of a naughty school child. Mr. Boyce beat out the installation sculptor Karla Black, the video artist Hilary Lloyd and the painter George Shaw. The five-person jury, led by Penelope Curtis, director of Tate Britain, said ''his work uses his knowledge of historic design to create distinctive sculptural installations.'' The prize, which was established in 1984 and named after the 19th-century landscape painter J.M.W. Turner, is given annually to a British artist under 50 for an outstanding exhibition or other presentation of their work in the 12 months before April 4, 2011. The winner gets £25,000 (about $39,000). Previous winners have included Damien Hirst, Grayson Perry and Mark Wallinger.

Leon Cooperman, a 68-year-old Wall Street veteran, says he is for higher taxes on the wealthy. He'd happily give up his Social Security checks. He voted for Al Gore in 2000. He says the special treatment of investment gains, or so-called carried interest, for private equity and hedge fund managers is ''ridiculous.'' He says he even sympathizes, at least to some extent, with the Occupy Wall Street protesters. And yet, Mr. Cooperman, a man with a rags-to-riches background who worked at Goldman Sachs for more than 25 years in the 1970s and 1980s before starting his own hedge fund, Omega Advisors, which has minted him an estimated $1.8 billion fortune, is waging a campaign against President Obama.

SPORTS Because of an editing error, the Sports of The Times column on Monday, about Stephon Marbury's success playing in the Chinese Basketball Association, misspelled the name of the Chinese team of another former N.B.A. player, Aaron Brooks. It is Guangdong, not Guandong.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Dec. 4, 2010, about Ron Santo, a star third baseman of the Chicago Cubs and their longtime broadcaster, gave an incorrect date for his death. He died last year on Dec. 3 -- not on Dec. 2, the date widely reported at the time. (The Times discovered the error on Monday after it was announced that Santo had been elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame. Coverage of his selection is on Page B14.)

HERTZ--Martin J. Died December 4, 2011 at age 83. Beloved husband of Judith, adored father to Mindy and his Pakistani son Arif, cherished grandfather of Daniel and David Keltz, dear brother of Leona. His love of life was boundless. He practiced law for more than 50 years, and it is hard to say what brought him more joy-ideas or helping people. He loved drama and poetry, and could recite both at great length, particularly Shakespeare and Lewis Carroll. He was athletic, a talented gardener, and had a sweet tenor voice. He was a tirelessly active leader in the Jewish community. He will be sorely missed by family, friends and the many he touched. Services 10am December 6, Central Synagogue 55th and Lexington.

Crash of Stealth C.I.A. Drone in Iran Reveals Secret U.S. Surveillance Effort | The C.I.A. RQ-170 drone that crashed in Iran last week has blown the cover off of one of the United States' most secret intelligence-collection efforts against the country. While American and Iranian officials dispute the cause of the drone's demise -- Iranian officials say the military hacked into the drone's control systems, Americans say the drone malfunctioned -- an essential question remains: What will happen with the centerpiece of a once covert program, now that the aircraft is in Iran's hands? Scott Shane and David E. Sanger report that the United States considered it too risky to retrieve or destroy the drone, which leaves open the possibilities that Iran could reverse-engineer the drone's technology, or turn the aircraft over to China or Russia. You can read the full report here.

For most every year since 1964, Pirelli, the Italian tire maker, has bankrolled a very unusual, very expensive promotional calendar. It typically involves a coterie of the world's hottest models jetting to an exquisitely remote clime - the Seychelles, say, or Botswana - to be photographed, nude, by an elite fashion photographer. The calendar began inauspiciously as a pinup that grease monkeys would post at continental service stations. But just like in the case of Michelin's influential guidebook, it took on a life of its own and now its connection to motoring seems completely incidental. (One must give props to all these European tire makers for their enduring contributions to world culture; the best thing our own Goodyear has come up with so far is a blimp.)

Mother Mary Magdalene had a dilemma. She had started a new Anglican Catholic order, the Community of Compassion, in Fort Worth, and she needed something for her and her Sisters to wear. "You can't just go to the store and buy a habit," she says. "Every order has to have a distinct one designed by the foundress, and you're not supposed to copy anyone else." Not only that, Mother Mary explained, but many old habits - many of them gorgeous - have been forgotten altogether as the order who wore them has died out. "There are no patterns, no documentation. It's really sad."

Of course you knew that kids have tantrums. But you probably didn't know that kids who have tantrums mostly have them in a neat, predictable pattern. Michael Potegal, a neurology professor, teamed up with James Green, a developmental psychologist, to look not at what causes tantrums but at how they work. They found three standard phases (video documented on NPR's Shots blog). Phase 1: yelling and screaming. Phase 2: physical actions. Phase 3: crying and whining.

Azzedine Alaïa has never obeyed the fashion calendar and shows only when he - and his clothes - are good and ready. In fact, in recent years, the designer, who is now in his 70s, has probably had as many runway presentations as museum exhibitions, including the one that opens this weekend at the Groninger Museum in the Netherlands. "Azzedine Alaïa in the 21st Century" focuses solely on his output from roughly the past decade, and yet there is more substance there than many designers could ever hope to achieve in a lifetime, including the fierce tailcoat above and a toothsome evening dress with a zipper that spirals suggestively around the body from the neck to the floor. Always the perfectionist in the pursuit of beauty (he's often referred to as a "sculptor of women's bodies"), Alaïa apparently recut or totally remade many of the pieces in the show to the exact proportions of the mannequins. In an open love letter to the designer, Mark Wilson, who curated the exhibition, writes, "I'm sure that certain people may wonder why we are doing this one more time?" referring to a massive Alaïa exhibition at the Groninger Museum back in in 1997-98. Wilson promptly answers his own question: "Because you are the last great couturier working today."

The members of the electronic dance music group Underworld have been named the musical directors for the opening ceremony of the 2012 Olympics in London, organizers announced on Wednesday. The duo, Rick Smith and Karl Hyde, will work alongside the artistic director, the British filmmaker Danny Boyle, to produce the music for the three-hour performance on July 27. It is not the first time Mr. Boyle has chosen Mr. Smith and Mr. Hyde to provide the soundtrack for one of his projects. The group is perhaps best known for its dance track "Born Slippy," which first appeared in a scene from Mr. Boyle's 1996 film "Trainspotting." Since then, they have created music for four other projects by Mr. Boyle, including a National Theater production of "Frankenstein" that received high praise from critics. Mr. Boyle said the hiring of Underworld to write music for the Games was "the last piece of the jigsaw puzzle" and praised the duo's creative range. Mr. Hyde said the chance to compose for the Olympics was a great honor. "We want to leave people with a musical memory of the show rather than a purely visual one," he said in a statement.

At first glance it's hard to find a common thread running through Valentino's spring capsule collection, Timestrings. The studded peep-toe booties, satin flats, polka-dot platforms and bow-embellished kitten heels carry many of the brand's signatures, but share none of them collectively. What all of the shoes do share is a handwritten time stamp - a numerical record of the amount of time it took to make each pair. For example, the sequence etched into a pair of silver chain wedge heels is 47.41'50", denoting 47 hours, 41 minutes and 50 seconds. "When we talk about luxury and time, it's clear that there's a strong connection between the two," says Maria Grazia Chiuri, one of the house's two co-designers. "Time is the new luxury, and luxury does not exist without time and the consciousness of a unique tradition." Classic Italian craftsmanship still exists (Valentino is known for its old Florentine factories), but in an age of fast everything it's easy to forget our Old World cobblers: the one devoted to flowers, the one who specializes in crystals and another with expertise in lace, for example. Pierpaolo Piccioli, Chiuri's design partner, adds, "It's nice to know that you're buying a kind of cultural process." Milled plexiglass and velvet wedges marked 38H? At $1,295, that's $34 an hour, if you break it down. And yes, it's worth it.

Participatory art, as it turns out, is not all fun and games. The New Museum, whose exhibition of the work of the Belgian-born artist Carsten Höller has been packing in crowds since it opened last month, has raised its general admission price to $16, from $12. The higher price will help it pay for the extra staff needed to shepherd museumgoers through Mr. Höller's carnival-like pieces, which take up all the museum's floors: goggles that turn the world upside down; a three-story tubular slide; and a heavily salinated sensory deprivation tank (complete with a shower and hooks for the clothes of those who decide to undress and get in for a float).

KARACHI, Pakistan - It's an unusual sight for a Sunday morning: a dozen Karachiites armed with brooms, rakes, sand and rubble crouch along a road on which none of them live or work in order to mend a large, sewage-filled pothole. The workers come in all shapes and sizes: a man in his 80's uses his walking stick to knock large rocks out of the way; a boy of 12 watches for traffic and waves passing cars to the side of the street. They are members of the Greener Karachi Trust, a volunteer group committed to showing its fellow Karachi dwellers that they needn't wait for the government to repair the city's crumbling infrastructure.

This year’s gift possibilities include scaled-down tablets for children, toys that talk and dance, and some creative uses for Apple devices.
Good-quality wines are now being sold in aluminum bottles and cans.
A new lab sets Johnson & Wales apart in the culinary arts as students wash glassware, make ice, mix standard drinks and create their own.
No need to restrict digital devices to the entertainment spaces. There’s an electronic device perfect for every room in the house, and even for the yard.
A recipe for the Mount Vernon cocktail.
Making the recipes from a buzzed-about guide like “The PDT Cocktail Book” requires budgetary leeway and a liquor store that stocks obscure spirits.
