PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. -- The N.H.L. board of directors met for three and a half hours Tuesday and never broached the subject of fighting, Commissioner Gary Bettman said. Fighting is an aspect of the game that has come under scrutiny by others in the wake of the recent deaths of three of the game's enforcers. One of those players was Derek Boogaard, a former Ranger who died in May of an accidental overdose of alcohol and oxycodone. On Monday, an article by The New York Times revealed that Boogaard's brain was found to have chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a degenerative brain ailment related to Alzheimer's disease that is believed to be caused by repeated blows to the head.
A listing of credits on Friday with a film review of ''The Yellow Sea,'' using information from a publicist, misstated the movie's running time. It is 2 hours 16 minutes, not 2 hours 37 minutes.

Amazon expanded its publishing ambitions on Tuesday by acquiring more than 450 titles from Marshall Cavendish Children's Books, a niche publisher. Amazon has published several children's books under its AmazonEncore imprint, but the acquisition represents Amazon's first significant push into the category.

7:33 p.m. | Updated LONDON - The Bank of England is calling for British banks to cut their employee compensation and shareholder dividends as a way to bolster their capital reserves in the face of sluggish earnings, tight debt markets and the European sovereign debt crisis.

At this point in 2007, Iowa residents had been subjected to 26,037 television commercials from presidential candidates and political groups in a barrage of advertising that was unparalleled. So far this year? Iowans have been hit with just 8,697 television ads.

Its name, Brooklyn Republic Vodka, radiates the borough's prickly pride. And though this crystalline new spirit does not begin life in Kings County, it achieves its clean aroma, bright flavor and smooth finish there. It's the work of a troika of resident Brooklyn vodka lovers: Gary Shokin, who came to New York from Lithuania some 30 years ago; his daughter Kary Laskin, born and raised in Brooklyn; and Mark Krupkin, originally from Latvia. The vodka starts in Missouri, where it is distilled from corn mixed with organic upstate New York wheat. The overproof distillate is shipped to Brooklyn Republic's Clinton Hill plant, where it is brought down to 80 proof with filtered Brooklyn tap water, then filtered several more times before being sealed in handsome bottles. Brooklyn Republic Vodka is $24.99 for 750 milliliters at Henry Harde's Wines and Liquors in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and Nancy's Wines for Food and Sea Grape Wine Shop in Manhattan. It's $23 at Park Avenue Liquor Shop, $19.99 at onlykosherwine.com.

A lottery drama may be coming to a close. After three Connecticut asset managers stepped forward last week to claim a $254.2 million Powerball jackpot on behalf of the Putnam Avenue Family Trust, speculation swirled that they were handling the money on behalf of a client who wished to remain anonymous.

OSAWATOMIE, Kan. -- Laying out a populist argument for his re-election next year, President Obama ventured into the conservative heartland on Tuesday to deliver his most pointed appeal yet for a strong governmental role through tax and regulation to level the economic playing field. ''This country succeeds when everyone gets a fair shot, when everyone does their fair share and when everyone plays by the same rules,'' Mr. Obama said in an address that sought to tie his economic differences with Republicans into an overarching message.

IT was while my station wagon sat stuck behind a dump truck as I inched across Westchester County trying to find a bottle of Italian chestnut honey distillate that I realized I was probably not cut out for this mixology thing. I had the passion, to be sure, even if my after-work bartending adventures only sporadically get beyond the pour-bourbon-on-top-of-ice stage. And the mission had seemed simple enough. The idea was to attempt to make a few recipes from the most buzzed-about cocktail guide in the country, ''The PDT Cocktail Book'' (Sterling Epicure; $24.95) by Jim Meehan. It's a mesmerizing volume. Start flipping through it and you can't help but be transported, sort of like Jack Nicholson in ''The Shining,'' to some faraway Jazz Age bacchanal where the bartenders muddle blueberries with half an ounce of Crème Yvette, pour in some Cognac and Champagne, and top off this ambrosial sip with an edible orchid. (At PDT, in the East Village, they really do that. See Page 147: the Imperial Blueberry Fizz. Sigh.) What would happen if I tried to conjure up a few of these speakeasy dreams in my own home, in the gridlocked, Yellowtail-friendly suburbs?

TOYS embedded with technology are everywhere. It seems every toy can light up, talk, walk and sing, occasionally in your choice of languages. They can even sell themselves, via motion-activated displays that see you coming and respond with a commercial. This is the age of the iPad, and children have no shortage of things pulling at their limited playtime, which, let's hope, includes some time to build a snowman. How do the tech toys measure up? This is not a typical ''best of the year'' list; rather, it is an attempt to make you -- a busy parent or grandparent -- smarter than a fifth grader, in 1,200 words or less, while pointing out a few noteworthy examples. The prices are from Amazon.com, unless noted.

POLLEY--Gordon. July 4th, 1933 November 16th 2011. He loved sailing, football, fishing, travel, gardening, cooking, business and science. Member Sachem's Head and New York Yacht Clubs. Graduate of Cornell and Harvard Business School. Husband to Jane, father to Hal and Tom, grandfather to Diego and Annie.

Frederik G. H. Meijer, who helped pioneer the concept of one-stop shopping at his family's Midwestern discount and grocery chain, died on Friday in Grand Rapids, Mich. He was 91. The cause was a stroke, the Meijer Corporation said.

One mission isn't enough for the Roots, who have released two albums almost simultaneously. ''Undun'' (Def Jam), the Roots' own 13th studio album, arrived on Tuesday, and a collaboration with the soul singer Betty Wright, ''Betty Wright: The Movie'' (Ms. B/S-Curve) came out on Nov. 15. The Roots, led by Ahmir (Questlove) Thompson on drums and the rapper Black Thought, are determined to focus attention on the bleak prospects of poor urban youth. They uphold pre-gangsta ideals of hip-hop as a history and outcry, while they reinvent hip-hop as music for a live band rather than for D.J.'s and programmers. They delve thoroughly into an African-American heritage of funk and soul, and they apply a fan's and a curator's curiosity to genres from indie-rock to Afro-beat. They mingle personal and political messages, reach out to older generations, reverse-engineer vintage songs and fearlessly experiment in their own music. Not every project is a masterpiece, but the ambition runs deep and true.

IF only shopping for electronics were as easy as buying a car. There was a time not so long ago that buying a car was one of the worst shopping experiences. As you drove off the dealer's lot, you couldn't escape the feeling that you hadn't gotten the best deal.

Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott was preparing to meet with the chancellor of the State Board of Regents, Merryl H. Tisch, when a reporter called. Dr. Tisch had just told the Daily News editorial board that she was frustrated with how New York City had been using millions of dollars from the federal government to fix failing schools, which she said had become ''warehouses'' for struggling students. What, the reporter wanted to know, did Mr. Walcott think of her assessment?

It's tempting to think that we know much more than we did at the start of the season. As of Sunday night, we learned -- or, at least, we thought we learned -- that San Francisco was really good, that San Diego had gone from unlucky to just plain bad and that the Rams were again one of the league's doormats. One day later, and maybe the Chargers are getting ready for another late-season run. By some measure, we have learned a lot. It is true that 2011 will not be the breakout season for the Rams, as many predicted. It is assured that San Francisco will win double-digit games and dominate the N.F.C. West. The Green Bay Packers are all but guaranteed to finish with the best record in the league.

Paul Doty, a biochemist who furthered understanding of the chemical secrets of heredity, then became a leader in bringing Soviet and American scientists together to try to control nuclear arms, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 91. The cause was congestive heart failure, his son, Gordon, said.

CASEY--John. The Lincoln Hall Board of Managers notes with deep regret the passing of John Casey who faithfully served on the Board for over three years. Mr. Casey served as Chairman of the Audit, Investment and Scholarship Committees. His expertise in finance and advocacy of the youth in Lincoln Hall's care made him an invaluable asset to the agency. The Board and staff extend sincere condolences to Mr. Casey's family on their loss. James G. Nugent, Chairman Douglas W. Wyatt, President and Lincoln Hall Board of Managers

Panettone, the yeasty, lightly sweetened mound with a smattering of dried fruits, usually has a shelf life surpassed only by that of fruitcake. But here is a panettone that will be reduced to crumbs in a short time. Scarpato, a pastry company founded in Legnano, Italy, in 1888, is baking a not-so-traditional Christmas version, using organic olive oil in the dough. The result -- moist, rich and aromatic -- is excellent plain with a glass of sweet wine after dinner, or turned into French toast for breakfast. The olive oil comes from a company called Nudo, which supports a collection of small growers in Central Italy, and encourages the public to ''adopt'' an olive tree to help the farmers -- in return for tins of oil. Nudo Panettone, $25 plus shipping for 35.27 ounces, must be ordered by Dec. 19 for delivery before Christmas, from nudo-italia.com; if any are available after that date, they can be ordered for later delivery. Tins of olive oils start at $7.99 for 8.4 ounces. It costs $109 to adopt a tree; donors will receive two shipments of oil during the year.

The jury in the federal corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook was sent home on Tuesday evening after deliberating for a third full day without reaching a verdict. The jury told the judge on Monday that it was at an impasse on all 12 counts in the case, in which Mr. Seabrook, a Bronx Democrat, has been accused of participating in a series of fraud schemes to direct more than $1 million in taxpayer money to nonprofit groups he controlled, so that he could then funnel money to family members and friends.

CASEY--John Patrick, died December 6 at Greenwich, (CT), Hospital at the age of 66, surrounded by family and friends. He was born June 5, 1945 in New York City and was raised on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. John was the quintessential fun-loving Irishman, known for his upbeat gregarious personality. He was beloved by his countless friends from all walks of life. John was the former CFO of the B. Altman and Co. and current CFO of the Altman Foundation. John was a long-time devoted member of the Union League Club, serving as President for three years. He also was an enthusiastic, dedicated Commissioner of the Rye Little League. He was a popular member of the Westchester Country Club where he excelled on the golf course with his unorthodox but effective swing. He also was a proud member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, the Rye Fish and Game Club, the ULC Trap and Skeet Team, and a revered member of the legendary "PotatoeHeads." John and his brother, Roger, were Irish step-dancing champions in their youth. He was a former board member of St. Agnes Hospital and LaSalle Academy, and a current board member of Lincoln Hall. John was a proud Veteran of the Army's "Fighting 69 th." John is survived by his devoted wife of 38 years, Kathy; his daughter Erin and her husband Brian Appleton, his son Sean; his beloved grandson Reed, and his brother Roger's family: Gail, Carolyn, Andrew, Maggie, Nora and Kevin. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Friday, December 9th at 10am at Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY. Family will receive visitors at Graham Funeral Parlor in Rye, NY from 4pm to 8pm on Thursday, December 8th. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

FUTABA, Japan -- Futaba is a modern-day ghost town -- not a boomtown gone bust, not even entirely a victim of the devastating earthquake and tsunami that leveled other parts of Japan's northeast coast. Its traditional wooden homes have begun to sag and collapse since they were abandoned in March by residents fleeing the nuclear plant on the edge of town that began spiraling toward disaster. Roofs possibly damaged by the earth's shaking have let rain seep in, starting the rot that is eating at the houses from the inside.

SIEGEL--Ruth (nee Leff), died at home peacefully on December 5, 2011 at the age of 84 after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. Our beloved Ruthie was the lodestar of family and friends, a passionate supporter of the arts, politics, her alma mater Sarah Lawrence, hospital research and patient care in New York, Israel and the Dominican Republic, a fiercely competitive athlete, a beautiful and graceful woman. She was born in New York City on December 3, 1927, the daughter of Phillip and Lillian Leff. She graduated from the Ethical Culture Fieldston School and Sarah Lawrence College. She was the cherished wife of Jerome Siegel, adored mother of Michael Levin and Laurence de Segonzac-Levin, Stephen and Amy Levin, Robin Levin, William and Sharon Levin, Henry and Talia Siegel, Elizabeth and David Carpenter, and Carol Siegel, dear sister of Joseph Leff and sister-in-law Juanita, double first cousin to life long confidantes Marjorie Miller and Maxine Myers, devoted grandmother of Alex, Max-Andre, Sebastien, Samantha, Eli, Noah, Sarah, Rachel, Matthew, David, Emma, Hannah, Alexis, Jayden, Ellah, Tessa, Adam and mentor to Luis Batista. In her lifelong pursuit of artistic excellence, Ruth founded and led Art Latitude Gallery and the Ruth Siegel Art Gallery, where she nurtured and brought to prominence major young American artists. She contributed as a board member of MoMA PS1 and the Museum of Arts and Design, as well as the Foundation for Art and Preservation in Embassies and Channel 13 Art Auctions. She was a tireless advocate for educational opportunity, as a teacher of young children, as a member of the Board of Trustees for Sarah Lawrence College, where she endowed The Ruth Leff Siegel Center, as a supporter of Westchester Community College and its Siegel Cafe, and as a founding supporter of the Hogar del Nino in the Dominican Republic. Ruth was an active supporter of the Democratic Party, hosting former President William Clinton and Hillary Clinton at her home on several occasions. She was selected to be a member of the delegation accompanying Vice President Al Gore to Warsaw in commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising. Ruth was also a generous contributor to national, state and local candidates. In the realm of health care, Ruth was on the Board of Patient Care of New York Presbyterian Hospital, and with Jerome endowed the Stroke Center at White Plains Hospital and child care services in La Romana, Dominican Republic. In the field of medical research, she and Jerome were early and devoted supporters of the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel, endowing a Chair of Virology. As a champion tennis player, in a career filled with trophies, she belonged to Beach Point Club and New Rochelle Tennis Club, added golf to her many athletic accomplishments at Quaker Ridge Golf Club, and excelled in bridge and duplicate bridge with Jerome at The Harmonie Club and the Regency Whist Club. Forty-four years ago Ruthie married her soul mate Jerome and they have been dancing on top of the world ever since. Always smiling, Ruth strove each day to ensure the happiness of her family and epitomized grace under pressure. Her radiant beauty, optimism, exquisite style and grace, joy for life, spirit of adventure, exuberance and, above all, her endless love of family and friends, will live in our hearts forever. Funeral Services will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, New York on Thursday, December 8, 2011 at 12:30pm. Donations in her memory may be made to The Pancreas Center at New York Presbyterian Hospital.

-Feeling congested? Not your nose, your toes. City surveys confirm that sidewalks are becoming more crowded. And transportation officials say that's good for the economy, the environment and for your physical, if not necessarily emotional, health. -Since the city began keeping score at 50 of the busiest intersections five years ago, its ''pedestrian volume index'' has climbed steadily, except for one year, from 2008 to 2009, perhaps because of the recession. Fixing the volume in 2007 at a base of 100, the index rose by more than 10 percent, to 113.2, last May.

It wasn't long ago that video games were on the verge of being marginalized in American culture -- like comic books. (When was the last time you saw an adult reading a comic book, err, excuse me, a ''graphic novel,'' in public? Never?) Now, it seems that almost everyone plays some kind of electronic game. You've got people who can hardly tell a thumbstick from a thumb drive out there who, nevertheless, just won't rest until they master every level of Angry Birds. You've got women who take refuge every day in FarmVille or Sims Social. And there are plenty of executives who seem to be perpetually negotiating some big business deal on their phones when they are really just playing Tetris or Bejeweled.

1:16 p.m. | Updated The Recording Academy, the music industry group that gives out the Grammy Awards, gave its explanation on Monday night for why a promised band-reunion announcement did not occur at its Grammy Awards nomination concert on Nov. 30. But the explanation offered few if any clues to the band's identity or why the announcement did not occur as expected.

SIEGEL--Ruth. The Board of Directors and the members of Quaker Ridge Golf Club are saddened by the passing of our beloved friend and esteemed member of 30 years, Ruth Siegel. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her entire family in their time of sorrow. Alan Howard, President

''Location, location, location'' did not become the most overused slogan in real estate without reason: a property's surroundings are as important as the property itself. So for decades, most commercial brokerage firms have had full-time canvassers or even entire departments of agents relentlessly pacing city blocks to keep up-to-date maps of fast-changing storefront businesses. But in recent months, several brokerage houses, including Massey Knakal Realty Services and the Winick Realty Group, have embraced a Web site called CityMaps.com, which has mapped all the storefront businesses on New York City's streets and tries to keep them current.

It was only a few days after the attack in December 1941 that the phrase ''Remember Pearl Harbor'' first appeared in The New York Times. It took barely a week for Hollywood to register it as a movie title. Today that film is justly forgotten. The phrase lives on, and 70 years have not dimmed the meaning and memory of that day. There was something paradoxical in that instant call to remember. It wasn't as if any American then living could forget. Certainly not those who were there, who smelled the blazing oil on the water, heard the shriek of sirens and planes, the frantic tapping of men trapped in the capsized Oklahoma. Certainly not those who heard the news that day of the lives lost and of world war.

A music review on Monday about performances by the singer Camané and the group Lisboa Soul, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, misstated the surname of a guitarist with Lisboa Soul in some editions. He is Marco Oliveira, not de Oliveira.

Against Baltimore on Sunday, Cleveland won the opening coin toss for the first time this season. The chance of losing 11 consecutive coin tosses is 1 in 2,048. Does it matter? It seems to. Through Week 12, teams that won the opening coin toss won about 55 percent of the time. About 6 times in 10, the team that wins the toss chooses to receive the opening kickoff. For some teams, it is the subject of weekly debate. Coin toss strategy is discussed in meetings on Fridays when coaches talk about game management, according to representatives from several teams.

An article on Saturday about a dearth of acorns in the Northeast this fall described incorrectly the wood thrush, an animal in the forest ecosystem that faces an increased threat as a result. Wood thrushes, which nest in shrubs and branches a few feet off the ground, are considered low-nesting birds; they are not ground-nesting birds.

The last place the professional sailor Ryan Godfrey expected to be this week was hiking around a remote volcanic island in the South Atlantic in long underwear and a T-shirt. On Nov. 21, Godfrey and his 10 fellow crew members on the Puma team were racing their 70-foot carbon sailboat, Mar Mostro, in the first leg of the round-the-world Volvo Ocean Race, from Alicante, Spain, to Cape Town, when their mast came crashing down. They were 2,150 nautical miles from Cape Town, and had only four days' worth of food, said Kimo Worthington, Puma's project manager. The crew embarked on an adventure that has included catching containers of extra diesel fuel from a passing Greek freighter, contacting the Brazilian Navy to research assistance possibilities, and navigating 700 nautical miles to the tiny island of Tristan de Cunha at a paltry speed of 3 knots with a makeshift sailing rig.
A report in the Dining Briefs last Wednesday described the mirrors at Café de la Esquina in Brooklyn incorrectly. They are painted, not etched.

Wal-Mart might have to wait to enter the Indian retail market - perhaps for years - but Ikea, the furniture and furnishing retail chain, might soon be selling its trademark Billy bookcases here.

Carmelo Anthony spent his last official basketball-free night hosting a premiere of "Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked" at a Manhattan theater.
Americans got much poorer last quarter, as their collective household net worth suffered the biggest decline in three years.

A federal bankruptcy judge ruled Thursday that the Los Angeles Dodgers can accelerate the sale of their future television rights over the objections of Fox Sports, whose Prime Ticket channel has a contract to carry the team's games through 2013.

How do you praise the sanctity of traditional heterosexual marriage when the best-known nuptials of the year, between a Kardashian and a basketball player, lasted all of 72 days? Or, for that matter, when a possible Republican nominee for president, Newt Gingrich, cares so much about marriage that he's tried it three times?

In the early days of Twitter the company's founders repeatedly said that expanding the service was like building a rocket ship in mid-flight. Twitter grew so quickly that it was almost impossible to add new features because engineers spent their time trying to keep the rocket ship from stalling -- which often happened anyway.

DALLAS - A league rival added perhaps the most threatening hitter in baseball, so Yankees General manager Brian Cashman was asked Thursday if he would react to it. The Los Angeles Angels now have Albert Pujols, but would that make Cashman redouble his efforts to add pitching?

It's clear, too, that for most of us the eating patterns we develop as children hang around forever.

The most famous meunière preparation is probably sole - it's a slam dunk for pretty much any thin, delicate, white fish fillet. But it's also one of the best ways to treat chicken cutlets. The recipe, which I wrote about in an early Minimalist column, is infinitely variable, but here I've done it about as simply as possible. Dredge the chicken in flour, cook it in a skillet with oil or butter until nicely browned and just cooked through - as long as you get really nice browning on one of the sides, you're fine - and finish with lemon juice and chopped parsley. The brown butter is luxurious and totally optional.

What Richard Chai calls his orchid cemetery is a narrow, north-facing window sill in the kitchen area of his Financial District loft. There, five flowerless orchid plants in uniform terracotta pots are getting indirect sunlight and enough water to keep the soil moist most of the time, and that's it. "Just ignore them," says Chai, who is literally -- a word he uses quite frequently -- bringing the gentle plants back to life (maybe rehab is a better word for the facility). "I used to obsess about orchids. But if you ignore them, they're so much happier."

For the first time this season, CBS was the No. 1 network in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic on a Wednesday night, narrowly surpassing Fox and ABC while also pulling in the highest number of total viewers. The victory was at least partly the result of some key programs on the other networks underperforming. "Modern Family" on ABC had a below-average showing in the 18-to-49 demo and hit a season low in total viewers -- 12.1 million. On Fox, a 90-minute episode of "The X Factor" was also down 11 percent in that demo when compared to last week, and that singing show had 10.6 million total viewers.

A little over a month ago, I wrote a column about the problems with contemporary liberalism's prescription for what ails the American middle class. My argument, in a nutshell, was that wage stagnation and social immobility are real issues, but that simply soaking the rich in order to invest more money in our existing public institutions (propping up Medicare and Social Security, preserving and expanding government employment, etc.) wouldn't necessarily do much to increase prosperity and mobility for the next generation of Americans, and might actually have perverse consequences instead.

Looking at art at an art fair can be a harried experience, and Art Basel Miami Beach in particular can feel like full-on holiday shopping. Some galleries play against the problem in a way that only exacerbates it, by putting up works that seem like shameless grabs for attention. The opposite tact is to show pieces that do not strain to be noticed over the din - artworks that intentionally depend on being somewhat overlooked. The Cuban artist Wilfredo Prieto's sculptures fit the latter category, subtly refracting the bizarre context of a fair through a simple and matter-of-fact visual wit.

There are worse fates than being stuck in Barbados for a long weekend, as I was last month, having tagged along with my lady friend to a conference at the University of the West Indies. I had been told that Barbados, the most British of Caribbean isles, is also among the most delicious, so I resolved to eat my way across it, a journey that involved much driving on roads with no signs and much sipping of Mount Gay Extra Old rum, but of course never at the same time. (If you visit Barbados, you will be extolled the virtues of house-made rum punch - it is often poured out of bottles that look as if they once held bleach - but this cloying potion guarantees a terrible hangover. Instead, drink the local rums neat or with fresh juice.)

Someone had to take the promotional picture for the Mutual Broadcasting System's "Deadline" program, showing the host, Louise Snyder, holding a large turkey. (It was Thanksgiving, after all.) Mutual's publicity photographer in the 1950s and '60s was Louis Nemeth, who had a much greater talent - and a much more interesting story - than his 8-by-10 glossies ever revealed. Over the course of 93 years, he moved all of three blocks in Hungarian Yorkville, from East 68th Street to East 65th Street. But his career also took him to the Buchenwald concentration camp during World War II. There, in April 1945, as a member of the 165th Signal Photo Company, he spent three days documenting the horrors uncovered after the camp's liberation. Maybe he used the next decades to create so many innocuous photo fantasies because he had already seen enough reality to last a lifetime. A video and a longer article are on Lens.

Adam Nagourney writes about Jay Carson and Chris Lehane, two former Democratic operatives in Washington who serve as the models for political consultants in different Hollywood movies. The Carson-inspired character was at the heart of "The Ides of March," directed by George Clooney; Mr. Lehane is a writer and producer of "Knife Fight," slated for release early next year, which also focuses on a political consultant. Both worked for President Bill Clinton, Mr. Nagourney writes, and "not surprisingly, each movie has an older male candidate who has sexual relations with an intern." But more generally, he writes that the movies "go beyond the usual Hollywood glorification of political consultants, offering dark and at times unsettling accounts of what is done in the name of winning elections."

One of the more overlooked statistics in football is penalty rate. Penalty yards per play is one of the more consistent attributes of N.F.L. teams, second only to offensive pass efficiency. Penalty rate's effect on game outcomes isn't as large as that of other team attributes, but in terms of predicting winners its consistency makes it as important as things like running efficiency and interception rates.

Charles Dickens, considered by many to be the first great novelist of the modern city and the age of mass culture, will be widely celebrated throughout Great Britain in 2012, the 200th anniversary of his birth. The first major exhibition will take place from Dec. 9 to June 10 at the Museum of London (150 London Wall; www.museumoflondon.org.uk/dickens). He will be commemorated with paintings, photographs, costumes and objects that illustrate themes from his works, as well as rare, hand-written manuscripts of his novels "Bleak House," "David Copperfield" and "Great Expectations." Visitors will also get a chance to see his writing desk and chair. And William Raban's documentary film "The Houseless Shadow" compares his London with the London of today.

Her first contribution involved traveling to her home state, Arkansas, to profile Annette Dove, who runs an afterschool program for underprivileged children in Pine Bluff.

An art review on Saturday about the Art Basel Miami Beach fair misidentified, in some copies, an artist whose work was shown at the Untitled gallery booth. He is Matthew Chambers -- not Matt Saunders, whose work was shown by the Harris Lieberman gallery. The review also misstated the size of a Frank Stella painting shown by the Edward Tyler Nahem gallery. It is 30 feet long, not 12 feet.

An article on Friday about Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton's visit to Myanmar, where she met Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the opposition leader and Nobel laureate, misstated the title of Madeleine K. Albright at the time she had sent a poster from a 1995 women's conference in Beijing autographed by Mrs. Clinton, then the First Lady, to Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi. Ms. Albright was the American ambassador to the United Nations; she had not yet become the Secretary of State. (That happened on Jan. 23, 1997, when she was sworn in, the first woman to hold the office.)

''I'M from that generation of artists who tries to think very hard about new sets of relationships between people and spaces and how people work with artwork,'' said Liam Gillick, who was one of several artists in Miami's Design District this month exploring a relationship with a big fashion brand. Cross-disciplinary collaborations, often accompanied by pop-up stores, are the name of the game during Design Miami, the design adjunct to Art Basel Miami Beach. This year's brilliant moments included Mr. Gillick and Pringle of Scotland; Beatriz Milhazes and Cartier; and Anselm Reyle and Dior. ''I didn't really want to do an ironic, one-off deconstructed sweater,'' Mr. Gillick said of his collaboration with Pringle, the Scottish cashmere brand. ''I'd rather do something that has more complicated implications.''

A headline in some copies on Wednesday with an article about a mother who killed herself at a state welfare office in San Antonio because she was angry over not qualifying for food stamps misstated the details of the incident. The woman, identified as Rachelle Grimmer, shot and critically injured her two children; they were not killed.

FORMAN--Joan Alpert, 68 years old, died on December 6, 2011. Devoted mother of Bruce Forman and his wife Sylvia, Andrew Forman and his wife Rosemary, and Wendy Stewart and her husband Anthony. Cherished grandmother of Jacob and Alexander Forman and Devin and Colin Stewart. Dearest sister of Mickey Alpert and his wife Sandra. There is nothing like a mother's love: Joan's endless and unconditional love of her family and friends will continue to inspire us. She will always warm our hearts and fill our memories. Funeral services 9:30am Friday at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (Opp. LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment to immediately follow at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

The unthinkable became reality on Wednesday when Manchester City and Manchester United, the star-studded two top teams in the English Premier League, failed to advance to the knockout round of the UEFA Champions League. It was a double dose of misery for the clubs from northwest England. In Group A, Manchester City defeated visiting Bayern Munich, the leader in the German Bundesliga, 2-0, on goals by David Silva and Yaya Toure, but needed winless Villarreal of Spain to tie or defeat Napoli in Italy. It was not to be, as Gokhan Inler and the substitute Marek Hamsik scored second-half goals and Napoli joined Munich in the next round.

An article on Tuesday about a Bronx evangelical church that lost a case before the Supreme Court that would have forced New York City to permit worship services in public schools misidentified the location of a school district in New York that was told by the Supreme Court in 2001 that it could not prevent a Christian youth group from using space in a public school after-hours. The district is in Milford, not Medford.

Defenseman Michael Sauer is out with a concussion after a collision with Dion Phaneuf in the Rangers' 4-2 loss to Toronto on Monday. Sauer, second on the Rangers with a plus-9 mark, is day to day, Coach John Tortorella said. CONCUSSION DATA ONLINE Saying that parents whose children play contact sports should ''not accept public health policy from the N.H.L., but do it for themselves,'' a doctor heading a team of Canadian concussion specialists began an online concussion library fully accessible to both the public and to research and medical professionals.

Is the stress of urban striving shredding your nerves? Do you fight the odd urge to throw the BlackBerry down the nearest manhole? Had it up to here with the overscheduled, information-saturated, distraction-filled frenzy that is contemporary American life? The smiling fellow in the slick suit, skinny tie and nifty hat has a proposition for you. Turn off the digital assistant, tune out the endless din and drop in to the friendly neighborhood depicted in the new play ''Maple and Vine,'' where social networking is a mere matter of inviting friends over for pigs in a blanket and crab puffs.

Browns (4-8) at Steelers (9-3) 8:20 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network Line: Steelers by 11 The Browns' signature play this season has been the dropped pass. Browns receivers have dropped 35 passes, the highest figure in the league, according to Stats LLC. They have collectively dropped more passes than all but one of their receivers has caught. Greg Little leads the team with 15 drops, and few were borderline cases of an off-target pass glancing off his outstretched fingertips. Little's hands and stomach seem to magnetically repel footballs. Running back Montario Hardesty is more culpable than Little, who at least leads the team with 50 receptions. Hardesty has 12 catches and 6 drops, most of them on dump-off passes that travel with all the distance and velocity of a stuffed bunny tossed to a toddler. If the Browns' receivers had caught half the passes they dropped this season, Colt McCoy's completion percentage would be nearly 4 points higher, and more important, the Browns may have won close games against the Rams and the Bengals.

A review in the New Music column on Tuesday about Robin Thicke's new album, ''Love After War,'' misstated the number of songs on it on which he has the sole song-writing credit. Besides ''Boring,'' there are four others.

More than 30,000 people are expected to pass through the Christie's exhibition space in Rockefeller Center to see the legendary jewel collection of Elizabeth Taylor before it goes up for auction later this month. The exhibition, which opened on Saturday and runs through Monday, is bringing out the star-struck, the nostalgic and the just plain curious. Here are the stories of some of those who came out on Monday. Interviews and photographs by Benjamin Norman for The New York Times.

This week's music sales are all about two things: Christmas and Adele. For a second week in a row Michael Buble's ''Christmas'' (143/Reprise) holds the top spot on the Billboard album chart. But while last week it reached No. 1 by a hair -- beating out a new Nickelback record by only 419 copies -- Mr. Buble's album reached the peak this week by a healthy margin with a total of 293,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

The new Droid Razr has a lot to live up to. The original Razr was a flip-phone marvel of sleek design. It became the best-selling phone in the United States until the iPhone knocked it from its perch. The new Razr, while lacking the wow factor of the original, is still a credible heir to the name. Two things - speed and battery life - set the phone apart.

LONDON - European regulators are pressing banks to shore up their balance sheets and bolster their capital cushions as the sovereign debt crisis continues to wreak havoc on the Continent. But some financial firms, including Barclays of Britain, Commerzbank of Germany and BNP Paribas of France, are rejiggering their bond holdings in a complex maneuver that allows them to improve their capital levels without raising additional funds. It's a costly accounting strategy that may drain cash, leaving firms more vulnerable to the economic turmoil.

Q. We spend our weekends in a rural area that offers only dial-up Internet, which is very inconvenient. We do, however, have both AT&T and Verizon cellphone coverage. Can we use these cellphone networks to access the Internet? If so, will we need to pay by minutes of usage?

You can't tightrope-walk across Niagara Falls if only one side says yes. And on Wednesday, local authorities on the Canadian side said no to Nik Wallenda, the seventh-generation funambulist who had sought to be the first man, woman or child to tiptoe above the rushing gorge in more than a century. The Niagara Parks Commission, which controls the parkland on the Ontario side of the falls, rejected Mr. Wallenda's proposal to traverse 1,800 feet on a two-inch steel cable, citing concerns about safety and copycats.

SIEGEL--Ruth (nee Leff), died at home peacefully on December 5, 2011 at the age of 84 after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. Our beloved Ruthie was the lodestar of family and friends, a passionate supporter of the arts, politics, her alma mater Sarah Lawrence, hospital research and patient care in New York, Israel and the Dominican Republic, a fiercely competitive athlete, a beautiful and graceful woman. She was born in New York City on December 3, 1927, the daughter of Phillip and Lillian Leff. She graduated from the Ethical Culture Fieldston School and Sarah Lawrence College. She was the cherished wife of Jerome Siegel, adored mother of Michael Levin and Laurence de Segonzac-Levin, Stephen and Amy Levin, Robin Levin, William and Sharon Levin, Henry and Talia Siegel, Elizabeth and David Carpenter, and Carol Siegel, dear sister of Joseph Leff and sister-in-law Juanita, double first cousin to life long confidantes Marjorie Miller and Maxine Myers, devoted grandmother of Alex, Max-Andre, Sebastien, Samantha, Eli, Noah, Sarah, Rachel, Matthew, David, Emma, Hannah, Alexis, Jayden, Ellah, Tessa, Adam and mentor to Luis Batista. In her lifelong pursuit of artistic excellence, Ruth founded and led Art Latitude Gallery and the Ruth Siegel Art Gallery, where she nurtured and brought to prominence major young American artists. She contributed as a board member of MoMA PS1 and the Museum of Arts and Design, as well as the Foundation for Art and Preservation in Embassies and Channel 13 Art Auctions. She was a tireless advocate for educational opportunity, as a teacher of young children, as a member of the Board of Trustees for Sarah Lawrence College, where she endowed The Ruth Leff Siegel Center, as a supporter of Westchester Community College and its Siegel Cafe, and as a founding supporter of the Hogar del Nino in the Dominican Republic. Ruth was an active supporter of the Democratic Party, hosting former President William Clinton and Hillary Clinton at her home on several occasions. She was selected to be a member of the delegation accompanying Vice President Al Gore to Warsaw in commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising. Ruth was also a generous contributor to national, state and local candidates. In the realm of health care, Ruth was on the Board of Patient Care of New York Presbyterian Hospital, and with Jerome endowed the Stroke Center at White Plains Hospital and child care services in La Romana, Dominican Republic. In the field of medical research, she and Jerome were early and devoted supporters of the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel, endowing a Chair of Virology. As a champion tennis player, in a career filled with trophies, she belonged to Beach Point Club and New Rochelle Tennis Club, added golf to her many athletic accomplishments at Quaker Ridge Golf Club, and excelled in bridge and duplicate bridge with Jerome at The Harmonie Club and the Regency Whist Club. Forty-four years ago Ruthie married her soul mate Jerome and they have been dancing on top of the world ever since. Always smiling, Ruth strove each day to ensure the happiness of her family and epitomized grace under pressure. Her radiant beauty, optimism, exquisite style and grace, joy for life, spirit of adventure, exuberance and, above all, her endless love of family and friends, will live in our hearts forever. Funeral Services will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, New York on Thursday, December 8, 2011 at 12:30pm. Donations in her memory may be made to The Pancreas Center at New York Presbyterian Hospital.

NATHANSON--Joseph, on December 7. Leaves beloved partner Lise Fortier, daughter Julie (Philip) Crawford, sister Ruth Pollack, sister-in-law Nora, predeceased by brother Bill, former Reuters correspondent. Recently chaired a Los Angeles PR firm. Family and friends will miss him.

An obituary on Monday about the cancer researcher Dr. Lloyd J. Old misspelled the surname of a colleague who worked with Dr. Old on immunological research. He was Dr. Edward A. Boyse, not Boyce. The obituary also misstated the length of Dr. Old's tenure as scientific director of the Cancer Research Institute. He held that position from 1971 until 2011 -- not until 2005. And the obituary gave an outdated title for Jill O'Donnell-Tormey of the Cancer Research Institute. She is the institute's chief executive; she is no longer its executive director.

That column full of buttons (officially known as the Navigation Pane) on the left side of the Microsoft Outlook 2007 and 2010 window makes it easy to jump around among Mail, Contacts, Calendar and the other parts of the program. You are not stuck with the default version of the Navigation Pane, though, and if you like to put the buttons in your own preferred order, you can customize it. To change the order, go to the bottom of the Navigation Pane, click the small black triangle and choose Navigation Pane Options from the menu. In the list for ''Display buttons in this order,'' click the button you want to move, and click Move Up or Move Down to reposition it accordingly. You can tweak things further, by adding or removing buttons, changing the Navigation Pane's font, or resizing the pane itself. Microsoft has full instructions here.

10:30 A.M. (Bio) THE DAY JOHN LENNON DIED On the 31st anniversary of Lennon's death this program recounts the events of his final day, including how he and his wife, Yoko Ono, had just returned to the Dakota, their New York apartment building, from a photo shoot with Annie Leibovitz and how he had autographed a copy of his record ''Double Fantasy'' for Mark David Chapman, the man who would shoot him. The program also features Lennon's music, interviews with friends and footage from the initial reports of his death; above, outside the Dakota the day after his death. 3:15 P.M. (IFC) MOULIN ROUGE (2001) A vibrant musical set in turn-of-the-20th-century France, this film follows the story of Satine (Nicole Kidman), the ''sparkling diamond'' of the Parisian cabaret and bordello Moulin Rouge, and the romantic British writer Christian (Ewan McGregor). He is dazzled by Satine, though she has her share of drama: not only is she is being pursued by the powerful Duke of Worcester (Richard Roxburgh), but she is also battling tuberculosis. In a review in The New York Times, Elvis Mitchell wrote that the director, Baz Luhrmann, took ''the most thrilling moments in a movie musical -- the seconds before the actors are about to burst into song and dance, when every breath they take is heightened -- and made an entire picture of such pinnacles.'' The film was nominated for a best picture Oscar.

In an appeal to hard-right conservatives, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is broadcasting a new campaign ad that seems to contrast Christianity with homosexuality, vows to end what he calls ''Obama's war on religion,'' and highlights Mr. Perry's criticism of overturning the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy for gays serving in the military. ''I'm not ashamed to admit that I'm a Christian,'' Mr. Perry says in the ad, ''but you don't need to be in the pew every Sunday to know there's something wrong in this country when gays can serve openly in the military but our kids can't openly celebrate Christmas or pray in school.''
I caused it all. I'm not blaming anyone. I was the governor, and I should have known better. ROD R. BLAGOJEVICH,

E-ink, the passive displays popular on many e-readers, just found a home on your wrist. Phosphor's new world-time watch looks like any other standard sports watch, but the face uses a piece of curved e-ink to display the time. The watch also has a touch-sensitive bezel that lets you swipe between multiple views, including the time at home and in a foreign city, making it a good traveler's companion.

A mediator has been appointed to help New York City Opera and its orchestra and chorus reach an agreement in a bitter labor dispute that is threatening the company's season, the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service's director, George Cohen, said on Wednesday. The service's deputy director, Allison Beck, will lead the effort, along with an official of the regional office, Mr. Cohen said. City Opera's management had made the request after talks fell apart shortly after midnight last Thursday, and union officials had said they were open to the idea. Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians represents the orchestra and the American Guild of Musical Artists represents the chorus, stage managers and assistant directors.

An article on Monday about an eastern box turtle that escaped from the Inwood Hill Nature Center in Manhattan referred imprecisely to one of the identifying characteristics of such turtles. While many can be identified by ''fiery red eyes,'' that is not the case for all of them. Males have fiery red eyes, but females generally have orange or brown eyes. (The escaped turtle, Lionel, is male.)

Updated, 2:38 p.m. | Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly made his first statement on Wednesday about the latest scandal to hit the New York Police Department, condemning the kind of hateful speech attributed to several police officers on a Facebook page dedicated to the unpleasantness of working the annual West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn. If you have ever looked at a garish pair of over-the-ear headphones and thought, ''I could design something better than those clown cans,'' here's your chance. A California-based headphone maker with the snicker-producing name of Fanny Wang (yes, it's on purpose), is making headphones that users can customize using a palette of fifteen colors.

COME spring, those leather cocktail dresses, the L.B.D. of choice for fall, will be turning up in a riot of colors -- that is, if the scenesters who have already adopted the look are any indication. Gucci may well have jump-started the trend on its fall runway, sending out leathers in ripe berry tones, but other designers caught up fast in the resort and spring collections. Blake Lively (above right) showed up at a recent awards show in a tangerine leather dress from the Gucci resort collection. (It will be in the store this month.) And at the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund awards last month, Zoe Kravitz (left) smoldered in a laser-cut burgundy dress from Alexander Wang's spring runway. For party season, take a cue from the model Hilary Rhoda (center), who recently wore a knee-grazing chocolate leather Sportmax dress, now in the SoHo shop for $895, with a Chloé fur jacket (there's always faux), a loose updo and dangling earrings. Other ways to try out the look might include a blue shift from Vince ($795 at Bergdorf Goodman) or a wine-colored Nina Ricci dress with a pleated flounce, now on sale at Barneys ($1,619, from $2,700).

Because of an editing error, a report in the Sports Briefing column on Tuesday misstated part of the name of the award given to the top college quarterback, which was won by Stanford's Andrew Luck. It is the Johnny Unitas Award, not the Johnny United Award. (It is formally known as the Johnny Unitas Golden Arm Award.)

Sidney Crosby will be held out of the Penguins' lineup for the next two games, the team said in a statement released late Wednesday afternoon. ''Sidney took a hard hit during our game against Boston Monday night and wasn't feeling 100 percent,'' Penguins General Manager Ray Shero said in the statement. ''He saw Dr. Micky Collins of UPMC today and took an ImPACT test, which showed no problems. However, we all think it's best that he sits out the next two games as a precaution.''

ANYONE who has erased years of coffee and wine stains from their teeth knows that a pageant-worthy smile can come with a price: tooth sensitivity. A new whitening system sold only at Walmart is promising to brighten teeth without the pain.

NO. 6, the Little Italy boutique known for its shearling and leather clog boots, has teamed up with Baggu, which makes durable totes that are popular as lunch bags. ''We took our classic black boot leather, fringed handles from our kilties, and tassels from the clogs to create what we think is the perfect winter tote,'' said Karin Bereson, who owns the shop with Morgan Yakus. The roomy tote, made with the same Italian wool blanket fabric as their new No. 6 clog boots, is completely reversible, with a waterproof Baggu nylon lining. That it can withstand food spillage makes it even better.

GREENBURGH, N.Y. - Rangers players and Coach John Tortorella declined to speak substantively Wednesday about the news that their former enforcer Derek Boogaard, who died last May of an accidental overdose of alcohol and painkillers, was found to have had the degenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy. The Rangers practiced for the first time since it was revealed Monday that Boogaard, who played for the Rangers last season, was the fourth N.H.L. player known to have had C.T.E., which is believed to be caused by repeated blows to the head.

A ''MythBusters'' stunt went awry on Tuesday, leaving cannonball-shaped holes in the wall of a home and in the window of a minivan in Dublin, Calif. Or, as the local sheriff's department spokesman put it, ''The cannonball took a few unfortunate bounces.'' No injuries were reported, though residents told local news media that they had been shaken up by the incident.

Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, called Wednesday for the resignation of the head of the Justice Department's criminal division, Lanny A. Breuer, in the latest flare-up connected to the disputed gun trafficking investigation known as Operation Fast and Furious. -In a Senate floor speech, Mr. Grassley accused Mr. Breuer, an assistant attorney general, of showing ''a complete lack of judgment'' in his response to learning about a similar earlier investigation by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, and also of ''misleading'' Congress.

Participatory art, as it turns out, is not all fun and games. The New Museum, whose exhibition of the work of the Belgian-born artist Carsten Holler has been packing in crowds since it opened last month, has raised its general admission price to $16, from $12. The higher price will help it pay for the extra staff needed to shepherd museumgoers through Mr. Holler's carnival-like pieces, which take up all the museum's floors: goggles that turn the world upside down; a three-story tubular slide; and a heavily salinated sensory deprivation tank (complete with a shower and hooks for the clothes of those who decide to undress and get in for a float). ''Due to unprecedented attendance for the Carsten Holler exhibition and increased staffing needs, we have increased admission prices,'' Gabriel Einsohn, a spokeswoman for the New Museum, told the Web site NewYorkology, which first reported the price change. ''It is most likely not a permanent increase.'' Admission remains free on Thursday evenings from 7 to 9 p.m.

SIEGEL--Ruth Leff. Sarah Lawrence College deeply mourns the loss of Ruth Leff Siegel, whose contributions to the College have had a significant and lasting impact. She served on the Board of Trustees from 1997 - 2005 and was subsequently named Honorary Trustee. An exceptionally generous benefactor, Ruth and her husband Jerome supported the conception and construction of the College's visual arts center which opened in 2004. Her generosity also made possible the renovation of a student dining and social center which was renamed the Ruth Leff Siegel Center in 1998. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, children, grandchildren, and members of her family who are also part of the Sarah Lawrence community. John A. Hill, Chairman of the Board Karen R. Lawrence, President

Tim McCarver was thinking about his broadcast partners at the Philadelphia Phillies on Wednesday when he won the National Baseball Hall of Fame's Ford C. Frick Award. McCarver was a broadcasting rookie in 1980, working with Harry Kalas, Chris Wheeler, Andy Musser and Richie Ashburn after 21 seasons as a catcher, largely for the Cardinals and Phillies.

The BBC said on Wednesday that it has ordered a sequel to ''The Hour,'' its hit mini-series about the competitive world of 1950s British television journalism. Created by Abi Morgan (the screenwriter of the coming film ''The Iron Lady,'' about Margaret Thatcher), ''The Hour'' centers on the intersecting lives of the frustrated reporter Freddie Lyon (Ben Whishaw), the dogged producer Bel Rowley (Romola Garai) and the unctuous news anchor Hector Madden (Dominic West, below left) at a fictional show called ''The Hour.'' In the new six-episode follow-up, which will feature new cast members, Bel will find herself reporting to a newly installed head of the news division (played by Peter Capaldi) and confronting a rival producer (Tom Burke); Hector, now a national celebrity, will be courted by another television network and befriend a nightclub hostess (Hannah Tointon); and Freddie, who was fired from ''The Hour'' after a controversial interview, will return to the program as its co-host. BBC America, which will co-produce the series and broadcast in the United States, said the new episodes would be shown next year.

An article on Nov. 18 about antigovernment protests in Kuwait misstated its number of citizens, many of them employed by the state. It is 1.3 million -- not 2.6 million, which is the total population.

LESSINGER--Minnie, died December 2, 2011, in Ithaca, NY, of Alzheimer's disease. She was born October 11, 1913. She lived most of her life in Brooklyn. Married Jacob C. Lessinger. Bookkeeper in the family business, Boro Photo. Lovingly cared for by her son and daughter-in-law, Les and Hanna. Later, she was moved closer to her son Eric and his family. She was a lifelong supporter of racial and economic justice and socialism. She was predeceased by her husband, brother Samuel Kalish, sister Ruth Feldman, and son Leslie. She is survived by a sister-in-law, Sadie Lessinger, of Toronto, Canada; daughter-in-law Hanna Lessinger of Brooklyn; son Eric Lessinger (Meredith Ellis) of Trumansburg, NY; mother of her grandchildren Susan Soboroff ; three grandchildren David Lessinger (Cassie Seiple) of New Orleans, LA, Eva Lessinger, and Jesse Lessinger, both of Brooklyn; and one great-grandchild Jacob Benton Lessinger, of New Orleans. If you are inclined to honor her memory with a gift, please consider Socialist Alternative, or the Rosenberg Fund for Children. Ness-Sibley Funeral home is assisting: 888-534-5446, or www.ness-sibley.com.

CASEY--John. The Lincoln Hall Board of Managers notes with deep regret the passing of John Casey who faithfully served on the Board for over three years. Mr. Casey served as Chairman of the Audit, Investment and Scholarship Committees. His expertise in finance and advocacy of the youth in Lincoln Hall's care made him an invaluable asset to the agency. The Board and staff extend sincere condolences to Mr. Casey's family on their loss. James G. Nugent, Chairman Douglas W. Wyatt, President and Lincoln Hall Board of Managers

LENOFF--Jerome H.,born April 7th, 1927, passed surrounded by family in his Pleasantville, NY home on Tuesday, December 6th. A World War II naval veteran, Jerry, as he was known to family and friends, attended the Parsons School of Design on the GI Bill, which launched him into a career in advertising. He worked on Madison Avenue as an award-winning art director and created many memorable campaigns for iconic brands, thoroughly enjoying the creative industry in which he chose to spend his entire career. He retired in 1989 to pursue his other creative loves. He was an accomplished watercolorist, showing his work in galleries throughout Westchester, a photographer and an award-winning gardener. In all these pursuits, he loved capturing the small moments of beauty in the world that often go unnoticed, whether it be the dunes on a Cape Cod beach or the irises from his own garden. He brought these same sensibilities of observing and embracing the world around him to his family. Married for almost 62 years, he supported his wife Audrey as she pursued her own career in education, and celebrated his two children, Michael and Leslee as they went on to careers and families of their own. He was the proud grandfather of Joshua, Jacqueline, Zachary and Julianna and father in-law to Angie and Tom. Private services will be held. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to Phelps Hospice or Pleasantville Community Synagogue.

AT Ida, a new shop in Williamsburg, showstopping hats from the milliner Ryan Wilde and whimsical metal jewelry from Georgia Varidakis occupy the same quaint space. The designers, who met as Artist & Fleas vendors and bonded over a shared Greek heritage, named their store for Mount Ida, where, in Greek myth, Zeus was born. Ms. Wilde, who was discovered and championed by Isabella Blow, and Ms. Varidakis, who uses vintage mementos and found objects in her work, display their wares in vintage cases and World War II-era wooden crates. (''We're hoarders of antique pieces,'' Ms. Varidakis said.) There are feathered cadet hats in solid black and houndstooth, $150 to $220; a chic black beret structured like a cloche, $200; and one-of-a-kind felt headbands, $45. The jewelry includes necklaces cast from fan coral, $70 and $120; sea horse pendants, $132; and necklaces festooned with lockets and crystals, $120 to $320. Ida, 175 Roebling Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (347) 699-6432, idawilliamsburg.com.

Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said Tuesday that Bobby Valentine would add a little spunk to the Boston Red Sox and the rivalry between the two teams. Less than 24 hours later Valentine obliged when asked if he would express his feeling about the Yankees. ''No, I hate the Yankees,'' he said with a smile. ''I don't want to waste this valuable time talking about the Yankees. This is too valuable. I told Joe Girardi I used to love him, but now I hate him.''

One man arrived from Brooklyn, riding north with a wagon of cider and Newtown Pippins affixed to the back of his bicycle.

Just as the musical ''Once'' was about to open at New York Theater Workshop Tuesday night, the show's commercial producers announced that it would go directly to Broadway after the Off Broadway run. Based on the 2007 movie of the same name, ''Once'' will begin previews at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater on Feb. 28, with opening night set for March 18.

A ruling is expected in federal court as soon as next week on whether the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff's massive fraud can appeal a decision that would make it difficult to recover potentially hundreds of millions of dollars from the owners of the Mets.

John H. Sununu, the former governor of New Hampshire who recently endorsed Mitt Romney, has spent the past two days attacking Newt Gingrich on Mr. Romney's behalf. But speaking on the Scott Hennen Show Friday, Mr. Sununu intensified his criticism of the former House speaker after the radio host asked him about comments Senator Tom Coburn of Oklahoma had made recently that were critical of Mr. Gingrich's leadership abilities.

Clara Barton, a 39-year-old single woman with New England written all over her dignified demeanor, could not rest easy until she found a way to join the Army. From the first day blood was spilled in 1861 - some of her old Massachusetts schoolmates were among the Yankee soldiers besieged in Baltimore by a mob of Southern sympathizers - the Civil War was what she lived for. She left a job in Washington as a Patent Office copyist for scenes of mass misery that broke all the record books.

WASHINGTON - The Obama administration has applauded the euro zone for moving to save its common currency and enforce fiscal discipline among its members. Yet the deal has done little to calm American concerns about an inadequate "firewall" -- financing put up by European governments to ensure that all euro zone countries maintain access to the debt markets at sustainable interest rates.

In this week's City Kitchen, we're not featuring a quick delicious meal. Or actually, we are, but it will require a 2 hour investment of time (though not necessarily consecutive hours). For cooks who want to have a little fun, here's a recipe for a pork and chicken pâté - the rustic, old-fashioned kind a French grandmother might make. True, it's a bit of a project, but the end result provides easy hors d'oeuvres for a holiday gathering, a great first course, or a fine sandwich. And once your pâté is made, it can wait in the refrigerator for a week before serving, all the while improving in flavor.

"I just hope that New York feels what I feel," the Brazilian rapper Criolo said just before making his American debut on Wednesday night at Nublu in the East Village. "I hope they feel my heart and soul." Now 36, Criolo was born Kleber Gomes in São Paulo and grew up (and still lives) in one of the city's poorest neighborhoods, the infamous Grajaú favela. It's a place where "one million people fight for life every day," he said.

"Buy now, wear now," is a phrase we hear a lot during the pre-fall presentations, with designers showing clothes better suited to summer (when they'll be delivering to stores) than to the fall they're prefacing. Not so at Calvin Klein, where Francisco Costa showed a stunning and focused collection of wool and leather suits, dresses and coats (lots of coats), all of which carried their tight seams and rather '90s silhouettes with terrific poise, and all of which will transition beautifully into chillier climates. Here, a wool felt single breasted coat over a sleeveless dress of the same fabric with a skirt tucked into the softest, rolling pleats says it all.

"Batman: The Black Mirror" enters our hardcover graphic books best sellers list at No. 1. Complicating things is the return of Commissioner Gordon's son, James, who is a psychopath. The Parisian designer Laurence Doligé makes exactly the kinds of clothes that give French dressing a good name: not too complicated, not too self-conscious, but still a little sexy. Now in its sixth season, Doligé's namesake line will finally be made available stateside this spring, at Mick Margo in Greenwich Village, Jill Robert's in Los Angeles and at shopbop.com. "To be sold in America feels like such an achievement," says the designer. "If you make it in the U.S., you can make it anywhere." The collection's clean white boat neck sundresses, plaid trousers and workman's denim jackets pair beautifully with her handbags, which come in two basic styles: a two-tone tote and a more structured satchel. "My collection is literally my wardrobe" says Doligé. "I love designers like Poiret and Yves Saint Laurent, but my collection is special to me because I can actually afford to wear it every day!"

In the first years of the euro, which was introduced in 1999, countries on the edge of the euro zone benefited economically more than Germany. But over the last five years, the situation has been reversed. The charts show data for euro zone countries divided into four groups. Germany and France, the two largest countries, are shown individually. Five Northern Europe economies, which some have speculated could join Germany and France in a new “strong euro” zone, are shown as a group labeled “Northern countries.” The other 10 countries are combined in a group labeled “Peripheral countries.” These include all the countries currently receiving European assistance, as well as Spain, Italy and other countries.
A five-bedroom penthouse at the Laureate, a new condominium at Broadway and 76th Street, was the biggest sale of the week, going for $9.79 million, according to city records.

The City Room blog is reporting how "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" - a TV show known for finding inspiration in recent headlines - was thwarted in its efforts to recreate the Occupy Wall Street protests for an episode. Around midnight, actual Occupy Wall Street protesters entered the set, stepping over yellow tape and ignoring objections from the few people watching the area. "Soon, more than 100 people were inside Foley Square. Some crawled into tents and lay down," Colin Moynihan writes. In a case of life imitating life, the police evicted the protesters and the film permit was rescinded. Read more »

Alain Ducasse will be the first chef to be awarded the Trophee des Arts, which the French Institute Alliance Francaise established in 1992 to recognize a person who enhances the cultural relationship between France and the United Sates. The presentation is a black-tie gala at the Institute, 583 Park Avenue (63rd Street), on the Upper East Side, and starts at 7 p.m. Some tickets are still available and can be purchased by calling (646) 388-6632. They are $500 for those 34 and under and $1,500 for patron tickets.

It's been clear for years that President Obama hates the crass salesmanship of American politics, the desperate need to absorb personal credit for governing, like a mayor who puts his name on every new railroad trestle. Although that diffidence has had a price-even now, most Americans have no idea what road projects were in the president's 2009 stimulus act-it also kept him from appearing insecure in office, and made him look occasionally magnanimous.

In Today's Times:Redistricting has pitted several incumbent House members against each other next year for redrawn districts, Jennifer Steinhauer writes. In California's San Fernando Valley, the matchup between the veteran Democrats Brad Sherman and Howard L. Berman is expected to draw in independent political groups with deep pockets, she adds.

Tanzina Vega writes about Hearst's introduction of Cosmopolitan Latina, which will begin publishing in May. The planned new magazine -- with one issue in the spring and one in the fall, and, at first, a print run of 545,000 copies -- is a recognition of the growing economic power of Latino women, who number nearly 25 million in the United States, she writes. Latino women account for one in every four subscribers of Cosmopolitan, and the Cosmopolitan Web site will have separate tab for Latino-focused content. The new magazine will be competing with Latina magazine, which just celebrated its 15th anniversary.

The Oscar race is usually well defined by this time, but the Bagger's colleague Brooks Barnes explains why this year may be different and the reason comes down to one person: Scott Rudin, the megaproducer who has kept one of his films, "Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close," under wraps to an unusual degree. It's a strategy that might best be described as "wait, wait wait -- pounce." Mr. Rudin himself wouldn't explain his thinking, saying in an email, "It's a movie, not a worm on the end of a hook," apparently a reference to the concept of Oscar bait. Read more »

European stocks are up today, and I have no idea why. I'm with Felix Salmon -- this looks like a disastrous meeting. More austerity, more posing of the crisis, wrongly, as being all about fiscal deficits; no mechanism for ECB funding. Somehow southern Europe is supposed to deflate its way to prosperity, while everyone runs a trade surplus, presumably against that potentially habitable planet we've discovered 600 light-years away.

The Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature (62, rue des Archives; 33-1-53-01- 92-40, www.chassenature.org) is a singular space. Dedicated to exploring man's interaction with nature, it has a permanent collection featuring hunting scene tapestries, ornately carved firearms, curiosity cabinets and taxidermied animals. And now, the museum is juxtaposing its rather sober items with whimsical pieces by the contemporary artist Françoise Pétrovitch, whose works will be on display through Jan. 22.

The Ford Econoline, marketed by Ford in its later years as the E-Series, is being replaced by the Transit, a model developed by Ford's European division and undergoing tests at the automaker's proving grounds in Michigan. But as the Econoline nameplate goes, so goes a legacy steeped in rock 'n' roll -- and in exceptional cases, chlorine and pizza sauce.

Tiësto, long a major figure in European electronic dance music, will begin hosting a music channel on Sirius XM satellite radio early next year, a spokesman for the radio network said. The channel will broadcast dance music in a variety of styles selected by Tiësto, the Dutch D.J. who is known for his six-hour live sets and his memorable performance during the opening ceremony of the 2004 Olympics in Athens. A master of trance and progressive house music, he has sold more than 761,000 records in the last decade. His new channel, called Tiësto's Club Life Radio, will feature Tiësto's own mixes and music by artists on his label, Musical Freedom, which he started in late 2010. "It will be an awesome way to showcase the incredible artists on my own label, play new material of my own as well as other music that I'm really passionate about," said Tiësto, whose real name is Tijs Verwest. Tiësto currently hosts a Saturday show on Sirius's Electric Area channel, but that program will be moved to the new dial setting: Channel 340 on Edge satellite radios and on the Sirius XM Internet radio site.

Two of my favorite analysts, Rhodes Cook and Josh Putnam, have a good debate going about just how plausible it is that a Republican who is not currently running for president could enter the race later and potentially win it (probably necessitating a brokered convention). Those of you who follow my Twitter feed will know that I think Mr. Cook has the stronger side of the argument; I think there is a small but nontrivial chance that the Republican nominee could be someone like Jeb Bush, Paul Ryan, Mitch Daniels, Tim Pawlenty or Chris Christie. (In fact, I was speculating about these scenarios as long as a month ago.)

"Darshan" is a Sanskrit term meaning sight, in the Hindu sense of beholding a deity and making an immediate spiritual connection. Overwhelmingly in India, Hindu gods and goddesses are rendered in paintings or sculpted from stone and clay.

The United States secretary of health publicly overruled the Food and Drug Administration this week, refusing to allow emergency contraception known as the "morning-after pill" to be sold without a prescription to people under 17. (If taken soon after unprotected sex, the pill halves the chances of a pregnancy.)

A vast inferno ripped through a Kolkata hospital, killing scores of patients who were trapped inside the smoke-filled building as rescue workers struggled to tame the blaze. The fire, which took place at a 161-bed private hospital, broke out in the basement, according to rescue officials, and sent huge plumes of smoke throughout the building. More than 70 people died in the blaze, many due to smoke inhalation, according to television news reports from the scene.

SAN FRANCISCO - Twitter unveiled an ambitious new design on Thursday that is intended to draw new users, keep them on the social network longer and attract more advertisers. Central to the new look and feel are two broad changes. The service's main pages now aim to help users understand how Twitter works, focusing on the # and @ shorthand symbols. And Twitter can now offer what it reckons to be relevant news and entertainment for a particular user, not just the stream of updates from people and brands that the user chooses to follow.

BERTINO--Mary Patricia "Pat", in New Haven, on December 6, 2011. Beloved wife of Joseph R. Bertino, MD, of Branford, CT. She was born in Philadelphia on March 25, 1929, daughter of the late Thomas Frederick and Margaret O'Rourke Hagemeyer. She was a Registered Nurse, having worked at Graduate Hospital at the University of Pennsylvania, and more recently at the Arden House in Hamden. Pat was a communicant of St. Therese Church in Branford. Besides her husband she is survived by her children and their families: Frederick and Armida Bertino and their children Niia, Tana and Eric of Needham, MA; Amy Marie Bertino (Gieg) and her husband Todd and son Max of Lynn, MA; Thomas and Kaitlin Bertino of Eagle Bridge, New York and his children Kylee and Thomas Joseph; Paul and Karina Bertino and their children Stella and Piera of Los Angeles, CA; and one great-grandchild. She was predeceased by her brother Thomas Hagemeyer. Relatives and friends are invited to calling hours on Sunday from 2-4 and 6-8pm at the W. S. Clancy Memorial Funeral Home, 244 North Main St., Branford, CT, and may attend a Memorial Mass of Christian Burial in St. Therese Church, Branford, CT Monday at 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to the Hospital of St. Raphael, 1450 Chapel St., New Haven, CT 06510. For directions and online memorial please visit: www.wsclancy.com.

An article on Monday about sightings of rare wild cats in southern Arizona erroneously attributed a distinction to the jaguar. While it is one of the larger felines, or genus Panthera, to be found in the wild in the Western Hemisphere, it is not the only feline found there. (The cougar and the bobcat are among the felines found there.)

7:31 p.m. | Updated A well-financed but largely unseen independent political group supporting Mitt Romney surfaced on Thursday in a big way, saying it was putting $3.1 million down on advertising in Iowa. The ad campaign, which would be the biggest single purchase yet in the Republican primary this year, was notable also for a stealth bait-and-switch move. The group, Restore Our Future, announced its plans by highlighting a 30-second spot that extolled Mr. Romney's record as a businessman.

A theater review on Thursday about ''Maple and Vine,'' at Playwrights Horizon on West 42nd Street, misspelled, in some editions, the surname of the actress who plays Ellen and Jenna. LENOFF--Jerome H.,born April 7th, 1927, passed surrounded by family in his Pleasantville, NY home on Tuesday, December 6th. A World War II naval veteran, Jerry, as he was known to family and friends, attended the Parsons School of Design on the GI Bill, which launched him into a career in advertising. He worked on Madison Avenue as an award-winning art director and created many memorable campaigns for iconic brands, thoroughly enjoying the creative industry in which he chose to spend his entire career. He retired in 1989 to pursue his other creative loves. He was an accomplished watercolorist, showing his work in galleries throughout Westchester, a photographer and an award-winning gardener. In all these pursuits, he loved capturing the small moments of beauty in the world that often go unnoticed, whether it be the dunes on a Cape Cod beach or the irises from his own garden. He brought these same sensibilities of observing and embracing the world around him to his family. Married for almost 62 years, he supported his wife Audrey as she pursued her own career in education, and celebrated his two children, Michael and Leslee as they went on to careers and families of their own. He was the proud grandfather of Joshua, Jacqueline, Zachary and Julianna and father in-law to Angie and Tom. Private services will be held. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to Phelps Hospice or Pleasantville Community Synagogue.
