Big investors have accused them of missing the problems with subprime loans. And regulators have been writing rules to diminish the importance of their ratings.

HAWKINS--John W. Friends and Family mourn the passing of literary agent, John Hawkins. Born in 1939 in Seattle, Washington, John Hawkins grew up in Kennett Square, PA. He graduated from Harvard in 1962 and received a master's degree in international relations from the University of Pennsylvania in 1964. He worked briefly at Banker's Trust, but in 1966, John Hawkins was persuaded by his father-in-law to join the firm of Paul R. Reynolds Inc, which had been established in 1893 by his wife's grandfather, Paul Revere Reynolds. He became president of the company in 1980 and changed the name of the firm to John Hawkins & Associates in 1985. Over the course of his 45 year career, he represented Joyce Carol Oates, Gail Godwin, Harry Crews, Alex Haley, James Clavell, Thomas McGuane, E. Lynn Harris, Steve Martini and Robert Parker. He will be remembered for his wit, his wisdom and his passionate advocacy for his clients. He is survived by his brother Richard Bruce Hawkins and his nephews, Graham Carty and Andrew Spencer Hawkins.

After winning on the indoor courts in Europe for most of November, Roger Federer was in the sunshine at a distant, undisclosed resort with his wife, Mirka, and twin daughters. But even with sand between the toes and the rackets in temporary storage, tennis remained part of the lounge-chair conversation. ''The vacation has only just started, and I had quite a trip trying to get down here,'' Federer said in a phone interview last week. ''But once down at the beach with the nice weather and the alone time with Mirka, I definitely look back and go, 'I can't believe I was just in my 100th final, and it's already my 70th title.' That's what I told her. I got together with her when I had zero titles, and we kind of went through all this together, and now we have a family. It's been pretty incredible.''

The New Museum, which recently raised its general admission price to pay for extra workers to accommodate the crowds for its exhibition of the work of Carsten Holler, said Thursday that the show - a highbrow funhouse with a slide, a sensory deprivation tank and a slow-motion carousel - had become the most highly attended show in the museum's 35-year history. The show, which continues through Jan. 15, is drawing a daily average of 1,700 visitors, said Gabriel Einsohn, a museum spokeswoman. Previous shows that came close were concurrent exhibitions of the work of Elizabeth Peyton and Mary Heilmann in 2008 and 2009, which drew an average of 1,300 visitors a day and this year's concurrent exhibitions of the work of George Condo and Linda Benglis, which drew slightly fewer than 1,300 a day. In early November the museum raised the general admission price to $16 from $12, to help offset the costs of running the Holler show.

DALLALE--Dina, died at home on October 9, 2011. Her generosity and wisdom made her a pivotal force in the lives of her family and her many friends. An accomplished diplomat and negotiator, she was the International Representative of the Costa Rican Sugar Industry. In 1974 she became the first woman Chairman of the International Sugar Organization. She founded ASFAMEX, an association of U.S. and Costa Rican textile manufacturers, for which she served as Managing Director. She is survived by her two nephews, Beriot and Robert Dellale. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated on Thursday, December 15 at 11am at The Church of Saint Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue (at 66th Street), New York.

A federal bankruptcy judge ruled Thursday that the Los Angeles Dodgers can accelerate the sale of their future television rights over the objections of Fox Sports, whose Prime Ticket channel has a contract to carry the team's games through 2013. Judge Kevin Gross of United States Bankruptcy Court decided in favor of the team after a two-day hearing. If upheld, his decision is likely to set off a vigorous auction for the TV rights between Time Warner Cable, AT&T, DirecTV and Fox.

-Something got twisted about a minute after Seth Cotterman turned on a machine that was no longer new when he was born in 1989. -Oh, the joys of open-reel tape. DALLAS - After selecting a pair of players in last year's Rule 5 Draft, the Mets elected not to pick anyone this time around. They did, however, lose Rhiner Cruz, a right-handed pitcher, to the Houston Astros, who took him with the first overall pick. It was a somewhat unfortunate but anticipated outcome for a team trying to gather and develop young talent.

An obituary on Dec. 2 about the author Christa Wolf referred incorrectly to her birthplace. The town where she was born, Landsberg, now known as Gorzow and part of Poland, was in the German province of Brandenburg, not Silesia.

The Detroit Symphony Orchestra detailed the financial effects of last season's bitter six-month strike on Thursday, citing lost ticket sales and donations, but found optimism in many new audience members and better than expected revenues so far this season. ''The signs this fall have been enormously positive,'' said Anne Parsons, the president. Another sign was the recent three-year extension given to Leonard Slatkin, the music director, who now will have the title through the 2015-2016 season. The orchestra reported a deficit of $1.8 million last season, when it did not start performing until April after the strike was settled and did not have to pay player salaries for the period. That was down from the previous season's $5.3 million deficit, and it still expects a $3 million shortfall this season, Ms. Parsons said.

An article on Thursday about global climate change talks in Durban, South Africa, transposed the name of a group whose executive vice president was quoted on the status of the negotiations. It is the Center for Climate and Energy Solutions, not the Center for Energy and Climate Solutions.

6:15 A.M. (HBO) MELINDA AND MELINDA (2004) Two playwrights -- one of serious dramas (Larry Pine), the other of comedies (Wallace Shawn) -- speculate on an anecdote about an unhappy young woman named Melinda (Radha Mitchell), who, after crashing a dinner party with an air of distress and a tale of woe, stirs up instabilities within her friends' lives. Will Ferrell (above, with Ms. Mitchell) and Chiwetel Ejiofor play the men vying for Melinda's affections in these two separate visions in this Woody Allen movie. '' 'Melinda and Melinda' is perhaps best thought of as an offering to the memories of Ernst Lubitsch and George S. Kaufman, half-forgotten culture heroes whose examples of crisp sophistication deserve to be kept alive for future generations,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But the real reason to appreciate Mr. Allen ''is as an unrivaled pornographer,'' Mr. Scott added. ''I'm not talking about sex; there is some bed hopping in 'Melinda and Melinda,' but the camera always stops at the bedroom door. These days, in any case, the kind of New Yorkers likely to see a Woody Allen movie reserve their true lust for real estate, and the long hallways, high ceilings and open kitchens on display in this movie are likely to keep local audiences sighing and moaning for the full 99 minutes.'' 8:45 A.M. (HBO Signature) ROUGH AUNTIES (2008) The women of Bobbi Bear, a child welfare group in South Africa, often provide the only support for the youngest residents of Durban, an impoverished city. This documentary from Kim Longinotto follows five of the group's members as they rescue and uphold the rights of abused children while helping them heal.

Dr. T. Franklin Williams, a former director of the National Institute on Aging and an early proponent of geriatric care as a medical specialty, died at his home in Rochester on Nov. 25, the day before his 90th birthday. The cause was complications of pneumonia, said Michael Wentzel, a spokesman for the University of Rochester Medical Center, where Dr. Williams had been a professor for more than 30 years.

The first Broadway production of ''Rodgers and Hammerstein's Cinderella'' is in the works for the 2012-13 theater season, with a new libretto by Douglas Carter Beane (''Lysistrata Jones,'' ''Sister Act'') based on the 1957 television musical that starred Julie Andrews, the producer Robyn Goodman said on Thursday. Calling Mr. Beane's book ''somewhat revisionist,'' Ms. Goodman said that the biggest twist was having Cinderella ''rescue the prince by teaching him good values.'' She described the plot as blending political satire (to interest adult theater-goers) with slapstick humor and the familiar story of cruel stepsisters, a fairy godmother, and a magic pumpkin (to appeal to children and teenagers). Mr. Beane also sought inspiration from various literary adaptation of the tale.

An article on Thursday about the effects of Europe's debt crisis on elections next year in the United States misidentified the venue in Berlin where then-Senator Barack Obama spoke in 2008 while running for president. His speech was at the base of the Victory Column in the Tiergarten, a sprawling park in the center of the city -- not at the nearby Brandenburg Gate.

Updated 5:44 p.m. | The jury in the federal corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook indicated on Thursday that it remained unable to reach a verdict on any of the 12 counts against him after more than five days of deliberation, and suggested that jurors should be discharged no later than Friday. The apparent stalemate was disclosed in a note sent at about 3:40 p.m. to Judge Robert P. Patterson Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan.

Columbia's two-week search for a football coach culminated Thursday with the hiring of Pete Mangurian, a former Ivy League head coach who has worked as an assistant with five N.F.L. teams. M. Dianne Murphy, the university's athletic director, had overseen a nationwide search since dismissing Norries Wilson on Nov. 20, a day after Columbia ended its fifth consecutive losing season, one in which the Lions did not win until their final game. She said Mangurian would be formally introduced at a news conference on campus Friday afternoon.

HUEBNER--William (Bill) Alfred. 70, of West Chester, PA, went peacefully home to the Lord on Tuesday, December 6, 2011, at Chester County Hospital with his loving wife, daughter and son-in-law at his side. His passing follows a courageous six-year battle with kidney cancer. He will be missed by his family and friends. He was born April 14, 1941 to Alfred and Helen (Quinn) Huebner in Woodhaven, NY. He shared 49 years of marriage with Margaret (Hoffman) Huebner. They have three sons from Connecticut, Jim (Renee), Gary (Heather) and Chris (Rebecca), and a daughter Karen (Kurt) Dibble from Delaware. He was grandfather to Courtney, Kyle, Brianna, Nicole, Hadley and Annelise. He is survived by brother, Hank (Judy), brother-in-law, John (Mary Anne) and many nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by a brother, Richard. Bill received his BS from Hofstra University and MBA from the University of Hartford. He was CFO, Vice President of Delphinus Engineering, Inc. in Eddystone. He was very dedicated to the company and prided himself on making it to the office during trying times of his treatment. He loved the Lord and was a devoted member of Calvary Lutheran Church, where he enjoyed singing with the chancel choir for years. He was a member of the West Goshen Lions, a Past District Governor of Pennsylvania Lions, and enjoyed being active at the state level. He was a board member of Lions Eye Bank of Delaware Valley and the Bing Miller Foundation. He was an avid sports fan and loved baseball, especially the Phillies. He also enjoyed following the UCONN basketball programs. He and Peg traveled often to share time with family and their fellow Lions. Relatives and friends are invited to a celebration of Bill's life with a visitation being held from 6 to 7:20pm on Friday, December 9, at the Calvary Lutheran Church, 730 South New Street, West Chester, PA 19382, followed by a Memorial Service at 7:30pm. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Bill's memory to the Kidney Cancer Association: https://secure.kidneycancer.org/np/clients/kca/donation.jsp, and/or The West Goshen Lions 435 Fern Hill Lane, West Chester, PA 19380, and/or the Calvary Lutheran Church at the above address. Services by DellaVecchia, Reilly, Smith & Boyd Funeral Home, Inc. of West Chester, PA 610-696-1181. www.DellaFH.com

An article on Nov. 26 about the tax strategies used by the businessman and philanthropist Ronald S. Lauder referred imprecisely to the tax treatment of art in commercial settings. While the purchase of decorative art or lease payments on rented art may be deducted or depreciated as a business expense, the cost of acquiring fine art like the examples in Mr. Lauder's collection is generally not deductible. The article also misidentified the previous owner of the Fifth Avenue mansion that is now the Neue Galerie. It was owned by Grace Wilson Vanderbilt, the widow of Cornelius Vanderbilt III, not by Cornelia Vanderbilt.

Dev Anand, a charismatic Bollywood actor and director who was known in his heyday for his striking good looks, died on Saturday in London. He was 88. The cause was a heart attack, his son, Suneil, said.

The Los Angeles Angels now have Albert Pujols, but would that make Cashman redouble his efforts to add pitching? ''It made us take two guys in the Rule 5 Draft,'' Cashman said, jokingly referring to the annual draft in which teams take unheralded and unprotected players from other teams.

Among the more colorful protesters to emerge from Occupy Wall Street was a uniformed former police commander from the Philadelphia police. His name is Ray Lewis, and, after retiring as a captain in 2004 after 24 years of service, he became active in the world of social justice. To New York City officers, his uniform was curious. It seemingly made him one of them, though his actions caused him to be arrested on Nov. 17, the movement's ''day of action,'' in an episode captured in widely viewed videos.

My Sunday column is from Ismailia, Egypt, the birthplace of the Muslim Brotherhood. It tries to look at why so many Egyptians voted for Islamic parties, and my bottom-line feeling is that Americans are feeling a bit more panicky than is justified. It's not that Egyptians seek a harsh Islamic regime; rather they think the Islamic candidates have a better record working in their neighborhoods and may be a little less likely to take bribes than other candidates. Plenty of the hand-wringing seems to be coming from Americans who've never actually met a Muslim Brotherhood member or a Salafi, and I'd suggest not overdoing the rhetoric. The picture is more complicated than some Americans seem to think (although I must acknowledge that plenty of Egyptian liberals are worried as well). Read the column and post your thoughts.

An article on Dec. 2 about Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton's visit to Myanmar, where she met the opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, misstated the location of a Nov. 30 video conference on Myanmar held by the Council on Foreign Relations in which Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi participated. A 6'9'' leading man who could match the height of basketball great Larry Bird was probably too much to hope for in ''Magic/Bird,'' the new play whose producers are aiming for Broadway in the spring of 2012. But 6'5'' will do. The producers, Fran Kirmser and Tony Ponturo, said in an interview Thursday that they have cast actor (and former college basketball player) Tug Coker in the role of Bird, the former Boston Celtic forward whose on-court rivalry and off-court friendship with Magic Johnson, the Los Angeles Lakers point guard, are the heart of the play. No official announcement of a Broadway production of ''Magic/Bird'' has been made, as the producers wait to learn if they will be offered one of the handful of Broadway theaters that are expected to be available this winter. Producers sometimes disclose casting for Broadway shows before they have been assured of a theater, as a public vote of confidence meant to assure their investors and theater owners (as well as potential ticket-buyers) that they are serious about bringing the productions to Broadway.

The president of the New York Public Library had his driver's license revoked after he pleaded guilty on Friday to having driven while intoxicated last month. The library president, Anthony W. Marx, was also ordered to attend a drunken-driving program.

Over on Slate yesterday, the new Moneybox columnist Matthew Yglesias sounded off on food drives. Having to pick up or sort your donations of random cans is highly inefficient. Much of the stuff that people remove from their pantries is unusable because it's old or it's junk food, he said. Plus, most food banks, he noted, can buy highly discounted bulk food in a variety of ways. It's better, he concluded, to simply hand over the money you would have spent on the food at retail prices and let the food banks buy what they need on the cheap.

5:53 p.m. | Updated In an effort to streamline its often complex relations with music publishers, YouTube has acquired RightsFlow, an upstart company in New York that processes royalties for the music industry. YouTube, which is owned by Google, announced the deal on a company blog on Friday afternoon. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed.

Mick Jagger and Keith Richards have offered to pay for the funeral of Hubert Sumlin, a great Chicago blues guitarist to whom they owe a musical debt, a spokeswoman for the Rolling Stones, Fran Curtis, confirmed. Mr. Sumlin died on Dec. 4. He was 80. He was the longtime guitarist for Howlin' Wolf and inspired a generation of rock and blues players with his emotional solos, among them Mr. Richards. Mr. Sumlin's longtime partner, Toni Ann Mamary, announced online Thursday that the Rolling Stones frontman and rhythm guitarist had agreed to pick up the costs of the interment and service. ''Mick Jagger and Keith Richards have insisted on picking up the full expenses for Hubert's funeral,'' she wrote, the music Web site Noise11 reported. ''God Bless the Rolling Stones.'' A public service will be held on Dec. 12 the Festa Memorial Funeral Home in Totowa, New Jersey. There will also be a public viewing at the funeral home on the previous day. A private service will be held in Mr. Sumlin's hometown of Homewood, Ill., on Dec. 13. It remained unclear which of these services the British band had agreed to underwrite.

ENZER--Hyman A.,PhD, 95, died Wednesday, December 7, 2011 in Amherst, MA. Services on Sunday at Agudas Achim in West Hartford, CT at 2pm. www.agudas.org. According to Hy's wishes his remains have been donated to the University of Massachusetts Medical School. A Memorial at Hofstra University is planned for Spring 2012.

ECKMAN--Harold (Hal), age 65, resident of Palm Beach, FL and New York City, originally from Manchester NH, died suddenly and too soon December 8, 2011 in Palm Beach Florida. A 1968 graduate of the University Of New Hampshire Whittemore School Of Business, Hal founded Eckman Construction in Bedford, NH, which he co-owned with his wife Amy until 2008, when they sold it to some key employees and retired. Hal was deeply involved in community life, including at various times Board of Directors of The Easter Seal Society of New Hampshire; Chair Easter Seals Telethon; Incorporator of the Catholic Medical Center; Board of Directors, Child Health Services; Board of Directors, Manchester (NH) Chamber of Commerce: Chairman, Economic Development Committee; Chairman, Manchester Airport Access Road Task Force; Chairman, Regional Economic Development Committee; Chair of Bishop of Manchester Summer Reception; Finalist, Entrepreneur of the Year, Ernst & Young/Inc. Magazine/Merrill-Lynch; candidate for U.S. Senate from NH. Deeply devoted to family and community, he leaves behind his wife of 31 years, Amy Kaplan Eckman, two sons: Dan and his wife Meggie of Los Angeles, and Jeff of New York City, as well as his parents, Gwen and George Eckman, of Bedford, NH, two brothers, Larry Eckman and his wife Liz of Amherst, NH and Gerry Eckman and his wife Martha of Hollis and Portsmouth, NH., and many nieces and nephews. An avid golfer, Hal was a member of Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale, NY as well as Banyon Golf Club in West Palm Beach, FL. Services will be held at Temple Adath Yeshurun 152 Prospect Street, Manchester NH at 11am Sunday, December 11, 2011, and the family will have calling hours at the home of Larry and Liz Eckman, on Sunday December 11 from 5-8pm.

PRAKAPAS--Eugene J. December 1, 2011, Bronxville, NY, beloved husband of Dorothy. Born in Lowell, MA '32; BA Yale '53; '53-57 US Navy Lieutenant; MA Oxon Balliol College, Oxford '59 on a Fullbright; Professional: '60-70, Vice President and Editor-in-Chief, Trident Press and Pocket Books Divisions Simon & Schuster; '71-72, studied Ikebana, here and in Japan; '73-76, Co-Director, Carus Gallery, NY; '76, started Prakapas Gallery, NY. '85 authored the forward to Bauhaus photography, MIT Press; '86 Visiting Curator, San Francisco Museum Modern Art. Member Art Dealers Association of America; Association of International Photography Art Dealers. Brilliant, imaginative, innovative, vibrant. He will be hugely missed by his wife and friends. A memorial gathering to be announced. Communications may be directed to: Carey Clark, c/o Dorothy Prakapas, 1 Northgate Apt 6B, Bronxville, NY 10708.

WALETZKY--Tsirl (Cecelia Grobla), 90. Cherished wife of Sholom (deceased), sister of Leona (deceased). Beloved mother of Linda, Josh, and Niel. Banks can do better at protecting their customers from the risk of identity fraud, a new report from Javelin Strategy & Research finds. The firm's annual Banking Identity Safety Scorecard looked at the consumer-security practices of 25 large banks and credit unions. It found that far too many still rely on customers' Social Security numbers for authentication purposes - for instance, to verify a customer's identity when he or she wants to speak to a bank representative over the telephone or re-set a password.

PHILLIPS--C. Gorham (Doc), 90, of Vero Beach, FL, died peacefully on December 8, 2011, of heart failure. Mr. Phillips was the son of Margaret Cook Atwell and Charles Swayne Phillips of Montclair, NJ, where Mr. Phillips was born and resided until his retirement. He attended the Montclair public schools and graduated from Williams College in 1943 where he was president of Phi Beta Kappa and winner of the Dewey Award for excellence. In 1942, he married his high school sweetheart, Martha Belden, and served from 1943 through 1946 in the Army Air Corps. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1948 and established a thriving career at the prominent New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood (now Dewey & LeBoeuf), retiring in 1990 as Chairman of the Management Committee. As a young attorney, he worked closely with Governor Thomas E. Dewey and helped develop some of his firm's most prominent clients, including American Can Company, Sinclair Oil Corporation, and Continental Oil Company. In his final decade at Dewey he worked with his partner, Joseph Califano, and others on the implementation of the long-term strategy that has helped propel Dewey & LeBoeuf to the top rank of international firms. He is survived by his wife and four children: Webster B. Phillips, of Montclair; Charles G. Phillips III, of Manhattan; Tacey P. Carroll, of Bronxville, NY; and Tyler A. Phillips of Sonoma, CA; ten grandchildren; and eight great-grandchildren. In retirement, Mr. Phillips served as Class Agent for the Williams Alumni Fund, winning five consecutive awards for highest participation. He was a skilled public speaker whose presentations always reflected his wonderful sense of humor. His appreciation of humor led him to compile several anthologies of his favorite jokes. He was a trustee of the Montclair Golf Club and the Riomar Club, the Kimberley School, and the Montclair Art Museum, and served on many civic and corporate boards. After his retirement, Mr. Phillips continued his interest in stamp collecting, earned master points in bridge, wrote reminiscences for friends and family, and, with his wife, was an avid traveler. He was a master needle pointer, whose projects included making the cushion that is on the main altar at Westminster Abbey and, with colleagues, the kneeler for the Dean of St. George's Chapel at Windsor Castle. Memorial gifts may be sent to Indian River Medical Center Foundation, 1000 36th St., Vero Beach, FL 32960.

Charlie Weis became known as a prolific recruiter when he was the head coach at Notre Dame, luring highly touted prospects like Michael Floyd, Jimmy Clausen and Manti Te'o to campus. In search of his first big recruiting coup as the new coach at Kansas, Weis may go back to one of his highly regarded prospects at Notre Dame: quarterback Dayne Crist. Two sources with direct knowledge of the situation confirmed that Crist was traveling to Lawrence, Kan., this weekend to discuss reuniting with his former coach, who was announced as the Jayhawks' coach on Thursday. Since Crist is set to graduate from Notre Dame this year, he is eligible to transfer without having to sit out next year. The Chicago Tribune reported Crist's desire to transfer last week. Wherever he goes, Crist will be able to participate in spring practice and play next season.

Credit card agreements are typically something you'd want to read only if you suffered from insomnia. A glance at a few lines of the dense type, printed on filmy paper, is sure to help you drift off. But buried in all that fine print are important provisions that affect you financially. So the federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is proposing a new, simplified form, to help make the agreements more readable and useful to card holders.

8 P.M. (HBO) HALL PASS (2011) Owen Wilson and Jason Sudeikis star as Rick and Fred, middle-aged buddies with the requisite paunches and innocently wandering eyes, suffering from the marriage blahs in this comedy from the Farrelly brothers. Jenna Fischer and Christina Applegate are Maggie and Grace, their exasperated wives, who decide to give their husbands a week's break from fidelity, which the men gleefully accept, heading with a coterie of sidekicks (Stephen Merchant, Larry Joe Campbell and J B Smoove) to hit the singles scene. First stop, Applebee's. And Nicky Whelan is Leigh, the comely barista Rick (Mr. Wilson, above left, with Mr. Sudeikis) can't take his eyes off. ''In 'Hall Pass' the Farrellys are exploring nominally adult realms, like marital fatigue and cheating, but too often these apparent good intentions get the best of them and their timing,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''Mr. Wilson, a naturally amusing screen presence, looks uneasy delivering relationship lines that could have been fed to him by Dr. Phil. He and the big-baby-faced Mr. Sudeikis were born to trade quips and suffer mutual comic humiliation.'' Still, she added, ''the Farrellys aren't the only contemporary filmmakers who have a tough time making marriage funny, even if it is heartening to see them try.'' 8 P.M. (NBC) AMERICAN GIVING AWARDS Bob Costas hosts this special, which rewards charities a share of a $2 million purse, with the winner of the $1 million grand prize determined by online voting before the show.

A ruling is expected in federal court as soon as next week on whether the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff's massive fraud can appeal a decision that would make it difficult to recover potentially hundreds of millions of dollars from the owners of the Mets. The appeal must be approved by United States District Judge Jed S. Rakoff, who in September dismissed nine of the 11 counts filed by the trustee against the Mets' owners. At the time, he ruled that Irving H. Picard, the trustee, had to prove that Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, the Mets' owners, willfully turned a blind eye to indications of possible fraud in Madoff's operation during their years of investing with him. ''Willful blindness'' is a higher legal standard to meet than the one that Picard has argued for. The Mets' owners have denied being aware of any red flags about Madoff.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - He's not even completely grown, but my son has already joined the Emergency Room Frequent Fliers club. There was a time when we were on a first-name basis with many of the nurses at our local hospital's E.R., all of whom thankfully had the good taste and training not to keep bringing up the fact that we spent most of our time there. Those of you who have raised children or been responsible for one for any length of time know what I'm talking about. Children are innocent creatures, filled with wonderment and the joy of experiencing the world for the first time, so it is completely natural for them to get themselves into predicaments that, had they happened to any normal adult, would have gotten that adult an immediate psychiatric evaluation ("Exactly HOW did the vacuum cleaner get stuck on his tongue, Ms. Amlen?")

Anyone admiring David Hume as I do finds much to cheer, but much to lament in the state of academic philosophy, as this year, the 300th anniversary of his birth, comes to a close. Hume was an anatomist of the mind, charting the ways we think and feel - a psychologist or cognitive scientist before his time. The cheering feature of the contemporary scene is that plenty of people are following in those footsteps. The nature versus nurture battle has declared an uneasy draw, but the human nature industry is in fine fettle, fed by many disciplines and eagerly consumed by the public.

ELLIS--Jane Bacon, 76, long-time food editor in New York City at House & Garden, the New York Post and House Beautiful, died peacefully at her home in Litchfield, CT, surrounded by her loving family - husband William and daughters Clare Ellis and Kate Hobsbawm. She is also survived by her beloved grandchildren Milo and Eve Hobsbawm of London and her sister Carol Davis of Dorchester, U.K. She graced everything she touched. She is irreplaceable to her family and her host of friends. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Church in Washington, CT on December 19 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Environmental Working Group (claudia@ewg.org). Burial is private and will take place in Dorchester, U.K.

CRANBERG--Lawrence M.,PhD. Lawrence Cranberg, 94, passed away on November 21, 2011 surrounded by his loving family. Cancer was the cause of death. Lawrence, a true patriot, was born on the 4th of July in 1917 in Bronx, New York, the eldest child of Fanny Rubenstein and Hyman Cranberg Polish and Russian immigrants. Lawrence married Charlotte Mount on October 31, 1953 in New Mexico at the Old Santa Fe Courthouse. A nuclear physicist, inventor and entrepreneur, Dr. Cranberg's career spanned seven decades, but the wonder and beauty of science was always on his mind. After graduating from Townsend Harris High School at age 16, he matriculated from the City College of New York, Harvard University, and The University of Pennsylvania. His career in science began in 1940 at the Signal Corps. Engineering Labs where he was a Senior Physicist. Dr. Cranberg developed systems of target detection and location-based use of infra-red radiation, a precursor technology to today's autofocus cameras. He later joined the Los Alamos National Laboratory where he became a fellow of the Atomic Energy Commission. At Los Alamos, he was a protege of Hans Bethe, and conducted groundbreaking research on high energy neutrons. Dr. Cranberg was appointed to the US delegation to the First International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy at Geneva in 1955 where he reported on his work. Among his many widely-cited publications were papers in The Scientific American and Physics Today. Dr. Cranberg also generously shared his intuitive insights with colleagues; one such insight directly led to the discovery of the neutrino. Dr. Cranberg was elected a Fellow of the American Physical Society in 1958 his nomination made by 1995 Nobelist and neutrino pioneer Frederick Reines and J.M.B. Kellogg. Once introduced as "Mr. Nanosecond" by Sir Denys Wilkinson to a London physics conference, Dr. Cranberg developed the means to measure a billionth of second before "nanotechnology" was a word; his "time-of-flight" method of measuring neutron spectra became the foundation for neutron spectrometry. Following a Guggenheim fellowship in 1962, Dr. Cranberg was instrumental in securing a large federal grant to the University of Virginia to build and to become founding director of its Physics Accelerator Laboratory. He was a devoted scientist and teacher. Thirty years later, one of his grateful graduate students would endow a scholarship and faculty research in his name at George Mason University, remarking that Dr. Cranberg inspired him by exemplifying the work ethic of American scientists. Dr. Cranberg didn't hesitate to fight for justice whether it be the case of his own academic freedom, or his involvement in the lawsuit that eventually forced UVA to accept women into its formerly all-male undergraduate school. In 1971, after winning an AAUP hearing that declared his academic freedom had been invaded, Dr. Cranberg moved to Austin where he joined a small high-tech company, eventually starting his own firm to develop fast-neutron techniques for the treatment of cancer. He was always grateful for the welcome arms of the private sector and of Texas, calling it "The Land of Milk and Honey". In 1975, Dr. Cranberg applied the laws of physics to fire-building and invented the Texas Fireframe grate. Later dubbed "The Physicist's Fire" by Time magazine, his invention was featured in news stories on CBS and BBC. His company is now run by his daughter. An advocate for social causes throughout his life, Dr. Cranberg fought for racial equality in Virginia (he also recruited the first black graduate physics student at UVA), for the freedom of Russian physicist Andrei Sakharov and for scientists and inventors not properly credited for their work. He wrote incisively about topics from the ethical problems of scientists to the pseudoscientific basis of Marxism. Dr. Cranberg's candidacy for the U.S. Senate from Texas was inspired by his desire for science to better inform decisions in and of the law. Dr. Cranberg's capacity for indignation at injustice was matched only by his optimistic belief in his ability to fight for change and to make a difference. Dr. Cranberg was a loving, devoted husband, father and grandfather: his last words were "I'm the richest man in the world." His enthusiasm, generosity, sense of humor and his quest for knowledge, truth, and justice are just a few of the qualities that his family, friends and colleagues will always remember him for. Dr. Cranberg is survived by Charlotte, wife of 58 years; son Alex of Austin, Texas; daughter Nicole and husband Giff Crosby of Cos Cob, Connecticut; and grandchildren Jacob, Hannah and Clare. Other surviving family members include brother, Gilbert Cranberg of Sarasota, Florida and sister, Sylvia Troy of Beverly Shores, Indiana. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorial donations be made to the Niels Bohr Physics Library Center for History of Physics: https://donate.aip.org/ Please type "In Honor of Lawrence Cranberg" in the comments box. A memorial service will be held by the family at a later date. To share memories, please visit http://texasfireframe.com/ fireplace-grate-blog/ 2011/11/24/remembering-lawrence-cranberg/

PALLY--Caryn Katkin, passed away December 8th at age 56. She is survived by husband Steven, children Adam, Erica and Risa, mother Sylvia and sister, Beth. Services and burial were Friday, December 9th; the family will sit Shiva at 33 North Hillside Avenue, Livingston, NJ through Wednesday night, December 14th. Caryn was a daughter, sister, wife, mother and friend of extraordinary measure. She graced this earth with her love and beauty for far too few years. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

4:55 p.m. | Updated California has the worst air quality in the country, according to the state's air resources board, and 40 percent of the contributing pollution comes from passenger cars and light-duty trucks. In its effort to improve the state's air, the board, commonly known as CARB, proposed a package of new rules on Wednesday intended to cut vehicle emissions while aggressively increasing the number of advanced clean cars on the state's roads, as well as fueling stations to serve them.
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel speaks to travel experts from the world of academia and gleans lessons useful for the average traveler.

An article last Sunday about cities that are affected by Congressional redistricting, leading local officials to fear they will lose clout in Washington, misstated the number of districts that the city of Austin was to have been divided into under legislation passed by the Texas Legislature earlier this year. That redistricting plan, which has since been halted by the courts, calls for dividing Austin into six Congressional districts, not into four.
''Perhaps a few of us thought that after German unification there would not be so much more to do.We were wrong there.'' Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, as the European debt crisis continued.

DUNHAM--Peter, 90, of Southbury, CT and formerly of New Canaan, CT, passed away peacefully December 7. A Harvard grad, Peter served as a navigator during WWII flying B-17s over Europe. He spent his advertising career at J. Walter Thompson. Pistol Pete is survived by his wife, Patricia, his children, Pamela and Peter and his grandchildren, Amanda and Peter. He was a first rate human being and will be greatly missed.

SIEGEL--Ruth. We are very saddened by the recent death of Ruth Leff Siegel. Ruth and her husband, Jerome Siegel, were kind and generous donors to Columbia University Medical Center, including the Division of Rheumatology, where they established the first Advanced Fellowship program. Mrs. Siegel also served as a long-standing member of the Health Sciences Advisory Council. Our deepest sympathies to her family on their great loss. Lee Goldman, M. D. Executive Vice President & Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Joan M. Bathon, M.D., Professor of Medicine & Chief, Division of Rheumatology Ralph S. Blume, M.D., Clinical Professor of Medicine

SCHUMANN--Robert Ford, born July 25, 1921, in Montclair, NJ, son of Florence Ford and John J. Schumann, Jr., former President and Chairman of GMAC, died peacefully on December 8, 2011. He was 90 years old. He attended public schools and Montclair Academy before attending Governor Dummer Academy in the class of 1940. He received his B. A. degree from Wesleyan University in 1944 and later an honorary Doctorate of Humane Letters. After working for United Airlines and two Buick dealerships, he obtained his own dealership in Binghamton, NY, known as Schumann Buick in 1949, later known as Schumann-Van Atta Buick. He served on the Board of Columbia Mutual Life Insurance for many years and also on the Advisory Board of the Lincoln-First Bank. A fifty-year resident of Binghamton, he was involved with many charities including Broome County United Way as President and Vice Chair of Campaigns. He served on the Advisory Board of Lourdes Hospital, was the first President of the Broome County Zoological Society, was on the Board of Roberson Museum of Arts and Science, and also on the Roberson Foundation Board. He spent every summer of his life and the last 10 years at his family's home in Madison, Connecticut. In Connecticut he served on the Board of the Florence Griswold Museum and Bob was one of the early supporters and members of the citizens' group that formed in 2001, which over nine years crusaded successfully to protect the land of the old Griswold airport in Madison from development. A passionate birder from childhood, Schumann spent many hours in quiet observation of birds, their habits and their habitats, and especially loved their songs. He served for many years on the Boards of the National Audubon Society and the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology. He served on the board and was President of the Schumann Foundation, headquartered in Montclair, NJ, which was created by his parents in 1962. It is now known as The Schumann Media Center and is headed by Bill Moyers. In honor of his length of service, the Foundation established a Chair at Wesleyan University known as The Robert Schumann Environmental Studies Program. He is survived by his wife Marilyn Hotchkiss Schumann and their combined families, to whom he was a loving husband, father and grandfather: their sons Robert Ford Schumann, Jr., David Dickinson Schumann, and Edgar James Hotchkiss, and their daughters Mary James Schumann Hurley, Lola Ford Schumann, Carol Hotchkiss Potts, Linda Hotchkiss, and Barbara Hotchkiss. He is also survived by seven grandchildren: Timothy Chad Hotchkiss, Brook Schumann, Robin Ford Schumann, Tague Webster Hurley, Robert Ford Hurley, Eliza Hope Hotchkiss-Yager and Judah Briggs Thissell, and two great-granddaughters; and by his brother Ward Ford Schumann, of Aspen, Colorado. He leaves behind many friends and admirers who will forever miss his kindness and generosity, and his standards of commitment to the values he strongly believed in. A memorial service will be held at the First Congregational Church of Madison, 26 Meetinghouse Lane, Madison, CT 06443, on December 16 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in his name to the charity of your choice.
From the number of golden retrievers on ski patrolto the price of a New England ski pass,taking the measure of ski country, from coast to coast.

A picture with an opinion essay on Dec. 4 about privatized food services in public schools was published in error. It showed students eating at Gates Chili Middle School in Rochester, but the school has not privatized or outsourced its cafeteria operations.
Television Neil Genzlinger

THE film ''Breakfast at Tiffany's'' spawned many iconic items. The little black dress. The oversized sunglasses. The wide-brimmed black straw hat. Now, as the movie celebrates its 50th anniversary, the familiar town house at 169 East 71st Street where Holly Golightly lived and hosted her wild cocktail parties has gone on the market for $5.85 million.

Ayrton Senna, the Brazilian who was a three-time Formula One world champion, died on the track in 1994, but his aura is never too far away from the sport. The recent release of the well-received ''Senna'' documentary has generated increased interest and perhaps provided the impetus for the re-release of ''Memories of Senna'' by Christopher Hilton. The book, first published in 2003, is essentially an oral history of Senna's career, culled from 120 people who knew him and raced against him. Their voices piece together a mosaic that's enjoyable for its nuance. There are plenty of boilerplate recollections of Senna's talent, religious faith, intellect and professionalism (during an age of the playboy racecar driver). But Senna's singular skill, as identified by race engineers and teammates, was his superior concentration and memory.

DELLALE--Dina, died at home on October 9, 2011. Her generosity and wisdom made her a pivotal force in the lives of her family and her many friends. An accomplished diplomat and negotiator, she was the International Representative of the Costa Rican Sugar Industry. In 1974 she became the first woman Chairman of the International Sugar Organization. She founded ASFAMEX, an association of U.S. and Costa Rican textile manufacturers, for which she served as Managing Director. She is survived by her two nephews, Beriot and Robert Dellale. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated on Thursday, December 15 at 11am at The Church of Saint Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue (at 66th Street), New York.

MIAMI BEACH THE first public sighting of Eli Broad, the 78-year-old billionaire philanthropist and art collector, came at 10:30 on a Wednesday morning. Quietly navigating the aisles of the Art Basel Miami Beach fair, with others in the early-admission V.I.P. crowd, he moved quietly and with single-minded determination, a shark in a blue blazer with a curator beside him like a remora along for the ride.

Texans (9-3) at Bengals (7-5) Sunday, 1 p.m. Line: Bengals by 3 After a high-scoring early season, N.F.L. offenses have entered a period of market correction. Points per team have leveled off at 21.9 per game, right in line with five-year averages. But those numbers are buoyed by the 10 percenters: the Packers, the Saints and the Patriots can still count on yields of over 30 points a game. Everyone else is tightening belts, and no team exemplifies the best way to survive the downturn like the Texans, former members of the jet set who have learned to get by on a strict 17-to-20 point weekly budget. The Texans live comfortably with third-string quarterback T.--J. Yates the same way the Broncos have thrived during the Tim Tebow experiment and the 49ers have made peace with the Alex Smith enigma: they avoid turnovers, pass judiciously if not always successfully and treat punts as opportunities for the defense, not as failures. It is not optimal football strategy, but it is better than going into denial like the Colts, the Bears and the Eagles, who pretend everything is status quo while backup quarterbacks stagger beneath oversized expectations. Risk-averse investments make great short-term strategies, and with the Texans poised to win their first division title with a victory and a Titans loss, their conservative offense will pay all of the dividends they really need. Pick: Texans

SPROTT--Eoin, on December 3, 2011 at his home in Sag Harbor. He was 77. ''Definitive'' is an ambitious goal, but one this hefty book tackles with élan -- perhaps the way a 1965 Gordon-Keeble might tackle a winding country road. I'd never heard of a Gordon-Keeble until I picked up ''Car,'' but there it is, parked among the hundreds of automobiles, both well loved and obscure, in this volume. They range from the primitive Grenville Steam Carriage of 1880 to the futuristic Alfa Romeo/Bertone Pandion of 2010, and readers will be hard-pressed to think of a make or model that isn't here, or at least represented by a close relative.

As a travel writer for a luxury magazine, I get to sleep in exotic locations on top of memory-foam mattresses with 800-thread-count sheets. It is a major indulgence, since for most of my childhood and my early teens, I slept on the floor on wet sheets and a rubber mat. I grew up in the 1980s in a town called Garividi, on the eastern coast of India. Garividi was slightly more advanced than a village because it had an iron ore factory, but it didn't have pharmacies selling Pull-Ups or doctors providing medication for chronic bed-wetters like me. And so, four to five nights a week, until high school, I woke up with a wet blanket under me and guilt over my head.
BRODY--Barbara, 102. Greatly beloved mother of Maris and Van (Arlynn), grandmother and great-grandmother. Exceptional in spirit, music, art and kindness.

FOR more than a decade, Autumn de Wilde has been one of indie rock's go-to portraitists. ''The people who didn't love being photographed -- word got around that I made it easier on them,'' said Ms. de Wilde, a Los Angeles photographer who has captured more unlikely stars than the Hubble Space Telescope, including Wilco, Death Cab for Cutie and the Decemberists. Her photographs and music videos don't sport an identifying visual stamp so much as a disquieting intimacy. They also tend to avoid two clichés of music portraiture: cool detachment and oddball energy. That much, at least, is evident in Ms. de Wilde's portraits of the art-pop chameleon Beck Hansen, which are collected in her latest book, ''Beck'' (Chronicle, $35). The volume stretches across their 16-year friendship. One reason Beck, above, is such a successful subject, Ms. de Wilde said, is his ability to darken playful scenarios with a touch of menace, like Bill Murray. And her own success? ''I'm able to make things colorful without making them sickeningly sweet.'' JONATHAN L. FISCHER

LANDOVER, Md. -- As Navy players on the sidelines hopped up and down, pleading for even more noise, sections filled with Midshipmen from the United States Naval Academy yelled for a big and late fourth-down stop, which Navy had not had to do much in the last decade against Army. Army quarterback Trent Steelman took the snap, turned to his right and was bear-hugged by linebacker Matt Warrick, who slammed him to the rutted turf. Steelman lost a yard, and the Black Knights lost again to Navy, this time by 27-21 on Saturday.

Two of the four pictures with the Surfacing column on Nov. 27, about the revival of downtown Beirut, were reversed. The restaurant Mybar was at the top and another restaurant, Momo at the Souks, was in the center, at far left.

FOR the last few days I've been in London on assignment, staying at the Portobello Hotel, where -- my friend Tim Blanks tells me -- he used to visit Nico in the '70s. ''It may have been the first boutique hotel in London,'' he said, recalling that the front-desk man in the Nico era wore a cropped Vivienne Westwood top with feather trim. To me, the Portobello, in Notting Hill, is actually the un-boutique hotel. It doesn't charge for Wi-Fi, and you can get porridge any time you want it. Somebody in the management thought to add a small carton of milk to the familiar bottles in the mini bar (with a cereal bowl in the cupboard). In other words, the hotel gives you exactly what you need, and doesn't try to be stylish or hip. It just is.

HEISLER--Edgar, W.,passed away at age 91 on December 6, 2011 with family members at his side. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Joan to whom he had been married for 48 years. He is survived by his cherished wife Jean with whom he shared 16 wonderful years of marriage in the twilight of his life. He leaves his much-loved children: daughters Patti (Chris), Janny (Michael), Laurie (Earnie); sons: David (Carol), Jeff (Panda) and step- daughters Nancy (Gary) and Janice (Rob); his adored grandchildren Erica, Melissa, Mark, Katie, William, Elizabeth, Joe and Katie, great-grandchildren Emily and Maggie, nieces, nephews and dear friends. He retired from Chase Manhattan Bank in 1985 after over 40 years of service, during which he represented the bank as a long-time member of the Yorkville Lions Club. He lived in Westbury, NY for 61 years and was deeply involved in his community and the Church of the Advent. He was a Veteran of World War II, having served proudly as a member of the U.S. Navy. His was a life well lived, and he will never be forgotten by those whose lives he touched. In lieu of flowers , please consider a donation to the National Kidney Foundation. Funeral services at: www.donohue-cecere.com

DUNN--Patricia C.,Climbed from an entry-level position as a secretarial assistant to become the Chief Executive Officer of San Francisco-based Barclays Global Investors (BGI) as it developed into the world's largest institutional money manager and subsequently served as the Non-Executive Chairman of the largest information technology company in the world, died on Sunday morning December 4th at her home in Orinda, CA. She was 58. The cause was ovarian cancer, according to William Jahnke, her husband of 30 years. Dunn was diagnosed with three different types of cancer over a three-year span starting in 2002, but remained active in various philanthropic causes until recently. Dunn's ascent in the investment and information technology worlds was remarkable; academically all she had was a degree in journalism from the University of California, Berkeley - no degree in business, economics, finance, engineering, or any other hard science. Her success in the professional and private life was due in part to her generous and gracious manner, her personal magnetism and the respectful manner in which she conducted her life. In 2006 Dunn found herself at the center of a media firestorm regarding an investigation by Hewlett-Packard to find the source of leaks to the press. Although the company later acknowledged she did not authorize, direct, or conduct the investigation she was asked to resign from the board because her continued presence had become a distraction given the attention to the matter by the media. Dunn graciously complied mounting an aggressive defense, which included testifying on Capitol Hill and, after being charged with four felonies, an appearance on 60 Minutes. All charges were later dropped in "the interest of justice" by a California Superior Court Judge before a scheduled preliminary hearing was held. Not only was the case against Dunn weak, there was evidence Dunn had been scapegoated. Dunn, a national merit scholar, attended the University of Oregon. She transferred to the University of California, Berkeley, graduating in 1975 with a degree in journalism. After being name CEO of Barclay's Global Advisors in 1998 she debuted at No. 11 on Fortune magazine's annual list of the most powerful women in business. At the height of media attention to the HP leak investigation story, the Bay Area Business Counsel inducted Dunn into its Hall of Fame for her contributions to the business community and philanthropic causes. At the time Dunn was the youngest recipient of the award and the only woman to be individually inducted in the Council's 64-year history. Dunn, who was legendarily even-tempered, collaborative and focused in her business dealings, was equally tenacious as a cancer patient. By some accounts, she underwent more chemotherapy at the University of California San Francisco Medical Center than anyone else in the institution's history, outliving the three-year life expectancy for her type of ovarian cancer by nearly five years. Dunn and her husband endowed a chair at UCSF's Department of Surgery and also funded clinical trials of an ovarian cancer immunotherapy at the University of Pennsylvania in which, in some cases, she participated. Besides her husband Bill Jahnke, who is a former chief executive of Wells Fargo Investment Advisers, Dunn is survived by two daughters, Janai Brengman and Michelle Cox, a son, Michael Jahnke, and ten grandchildren, as well as a brother, Paul Dunn, and a sister, Debbie Lammers and her husband Chris, along with their children Paul Dunn, Jr. and Laura, Stephen and Kelly Lammers. (Additional information regarding Dunn's life will be found on her website www.PattieDunn.com).

GAIA, the ancient Greek earth goddess, is being sold to the highest bidder -- for a good cause. Gaia & Gino, the Turkish home-accessories company, has collaborated with the New York designer Harry Allen and Swarovski Elements on ''The Goddess Adorned,'' an auction of 15 of Mr. Allen's limited-edition Gaia vases. The shapely vases, customized by style glitterati like Ashley and Mary-Kate Olsen for Elizabeth and James, Kenneth Jay Lane and Mr. Allen himself, are being auctioned online until Dec. 20 to benefit Housing Works; they are on view at the Swarovski Crystallized concept store, 499 Broadway (Broome Street) in SoHo. Mr. Allen said he would fill his vase, ''The Black Swan,'' right, with dark flowers like aubergine sweet peas or chocolate cosmos, because ''every ballerina needs a dramatic headdress.'' PILAR VILADAS

DWORSKY--David, died on December 7, 2011 at his home in New York City. He was 71 years old, and lost his battle with ALS. He was a New York Times financial reporter after graduation from Rider University in 1962 until 1967 when he moved into the field of public relations, and later became an SVP with Burson Marsteller. David saw the world through the eyes of a journalist. He recently compled his novel "Master Mac". He loved being on his boat the "Just Write" off the waters of Sandy Hook, NJ. David is survived by and will always be loved and missed by his wife of 49 years, the former Sherry Kaplan and his children Rachael Anne and Peter Isaac and his grandchildren, Eric, Amy and Lyndzie. Services were held on December 9, 2011. Donations may be made in his memory to: The Transition Network, P.O. Box 231240, Ansonia Station, New York, New York, 10023.

A Utah ski lift proposed last month could be the first step in a decades-old vision of interconnecting seven Wasatch Mountain ski resorts near Salt Lake City and creating a European-style valley-to-valley ski experience in North America. The owner of Canyons near Park City wants to build a nearly two-mile-long gondola that would reach over the Wasatch Crest to the base of Solitude Mountain Resort in Big Cottonwood Canyon. Carrying 1,000 people an hour, the gondola would take 11 minutes and connect 6,000 acres of skiing.

From tribesmen to billionaire philanthropists, the social value of generosity is already well known. But new research suggests it also matters much more intimately than we imagined, even down to our most personal relationships. Researchers from the University of Virginia's National Marriage Project recently studied the role of generosity in the marriages of 2,870 men and women. Generosity was defined as ''the virtue of giving good things to one's spouse freely and abundantly'' -- like simply making them coffee in the morning -- and researchers quizzed men and women on how often they behaved generously toward their partners. How often did they express affection? How willing were they to forgive?

Outerwear moved onto center stage with last week's blast of wintry weather. The cloth coat, swathed in fake or real fur, was a standout. One of the most elegant holiday displays, without a scrap of green or red, is the 1913 facade of 597 Fifth Avenue at 48th Street, spectacular laser cutouts suggesting the delicate lace curtains of Fifth Avenue mansions of an earlier age. The insets, where the side doors should be, are vintage coats, lavishly trimmed in fur and welcome departures from the signature solid black of the city.

A day after Newt Gingrich made comments implying that he opposed a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, provoking wide criticism, his campaign tried to carry out some damage control. Mr. Gingrich told a Jewish television channel that Palestinians historically were an ''invented'' people and that the Palestinian leadership sought to destroy Israel. The statements suggested that Mr. Gingrich did not agree with long-standing American and Israeli policy in favor of negotiating an independent and peaceful Palestinian state alongside Israel.

Americans usually associate Volkswagen vans with hippies and camping. But in Europe, much of Latin America and other parts of the world, the vans are ubiquitous, and over five generations (since 1949), they have fulfilled a multitude of tasks, including some quite improbable ones. The authors of both of these British books apparently assume that their readers are Volkswagen van collectors. Despite that, and to varying degrees, these volumes may also interest present and past VW van owners who are curious about their vehicles' history.

AZZEDINE ALAÏA has never obeyed the fashion calendar and shows his lines only when he -- and his clothes -- are good and ready. In fact, in recent years the designer, who is now in his 70s, has probably had as many runway presentations as museum exhibitions, including the one that opens today at the Groninger Museum in the Netherlands. ''Azzedine Alaïa in the 21st Century'' focuses solely on his output from roughly the past decade, and yet there is more substance there than many designers could hope to achieve in a lifetime, including the fierce tailcoat at left and a toothsome evening dress with a zipper that spirals suggestively around the body from the neck to the floor. The exhibition runs until May 6; groningermuseum.nl. ALIX BROWNE

In last week's Big City column, Ginia Bellafante wrote about a major waterfront development project on Staten Island's North Shore, asking whether it could help attract young people to the borough, as similar initiatives have helped revitalize other New York neighborhoods. I am a 24 year old living on Staten Island (born and raised); college educated and have worked on the island for a while. After a brief move to Williamsburg, I returned to Staten Island and will likely remain here. I am an artist and often frequent ETG, Deep Tanks, the Full Cup and other contemporary arts galleries, shows and venues.

Stevens Pass, a snow-smothered ski area 78 miles east of Seattle that is beloved by Northwesterners, was sold last month. It wasn't big news, unless you noticed the buyer: CNL Lifestyle Properties. Stevens Pass is the 17th ski resort in which CNL Lifestyle Properties has full ownership or is a major investor. This Orlando-based company has in the last decade quietly surpassed the giants Vail Resorts and Intrawest to become the largest owner of ski resorts in the nation. Often, CNL buys the properties and then leases them back to the former owners. Its resorts include marquee names like Crested Butte Mountain Resort in Colorado, Sunday River and Sugarloaf in Maine and Northstar California and Sierra at Tahoe in California. Last year nearly one in 10 visits to ski areas nationwide was to a CNL Lifestyle Properties mountain.

The ill-fated 1948 Tucker Torpedo wasn't the first automobile with a rear-mounted engine, automatic transmission or three headlamps, and Preston Tucker wasn't the first entrepreneur to try to beat the industry giants. Automotive history is rich with David-vs.-Goliath stories of clever inventors and brash start-ups battling the odds to get their ideas into production. Some of these ventures succeeded, and some, like Tucker's, ultimately failed.

It's absurd when you think about it: photography for radio. Yet radio networks need advertisers. To claim advertisers, they need listeners. To lure listeners, they need publicity. Where? In newspapers and magazines, which are hungry for pictures, especially free pictures. (Of celebrities, preferably, but pretty young women will also do.)

Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy). At the risk of being struck down from the heavens, we're here to say that we're down on Tim Tebow (DEN vs. Chicago) in Week 14. One reason is that Tebow's legs might not be able to save him against the Bears' sixth-ranked run defense. Chicago has held opposing teams' ground games to just under 100 yards a game this season. The Bears' pass defense is also better than you might think. If you take away the major beat-downs from Aaron Rodgers, Drew Brees and Cam Newton this season, the Bears are coughing up just 12 fantasy points on average to opposing quarterbacks. Thus, Tebow is among our unfavorable matchup picks for Week 14.

RIPPIN--John E.,age 62, Dayton, Ohio, died November 21, 2011. Born December 26, 1948, John studied at Cleveland Institute of Music, graduated from Case Western Reserve University, and attended Manhattan School of Music for graduate studies. During his career, he was a pianist for American Ballet Theatre and Joffrey Ballet School in New York; Les Grandes Ballets Canadiens in Montreal, Canada; the Dayton Ballet, John Rodriquez School of Ballet, Wright State University, Pontecorvo Ballet Studios, Ballet de Jeunesse, and Dayton Contemporary Dance Company in Dayton, Ohio, among many other studios. He also had his own piano studio and taught many students in and around the Dayton, Ohio area. John was active in musical theater as both a performer and music director for many years. He also designed a comprehensive, comparative Western Civilization arts history course, which he taught as an Immersion Class at The Miami Valley School. Preceded in death by his mother, Mary Jo Rippin, and brother, Richard Rippin. Survived by his father, James F. Rippin, loving friends, Blake Senseman and Dianne Suiter, and many other dear friends. A celebration of John's life will take place on December 11, 2011 from 2:00-4:00pm at 270 Orchard Hill Dr., West Carrollton, Ohio. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Foundation for AIDS Research, 120 Wall St., 13th Floor, NY 10005-3902. John's talent and love for all of the arts, as well as his deep empathy for people, have left an unforgettable gift for many whose life he touched. Services in care of Newcomer Funeral Home (Kettering, Ohio). To send the family a condolence online, please visit: www.NewcomerDayton.com.

The ski industry is looking to nurture the next generation of downhillers with new attractions for the toddler set and older. In California, Mammoth Mountain recently started offering day care for ages 3 and up that includes optional snowboard lessons that allow children to slide on gentle terrain groomed with snow humps that start and stop momentum. Sessions last no more than 90 minutes in groups of three or fewer per instructor.

COSENTINO--John Arthur, died peacefully at his Manhattan home on December 9, 2011. John was born on November 25, 1922, the son of Charles and Ethel Buckley Clark Cosentino. He grew up in Clifton, NJ, graduated from Montclair Academy in 1940, and was a member of the Harvard College Class of 1944, graduating in 1946 after a WWII tour of domestic duty in the United States Army. He married Josephine Batchelder in 1947 and their sons John Arthur Jr. and Paul Batchelder were born in 1949 and 1953. John's entire working career was spent managing the family textile business in Paterson, NJ, keeping it alive and prosperous long after much of the American textile industry had either failed or moved offshore. He and his wife raised the family in Montclair, NJ. He was a champion skeet shooter, a middle handicap golfer at the Montclair Golf Club, a skilled poker player, an opera lover, a voracious reader, and, led by his wife, a frequent European traveler. More importantly, he was a loving and dedicated - and beloved - husband, father, and friend. He was particularly active with and loyal to Harvard, president of various alumni organizations, interviewing applicants and recruiting athletes for decades, and following Harvard athletics. He was happy and proud that his sons and granddaughter, Jessica, were able to follow in his Harvard footsteps. John was predeceased by his grandson, Willy, in 1996 and by his wife of 54 years, Jo, in 2001. He is survived by his sons and daughters-in-law, John and Deborah and Paul and Anne Hays, his grandchildren, Jessica (Orthman), Trent, Joshua and Matthew, his brother-in-law, Harry Batchelder, his dear friend, Elizabeth Wolf, and by innumerable friends and former colleagues. John Cosentino was a wonderful man. We'll have a small, private celebration of his life in the near future and he will be in our hearts forever.

Marielle Anzelone, a botanist and urban ecologist who founded NYC Wildflower Week, has been reporting from a patch of forest in Inwood Hill Park in Upper Manhattan once a week since the first day of autumn, Sept. 23. In her last dispatch, she recorded evidence of insect life. Read the full series at nytimes.com/cityroom. A heavy mist shrouds the park on Monday, knitting together the gaps left behind by fallen leaves and restoring our site's earlier intimacy. The forest appears two-dimensional today. The trees are veiled and ghostly.

So many books have been written about the Ford Mustang and the Chevrolet Camaro that devoted readers may wonder if the same information is being exhumed over and over. In the case of two new books on these well-covered subjects, it turns out that readers are, in fact, being presented repackaged material. In ''Camaro: Five Generations of Performance,'' Darwin Holmstrom is updating his 2007 book that covered the Camaro's first four generations. Mr. Holmstrom's writing is heavily weighted toward the Camaro's early years. Camaros of the 1960s, for instance, get nearly half of the 348 pages, while the fifth generation gets barely 15 pages, many of them devoted to really large photographs. (For a more comprehensive treatment of the fifth-gen car, Tom Peters, Camaro's design chief, recommends Larry Edsall's ''Camaro: A Legend Reborn,'' published by Motorbooks in 2009.)

Because of an editing error, a report in the Around the Nation college football notebook in some editions on Nov. 20 described incorrectly the role of Florida quarterback John Brantley in a play that led to a safety in his team's 54-32 victory over Furman the previous day. A botched snap went over his head and into the end zone; Brantley did not botch the snap.

Because of an editing error, a review on Nov. 20 about ''Inferno:The World at War, 1939-1945,'' by Max Hastings, misspelled the given name of an American general who the author argues was more capable than MacArthur. He was Lucian Truscott, not Lucien.

MIDDLETON--T. Michael Passed away at the age of 77. He was the loving husband of Joan Perkinson Middleton, with whom he shared 48 years of marriage. He was father to Thomas M. Middleton, III of Hingham, MA and Leslie S. Gilvar, of Plano, TX and "Papa" to seven grandchildren. He is survived by his two sisters, Mary Gould of New York and Katherine Brock, of Madison, WI. Mike attended Wooster School in Danbury, CT, and graduated from Yale University in 1956. He received his MBA from Harvard Business School after serving as an officer in the US Navy. Mike founded his investment firm, Middleton & Company in 1984. He was on many boards and committees during his life, including the Mount Pleasant Home, The Children's Museum, the Boston Security Analyst Society, Mass College of Pharmacy, the South Shore Conservatory of Music, and the Trustees of Reservations. SOLLITTO--Richard Alan M.D.,died after a short illness on November 26, 2011. Richard was raised in New Jersey and graduated Summa Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Colgate University then received his M.D. from the University of Pennsylvania. After completing his internship in Internal Medicine at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia, Richard came to San Francisco in 1979 to study Radiology and Nuclear Medicine at the University of California San Francisco. In 1983 he was hired as a faculty member in the Department of Radiology where he remained until his recent retirement as a Clinical Professor. Richard enjoyed a robust and successful 28 year career at UCSF highlighted by numerous leadership positions including Chief Resident of Nuclear Medicine, Chief of Radiology in the Ambulatory Care Clinics and Mount Zion campuses and Associate Chair of the UCSF Department of Radiology. He was a deeply trusted, highly respected colleague, mentor and close friend to many. Richard was a founding board member and President of the Margulis Society which benefits Radiology Resident and Fellow training, where he spent countless hours promoting and fund raising and where he had a phenomenal rapport with the students. Richard also found time to give back to the community that he embraced including board positions with Community Hospice Foundation of the Bay Area and the Upper Market Community Benefit District. He was also a member of the general committee of the Columbus Day celebration of San Francisco for several years and a supporter of the San Francisco Opera. Richard's warmth, kind smile, gregarious personality and keen intellect will be missed by many who loved him dearly and all of whom were better for having known him. He is survived by his siblings Dr. Ronald Sollitto, Dr. Robert Sollitto, Dr. Andrea Lynn Sollitto and their families along with his mother Amelia. Private Services. Donations suggested in Richard's memory may be made to the Margulis Society, c/o UCSF Foundation, Box 45339, San Francisco, California 94145-0339.

ECKMAN--Harold (Hal), age 65, resident of Palm Beach, FL and New York City, originally from Manchester NH, died suddenly and too soon December 8, 2011 in Palm Beach Florida. A 1968 graduate of the University Of New Hampshire Whittemore School Of Business, Hal founded Eckman Construction in Bedford, NH, which he co-owned with his wife Amy until 2008, when they sold it to some key employees and retired. Hal was deeply involved in community life, including at various times Board of Directors of The Easter Seal Society of New Hampshire; Chair Easter Seals Telethon; Incorporator of the Catholic Medical Center; Board of Directors, Child Health Services; Board of Directors, Manchester (NH) Chamber of Commerce: Chairman, Economic Development Committee; Chairman, Manchester Airport Access Road Task Force; Chairman, Regional Economic Development Committee; Chair of Bishop of Manchester Summer Reception; Finalist, Entrepreneur of the Year, Ernst & Young/Inc. Magazine/Merrill-Lynch; candidate for U.S. Senate from NH. Deeply devoted to family and community, he leaves behind his wife of 31 years, Amy Kaplan Eckman, two sons: Dan and his wife Meggie of Los Angeles, and Jeff of New York City, as well as his parents, Gwen and George Eckman, of Bedford, NH, two brothers, Larry Eckman and his wife Liz of Amherst, NH and Gerry Eckman and his wife Martha of Hollis and Portsmouth, NH., and many nieces and nephews. An avid golfer, Hal was a member of Quaker Ridge Golf Club in Scarsdale, NY as well as Banyon Golf Club in West Palm Beach, FL. Services will be held at Temple Adath Yeshurun 152 Prospect Street, Manchester NH at 11am Sunday, December 11, 2011, and the family will have calling hours at the home of Larry and Liz Eckman, on Sunday December 11 from 5-8pm.

A five-bedroom penthouse at the Laureate, a new condominium at Broadway and 76th Street, was the biggest sale of the week, going for $9.79 million, according to city records. Emulating the success of 15 Central Park West, theRobert A. M. Stern building a few blocks away, the Laureate is nearly sold out, and some apartments have commanded more than $3,000 per square foot. Which seems to support the thesis that when it comes to luxury living, retro is all the rage on the Upper West Side.

The gleaming Manhattan skyline rising over the Hudson River is about as real as a stage prop to Cruz, Emilio and their friends. They can see this illusory panorama from their wind-swept perch - a collection of shacks tucked along cliffs in Union City, N.J. In 2008, Ester Jove Soligue, 32, a Spanish photographer, began documenting this improvised neighborhood just inland from Weehawken Cove. She had been studying at the International Center of Photography, and had recently moved to Union City. A neighbor who had grown up in town told her about the encampment, which had been there for decades, and took her there.

This week marks the last sessions of my Yale law school class on law, liberalism and religion. In the course of the semester my students have learned how to read religion clause cases against the background of long-standing debates in philosophy and theology about the relationship between religious imperatives and the obligations of democratic citizenship. They have become adept at recognizing the arguments behind the arguments the justices are making explicitly. They can see how a case ostensibly about vouchers or school prayer or Christmas trees on courthouse steps is really about whether principle or history should inform a court's decisions. They can see how a case about head coverings or beards in the military (a topic that has surfaced once again) turns on the distinctions set down in John Locke's "Letter Concerning Toleration" (1689), a tract the justices may never have read. They can see how the majority and dissenting opinions in a free exercise case often reflect a tension between negative and positive liberty as these terms are defined by Isaiah Berlin, an author the justices will likely not have referenced. They can see how the entire history of religion-clause jurisprudence at once illustrates and is an extended critique of John Rawls's attempt in "Political Liberalism" to devise a form of government that will be fair to religion while at the same time keeping it at arm's length.

HONG KONG - China hosts some 300 million microblog accounts (including my own), and officials say that domestic social media put out more than 200 million posts every day. In hopes of getting a handle on this potentially threatening surge of information, the government has started a campaign that aims to quash what it calls "rumors" - statements that it says threaten the public order but that it has not bothered to define. After a series of public opinion disasters this past year, the Communist Party has been pressuring social media providers to weed out allegations it finds threatening, and state media have tried to whip up fear over their malignant social effects.The party's fever over rumors began in August, following the July 23 high-speed rail collision in Wenzhou. The government took a public opinion beating over the crash, in large part because social media harnessed anger over the bungled rescue effort, the safety of the high-speed rail network and corruption in the Railways Ministry. Once party leaders wrested back control of the story, they pushed all relevant facts into the darkness, leaving only rumors to sate the public's appetite for the truth. And this summer two other embarrassing public opinion defeats for China's leadership originally took off on the Internet: the Guo Meimei affair, which exposed irregularities at the government-run Red Cross Society of China, and the massive and well-organized public demonstrations against a chemical project in Dalian.

For nearly three weeks now, the Indian Parliament has resembled a patient in a coma, its faculties frozen, its strength ebbing, with no flickers of consciousness at all. The doctors profess themselves flummoxed. No business has been transacted in the winter session of the upper and lower houses at all; instead, the opposition has substituted debate with stubborn rabble-rousing, while the government has flailed weakly against a phalanx of internal crises.One news report has estimated that the time lost by disruptions and adjournments has already cost the taxpayer more than Rs 250 million. Improbably, this paralysis has even prompted a member of Parliament - Shashi Tharoor, in an article for Tehelka - to propose doing away with his own institution, a public gesture of limp-handed helplessness if there ever was one.

Even early in Z-100's Jingle Ball on Friday night, when the girl-screams at Madison Square Garden were not yet full-blooded, Elvis Duran, the Z-100 D.J. and the evening's principal M.C., looked like a cat who had swallowed an eagle. He was sitting on an apotheosis, something that made Jingle Ball seem like much more than a promotional orgy for Top 40 radio and its advertisers, a place for pop acts to ram home their hits between screened advertisements for Splat hair color and Sweethearts Jewelry. He had Lady Gaga, whom he called ''our favorite woman on the planet,'' as the evening's headliner. He related Lady Gaga's Jingle Ball story, which is that her mom had taken her to the concert when she was a child. (On Friday, Lady Gaga herself said she was 11 at the time; earlier reports of the same story said she was 12.) It was her first concert. Not only that: the girl then known as Stefani Germanotta turned to her mother, Cynthia, and said, ''I want to be a singer.''
