As much as it pains me to say this: privacy is on its deathbed. I came to this sad realization recently when a stranger began leaving comments on photos I had uploaded to Instagram, the iPhone photo-sharing app. After several comments - all of which were nice - I began wondering who this person was. Now the catch here is that she had used only a first name on her Instagram profile. You would think a first name online is enough to conceal your identity.

GOLDSTEIN--Mildred, on December 11, 2011, at the age of 96. Loving and beloved, feisty, curious, engaged to the very end of her days. A lifelong, enthusiastic New Yorker, Mildred loved Central Park, the arts, travel, and most of all, her family. Predeceased by sisters Sadie Weiss and Hannah Kashner, she is survived by her sister, Dorothy Trencher and the nieces and nephews, great and great-great nieces and nephews she nurtured, cheered on, and ruthlessly exposed to culture: Miriam Levine (Len, Z''L), Manny Weiss (Marilyn), Howard Kashner (Rita), Leonard Kashner (Beth), Frank Kashner (Cathy), Lewis Trencher (Esther, Z''L), Janie Perlstein (Rabbi Elliot); great-nieces and nephews Ronnie, Jayne, David, Bruce, Susan, Elisabeth, Megan, Anna, Zoe, Max, Jon, Eliott, Joseph, Caroline, Philip, Jordana, Elana, and Samara,; and many more of the next generation. Memorial gifts may be made to Central Park Conservancy.

ROSENFELD--Fay, died December 8, 2011, near Baltimore, the last of three sisters who, with their parents Herman and Eva Portnoy, arrived at Ellis Island on the ship Acropolis on January 15, 1923. They had fled the pogroms in the shtetl Sobilivka, where previously the great excitement, as Sholem Aleichem recounted, was waiting for the daily train to arrive. They settled in Philadelphia, where the Portnoy girls, listed on the ship's manifest as Esther, Anne, and Feiga, grew up as Freda, Anna, and Fay. Their fourth sister, Shirley, was born here. Herman sold newspapers, cigars and Tootsie Rolls from a stand in a Center City office building, where Eva peddled goods floor to floor from a basket. School was their daughters' babysitter; Fay started Kindergarten while still only three years old. You had to be six to go, but the teachers knew the circumstances, Freda, the oldest, later recalled. Fay went to Kindergarten for a long time, on account of that! Freda married Manuel Fives, Anna married Al Roseman, Fay married Sidney Rosenfeld, and Shirley married Irv Zuckerman. The four sisters had 10 children, and scores of grandchildren and great-grandchildren. We are engineers, doctors, educators, photographers, communicators, business owners, investors, and salesmen, spread across the United States. We would not be here but for the courage of the Portnoy family, who came to America as strangers in a strange land and made it their home.

The Champagne was flat: ''New Year's Eve'' was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend with about $13.7 million in ticket sales. But it failed to meet the prerelease estimates of analysts, who had anticipated sales of over $20 million. Warner Brothers had hoped that this romantic comedy, which cost about $55 million to produce and tens of millions more to market, would soar on the backs of its star-speckled cast; a similar endeavor last year, ''Valentine's Day,'' was a global hit. But that movie featured stars like Julia Roberts and Jamie Foxx. ''New Year's Eve'' included actors better known for TV -- Ashton Kutcher, Lea Michele, Sofia Vergara -- and some whose careers appear to be ice cold (Hilary Swank, Halle Berry).

In its final week of repertory in America, the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, dancing six works in three programs at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from Wednesday to Saturday, kept hitting high after high. The highs kept extending our sense both of these dancers, an exceptionally attractive, diverse and skilled group, and of Cunningham himself. On Friday and Saturday the triple bill included ''Pond Way'' (1998), ''RainForest'' (1968) and ''Split Sides'' (2003). At each performance, toward the end of ''Split Sides,'' gasps attended an extraordinary solo danced by Silas Riener. As this marvel of both tautness and pliancy moved from position to position, often while changing balance on one leg, he must have done 15 successive acts that were physically astonishing and 50 that went beyond any choreographic precedent. Much of ''Split Sides'' is about maintaining equilibrium while the body is tilting one way or another: this solo takes that challenge to new virtuoso extremes, phenomenal in terms of sheer gymnastics as well as rhythm, shape and linear complexity.

DOUGLAS--James Alexander Miller, of Bedford, NY, died December 8, 2011. Jimmy is survived by his wife, Gail K. Douglas, his three children, James A. M. Douglas, Jr. (Sandy), Evelyn Douglas and Constance Douglas and his stepdaughter Christie Densen Root. Jimmy was predeceased by his son, Palmer Caton Douglas in 2010. He is survived by 14 grandchildren, Stirling Douglas McDavid; Miller, Watts and Nelson Douglas; William, Emily and Mattie Saulnier; Florry, Ellie and Christopher Arnold; Blake Douglas; and TJ, Emma and Maggie Root. Jim was a graduate of the Buckley School, St. Paul's School and Yale University. He had a long and distinguished career in the investment advisory industry, co-founding Douglas, Noyes & Co. in 1982. In 2002, Jim joined Sanders, Morris, Harris. In 2005, he became a Managing Director at TBP Advisors, Ltd for the remainder of his career. Jimmy is also survived by many, many dear friends and extended family. Jimmy's humor, sweet nature and love of friends and family will be remembered by us all. Visitation will be on Thursday, December 15, 2011 from 4 to 7pm at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY. A Memorial Service will be held at 11 am on Friday, December 16, 2011 at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, 382 Cantitoe Street, Bedford, New York 10506. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH 03301.

ZEIDE--Harold J. M.D.,94, passed away on December 10 in Florida of natural causes. A graduate of Chicago Medical School, he practiced in Brooklyn, New York for over 54 years. He was a Master Magician and loved the opera. He is a direct descendent of the Shpoler Zeide. He leaves behind his wife Stella, married for 66 years; his children, Dr. Michael Zeide, Susan Schaller, Dr. Donna Zeide Kener, Janet Liebowitz; his in-laws, Denise Zeide, Dr. Stephen Schaller, Morris Kener, and Dr. Jay Liebowitz; his eight grandchildren, Elana, David (wife Annette), Robert, Jeffrey, Hillary, Andrew, Jason, Kenny; and his great-grandson, Noah.

Cisco introduced a comprehensive collection of computer networking hardware for cloud computing on Tuesday. The parts are not particularly new, but the packaging is -- and that matters for both customer education and sales. The framework, CloudVerse, unifies computing and network management; computer applications, including video and collaboration software; and movement of data between clouds. The benefits should include lower cost, faster deployment, and easier management, the company says.

FRAADE--Dorothy. Beloved mother, grandmother and wife of her late husband Bert. Survived by her loving sons, Steven, Alan and Jon, daughters-in-law, Ellen and Marcie and grandchildren Sharon, Shoshana, Rena, Nathaniel, Jordan, Michael, Liora and Rachel. She will be greatly missed by family, friends and all who knew her. Funeral services at 1:30pm today at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 91st and Amsterdam, New York City.

- Discovery Times Square - the crowd-pleasing exhibition space on West 44th Street that is now the host to ''The Dead Sea Scrolls: Life and Faith in Biblical Times'' - announced that it planned to briefly add a new scroll to the show, one of the oldest and best-preserved manuscripts of the Ten Commandments. -The show, which opened Oct. 28 and will continue through April 15, brings together hundreds of artifacts drawn from archaeological explorations by the Israel Antiquities Authority and from the historic discovery of the scrolls in 1947 by Bedouins in caves near the Dead Sea. The Ten Commandments scroll - which dates from 30 B.C. to 1 B.C. and was discovered in 1952 - will be added to the show from Dec. 16 through Jan. 2. Like many of those on display, the scroll is extremely sensitive to light and humidity and can be shown for only a limited amount of time.

HAWKINS--John W. Friends and Family mourn the passing of literary agent, John Hawkins. Born in 1939 in Seattle, Washington, John Hawkins grew up in Kennett Square, PA. He graduated from Harvard in 1962 and received a master's degree in international relations from the University of Pennsylvania in 1964. He worked briefly at Banker's Trust, but in 1966, John Hawkins was persuaded by his father-in-law to join the firm of Paul R. Reynolds Inc, which had been established in 1893 by his wife's grandfather, Paul Revere Reynolds. He became president of the company in 1980 and changed the name of the firm to John Hawkins & Associates in 1985. Over the course of his 45 year career, he represented Joyce Carol Oates, Gail Godwin, Harry Crews, Alex Haley, James Clavell, Thomas McGuane, E. Lynn Harris, Steve Martini and Robert Parker. He will be remembered for his wit, his wisdom and his passionate advocacy for his clients. He is survived by his brother Richard Bruce Hawkins and his nephews, Graham Carty and Andrew Spencer Hawkins.

BELANOFF--Sidney, 86, of New York City died on Saturday December 10, 2011. Proud Marine, devoted husband and loving father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Nothing for him was impossible. Services, today at Stephen Wise Synagogue, 30 West 68th St., New York City at 10:30am.

Updated with correction, Dec. 13 | In the eyes of some longtime residents of Stuyvesant Town in Manhattan, the ruin of their apartment complex has come in stages. First, the development's former managers, Tishman Speyer, opened a green market in 2008, which drew large crowds of nonresidents, and they scheduled noisy music concerts afterward. They allowed vendor carts onto the property: neon-colored trucks that sell tacos, Greek food and desserts on the tree-shaded paths.

Soon after taking the reins of MF Global in 2010, Jon S. Corzine visited the Wall Street firm's Chicago offices for the first time, greeting the brokers, analysts and sales staff there. One broker, Cy Monley, caught Mr. Corzine's eye. Unknown to MF Global's top management in New York, the employee, whose job was to match buyers and sellers in energy derivatives, was also trading a small account on the side, using the firm's capital.

(OVA) MARIINSKY THEATER'S THE NUTCRACKER The Tchaikovsky ballet, with music like ''Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy'' and ''Russian Dance'' portrays a girl's fanciful Christmas Eve dream about a gingerbread army, a Mouse King and a journey to the Land of Sweets. (MAX) THE USUAL SUSPECTS (1995) Things are not what they appear to be in this crime thriller directed by Bryan Singer. While sharing a jail cell, five New York crooks, including the fearless McManus (Stephen Baldwin), the wily Fenster (Benicio Del Toro) and the limping Verbal (Kevin Spacey), hatch a plot for a complicated heist. The plan succeeds, but after pulling a second job they are blackmailed by Keyser Soze, the unseen mastermind who is known only by his legendary wrath. He charges the group with a near-suicidal mission to kill the one man who can identify him.

BuzzFeed, a site where the editors and algorithms sift the Web in search of viral articles elsewhere, has decided that it needs articles of its own. In a move that is sure to surprise the political and journalistic classes, the site is hiring Ben Smith, one of the foremost writers at Politico, to build a new breed of social news organization.

The Postal Service said last week that it would close at least 200 of its 487 processing centers, partly because of a 27 percent drop in first-class mail in the last three years. Many people still buy first-class stamps to send holiday cards, even if they go online for bill payment or party invitations. (AmericanGreetings.com, which offers traditional holiday cards and e-cards, was the top greeting card site in October, with 4.8 million visitors.) The major competition at this time of year is not in cards or catalogs, but in retail and consumer shipping, which users can track online.

When I.B.M.'s Watson computer beat two human ''Jeopardy!'' champions earlier this year, it was a triumphant demonstration of the company's technology. It was great for Big Blue's image, but it was not a moneymaker on its own. Yet that process is under way. Watson was a bundle of advanced technologies, including speech recognition, machine learning, natural-language processing, data mining and ultrafast in-memory computer hardware. They have been under development at I.B.M. for years, and were pulled into Watson.

STATSINGER--Irving, age 96, on December 10, 2011. Devoted husband of the late Rosyln, loving father to Judith and Lanie, adoring grandfather of Alisha and her husband Neill. A loving and generous man who will be sorely missed. Services, Monday 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

COSENTINO--John Arthur, died peacefully at his Manhattan home on December 9, 2011. John was born on November 25, 1922, the son of Charles and Ethel Buckley Clark Cosentino. He grew up in Clifton, NJ, graduated from Montclair Academy in 1940, and was a member of the Harvard College Class of 1944, graduating in 1946 after a WWII tour of domestic duty in the United States Army. He married Josephine Batchelder in 1947 and their sons John Arthur Jr. and Paul Batchelder were born in 1949 and 1953. John's entire working career was spent managing the family textile business in Paterson, NJ, keeping it alive and prosperous long after much of the American textile industry had either failed or moved offshore. He and his wife raised the family in Montclair, NJ. He was a champion skeet shooter, a middle handicap golfer at the Montclair Golf Club, a skilled poker player, an opera lover, a voracious reader, and, led by his wife, a frequent European traveler. More importantly, he was a loving and dedicated - and beloved - husband, father, and friend. He was particularly active with and loyal to Harvard, president of various alumni organizations, interviewing applicants and recruiting athletes for decades, and following Harvard athletics. He was happy and proud that his sons and granddaughter, Jessica, were able to follow in his Harvard footsteps. John was predeceased by his grandson, Willy, in 1996 and by his wife of 54 years, Jo, in 2001. He is survived by his sons and daughters-in-law, John and Deborah and Paul and Anne Hays, his grandchildren, Jessica (Orthman), Trent, Joshua and Matthew, his brother-in-law, Harry Batchelder, his dear friend, Elizabeth Wolf, and by innumerable friends and former colleagues. John Cosentino was a wonderful man. We'll have a small, private celebration of his life in the near future and he will be in our hearts forever.

Newt Gingrich, the Republican presidential hopeful, wants you to know that as commander in chief he is ready to confront one of the most nightmarish of doomsday scenarios: a nuclear blast high above the United States that would instantly throw the nation into a dark age. In debates and speeches, interviews and a popular book, he is ringing alarm bells over what experts call the electromagnetic pulse, or EMP -- a poorly understood phenomenon of the nuclear age.

Rob Gronkowski of the Patriots set the N.F.L. record for most touchdown catches in a season by a tight end when he raised his total to 15 with two scores in Sunday's 34-27 win over the Redskins. The previous record of 13 was set by Antonio Gates in 2004 and matched by Vernon Davis in 2009. Gronkowski finished with six catches for 160 yards. Terrell Suggs, right, had three sacks and forced three fumbles as the Ravens' defense overwhelmed the winless Colts, 24-10. Suggs has a career-high 13 sacks this season.

At 11:30 a.m. on the beautiful, crisp morning of Dec. 9, 1861, several thousand somber Confederate soldiers in Gen. Edmund Kirby Smith's division formed a three-sided square around a slight natural depression outside their camp near Centreville, Va. Outside the ranks, both soldiers and civilians climbed into trees and onto rooftops to get a better view, for this was no ordinary muster. A military court had convicted two men for attacking an officer and trying to free some prisoners from a guard house. The sentence was death by firing squad.

The new Broadway revival of "Private Lives," starring Kim Cattrall ("Sex and the City") and Paul Gross, will close five weeks earlier than planned because of weak ticket sales, the producers announced on Tuesday night. Pulqueria , one of this week's Dining Briefs, is the latest venture by Heather and Christopher Tierney, the siblings behind Apothéke. The restaurant and bar is the city's first to focus on pulque, the fermented agave sap that Mexicans have been drinking since pre-Columbian times, here mixed with fresh juices and smoky mezcal. A lively crowd dines on chef Nacxitl Gaxiola's friendly, mildly authentic accompaniments: masa gorditos and empanadas, savory little tacos, selections of salsas from throughout Mexico, and larger, more robust plates like pork shank confit. Some of the dishes are a bit too tame, but there's also a lot of interest. The Yucatecan pumpkin seed spread, sikil pak, and the tuna tostadas are real winners.

Apple quietly announced on Tuesday that it had opened its iTunes store in Brazil and 15 other countries in Latin America, including Argentina, Venezuela, Chile, Colombia, Nicaragua and Peru. Apple now operates the iTunes music store in 51 countries.

Over on the Dot Earth blog, the columnist Andrew C Revkin interviews Marshall Curry, who with Sam Cullman directed "If a Tree Falls," one of 15 films on the shortlist for the best documentary feature Oscar. As an earlier Arts & Leisure article explained, the film examines the case of a former member of the radical Earth Liberation Front who was sentenced under terror enhancement provisions of federal law to seven years in prison for his role in an arson fire. The issue of what constitutes terrorism is one of several the film raises, as the various players (the detective, the prosecutor and so on) relate their shifting feelings about the case, including regret and confusion. "We tried to take the audience on this same zigzaggy ride," Mr. Curry says in the Q&A, "offering ideas and then challenging those ideas again and again." Read more »

Proud residents of Porto, Portugal, will tell you that the only good thing about Vila Nova de Gaia, the town across the Douro River, is its view of Porto. That's not inaccurate - it's just half the story. For port wine lovers, the south-bank town is a sacred place of oak-barreled Burgundy aging to perfection in a cobblestone warren on wobbly, centuries-old port lodges. Above them sits the new Yeatman Hotel, an 82-room resort and spa that takes the idea of a wine hotel (see also the Hotel Marques de Riscal) to new heights. Certainly it's easy to get that impression after a visit to the hotel's cork and wine museum or after a stay in suites sponsored and decorated by various Portuguese wineries. The Fladgate master suite ($430 per night) features a 50,000-liter port barrel repurposed as a king-size bed.

Our colleagues at the Economix blog have have just published a post about a new National Federation of Independent Business survey indicating that the net share of companies planning to hire workers is at its highest point in 38 months. George W. Bush could not declare victory until Gore conceded defeat.

Like many artists responding to our duplicitous marketing- and infotainment-driven world, Neïl Beloufa, a young French Algerian video artist based in Paris, works in the interstices of fact and fiction. In "Kempinski (2007)," which was on view last year at the New Museum, Beloufa uses a simple tweak in tense to build an eerie alternate reality. Shot at night in Mali, "Kempinski" features interviews with local inhabitants in rural settings - in a crowd of oxen, in bushes, in dusty courtyards - who speak about things from telepathic communication with stars, animals and machines to teleportation via light and sound, as if they were present-day realities. The scenes are lit by handheld, corded fluorescent lights that could, if you squint, be mistaken for alien technology, and the subjects' assertions register as farcical deadpan: Beloufa's tone of choice. The narration plays on a viewer's superficial ideas of where primitive magic and futuristic science might meet, hinging on that rhetorical switch from "will be" to "is."

O.K., I take it back. No sooner did I write a post suggesting that future primaries would benefit from more intimate debates - featuring smaller group of candidates rather than the whole field, longer answers rather than short ones, and so on - than yesterday's Jon Huntsman-Newt Gingrich "Lincoln-Douglas" debate went and demonstrated why that could turn out to be an absolutely terrible idea. Trip Gabriel's writeup for the Times does a good job of capturing the droning deadliness of the affair, the painful seminar-room quality, the absence any spark in the candidates's answers to the exquisitely-polite questions. ("After an hour and a half, when the moderator offered the candidates a chance to hit the remaining five topics in a lightning round and they declined, the audience seemed to collectively sigh with relief.") If Gingrich made good on his pledge to teach an online class while in the Oval Office, I imagine that it would turn out something like this. And if Huntsman's supporters want to know why their man has struggled to inspire any excitement or strong support, despite an impressive record and solid conservative bona fides, the answer begins with the fact that he just spent 90 minutes on a stage with the candidate leading in the polls and never once said anything that might actually make some real news for his own struggling campaign. (And yes, I understand that it was all about tag-teaming Romney. But that's no excuse for being lights-out boring.)

LOS ANGELES - The Orson Welles Oscar is back on the block. The Nate D. Sanders auction house here says it is selling the screenwriting Oscar that was awarded to Welles in 1942 for his work, with Herman J. Mankiewicz, on ''Citizen Kane.'' The statuette was best known in recent years as the subject of a court fight in which Welles's daughter - having recovered it from a cinematographer who said Welles had given it to him as a gift - defeated an effort by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to block a sale. Oscars awarded in recent decades must be returned to the Academy rather than sold on the open market, but older statuettes are generally not subject to the restriction. In 2007, a charitable foundation that then owned the Oscar offered it for sale through Sotheby's, but the sale was withdrawn after the statuette failed to draw a reserve price that was not disclosed.

Another weekend, another batch of Christmas-themed movies, new or rebroadcast. On the Hallmark Channel, you can see fare like ''All I Want for Christmas'' and ''Annie Claus Is Coming to Town.'' On Lifetime, there's ''A Nanny for Christmas'' and ''Holiday in Your Heart,'' among others. You know the ingredients: a single parent, a plucky child or two, a hardship of some kind, a serendipitous meeting that leads to love. Yet with all this, you may find there are still some stories that have not appeared on anyone's schedule. Here are five Christmas movies I'd like to see. Feel free to add your own:

MERGER CONCERNS A German regulator has called for changes to the proposed $9 billion merger between Deutsche Börse and NYSE Euronext after raising concerns about how the deal would affect operations in Frankfurt. A spokesman for the Hessian Ministry of Economy, the German regulator for the Frankfurt exchange, would not provide details on the concerns. The ministry has the power to forbid any changes to the ownership structure that result from the merger. MARK SCOTT

GUTIERREZ--H. Omar, M.D.,of Pound Ridge, NY, died December 10 at age 74. Caring and compassionate psychiatrist, native of Colombia, proud U.S. citizen since 1972, former U.S. Navy Lieutenant Commander. Beloved husband of Ann Johansmeyer, cherished father of Omar D. Gutierrez, M.D. (Ana Marte), Carmencita Gutierrez (Franco Quartuccio), Captain Soren Gutierrez, U.S. Army (Cassandra Griffin), and Paloma Espinoza (Esau Espinoza-Lucas). The family would appreciate donations in Dr. Gutierrez's memory to the Pound Ridge Lions Ambulance Corps., Box 237, Pound Ridge, NY 10576. Private services will be held, and the family will receive friends and neighbors from 2 to 5pm on Saturday, December 17 at Conant Hall, 255 Westchester Avenue, Pound Ridge.

THE FACTS Every winter, as blizzards bury towns across the nation, reports inevitably surface of middle-aged snow-shovelers suffering heart attacks. Many health officials routinely warn that shoveling snow can raise the risk of heart attacks. But the warnings have largely been based on anecdotal reports.

(NBC) WILLIAM & KATE: INSIDE THE ROYAL MARRIAGE Natalie Morales interviews royal insiders and Prince William's and Kate Middleton's friends and relatives about the first six months of the couple's marriage. Highlights include scenes from the April nuptials of the pair, now the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, above; their life in Anglesey, Wales; and their first trip abroad since the wedding. 11:30 A.M. (HBO) CINEMA VERITE (2011) In 1973 members of the Loud family became a national sensation when they welcomed a camera crew into their Santa Barbara, Calif., home, opening up their lives to public scrutiny and helping to create a new genre: reality television. Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini recreate the drama -- the philandering, the marital discord, the invasion of privacy and questionable ethics -- with a cast that includes Diane Lane as Pat Loud; Tim Robbins as her husband, Bill; and Thomas Dekker as Lance Loud, their eldest son, who is gay. James Gandolfini plays Craig Gilbert, the producer who, inspired by the anthropologist Margaret Mead, devised the series ''An American Family,'' which featured the Louds and was shown on PBS. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley called the film ''a clever, beautifully made but somehow underwhelming re-enactment of the breakup of the Loud marriage, on camera and off.''

ELKISCH--Liselotte, died peacefully on December 10, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Gerhard. Survived by her son Michael and his wife Sallie, and grandchildren Scott and Jamie. She will be missed. Graveside service on Thursday December 15th at the Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens, NY.

REICH--Oswald (Wally) H.,of Randolph, NJ passed away peacefully on December 12, 2011. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Wally lived there many years before moving to Pt. Washington, NY and then later to Randolph, NJ. A graduate of James Madison High School in Brooklyn and Pace University, he also received a Master's Degree in Business Administration from LIU. Wally was employed as the former VP and Tax Director of CIT Financial Corp. in NYC and Livingston, NJ. He was a veteran of the US Army Air Corp serving in WWII. Wally was a loving husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Doni, children Amy Reich (husband John Pracher), and Elizabeth Rohan (husband Don Rohan), sister Phyllis Hiller (husband Jack Hiller), his grandchildren Annika, Zachary, Timothy and Kate and many nieces and nephews. Services will be held on Thursday, December 15, 2011 at 11 o'clock am at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

The Broadway production of the David Ives play ''Venus in Fur,'' starring Nina Arianda and Hugh Dancy, will take a break after ending its run at the Manhattan Theater Club's Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Sunday and resume performances at the Lyceum Theater on Feb. 7, 2012, for a limited engagement through June 17. The Lyceum will be the third and largest home for ''Venus in Fur,'' which takes place during an erotically-charged audition. The play transferred to the 650-seat Friedman after an acclaimed Off Broadway run at the Classic Stage Company that opened in January 2010 with Ms. Arianda in the role of the manic actress Vanda and Wes Bentley as Thomas, the playwright-director. The Lyceum, which seats just over 900, is currently unoccupied. (The last show there was John Leguizamo's ''Ghetto Klown,'' which closed in July.)

PETIONI--Muriel. The Board of Trustees and staff of The New York Academy of Medicine extend our deepest condolences to the family of Muriel Petioni, MD, our cherished friend and colleague. We were fortunate to experience her personal warmth, humor, and wisdom as a valued advisor and volunteer mentor and role model in our programs encouraging young women in East Harlem to pursue health careers. She will be deeply missed. Thomas Q. Morris, MD Chairman Jo Ivey Boufford, MD President
MANASSE--Gustave. The Center for Environmental Therapeutics mourns and honors its founding board member and clinical guide. Michael Terman, President

10:13 p.m. | Updated Faced with the prospect of starting next season without their two best sluggers, the Milwaukee Brewers reached agreement Monday on a three-year contract with third baseman Aramis Ramirez, pending a physical, according to an official with knowledge of the deal. Ramirez, 33, is a two-time All-Star who batted .306 with 26 homers and 93 runs batted in for the Chicago Cubs last season. He has had an on-base percentage of at least .360 in four of the last five seasons and has 315 career homers.

A picture caption on Nov. 22 with an article about the turnover among national leaders in Europe caused by the continent's debt crisis misstated the circumstances under which Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero of Spain left office. He ceded the leadership of his party and did not seek re-election in the Nov. 20 general election, when his party was defeated; he did not personally lose in the election.

MAMES--Eva. American Friends of Magen David Adom is deeply saddened by the loss of Eva Mames, President of AFMDA's Dr. John J. Mames Chapter Michigan Region, named for her late husband. Dr. and Mrs. Mames were both Holocaust survivors and they founded the Michigan chapter after Israel's Six Day War in 1967. Mrs. Mames worked tirelessly for decades to raise funds for ambulances, medical equipment and stations in Israel and inspired others to do the same. Always modest about her achievements on behalf of AFMDA, Mrs. Mames and her incredible dedication to the cause will be greatly missed by everyone in the organization. Mark D. Lebow, National Chairman Arnold Gerson, CEO

ROSENFELD--Fay, died December 8, 2011, near Baltimore, the last of three sisters who, with their parents Herman and Eva Portnoy, arrived at Ellis Island on the ship Acropolis on January 15, 1923. They had fled the pogroms in the shtetl Sobilivka, where previously the great excitement, as Sholem Aleichem recounted, was waiting for the daily train to arrive. They settled in Philadelphia, where the Portnoy girls, listed on the ship's manifest as Esther, Anne, and Feiga, grew up as Freda, Anna, and Fay. Their fourth sister, Shirley, was born here. Herman sold newspapers, cigars and Tootsie Rolls from a stand in a Center City office building, where Eva peddled goods floor to floor from a basket. School was their daughters' babysitter; Fay started Kindergarten while still only three years old. You had to be six to go, but the teachers knew the circumstances, Freda, the oldest, later recalled. Fay went to Kindergarten for a long time, on account of that! Freda married Manuel Fives, Anna married Al Roseman, Fay married Sidney Rosenfeld, and Shirley married Irv Zuckerman. The four sisters had 10 children, and scores of grandchildren and great-grandchildren. We are engineers, doctors, educators, photographers, communicators, business owners, investors, and salesmen, spread across the United States. We would not be here but for the courage of the Portnoy family, who came to America as strangers in a strange land and made it their home.

COSENTINO--John Arthur, died peacefully at his Manhattan home on December 9, 2011. John was born on November 25, 1922, the son of Charles and Ethel Buckley Clark Cosentino. He grew up in Clifton, NJ, graduated from Montclair Academy in 1940, and was a member of the Harvard College Class of 1944, graduating in 1946 after a WWII tour of domestic duty in the United States Army. He married Josephine Batchelder in 1947 and their sons John Arthur Jr. and Paul Batchelder were born in 1949 and 1953. John's entire working career was spent managing the family textile business in Paterson, NJ, keeping it alive and prosperous long after much of the American textile industry had either failed or moved offshore. He and his wife raised the family in Montclair, NJ. He was a champion skeet shooter, a middle handicap golfer at the Montclair Golf Club, a skilled poker player, an opera lover, a voracious reader, and, led by his wife, a frequent European traveler. More importantly, he was a loving and dedicated - and beloved - husband, father, and friend. He was particularly active with and loyal to Harvard, president of various alumni organizations, interviewing applicants and recruiting athletes for decades, and following Harvard athletics. He was happy and proud that his sons and granddaughter, Jessica, were able to follow in his Harvard footsteps. John was predeceased by his grandson, Willy, in 1996 and by his wife of 54 years, Jo, in 2001. He is survived by his sons and daughters-in-law, John and Deborah and Paul and Anne Hays, his grandchildren, Jessica (Orthman), Trent, Joshua and Matthew, his brother-in-law, Harry Batchelder, his dear friend, Elizabeth Wolf, and by innumerable friends and former colleagues. John Cosentino was a wonderful man. We'll have a small, private celebration of his life in the near future and he will be in our hearts forever.

8:57 p.m. | Updated Jon S. Corzine bore the brunt of public fury last week when Congress began examining the downfall of MF Global. Now, two of Mr. Corzine's former top deputies at the brokerage firm are entering the spotlight, as lawmakers demand answers about an estimated $1 billion in customer money that vanished during MF Global's final days.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Monday with a review of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, misstated the given name of the dancer shown in the foreground. He is Silas Riener, not Silar. And the review also misspelled his surname at one point as ''Reiner.''

An article on Thursday about a push to ban horse-drawn carriage rides in Central Park misstated part of the name of an organization to which an upstate New York veterinarian belongs, and it described the carriages incorrectly at one point. The veterinarian, Dr. Nena Winand, is a member of the American Association of Equine Practitioners, not the American Society of Equine Practitioners. And the carriages have four wheels, and therefore are not ''hansom cabs,'' which are two-wheeled. An accompanying picture caption, as well as a subheading in some editions, and a correction in this space on Friday repeated the error about the cabs. (A reader pointed out this inaccuracy in a letter published in The Times in 1985, but this is the first correction of numerous such references through the years.)

DELLALE--Dina, died at home on October 9, 2011. Her generosity and wisdom made her a pivotal force in the lives of her family and her many friends. An accomplished diplomat and negotiator, she was the International Representative of the Costa Rican Sugar Industry. In 1974 she became the first woman Chairman of the International Sugar Organization. She founded ASFAMEX, an association of U.S. and Costa Rican textile manufacturers, for which she served as Managing Director. She is survived by her two nephews, Beriot and Robert Dellale. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated on Thursday, December 15 at 11am at The Church of Saint Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue (at 66th Street), New York.

Krtek, a snub-nosed, wide-eyed mole, has delighted cartoon lovers around the world for more than 50 years. Gently, cheerfully and almost always wordlessly, he has prodded bureaucrats, come to the aid of those in need and lamented the destruction of the environment. In one adventure, he finds his forest invaded by voracious builders but manages to secure a new home in a nearby forest (with the help of a slip of paper from a high-ranking official). In another, he roams the world and is stunned by an American mole's superior burrowing technology.

St. Ann's Warehouse, the Brooklyn theater that has provided a home for highly regarded productions including ''Black Watch'' and ''Misterman,'' will itself continue to have a home in Dumbo, not far from its current location in that neighborhood. The theater said on Monday that it had signed a three-year lease for a new space at 29 Jay Street, where it plans to open next fall after leaving its longtime base of operations at 38 Water Street following the conclusion of its current season in May. St. Ann's was required to leave 38 Water Street, where it has been since 2001, because the space is scheduled for commercial development. A plan to move the theater into the Tobacco Warehouse, a Civil War-era structure opposite the Water Street building, and provide it with a $15 million renovation had to be abandoned earlier this year when a judge struck down a decision by the National Park Service to remove the Tobacco Warehouse from classification as federally designated parkland.

An obituary on Monday about Joseph M. Chamberlain, who ran the Hayden Planetariums in New York and the Adler Planetarium in Chicago, misstated the year in which he gave an interview to The New York Daily Mirror. It was 1954, not 1964.

VANDER POEL--Beverly S.,of Glen Cove, NY, died peacefully on December 10, 2011 at the age of 93. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin F. On Monday, the Henry Hudson Bridge - that triumphalist crossing over the Harlem River, a steel archway slicing through a verdant vista of water, trees and cliffs - celebrates its diamond anniversary, the 75th. And like many older citizens of New York City, the bridge has had its share of wear-and-tear. It is one of the least-used bridges in the region's arsenal, but its operations have piled up over the years, closing lanes and upsetting commuters bound for the many gilded Westchester County suburbs it serves.

What happens inside the skull of a soccer player who repeatedly heads a soccer ball? That question motivated a provocative new study of the brains of experienced players that has prompted discussion and debate in the soccer community, and some anxiety among those of us with soccer-playing offspring. For the study, researchers at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York recruited 34 adults, men and women. All of the volunteers had played soccer since childhood and now competed year-round in adult soccer leagues. Each filled out a detailed questionnaire developed especially for this study to determine how many times they had headed a soccer ball in the previous year, as well as whether they had experienced any known concussions in the past.

David Bomford, who has been acting director of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles since 2010, will be returning to his home in London where he plans to pursue research, scholarship and writing, the institution announced on Tuesday. Wood, who was then the president and chief executive of the Getty Trust, the umbrella organization that oversees the museum. Mr. Wood died later that year and was replaced by James Cuno, the former director of the Art Institute of Chicago.

For Windows 7 users, passing the cursor over the Show Desktop button (that thin vertical sliver on the far right side of the Taskbar) is a handy way to glance at the computer's desktop, even with a screen full of open windows. But for those who accidentally brush the mouse over the button and get distracted by the disappearing documents on the screen, there is a way to disable the Show Desktop button -- just right-click on the Show Desktop button and remove the checkmark next to "Peek at desktop." Later, if you want to restore your peeking powers, right-click the Show Desktop button again and re-select the option.

More than a dozen states have enacted laws that are intended to make it more burdensome for Americans to cast a ballot, which President Lyndon Johnson called "the basic right, without which all others are meaningless." From our colleagues at Bucks, a new analysis from the automotive Web site CarGurus.com suggests that shoppers get much better deals on used cars toward the Christmas holiday, instead of waiting until later in the winter. Bon Jovi, Foo Fighters and Blink-182 will be the big acts leading the lineup for the three-day Bamboozle festival in May, which is returning to the boardwalk in Asbury Park, N.J., for the first time since 2006, the organizers announced Tuesday. The decade-old festival, which will start on May 18, will showcase more than 100 groups and solo performers on nine stages, both on the beach and along the boardwalk. Organizers said they will announce the rest of the lineup after the New Year. The festival will include a competition for unsigned bands, known as ''The Break Contest,'' and the winner will be given a chance to perform.

BLUM--Donald J. 87, died December 12, 2011. Son of Madelaine & Joseph K. Blum. Lifelong resident of Scarsdale, NY. WWII veteran, survivor of the sinking of the USS Indianapolis. Member of the Old Guard. Skier, sailor, golfer, mechanical engineer. Celebrated 60 years of marriage to Sandra. Children Linda, James, Thomas & grandchildren: Aza, Aviva, Henry, Tiina, Aenea, Eric, Annie, Mark & Lauren. Donations to Human Development Services of Westchester or Rails-to-Trails.

WIENER--Milton, died peacefully on December 5, 2011, at the age of 92. He was the beloved husband of Eleanor for 70 years; the cherished father of Alan Wiener and his wife Frances; daughters Karen (Alston) and Robin Wiener; and the proud Pop of Matthew and his wife Jennifer, David, Elizabeth and her husband Julian; Santi and his wife Rachel; and great-grandfather of Madelyn, Amelia, Ayva and Hazel. He was a Veteran of WWII and a devoted Yankees fan. Milton will be deeply missed by his family and friends. A memorial gathering to be announced. Donations in his memory may be made to Sunsounds, 2323 W. 14th St, Tempe, AZ 85281 or ReMIND, Bob Woodruff Foundation, PO Box 955, Bristow, VA 20136.

The Englishman Luke Donald cemented his place in golf history last weekend by becoming the first player to win the money titles on the European and PGA Tours. In a teleconference call with reporters Tuesday, Donald sounded as if he would trade that coup for the one feat that eluded him during a sparkling season that culminated in his winning the PGA Tour player of the year in a vote of his peers. Donald, 34, recorded 14 top-10 finishes in 19 PGA Tour starts, but he was less consistent in the four majors: he tied for 4th at the Masters, tied for 45th at the United States Open, missed the cut at the British Open and tied for 8th at the P.G.A. Championship.

With 71 catches for 1,088 yards and 15 receiving touchdowns (he also has one rushing touchdown), Gronkowski is on pace for a ridiculous 87 catches for 1,339 yards and 20 touchdowns (19 receiving).

After a five-year hiatus, NBC's gross-out competition ''Fear Factor'' delivered strong numbers for over a two-hour period with an average of 8.6 million total viewers. It also matched the highest 8 p.m. rating in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for a non-sports program on NBC since February 2008. At 10 p.m., also on NBC, Chelsea Clinton's debut as a news correspondent gave ''Rock Center with Brian Williams'' a slight ratings bump, with four million viewers tuning in. But CBS was still the No. 1 network over all for the night in both ratings categories, led by ''Two and a Half Men'' (14.7 million total viewers) and ''2 Broke Girls'' (12.5 million).

WASHINGTON - A Senate hearing into the collapse of MF Global was thrown into confusion on Tuesday after a main witness implied that Jon S. Corzine, its former chief executive, knew the firm had been misusing customer funds, an accusation that could not be substantiated. Terrence A. Duffy, executive chairman of the CME Group, told lawmakers that MF Global had used $175 million in customer funds to lend from one arm of the firm to another - an assertion that, on its face, may not be illegal - and that Mr. Corzine had known about it.

An article in some editions on Monday about the new American ownership group of the Italian soccer team A.S. Roma misstated the name of A.S. Roma's home stadium and misspelled part of the team's official name. The name of the stadium is Stadio Olimpico -- not Estadio Olimpico, the Spanish equivalent. And the official name of the club is Associazione Sportiva Roma (not Sportivo).

An article on Friday about a draft finding by the Environmental Protection Agency that chemicals used in natural gas drilling were probably the cause of contamination of drinking water in a valley in Wyoming described the composition of natural gas incorrectly. Natural gas is made up primarily of methane when it emerges from the ground; methane is not merely ''often'' present.

Tyson Balcomb quit Facebook after a chance encounter on an elevator. He found himself standing next to a woman he had never met -- yet through Facebook he knew what her older brother looked like, that she was from a tiny island off the coast of Washington and that she had recently visited the Space Needle in Seattle. ''I knew all these things about her, but I'd never even talked to her,'' said Mr. Balcomb, a pre-med student in Oregon who had some real-life friends in common with the woman. ''At that point I thought, maybe this is a little unhealthy.''

WASSERMAN--Arthur. We are all heartbroken at the loss of Arthur Wasserman, devoted husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, cousin and friend. Arthur's quiet, unpretentious demeanor belied an exceptional intelligence, wit, and sensitivity that those of us who were fortunate enough to know him well will carry within us forever. His generosity, integrity, and strength of character serve as a model for us all. He devoted himself to his wife of 60 years, Grace; his children Mona, Katie and Jeffrey; his daughters-in-law, Winnie and Karen; his grandchildren, Jared, Zack, Alice, and Jacob; his sister, Annette; and to countless family members and friends. We love him, miss him deeply, and will remember all that he gave us on so many levels for 87 years.

Six teams came back from 10-point deficits Sunday, tying an N.F.L. record. Five of those teams trailed by at least 12 points, making Week 14 the first week in history to have so many teams rally from a 12-point deficit to win. Some of the quarterbacks on those teams are getting pretty good at this comeback thing. Scott Kacsmar, who writes the ''Captain Comeback'' column for Cold, Hard Football Facts (and has contributed his comeback research to Pro-Football-Reference.com), e-mailed me some additional notes on Monday: In T.J. Yates's first start, in Week 13, the Texans and the Falcons were tied in the fourth quarter before Yates led Houston on a 19-play, 85-yard drive for the game-winning touchdown. This past weekend, Yates brought the Texans back from a 16-3 deficit, and threw the game-winning touchdown pass with just two seconds remaining. By leading a game-winning, fourth-quarter drive in each of his first two starts, Yates became the first rookie quarterback to accomplish that feat since Virgil Carter did it in each of his first three starts in 1968.

Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about problems in cleaning up land contaminated by the nuclear disaster in Japan misstated, at one point, the amount of Japan's land mass covered by the evacuation zone around the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant. It's not the first time the film has come under fire before the public gets to see it this month. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Soon after the accompanying article was posted on NYTimes.com on Tuesday afternoon, more than 700 people had ''liked'' it -- on Facebook itself. Many left comments about it on the Facebook page for The New York Times and on the paper's site. Here are some excerpts, with names or online handles as supplied. Never mind concerns about privacy: Facebook is symptomatic of a society where the virtual is increasingly substituted for the real, and all aspects of life are turning into commodities, including people themselves who end up being completely addicted to their toys, where empty connectedness has replaced communication and meaning. A very lonely world indeed. -- jw

DES MOINES - Much of the thrust of Gov. Rick Perry's campaign message has drifted in recent weeks to his proposal to ''overhaul Washington.'' It includes stripping federal judges of lifetime tenure - which legal scholars say means getting 38 states to pass amendments rewriting Article III of the Constitution - and he also calls for somehow persuading members of Congress to cut their own salaries by 50 percent to 75 percent. He offers less-clear proposals to break the power of Washington lobbyists and pledges to be the ''outsider'' who tears down the corrupt status quo. He has been hitting that theme over and over again on the campaign trail, including on Tuesday with a new commercial running in Iowa and on national cable, part of Mr. Perry's multimillion-dollar ad blitz in the weeks leading to the Jan. 3 Iowa caucuses.

LANGDON--George D.,Jr. The Trustees and community of the American Museum of Natural History are saddened by the death of George Langdon, President of the Museum from 1988 to 1993. He served as President at a pivotal time in the institution's history, and the Museum will always be grateful for his leadership. Our deepest sympathies go to the entire Langdon family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President

ITURREGUI--Irma Balbi, 90, of New York, NY died December 11, 2011. Born September 16, 1921 in Lima, Peru, she emigrated to the United States in 1950. She was a classically trained opera singer and offered the gift of her voice at many masses at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan and at other parishes in New York City. Her love of fine arts and music is something she often shared with her family and friends and it is in this respect that she will be lovingly remembered. Professionally, she worked as a bookkeeper for various medical practices and was a licensed tax preparer. Funeral Mass will take place at 11:00am on Friday, December 16, 2011 at St. Ignatius Loyola, Church in Manhattan.

Tim Tebow's late-game performances are already the stuff of legend. He has captivated the nation with a string of last-minute heroics, leaving the public wanting more. Tebow's statistics aren't very impressive, but he is a flavor best enjoyed without serious thought. You have to see it to understand it. And that makes his run reminiscent of an improbable stretch that took place over four decades ago. In 1970, 43-year-old George Blanda had so many late-game heroics that the Maxwell Club named him the most outstanding player of the season. As with Tebow, Blanda's clutch play was hard to fathom. He had such an impact on important situations that he was named the A.F.C. offensive player of the year by United Press International despite throwing only 55 passes.

Though at one point talked up for Broadway, Lisa D'Amour's ''Detroit,'' a finalist for the 2011 Pulitzer Prize in drama, will open the 2012-13 season at Playwrights Horizons, officials at the Off Broadway theater said on Monday. After positive reviews for Austin Pendleton's production at Steppenwolf Theater last fall, ''Detroit'' was announced for Broadway. Instead, Playwrights will put on a new production of the five-character comedy, which zooms in on the adjacent backyards of two recovering addicts and their anxious middle-class neighbors. Anne Kauffman, now represented by ''Maple and Vine'' at Playwrights, will direct.

An article on Friday about the Japanese star pitcher Yu Darvish's being posted for Major League Baseball teams to bid on misstated, in some copies, Darvish's career statistics with the Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters. He was 93-38 with a career 1.99 earned run average over seven years; he was not 58-22 with a 1.81 E.R.A. over four years. The article also referred incorrectly to his E.R.A. statistics. Darvish has indeed had an E.R.A. over 1.88 -- in his first two seasons, 2005 and 2006. It is not the case that he has never had an E.R.A. over 1.88.

Russ Stanton, who was put at the helm of The Los Angeles Times to guide the paper through a series of wrenching newsroom cuts, will step down as its editor on Dec. 23, the paper said Tuesday. The current managing editor, Davan Maharaj, a frequent presence in the newsroom and a champion for the paper's growing Web site, will take over. Mr. Stanton, 52, joined the Los Angeles Times in 1997 as a business reporter. He took over as editor in early 2008, a tumultuous time for the newsroom. During his tenure, the newspaper underwent a series of cuts including the elimination of 250 jobs in mid-2008. The layoffs reduced newsroom staff to about 550 people from 900 in 2007. It led to a paper more focused on regional coverage and with less of a national reach.

The benefit of writing a column about solutions is that it provides an alternative lens through which to view the world. The daily news tends to be dominated by daunting challenges (unemployment, climate change, the polarization of Congress) and flashpoint events (the killing of Osama bin Laden, the tsunami in Japan, the Penn State scandal). These stories are vital to cover. However, people often come away from the news with a lot more information about problems than about how society is dealing with them.

The Nov. 30, 1861, issue of Harper's Weekly featured a poem destined to become one of the essential texts of the Civil War, Ethel Lynn Beers's "The Picket-Guard." Beers, a 34-year-old native of Goshen, N.Y., said later that she wrote her only famous work in a single morning, after a boardinghouse breakfast at which one of her fellow residents relayed a newspaper report of "all quiet along the Potomac, as usual." Beers had answered by reading aloud the sub-headline, "except a poor picket shot." Her versified elaboration on the dispatch, in which a lonely guard is killed by a sniper early one morning, posed moral questions about the culture of war-making that have proved far more durable than her sentimental literary style.

Although fighting has always been accepted in North American hockey and permitted under the N.H.L.'s rules, the role of fighters and the process of dropping the gloves have changed dramatically. A lot of bad habits when analyzing general election polls can be good ones when it comes to primaries and caucuses. In particular, making inferences about a trend based on just a couple of polls will often lead you astray in the general election. As I wrote about on Tuesday, however, this is probably the lesser of evils when it comes to primaries. Voter preferences can change fast in primaries, and although the polls may or may not track them as accurately as we might like, in the long run you will benefit from being aggressive about trying to discern who has the momentum.

They're calling them "spants," said a fellow observer at the Theyskens' Theory prefall collection appointment yesterday afternoon. Spants - like these silk wide leg pants with a built-in split train - are a perfect mix of the designer Olivier Theyskens's past successes: the long flowing silk skirts (styled with a faded tee) and the super-wide-leg trouser. Also new among the label's faithful hot shorts, biker jackets and low slung denim pants are crystal-embroidered sheer tops and tights (that slouch in the perfect, grungy way) and a glowing signature print inspired by certain light-catching prisms.

During my latest eczema outbreak, the routine was typical. I wake up and remove from my hands the white cotton socks that prevent me from scratching overnight, then press a tissue to my closed eyes to remove the pus and blood that have accumulated in the folds of my eyelids. In the bathroom, I try not to dwell too long at the sight of myself in the mirror before patting my skin dry and slathering it with lotion. I wrap bandages over the raw and weeping patches in the crooks of my elbows -- a stopgap, really, since the bandages will soak through in several hours. I take Benadryl to calm the itching, and ibuprofen to temper the swelling and pain, before heading to meetings in an antihistamine haze. I hope no one stares, but they do.

If you are mildly surprised the N.B.A. finally managed to trade Chris Paul on Wednesday, keep in mind that the N.B.A. had to trade Chris Paul. After nearly a week of unrelenting scorn for playing puppetmaster with the highest profile star on the team the league operates, Commissioner David Stern did the one thing he had to do to turn off that rather uncomfortable klieg light: get the hapless Hornets a respectable deal for Paul. "The Artist," Michel Hazanavicius's black-and-white silent film, had the most to shout about after Thursday morning's announcement of the nominations for the Golden Globe Awards: it was nominated for six, including best comedy or musical motion picture, best actor (for its lead, Jean Dujardin), supporting actress (Bérénice Bejo) and director (Michel Hazanavicius). "The Descendants" and "The Help" were each nominated for five awards, including best dramatic motion picture. A list of Golden Globe nominees can be found here. The dramatic motion-picture nominees included "Hugo," "The Ides of March," "Moneyball" and "War Horse"; the nominees for comedy or musical included "50/50," "Bridesmaids," "Carnage," "Midnight in Paris" and "My Week With Marilyn." In the television categories, "Enlightened," "Episodes," "Glee," "Modern Family" and "New Girl" were nominated for best comedy or musical; "American Horror Story," "Boardwalk Empire," "Boss," "Game of Thrones" and "Homeland" were nominated for best drama.

The House of Representatives and the Senate have resolved a three-year battle over the future of two important federal initiatives to aid small businesses: the Small Business Innovation Research program and the Small Business Technology Transfer program. On the particulars, the Senate seems to have carried the day, but the House has won long-term changes to the innovation research program that open it up to companies backed by venture capital. In their dispute, the House and Senate have served as proxies for opposing views of the program's purpose: whether it should funnel funds to small businesses otherwise neglected by the markets, or maximize the return to the economy in job and wealth creation.

Two Congressional bills take aim at Internet sites that offer pirated copies of movies, television shows and music, reports Edward Wyatt in Thursday's New York Times. Most such sites operate overseas, but the legislation, with bipartisan support, is directed at companies in this country -- search engines like Google and Yahoo, payment sites like PayPal and ad servers -- that help the sites stay in business.

Marine Cpl. Robert Marcus Rodriguez of Maspeth, Queens, all of 21 years old, was the first serviceman from New York City to die in the Iraq war. That was a few days after the start of combat in March 2003. He was assuredly not the last to be killed. That sad distinction fell in August 2008 to Army Specialist Jorge Luis Feliz Nieve, 26, of Queens Village.

On Thursday, a House committee plans to take up the Stop Online Piracy Act, one of a pair of bills in the Congress intended to curb online piracy, particularly of movies, music and television shows. On one side is the entertainment business, which considers the current tools inadequate to fight pirating sites, "a Whac-a-Mole approach," Edward Wyatt writes. On the other side, technology companies, who argue that the bills are "so broad and heavy-handed that they threaten to close Web sites and broadband service providers and stifle free speech." Each is marshaling huge resources to lobby Congress and the American public, with the entertainment business framing the issue as about protecting jobs in the United States.

WILSON--Erica. All of us at Pointed Leaf Press are deeply saddened by the loss of Erica Wilson, wife of our wonderful author Vladimir Kagan. Her brilliance, wit, enthusiasm and love of life inspired us all. Suzy and Michael, Stafford, Regan, Deanna and Nyasha

Last week, we published a case study about two disaster-frazzled entrepreneurs seemingly in need of some of the calming supplemental holistic health services - yoga and massage - that they offer at Pulling Down the Moon, a Chicago business that was hit by two floods within a year. Because the entrepreneurs, Beth Heller and Tamara Quinn, linked their yoga business to referrals from Fertility Centers of Illinois, from which they subleased quarters in a rented building on the Chicago River, they temporarily relocated their business while the similarly displaced fertility clinic reconfigured and rebuilt the first floor offices after the July 2010 flood. This past July, the water damage from the second flood was not as severe. The company was able to stay open during the repairs, which required cutting out the bottom foot of some walls and bringing in industrial blowers. Because of delays with insurance assessments and payment approvals, the restoration dragged on until mid-October.

Over the last several years, as cultural patrimony cases have roiled the art world, federal marshals have made surprise visits to numerous American museums and galleries to cart away artifacts that foreign governments claimed were looted. Such a visit has never been much of worry for the people who run Creative Time, the scrappy New York public art organization that helps contemporary artists realize unusual projects like turning a building into a musical instrument or painting signs for Coney Island midway merchants.

SEGAL--Linda Polase, was born in September, 1945. She graduated the American Academy of Dramatic Arts and New York University while working as a Revlon model. She began a successful career in the fashion industry rising to the presidency of Sigallo Limited. In 1986 she married Steven Segal, Chairman of Sigallo Limited, enjoying a happy marriage until his death in 2000. She began a second, equally successful venture, consulting and assisting start up companies with their financial organization. She worked with the Cabaret Performance Workshop pursuing her passion as a cabaret singer forming relationships with many of her closest friends. She was diagnosed with kidney cancer in 2009. She was exemplary in the fortitude and courage with which she faced what came to be a mortal illness. Her warmth, her charm, her intelligence, her thoughtfulness and above all her humanity touched all those who knew her. Her sister Dorothea Oliver, her niece Lisa and her husband Richard, her nephew Joseph and great-nephews Brendan and Edan, and her great-niece, Ava, survive her. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue on Saturday, December 17, 2011 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, Linda wished the funds might be used to benefit the Central Park Conservancy. If you wish to speak with her after the funeral, you can find her bench next to Steven's by the carousel in Central Park.

IN a setting reminiscent of a speed-dating bar scene, but with no promise of even a first date, much less a long-term relationship, more than 20 fledgling fashion companies pitched their talent, their drive and their ideas to an audience of potential investors at the Fashion Institute of Technology last week. Freschman and Karen Griffith Gryga, venture capitalists, is a platform that acts as a kind of matchmaker between seedling fashion companies and investors.

In almost every Road Runner cartoon, Wile E. Coyote overshoots the edge of a cliff and finds his feet spinning in the air, frantically pawing for the terra firma that he has left behind. Those of us watching know he is about to fall, and even as he continues to flail in midair, deep inside he knows it as well. We might wonder whether James Murdoch, the deputy chief operating officer of News Corporation, now finds himself at a Wile E. Coyote moment.

The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about factors that stifle the reporting of sexual assault, described the law on sexual activity involving minors incorrectly. The legal age of consent in many states is 16 or 17, so it is not the case that ''a minor cannot legally consent to sexual activity.''

Little Dudes and Divas is a small business with some very big competition. Started seven years ago by Steve and Susan Karasanti, husband and wife, the company has three employees and sells clothes and accessories for infants and toddlers. Ninety percent of the sales come through the Web site, the rest through a newly opened brick-and-mortar store in Rockaway Park, N.Y., where the company is based. ''Our business model is based on keeping things fresh and selling only items which we feel are of the highest quality,'' Steve Karasanti said. ''If a new bag or print comes out, we want to be the first to have it on our site. You don't want your customer to tell you that she saw something on another site from a manufacturer you carry.''

Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about growing frankincense referred incorrectly to the president of the Union Theological Seminary in New York City. The seminary president, Dr. Serene Jones, is a woman.

BANKING LAYOFFS Crédit Agricole announced Wednesday that it would cut 2,350 jobs as the French bank scales back its operations to adapt to continued instability in the world's financial markets. The layoffs will be spread across Crédit Agricole's investment banking and consumer finance businesses. The bank also said it expected to report a loss in 2011 after writing down 2.5 billion euros, or $3.2 billion, primarily connected to its investment banking division. DAVID JOLLY and MARK SCOTT

If you want to know just how far jazz has slipped in the hierarchy of pop music, just look the line-up for next year's New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. Sure, Herbie Hancock is a headliner, but the rest of the names at the top of the bill to be announced Wednesday morning are a hodge-podge of pop, rock and R&B stars from various eras. The headline acts include the Eagles, Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, Al Green and Bonnie Raitt for older fans; Foo Fighters, Florence & the Machine and My Morning Jacket for contemporary rock lovers; Bon Iver for fans of indie, electronic songs; the Zac Brown Band for hard-core country fans; Jill Scott and Ne-Yo for those who like contemporary rhythm and blues; and Paulina Rubio, for Latin pop fans.

The Baryshnikov Arts Center's spring 2012 performance season, running Jan. 12 to June 17, will include several premieres by international artists from the worlds of theater, dance, music and film. The season includes the company's first co-presentation with Performance Space 122, as well as the New York premiere of a project organized by the theater artist Robert Wilson. ''Untitled Feminist Show'' which runs Jan. 12-28, is part of P.S. 122's Coil festival of contemporary performance. Conceived and directed by Young Jean Lee, music and dance are incorporated in a performance described as a ''nearly wordless'' commentary on gender and human transformation.

Major League Baseball's new collective bargaining agreement, which is expected to be ratified on Thursday, covers many familiar topics: revenue sharing, drug testing, video replays and so on. But tucked into its many pages is a curious addition that obligates any player who changes his uniform number during the season to buy any the unsold jerseys and other licensed goods that have his name and old number on them.

The trouble with compact music systems is their compact sound. JBL has taken a shot at the laws of physics by packing quality sound into a relatively small package, the JBL OnBeat Extreme. The player takes up modest desktop real estate, but it has high wattage for its size, with 30 watts to each bass speaker and 15 watts to each high-range speaker.

Updated 8:03 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has dispatched private investigators to gun stores and gun shows as far away as Arizona to illustrate how some dealers are willing to sell firearms to people they believe are disqualified from owning them. Now the mayor has turned his attention to the online marketplace: in a sting operation, the city hired private investigators to buy guns from sellers they found online. In many instances, the sales went forward even though the investigators told the sellers they were probably unable to pass a background check or were too young to buy a pistol legally, Mr. Bloomberg said at a news conference on Wednesday.
In Yaroslavl, the hockey team Lokomotiv is being carefully reconstructed.

An article last Thursday about relationships that undergo stress because of electronic devices misspelled the surname of a husband who felt betrayed when his wife switched from a Droid to an iPhone. He is Bill Douglass, not Douglas.

When the Yankees traded relief pitcher Mark Melancon to the Houston Astros for Lance Berkman just hours before the trade deadline in 2010, they probably did not envision Melancon winding up in the Boston Red Sox' bullpen. But the Astros turned around and traded the 26-year-old Melancon to the Red Sox on Wednesday for shortstop Jed Lowrie and relief pitcher Kyle Weiland, according to an official with one of the teams who would not speak on the record because the trade has not been announced. It appears Melancon will be firing pitches at his old teammates next year.

Jaguars (4-9) at Falcons (8-5) 8:30 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network Line: Falcons by 11 Great news, NFL Network: the Jaguars may no longer be television ratings poison. The Jaguars were responsible for the two lowest ''Monday Night Football'' ratings of the season, but the Seahawks and the Rams managed to tunnel beneath them with this week's cavalcade of blocked punts, hacky-sacked snaps and screen passes that hit the receiver's knee on one bounce. The Jaguars also scored 41 points in their win over the Buccaneers, more than in their previous three games combined and more than twice their previous season high.

MEGAN MARRIN, an artist and designer who makes ceramic jewelry under the name M. Graves (the centerpieces being antique doll parts), has worked her odd materials into a new collection of cameo necklaces. ''The comment for years has been that the pieces seem weird,'' Ms. Marrin said of the disembodied doll parts. ''I always thought they looked more like a Greek sculpture than a strange foot.'' This time around, doll heads, limbs and, on some pieces, feet from a 1920s pincushion doll are attached to porcelain rounds and covered with colored enamels. M. Graves porcelain cameo necklaces, $300 at Opening Ceremony at the Ace Hotel, 1190-1192 Broadway, (646) 695-5680; and mgravesjewelry.com.

PARTY pants, now in updated styles from the resort collections, feel fresh for the holidays. Lanvin's chic silk-print pants, with a high waist and tapered legs, are shiny and festive, as are Balenciaga's metallic trousers, which look rather like track pants, with the contrasting fabric insets down the sides. The British label Reiss also has glittery holiday pants, cropped with a high waist, in a dark gold sequin print. For style guidance, look to Charlotte Gainsbourg (right), who, for the premiere of ''Melancholia,'' wore her Balenciagas with a loose black shirt. For additional options, the junior set might check out the denim brands: AG, Siwy and Genetic Denim all have versions of sequin jeans in stores now. From top: Jewel-print silk pants, $1,880 at Lanvin, 815 Madison Avenue; (646) 439-0380. Cropped sequin pants, $330 at Reiss, 387 West Broadway; (212) 925-5707.

An article on Nov. 24 about the photographer Steven Klein misstated the year that the magazine Dutch published pictures showing men being brutally handcuffed by police. The photographs appeared in the May-June 2002 issue, not in 2003. The article also erroneously included an American actor among the men shown in the pictures. Dutch did not publish a picture of Brad Pitt ''kneeling and bare-chested, being brutally cuffed by the police.'' (The magazine identified the men as Travis, Adam Durocher and Eric White.)

LESNOR--Carl, died peacefully in his Manhattan home on December 13, 2011. Carl was born in Brooklyn on July 5, 1933, the son of Alexander and Ann Lesnor. He grew up in Brooklyn, graduated from Brooklyn Friends School in 1951, and was a member of Wesleyan College class of 1955. An itinerant intellectual, he attended Columbia University, The University of Chicago and La Sorbonne. Carl was a man of deep and passionate intellectual commitments to peace and justice, with an abiding appreciation for history, politics, philosophy, literature, music and art. His love of travel and cooking, his fluency in all matters French, and his political acuity have shaped the lives of his many friends. A scholar, activist and gadfly, he was also a Director of Hackett Publishing. Carl will be profoundly missed. A viewing will be held at 12:30pm to be followed by a Funeral Service at 1:30pm on Sunday, December 18 at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street in New York. In lieu of flowers, donations in Carl Lesnor's memory can be made to The Metropolitan Museum of Art; Development Office, 1000 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10028.

WARSAW -- Does Poland have the last healthy economy in Europe? With robust economic growth, rising foreign investment and a new luxury high-rise, designed by Daniel Libeskind, redefining the Warsaw skyline, it certainly feels like a different world from most of its neighbors, troubled by the debt crisis and recession fears.

A STATEMENT black leather belt can be the quick fix you need this holiday season. ''With tailored high-waist trousers and a sheer blouse or crisp button-down, a bold belt will cinch the whole look,'' said the stylist Kathryn Typaldos. If you're heading straight out from work, Ms. Typaldos suggests adding a black belt to a tunic or a dress with a waistline. ''The belt will add structure and refinement,'' she said. These three styles -- a wide corset wrap, a belt with a quirky feather trim and a patent leather one with a playful origami animal head -- capture just the right amount of flair. Add lipstick and you're off. From top: B-Low feather belt, $155 at shopbop.com. Co. wrap corset belt, $335 at Curve, 83 Mercer Street; (212) 966-3626. Patent leather belt with fox head, $150 at Phillip Lim, 115 Mercer Street, (212) 334-1160.

This week on the music charts, Michael Buble's holiday album holds strong at No. 1, beating out new releases by the Black Keys and Amy Winehouse, and the party-rockers of LMFAO reclaim the top slot for the most downloaded track. Mr. Buble's ''Christmas'' (143/Reprise) has been out for seven weeks, and it remains a solid hit. It sold 479,000 copies in its most recent week, according to Nielsen, giving the album its third week at No. 1 on Billboard's album chart, and bringing its total to just over 1.5 million.

Selma Heraldo lived the entirety of her 88 years in a white, two-story house on 107th Street in Corona, Queens, and her life may have been very different had she not gained new next-door neighbors in 1943 -- Louis Armstrong and his wife, Lucille. Ms. Heraldo quickly became known as Louis Armstrong's next-door neighbor, a good friend to the jazz great. After Armstrong died in 1971 and Lucille Armstrong died in 1983, and their house was transformed into the Louis Armstrong House Museum, Ms. Heraldo became the main local living link to the couple.

Technology gurus have long lamented how hard it is for foreign talent to secure American visas and create start-ups here. As Congress spins its wheels with endless debate over immigration, an ambitious venture based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is trying to chart a more productive course aboard a 600-foot boat, or possibly a barge. That's the idea behind Blueseed, which aims to create a visa-free, floating incubator for international entrepreneurs off the California coast near Silicon Valley.
