Elizabeth Taylor's stardust lent a profitable glow to the first night of Christie's auction of the movie star's extensive collection of jewelry and clothing. The sale of Taylor's ''Legendary Jewels'' grossed just under $116 million, more than doubling the previous record for a private jewel collection sold at auction. The jewels of the Duchess of Windsor garnered about $50 million in 1987. Many of the 80 lots sold on Tuesday night went for as much as - or more than -- 10 times the catalog estimates, which were based primarily on the value of the gems themselves. The first lot, a charm bracelet estimated at $25,000-$35,000, sold for $326,500, setting the giddy tone for the evening sale, which lasted more than four hours.

In a question-and-answer session with the online community Reddit, the comedian Louis C. K. fantasized about the possibility of making ''eight million bucks'' through sales of an Internet-only comedy special, money that could then be applied to other projects like making a feature film or amassing a collection of really nice camera lenses. Though he hasn't hit such lofty figures yet for his comedy special, ''Louis C. K.: Live at the Beacon Theater,'' which is currently for sale only through his Web site, he said he had already turned a profit on the project.

So what does Mitt Romney, perhaps the best-known Mormon in the country, think of ''The Book of Mormon,'' the Broadway musical send-up of his faith, complete with profanity and sexually explicit humor? ''I actually encouraged the guys that did that play, 'The Book of Mormon,' because I thought that'd be really helpful,'' Mr. Romney joked to The New York Times in an interview Wednesday. The creators of the musical, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, also created the television series ''South Park.''

The new Broadway revival of ''Private Lives,'' starring Kim Cattrall (''Sex and the City'') and Paul Gross, will close five weeks earlier than planned because of weak ticket sales, the producers announced on Tuesday night. The production of the classic Noel Coward play, which opened on Nov. 17 to generally good reviews, will now end on Dec. 31 instead of the original closing date of Feb. 5, 2012. Box office sales for ''Private Lives'' have been uneven, with the show's total gross falling by $53,160 last week to $327,173 - a respectable amount, but still modest for a star vehicle during the busy tourist season in New York. One of the producers, Paul Elliott, said in a statement on Tuesday: ''Despite fantastic reviews, ticket sales have been slower than we had hoped for and it would be irresponsible to continue running into the notoriously difficult January period.''

An article on Tuesday about Intel's efforts to turn a shortage of hard drives into an opportunity for ultrabook computers that use its solid-state drives, misstated a product used in the MacBook Air from Apple. While the Air does not have an Intel solid-state drive, it does have the company's chips; it is not the case that it does not use Intel chips.

For years - since its inception - Amazon has been at implicit war with local brick-and-mortar stores. Last week, the implicit seemingly became explicit when Amazon began a promotion that encouraged customers to check out prices at local retailers and use a specially designed ''Price Check'' smartphone app to report what they found back to Amazon. Customers who then purchased the same item from Amazon received a 5 percent discount, up to $5. (The deal was available only from Friday night through Saturday, and only for certain kinds of products.) For its initiative, Amazon has been greeted with a barrage of rotten tomatoes, from the press and from small businesses and their sympathizers. (Gawker, for one, described it as ''a Christmas attack on local shops'' and a ''cheap, sad thing.'') On Thursday, Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine, the top Republican on the Small Business Committee, joined the fray. ''Incentivizing consumers to spy on local shops is a bridge too far,'' she said in a statement. ''During the busiest shopping season of the year, we should remember that our local restaurants, bookshops and hardware stores are the economic engines in our communities.'' Ms. Snowe urged Amazon to cancel the promotion.

NOON (IFC) MEDICINE FOR MELANCHOLY (2009) Micah and Jo' (Wyatt Cenac and Tracey Heggins), who are in their 20s and living amid gentrification, hook up while pondering the idea that their embrace of urban hipsterism requires the suppression of their African-American identities. The film ''is a two-hander, occupied entirely with the day Jo' and Micah spend together, chatting, flirting, arguing and seeing the sights of San Francisco,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times about this film, written and directed by Barry Jenkins. ''But the city's lovingly captured neighborhoods (shot by James Laxton in high-definition digital video from which all but the faintest hints of color have been drained) make the story as much a love triangle as a romance.'' This movie earned a spot on Mr. Scott's list of that year's best.

Cold weather and holidays bring the opportunity to shoot those enchanting firelight pictures, rich with amber hues that make every frame warm and inviting. But Vincent Laforet, Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer, filmmaker and author of ''Visual Stories: Behind the Lens with Vincent Laforet,'' warns it's not as easy as rolling off a yule log. Here are his seven tips to get that shot of your family lit by hearth, menorah or blinking Christmas tree lights. Get more stops. ''The easiest way is to get a very bright lens,'' said Mr. Laforet, meaning using a lens that lets in a lot of light, which is described by an ''f'' number. It's counterintuitive, but the lower the number, the more light a lens lets in. He said to look for at least an f 2.0, but if you can afford it, get an f 1.2. The hitch is that the faster the lens the more it costs. To go from an f 1.8 50mm lens to an f 1.4 lens almost doubles the price. ''Those lenses tend to be more expensive, but they get some great images,'' he said.

To the Editor: Re ''Cellphones Test Strength of Gym Rules'' by Catherine Saint Louis (Thursday Styles, Dec. 8):

One out of every 15 high school students smokes marijuana on a near daily basis, a figure that has reached a 30-year peak even as use of alcohol, cigarettes and cocaine among teenagers continues a slow decline, according to a new government report. The popularity of marijuana, which is now more prevalent among 10th graders than cigarette smoking, reflects what researchers and drug officials say is a growing perception among teenagers that habitual marijuana use carries little risk of harm. That perception, experts say, is fueled in part by wider familiarity with medicinal marijuana and greater ease in obtaining it.

SAN ANTONIO - Thursday night's national semifinal matches of the N.C.A.A. women's volleyball Final Four could not have played out more differently. U.C.L.A. swept the first match of the night, 3-0, against Florida State. In the second game, Illinois and Southern California pushed their match to five sets. Illinois won the fifth set on a match point that included about 50 touches before the Illini notched the 15th and decisive point. After the exhausting conclusion of the match, the Illini did not celebrate their program's first championship game appearance; the players lined up, shook hands with their Southern California counterparts and began preparing for their matchup against U.C.L.A.
A view of the day in sports, including the women’s World Handball Championships and the Division III football national championship.

Detroit gets all the scary headlines, but there is a more desperate city in the state of Michigan, and it is called Benton Harbor. For the magazine's cover story this week, Jonathan Mahler went there to investigate the city's plan to revive itself with a publicly subsidized golf course and luxury-housing development in the very place where factories once provided thousands of blue-collar workers with a way of life. Slowly, since the 1960s, Benton Harbor has lost all its factories and half its population; those who remain subsist on a per capita income of $10,000. The city's finances are so wrecked that the state government sent in an emergency manager who answers to no one locally. Putting a golf course in the midst of all this is, as Jon observes, "almost a caricature of economic disparity."

It doesn't take much in the way of ingredients to make a good fish stew, but it does need good fresh fish. Enter local fishmonger Alex Villani of Blue Moon Fish. Well known in Manhattan and Brooklyn Greenmarkets, his fish and shellfish have a loyal following. In an admirably energetic and unusual arrangement, the man catches the fish out by Mattituck on Long Island, drives it to market, and, with the help of his wife, Stephanie, sells it at his stall, all the while smiling about it.

Daniel (Rudy) Ruettinger, whose story of making the Notre Dame football team despite his small size became the basis of the 1993 movie "Rudy," was sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday in connection with a sports drink company, Rudy Beverage, that was meant to compete with Gatorade. The commission accused him and 12 others of running a pump-and-dump investment scheme in 2008 that reaped more than $11 million in illicit gains, DealBook reported. Mr. Ruettinger settled the charges without admitting to or denying the accusations, and paid $382,866. Read more » at DealBook

When you're spending this kind of money on a hunk of meat, it really makes sense to find a butcher you can trust, or at least strike up conversation with the meat carvers in the back of your supermarket. You want to make sure the fillet you are buying is well trimmed of any silverskin, which is a thin layer of white connective tissue that is as unpleasant as gristle to chew (and all gristle should be expunged as well). Then have your butcher tie up the roast so it's easier to handle and will cook more evenly. Failing that, you can watch my latest video, above, on how to tie up a roast. It's not hard but does take more time than, say, having someone else do it for you.

The number of private sector workers who were laid off or discharged over the last 12 months is the lowest for any similar period since the government began collecting the statistics in 1990. The rate of hiring also remains low, but has improved since the recession ended in 2009. The number of workers quitting their jobs — a sign of confidence that they can do better elsewhere — has also risen. The number of job openings relative to the number of unemployed workers is down from the peak, but remains far above prerecession levels.

In October I flew to Houston to interview Christopher Hitchens in his hospital room at the MD Anderson Cancer Center. When he greeted me his shirt was open and, I couldn't help noticing, there was a plastic tube sticking out of his chest. Hitchens, who died on Thursday at the age of 62, was matter of fact about it, as he was about everything having to do with his illness. Cancer was an inconvenience, he gave me to understand -- big inconvenience, probably a terminal one -- but it wasn't going to keep him from doing what he loved most, which was to write.

MOSCOW - Once a year the Russian leader Vladimir Putin engages in a bizarre ritual: he holds a marathon question-and-answer session broadcast live on Russian television. Year after year, he beats his own record for the length of time spent in front of the camera in one sitting. The questions are pre-screened, as they are during Putin's other annual political ritual, his press conference. These two yearly events represent the sum total of Putin's direct communication with the public.

If you're reading this blog, you're probably familiar with the "For Your Consideration" ads that studios flaunt during awards season, a tradition that goes back to at least 1955, when one such promo for "The Man With the Golden Arm" appeared in a Hollywood trade publication. (It worked, to some extent anyway: the movie's star, Frank Sinatra, was nominated for an Oscar, though he didn't win.) The Bagger discovered these and other treasures - like "For Your Consideration: Best Actor, Michael Jordan" - as we investigated the history of vintage film promotion and why Hollywood is so enamored with the dawn of cinema in new pictures like "The Artist," which led the Golden Globe nominations on Thursday, and "Hugo," which picked up a few nods as well. Most family businesses don't survive beyond the founder's generation. Bari Jay, in its second generation, and Johnson Security Bureau, in its third, are two exceptions. Both companies are thriving largely because of the efforts of two of our business group members, Susan Parker and Jessica Johnson, respectively. Each woman stepped in after her father's death, and remade aspects of the business, often taking steps that their fathers never would have  considered - or endorsed. During our latest meeting of the group, Ms. Johnson and Ms. Parker talked about what their fathers might think if they were to see how things run today.

Most national candidates, and too many political commentators, miss the mini-primaries that lead up to the real events. In coalition parties, which the Democrats have been since F.D.R. and the Republicans have been since Nixon, campaigns are formed by creating personal coalitions around the various candidates. And for grassroots campaigns, of the sort I constructed for myself in 1983-84, it is even more basic than that. It is about finding key people in key primary states who combine a high reputation, organizational skill and a network of political contacts to form a campaign nucleus around which the rest of the state can be organized. I was once asked how many people I needed to win New Hampshire and I said, "Six."

ZIMMERMAN--Rose, 104, passed away peacefully on Tuesday. The beloved wife of the late Lou, she spent her career teaching in the New York City public schools. She lived life to its fullest, as a starting varsity center for the Hunter College basketball team, a sculptor, a folk dance choreographer, a square dance caller, and an enthusiastic patron of the arts. She is survived by sons Paul and Seth; grandchildren Jeff, Jon, Julie and Nadya: and seven great-grandchildren. Services Sunday, 11:30am at Riverside, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

Baseball's two oldest and most iconic ballparks are on divergent paths when it comes to recognizing their historic status. After a decade of renovations, Boston's Fenway Park is hurtling toward federal landmark recognition - and the tax credits that come with it. Meanwhile, in Chicago, the Cubs contend that Wrigley Field's local landmark designation is a roadblock to upgrading the stadium and increasing revenue. On Wednesday, the Massachusetts Historical Commission unanimously voted to approve Fenway's application for a listing in the National Register of Historic Places. That sends the nomination to the National Parks Service for a final decision that could come as soon as early 2012.

WESSEL--John C. John C. Wessel, formerly of NYC, died at home on December 9 in Pennsylvania from ALS. Born in St. Louis in 1941, a Graduate of the Goodman School of the Art Institute of Chicago, he spent five seasons at the St. Louis Municipal Opera and two seasons on Broadway with Phoenix Rep. He served in the Peace Corps in Venezuela 1966-68, worked for the Arts & Education Council of St. Louis, as Director of the Staten Island Council on the Arts, at the New York State Council on the Arts, and as regional representative for the National Endowment for the Arts from 1977-84. In 1979, he met William C. O'Connor, his joy, strength, and love for the next 33 years. They were married in 2008. They moved to Rome, Italy in 1985 and opened the Wessel O'Connor Gallery, then relocated to New York by 1987. In addition to his husband, survived by siblings Ginger (and John) Williams of Chicago, Tom (and Susan) Wessel of Ironton, MO, Jerry (and Joan) Wessel of Poplar Bluff, MO, and Edward Jr. (and Babette) Wessel of St. Louis, by numerous nephews and nieces, and eight O'Connor siblings. Memorial Mass January 21 at St. Francis Xavier Church 46 W. 16 St., NYC at 10:30am. Donations in his honor may be made to La Mama ETC, 74A East 4th St., New York 10003

An article on Thursday about the surging economy in Poland, in contrast to its European Union neighbors, omitted part of the name of an Austrian bank with operations in Poland. That bank, whose leader in Poland, Piotr Czarnecki, complained of jammed roads in Warsaw, is Raiffeisen Bank International, not Raiffeisen International.

Madonna's next album will be released on Interscope Records in March, the first in a three-album deal with the label. In 2007 Madonna left her longtime label, Warner Brothers, to sign a broad 10-year agreement with Live Nation Entertainment, which gave that company a stake in her concerts, recorded music, touring, films, sponsorship and other projects, and was reportedly worth $120 million. The company has signed comparable agreements with Jay-Z, U2 and Shakira.

PHILBIN--Ewing R.,Jr., died on December 11, 2011. A resident of Portola Valley, California, he was the father of three sons, Ewing R. Philbin, James W. Philbin, and Cavin W. Philbin, all born to his former wife, Cynthia (Mrs. Robert Jamplis) of Woodside, California. They also share eight grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Ewing was a naval aviator and served overseas, a captain in the U.S. Marine Corps. In late 1943, he was officially credited, together with a fellow pilot, with sinking a Japanese destroyer on a skip bombing strike at Rabaul in the Solomon Island Campaign. During his business career, Ewing held prominent positions in two of the New York's leading advertising agencies, Young & Rubicam and Dancer Fitzgerald Sample and, at career's end, served as a partner at Lincoln Property Company, Foster City, California. Friends are invited to attend a memorial service on Monday, December 19, 2011 at 2:00pm at Unity Church, 3391 Middlefield Road, Palo Alto, California. Memorial Contributions to your favorite charity is preferred. Services under the direction of Crippen & Flynn Woodside Chapel 650-369-4103.

DES MOINES -- With less than three weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Rick Perry is firing his toughest volley yet at Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich, the front-runners in many national polls, with a new commercial that seeks to paint them as ''political insiders.'' The ad cites Mr. Gingrich's support for raising the federal debt ceiling while he was speaker of the House and Mr. Romney's raising taxes on business while he was governor of Massachusetts.
An obituary on Saturday about Dr. Muriel Petioni, the Harlem physician and community activist, misstated the date of her death. It was Tuesday, Dec. 6 -- not Monday, Dec. 5.

BROWN--Mary Anne Symons, 69, passed away peacefully on December 11, 2011, after a long illness. She is survived by her husband, Norman; her son, Dennis; her daughter, Jenny; and her brother, Michael Symons. For more information, please contact Jenny, at brown1638@aol.com.

SANGER--Dr. Cyril, 90, died peacefully on December 10 in Teaneck, NJ after a short illness. Born 1921 in Plymouth England, Dr. Sanger trained in anesthesia at St. Bartholomew's Hospital Medical College (Barts), then served in the British Army where he met his wife Ann (nee Stewart) in 1947. He served on the staff at St Thomas' Hospital in London, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital and Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital, and was a past president of the British Schools and Universities Club and an active member of the St. George's Society of New York. He is survived by his sons David and Peter, daughters-in-law Sally and Michelle, grandchildren Jonathan Sanger, Freyja Sanger, Elizabeth Flegel and Ashley Dion and two great-grandchildren. Donations in his memory may be made to the St. George's Society of New York, 216 East 45th Street, Suite 901, New York, NY 10017. www.stgeorgessociety.org

HYMAN--Dr. Paula. The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family and the Jewish people in mourning the loss of Dr. Paula Hyman (z"l), the first female dean of the Seminary College of Jewish Studies, now List College. A recipient of an honorary doctorate from JTS, Professor Hyman was a pioneer in Jewish gender and women's studies, instrumental in creating the field; an expert on modern European and American Jewish history; and a valued friend and colleague. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the possible expulsion from the Tokyo Stock Exchange of the Japanese camera maker Olympus misstated, in some editions, the accusations against another company that was banished by the exchange last year. That company, Senior Communication, was accused of padding profit by a little more than $28 million over six years, not $28,000.

Howard Stern has signed up to be a judge on ''America's Got Talent,'' NBC's popular summer series, he said on Thursday morning. Mr. Stern claimed to be signing the contract while on the air on ''The Howard Stern Show,'' which is broadcast by Sirius XM. NBC confirmed the news a few minutes later and said that part of the show would be moving to New York, where Mr. Stern's radio show is produced.

''Flashdance,'' the 1983 film that made a fashion statement out of oversized sweatshirts and leg warmers, is the latest movie undergoing a Broadway makeover. A group of veteran theater producers plans to bring a musical version of ''Flashdance'' to New York next fall, following an overhaul of the show's script and score after a critically drubbed production in London in 2010. One of the producers, Thomas Viertel, said in an interview that the libretto has been ''totally rewritten to emphasize different plotlines and different relationships'' - chiefly, strengthening a romantic subplot between the main character Alex, the working-class welder who dreams of becoming a dancer (and who was played by Jennifer Beals in the movie), and Nick, a wealthy young man whose family owns the steel plant.

MALLIARAKIS--Eva A.,of Manhattan, NY, died on December 7, 2011. Widow of Antonios, beloved mother of Nikita and Rallou, devoted grandmother of Anthony, Kathleen, and Eugenia, mother-in-law of Kathleen Driscoll. Mother of us all, she will be deeply missed.

A music review on Dec. 8 about a performance of Handel's ''Messiah,'' at St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue, referred incorrectly to the role of the boys in the choir. They sang the soprano line, not the soprano and the alto. (Men sang that part).

WASHINGTON - Jon S. Corzine, the former chief executive of MF Global, on Thursday denied claims that he had known the brokerage firm was improperly tapping customer funds to stave off collapse. Mr. Corzine told a House panel that he had received assurances, ''both orally and in writing,'' that the firm followed federal laws about keeping customer money separate from firm funds.

BLUM--Donald J. 87, died December 12, 2011. Son of Madelaine & Joseph K. Blum. Lifelong resident of Scarsdale, NY. WWII veteran, survivor of the sinking of the USS Indianapolis. Member of the Old Guard. Skier, sailor, golfer, mechanical engineer. Celebrated 60 years of marriage to Sandra. Children Linda, James, Thomas & grandchildren: Aza, Aviva, Henry, Tiina, Aenea, Eric, Annie, Mark & Lauren. Also survived by sister Elizabeth Landauer and brother Roger G. Blum. Donations to Human Development Services of Westchester or Rails-to-Trails.

3:23 p.m. | Updated The number of obese New York City schoolchildren fell by 5.5 percent over five years, federal and city officials said Thursday, offering a glimmer of optimism about one of the country's intractable health scourges. The decline, documented by annual fitness exams given to most of the city's kindergarten through eighth-grade students, was the biggest reported by any large city. Over all, the rate of obesity dropped in New York City to 207 children per 1,000 in the 2010-11 school year, down from 219 five years earlier, meaning that 20.7 percent were still considered obese.

SPINOFF Covidien, the health care company run by José E. Almeida, below, that was carved out of Tyco International in 2007, plans to turn its pharmaceuticals unit into a stand-alone public company as it looks to increase shareholder value. Spinning off from its parent would give the new company ''the financial and strategic flexibility to pursue its growth plans,'' as well as allow it to bring new products to market, Covidien said in a statement. KEVIN ROOSE

Don't just repeat it. Report it. That's the lesson this week for MSNBC and for The Washington Post, both of which apologized for repeating a liberal blog's claim that Mitt Romney had uttered a phrase on the campaign stump that was used in the past by the Ku Klux Klan.

Aug. 14, 1945 - V-J Day - marked the surrender of Japan to end World War II, and crowds flooded into Times Square to celebrate. Ticker tape flew from windows and service members in uniform ran around kissing women, for the sheer joy of it and for the cameras. Flash forward to Thursday, when the United States military officially declared an end to its mission in Iraq. In Times Square, it was hard to find even a mention of the Iraq pull-out on the news tickers.

CHODOSH--Stewart M. Ph.D.,researcher and developer of lithium batteries, left us suddenly on Wednesday. An adoring husband to Miriam for over 60 years. A spectacular family man. An obituary on Thursday about Anthony Amato, the founder and artistic director of the Amato Opera Theater in Manhattan, misidentified, in some editions, the composer of the opera ''The Barber of Seville,'' which was the company's first production in 1948. It was written by Rossini, not Mozart.

Bellevue Hospital Center celebrated its 275th anniversary Thursday with what one hospital official called a ''conservative, restrained'' noontime event, consonant with economic hard times, in the hospital atrium on the east side of Manhattan. Although a 275th birthday might not match up in gravitas to 200 years or 250 or 300, there is a word for it: dodranstricentennial. Besides, in the coming era of Medicaid cuts and federal healthcare overhaul, mere continuity is to be celebrated at a place like Bellevue, dedicated to serving the poor and uninsured, including illegal immigrants, who will still be uninsured and hence a drain on resources under healthcare reform.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Thursday about the lineup for the New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival next spring misspelled the given name of a singer who is scheduled to perform. She is Dianne Reeves, not Diane.

HYMAN--Paula, 65, died on December 15 in New Haven, CT, surrounded by her family. The cause was cancer, a disease she had fought successfully four times in her 30s. She continued to live life fully - raising a family and building a groundbreaking academic career - throughout those difficult years. She is survived by her husband of 42 years, Dr. Stanley Rosenbaum, their daughters, Dr. Judith Rosenbaum (Rabbi Or Rose) and Adina Rosenbaum; twin grandchildren Ma'ayan and Aviv Rosenbaum; her mother, Ida Hyman, and two sisters, Toby and Merle Hyman. She was born in Boston, MA, the eldest daughter of Sydney and Ida Hyman. A graduate of Girls' Latin School, Hyman went on to earn a BA at Radcliffe College, a B.J.Ed at Hebrew Teacher's College, and a PhD in history at Columbia University. She began her distinguished career at Columbia and served as the Dean of the Seminary College of Jewish Studies at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, before becoming the Lucy G. Moses Professor of Modern Jewish History at Yale University in 1986. The author or editor of ten books and numerous scholarly articles on modern Jewish history, she helped create the field of Jewish gender studies. In addition to her academic contributions, Hyman was a Jewish feminist pioneer and a founding member of Ezrat Nashim, an influential American Jewish feminist organization. Hyman was a devoted activist who served both the academic and Jewish communities in many leadership roles. She received several distinguished prizes and awards, including honorary degrees from Hebrew Union College and The Jewish Theological Seminary. She was a role model for many throughout her lifetime and will remain so for years to come. Funeral services will be held on Friday, December 16 at 11:30am at Congregation Beth El-Keser Israel, 85 Harrison Street, in New Haven, CT. Donations in her memory may be made to Hebrew College of Boston or the Jewish Women's Archive (JWA.org).

It's the dream of every art collector to buy a painting from a little-known artist for $100 and later sell it for $1 million. But how does that artist feel? Some think it unfair that artists typically do not directly benefit when a particular work escalates in value, and a bill introduced Thursday by Representative Jerrold Nadler, Democrat of New York, and Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, seeks to redress that. With the support of organizations like the Visual Artists and Galleries Association and the Artists Rights Society, the lawmakers propose setting aside 7 percent of the price of artworks that are resold for more than $10,000 at auction houses. Half of the commission would go to the artist and the other half to nonprofit art museums. The legislation, which would apply only to the resale of work, models itself on laws - more commonly known as droit de suite - already on the books in dozens of countries. The Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works also provides for a resale royalty. Previous attempts to enact a national royalty resale law have failed. At the moment, California is the only state that requires resellers to pay royalties to the artist. This fall, three class-action suits were brought by artists against Sotheby's, Christie's and the online auction site eBay for failure to pay royalties under the California law. The auction houses, as well as museums and galleries, have traditionally opposed the idea of resale royalties, calling it a tax that increases the cost of doing business. Mr. Nadler said that ''visual artists deserve a share in the sales and resales of their creative works.''

The Doha Journal article on Nov. 30, about the development of that city, the capital of Qatar, referred imprecisely to local transportation. While Doha is working on a new metro system and an airport, the projects are not yet completed.

An Op-Ed essay on Dec. 7 about Adm. Isoroku Yamamoto, the architect of the Pearl Harbor attack, misstated the proportion of American military aircraft destroyed in the assault. It was two-thirds of the aircraft based on the island of Oahu, not two-thirds of the aircraft based in the Pacific theater.

Updated, 9:10 p.m. | One year after the elevator accident that nearly claimed her life, Debra Jordan still struggles to use her left leg and dreads whenever she must change floors. She suffered her injuries in an accident eerily similar to the one on Wednesday that killed an advertising executive in Manhattan. In each case, the elevator doors closed suddenly, trapping the woman in between, as the car shot up the elevator shaft. Were it not for the location of Ms. Jordan's elevator - in a hospital - she might not have survived.

WHALEN--Elizabeth Law, on November 27, 2011, after a long courageous struggle with Dementia and Alzheimer's Disease, Elizabeth Law Whalen, died peacefully in Wilton, CT near her daughter Sarah. She was predeceased by her brother Dr. Robin Caird Watson of New York, NY, but is survived by her husband Dr. Gerald F. Whalen of Shrewsbury, NJ, and by her four children: Dr. Giles F. Whalen of Sutton, MA, Daniel W. Whalen of Rumson, NJ, Sarah V. Robinson of South Salem, NY and Philippa C. Burke of New York, NY. She is also survived by nine grandchildren. She was born December 3, 1925, the first child of Eleanor Lloyd Watson and William Watson in London, England, and was raised there with her younger brother, Robin. She graduated as a physician from the University of Aberdeen and at the age of 21 returned to London as a pediatric specialist at the Great Ormand Street Childrens Hospital. While there she met a visiting American neurosurgeon, Gerald Whalen, who swept her off her feet. They were married on May 9, 1953 in the chapel of Portuguese embassy in London and sailed for New York later that year. The couple settled in Shrewsbury where Elizabeth raised her children and made her home for 56 years. Her genuine warmth drew people to her naturally and her life was devoted to family and friends. She delighted in the things that make life joyous but was a steadying, ethical influence for all around her and always someone to turn to for wisdom and perspective. She loved learning, children, gardening, friends, travel, china, holidays, cooking and family dinners. She had a generous spirit, saw the good in all people and was a living example of human decency. She made her home a place of grace and light that was both refuge and beacon. Although her spirit still shines brightly for those who loved her, her illness had dimmed her presence for too long. She has been much missed, was much loved, and will long be remembered. A memorial service will be held on January 7, 2012 at Christ Church in Shrewsbury, NJ at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to the Alzheimer's Association.

The federal bankruptcy judge who last week ruled that the Los Angeles Dodgers could accelerate a plan to sell their future TV rights elaborated on his decision Thursday. He criticized Fox Sports, whose Prime Ticket channel has a contract to show Dodgers games through 2013, for trying to prevent the team from selling the TV rights before the end of their 45-day exclusive negotiating period on Nov. 30, 2012. Judge Kevin Gross called Fox's attempts to delay the sale ''disingenuous'' considering that Fox negotiated a 17-year deal with the Dodgers earlier this year that would have given Frank McCourt, the team's owner, an upfront payment of $385 million, and about one-third ownership of Prime Ticket.

LOS ANGELES -- GOLDEN GLOBE voters did little to clear up a blurry awards picture in Hollywood on Thursday, giving films like ''The Artist,'' ''The Help'' and'' The Descendants'' roughly the same number of nominations and snubbing some perceived Oscar front-runners. The movie industry's self-congratulatory season is typically well defined by now, with favorites firmly established and potential dark horses looming. But consensus has yet to form fully around any film this year, perhaps because an unusual number of top contenders are arriving late.

LESNOR--Carl, died peacefully in his Manhattan home on December 13, 2011. Carl was born in Brooklyn on July 5, 1933, the son of Alexander and Ann Lesnor. He grew up in Brooklyn, graduated from Brooklyn Friends School in 1951, and was a member of Wesleyan College class of 1955. An itinerant intellectual, he attended Columbia University, The University of Chicago and La Sorbonne. Carl was a man of deep and passionate intellectual commitments to peace and justice, with an abiding appreciation for history, politics, philosophy, literature, music and art. His love of travel and cooking, his fluency in all matters French, and his political acuity have shaped the lives of his many friends. A scholar, activist and gadfly, he was also a Director of Hackett Publishing. Carl will be profoundly missed. A viewing will be held at 12:30pm to be followed by a Funeral Service at 1:30pm on Sunday, December 18 at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street in New York. In lieu of flowers, donations in Carl Lesnor's memory can be made to The Metropolitan Museum of Art; Development Office, 1000 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10028.

Over the objections of a group of vocal opponents the city council of Newport, R.I., voted Wednesday night to approve the use of a small park for a permanent installation being designed by the artist Maya Lin to evoke the city's past and to honor the heiress Doris Duke. The proposal to allow the $3.5 million project to proceed on city-owned land near the harbor, in the park known as Queen Anne Square, was approved by a 5-to-1 vote. The installation, called ''Meeting Room,'' would involve building three low-walled structures within the roughly one-acre space of the square, each to be made from salvaged local stone and intended to suggest the foundations of vanished centuries-old buildings that can still be found throughout New England. Duke paid for and supervised the creation of Queen Anne Square in the late 1970s, wresting the open space from a former commercial area of derelict buildings.

An article on Tuesday about the race between Roald Amundsen and Robert Falcon Scott to reach the South Pole 100 years ago described the location of China's Plateau Observatory incorrectly. It is 700 miles from the South Pole, in East Antarctica, not ''700 miles east of the South Pole.''

A rare collection of almost 38,000 coins is expected to raise between $25 million and $35 million for the Hispanic Society of America, Sotheby's New York announced Thursday. The collection, assembled more than 100 years ago by Archer M. Huntington, the founder of the Hispanic Society, will be offered as a single lot in sealed bid auction beginning Thursday and ending next March. Considered one of the most important collections outside of Spain related to Spanish history, it includes the ''50 Excelentes,'' a gold coin weighing nearly five ounces created in the 15th century, during the period of Christopher Columbus's voyages to the New World. The coin, according to a statement from Sotheby's, ''is the largest gold coin from the 15th century that survives today.'' In addition, there are more than 400 Roman gold coins that span the full history of Rome, including examples struck under Julius Caesar.

As other American forces shipped out of Iraq, a handful of units stayed behind to help wind up the bases. At the center of the logistical nightmare of leaving the country after nearly nine years of war was a Kentucky National Guard unit, the 149th Maneuver Enhancement Brigade. Finally it was the unit's turn to go. With sighs and a toast with nonalcoholic beer, the 149th's heavy convoy of armored vehicles bounced one by one through the final checkpoint. Local children cheered until the last vehicle left -- that one they hit with a rock.

BEIJING - When Gary Rieschel moved to China in 2005, he was looking to take a break. He had spent two decades bouncing between Silicon Valley and Asia, most recently managing technology investments in the aftermath of the dot-com bust. But China proved irresistible to Mr. Rieschel, a longtime venture capitalist. The country had a nascent Internet sector, a growing middle class and plenty of potential. Within months of relocating, he co-founded Qiming Venture Partners, at the time one of the few investment firms focused on start-ups.

My Sunday column is about Bahrain, our ally in the Gulf, and the Obama administration's proposed $53 million arms sale to the regime. As you may know from my last column, I was detained in Bahrain by riot police who also broke the camera and roughed up the video journalist with me. But, truth be told, I also have a good deal of admiration for Bahrain and what the royal family has accomplished here -- the soaring living standards, the investment in education, the empowerment of women, the solid middle class. It's just that when you educate people and create a cosmopolitan nation, you can't continue to deny them democracy. People want more from life than fine watches and nice houses.

Cowboys (7-6) at Buccaneers (4-9) Saturday, 8:20 p.m. Line: Cowboys by 7 Two of the league's most idiosyncratic late-game tacticians face off in a game destined to turn into toddler chess (''my horsy got magic powers and blow'd up all your pointy guys'') in the final minutes. Jason Garrett's late-game over-complications have become the stuff of legend, but let's listen in on Raheem Morris's clock-management dissertation after the Buccaneers' loss to the Titans a few weeks ago: ''We spike the ball after every first down you get. You pick up a first down, you have to go spike it, you have no timeouts left. Every first down after that point has got to be a spiked ball.'' Somewhere, Herm Edwards, and only Herm Edwards, is nodding in approval. Clock-management issues have become increasingly moot during the Buccaneers' seven-game losing streak as 37-9 and 41-14 losses have piled up. Josh Freeman has been battling both inconsistency and shoulder and finger injuries, and the Buccaneers' defense often caves in at the red zone, having allowed 14 touchdowns in their opponents' last 17 trips inside the 20. With Freeman spraying passes and the Bucs waving opponents into the end zone like parking lot attendants, Garrett can enjoy a consequence-free last-second timeout spree if he chooses. Pick: Cowboys

''Bonnie & Clyde,'' the composer Frank Wildhorn's latest bid for Broadway success after several flops, won't end his unlucky streak. Producers announced on Friday that the show, starring Jeremy Jordan and Laura Osnes, will close on Dec. 30. After tryouts at two regional theaters, the $6 million musical opened to mixed reviews at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. Upon its closing, it will have played 69 performances.

Having risen and fallen and risen again a few times already on the British airwaves, Russell Brand now finds himself in ascendance on American television, where he'll host a series of late-night specials for the FX cable network next year, FX announced on Thursday. Mr. Brand, the irrepressible comedian, actor, author and personality, will shoot six episodes of an unscripted series that will offer his ''unvarnished, unfiltered take on current events, politics and pop culture,'' according to a news release from FX, and capture his unpredictable interactions with a studio audience.

Planning a party this holiday season? The insurer MetLife reports that some two-thirds of potential hosts say they will take extra steps to protect their belongings during parties this year, including plans to ''lock, hide or move'' their valuables. (Which begs the question: Who are they inviting to their eggnog shindigs, anyway?) In addition to safeguarding pricey items, the survey found, potential hosts also said they planned to restrict the party to a central location. Metlife - which, of course, is in the business of worrying about theft and other risks - suggests in a news release that such steps are ''common sense'' when less-well-known neighbors, co-workers and casual acquaintances are included on the guest list.

The Personal Health column on Tuesday, about factors that stifle the reporting of sexual assault, using outdated information from an advocacy group's Web site, misstated the number of Americans who were victims of sexual violence last year, according to the Department of Justice. It is 188,830 -- not 272,350, the corresponding figure from 2006. (The error was repeated on Thursday in an article about a survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on sexual violence and domestic abuse.)

-Holiday spending is a source of concern and stress for many Americans, even as they plan to spend less money, according to recent CBS News polls. A third say they feel more stress than usual about the amount they plan to spend on gifts, and half are concerned they will not be able to afford the gifts on their list this season. And with these anxieties, few anticipate spending any more this year than last year. -Not surprisingly, household income plays a role in how people consider their holiday budgets. Those who are less affluent are more likely to spend less money on gifts this year, are more concerned about not being able to afford what they want to buy, and express more anxiety about the spending money on gifts this year. The poll was taken Nov. 18-21 with 951 adults.

Wynton Marsalis, the virtuoso jazz trumpet player and longtime artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, is adding another job to his resume: television commentator. CBS News announced on Thursday that Mr. Marsalis would begin appearing on its morning shows as a ''cultural correspondent'' in mid-January. Though his precise role is unclear, the announcement said the 50-year-old jazz artist from New Orleans would offer ''insight into a broad range of cultural and educational developments.''

UNSCHULD--Fay, on December 15, 2011. Beloved wife of Ben, devoted mother of Ira, cherished sister of Lorraine Zam, dear aunt of Edward, Adele, Henry and Allison. She will always be with us. Service Sunday, 11:15am, at "The Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Over the past year visual-art obsessives have been having a field day with the feature of the Google smart-phone app called Google Goggles, which allows a user to shoot a picture of something - a painting, a photograph, a poster - and in seconds see an identification of the image and a list of search results for more information about it. The app, which was introduced for Android phones in late 2009 and last year for the iPhone, has been getting much better recently at digging up the title, artist and art-historical provenance of the work that the phone camera is looking at. Part of the credit for that can go to holders of huge art-image databases like the J. Paul Getty Museum, which provided Google several months ago with access to several hundred images from its collection, becoming the first museum to do so.

WESSEL--John C. John C. Wessel, formerly of NYC, died at home on December 9 in Pennsylvania from ALS. Born in St. Louis in 1941, a Graduate of the Goodman School of the Art Institute of Chicago, he spent five seasons at the St. Louis Municipal Opera and two seasons on Broadway with Phoenix Rep. He served in the Peace Corps in Venezuela 1966-68, worked for the Arts & Education Council of St. Louis, as Director of the Staten Island Council on the Arts, at the New York State Council on the Arts, and as regional representative for the National Endowment for the Arts from 1977-84. In 1979, he met William C. O'Connor, his joy, strength, and love for the next 33 years. They were married in 2008. They moved to Rome, Italy in 1985 and opened the Wessel O'Connor Gallery, then relocated to New York by 1987. In addition to his husband, survived by siblings Ginger (and John) Williams of Chicago, Tom (and Susan) Wessel of Ironton, MO, Jerry (and Joan) Wessel of Poplar Bluff, MO, and Edward Jr. (and Babette) Wessel of St. Louis, by numerous nephews and nieces, and eight O'Connor siblings. Memorial Mass January 21 at St. Francis Xavier Church 46 W. 16 St., NYC at 10:30am. Donations in his honor may be made to La Mama ETC, 74A East 4th St., New York 10003

Rick Perry of Texas has been beating the drum about cutting the pay of Congress in half -- or by 75 percent under one plan -- a proposal that has become a cornerstone of his presidential campaign platform. But he boosted his own taxpayer-financed compensation by about 60 percent this year, Jay Root at The Texas Tribune reports.

Knoller--Otto, M.D. Died Wednesday, December 14, 2011 at age 98, after life of courage, honor and 48 years medical practice. Beloved husband of 62 years of Lotte and devoted father of Judy, Mark and Cindy.

LE MARS, Iowa -- Laura Bush, a former librarian, dedicated herself as first lady to improving reading. Michele Obama wants to help children become healthier. But if Michele Bachmann becomes president, her husband, Marcus, said Friday that he would use his time as first spouse to wage a pro-marriage, pro-family and pro-life campaign.

Fifty years after they first played together, the Beach Boys announced Friday that they would release a new studio album and go on a 50-date tour in 2012, beginning with a reunion concert at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage festival in April. The line-up for the reunion tour will include the group's original leaders Brian Wilson and Mike Love, along with one of the first members, Al Jardine. Those three were part of the original quintet that formed in Hawthorne, Calif., in 1961, and fused Chuck Berry guitar parts with smooth harmonies to celebrate surf culture. Two other early members will join them: David Marks, who joined the group in 1962 for their first album ''Surfin' Safari'' on Capitol Records; and Bruce Johnston, who joined the band in 1965 after Brian Wilson quit touring to focus on writing songs.

Since the federal government does not recognize same-sex marriage, such couples are viewed as strangers in many spheres of their financial lives. They need to file separate federal tax returns, for instance. And sometimes, that can come with certain advantages. Take the adoption tax credit. If you adopt your spouse's child, you cannot claim the credit. But since same-sex married couples are not considered spouses under federal law, they are permitted to use the credit -- at least until their unions are recognized.

An article in some editions on Nov. 2 about Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman's off-season plans after signing a contract extension referred imprecisely to Albert Pujols, Prince Fielder and Carlos Beltran. At the time, they were free agents, although their current teams had exclusive negotiating rights with them until Nov. 3; the players were not ''likely to become free agents.'' (A reader pointed out the error shortly after the article was published, but editors did not follow through on the complaint.)

A miniature handwritten magazine created by Charlotte Bronte when she was 14 years old was sold to a Paris museum for nearly 700,000, or $1.1 million, at an auction at Sotheby's in London on Thursday. The sale was not only a record for a Bronte manuscript but also a significant blow to the Bronte Parsonage Museum in Haworth, West Yorkshire, which had received a grant of more than $900,000 from the National Heritage Memorial Fund, along with a number of public donations, after an appeal to keep the 1.5 by 2.5-inch manuscript in Britain.

An article on Page 36 this weekend about Benton Harbor, Mich., misstates the title of an official in a neighboring city and refers imprecisely to the concern he expressed about the rising number of Benton Harbor's requests for help from his department. The official, who was not quoted by name, is the fire chief of St. Joseph, not the police chief, and Benton Harbor has been requesting help for its firefighters, not for its police force.

The Staten Island Ferry's terminals are bereft of holiday decor this year. Commuters may grouse, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Friday that the city's Transportation Department did the right thing by skipping the Christmas trees, menorahs and holiday lights that had festooned the terminals in previous years. ''The Department of Transportation got sued one time too many,'' the mayor said.

World-renowned in the fields of strabismus and ocular electromyography, Dr. Breinin will also be remembered for his erudition, creativity and wit. We extend our condolences to his family and friends. Jack Dodick, MD Professor and Chairman

William Berloni, the animal trainer who won a special Tony in June but has had trouble finding Broadway work because of the expense of using live animals, is aiming to return in a big way. He's part of the creative team for ''Because of Winn-Dixie,'' a musical adaptation of Kate DiCamillo's best-selling novel about a 10-year-old girl who connects with her remote father with the help of a stray dog picked up in a supermarket. He'll be working closely with the show's star, an Irish wolfhound named Taran who he discovered at a Connecticut breeder when he was five months old.

Daniel Ruettinger may have turned his tale as one of the sports world's ultimate underdogs into a highly profitable motivational speaking career and the movie ''Rudy.'' But his reputation wasn't enough to ward off fraud charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The agency on Friday sued Mr. Ruettinger and 12 others in federal district court in Las Vegas, charging them with running a pump-and-dump investment scheme in 2008 that reaped more than $11 million in illicit gains.

CONLON--James Thomas, 64, of Kansas City, MO, passed away unexpectedly on December 10, 2011. Jim was born May 20, 1947 to Jim and Carolyn Conlon in New York. Jim was an outstanding baseball player at St. Sebastian School (graduated 1965) and at Holy Cross, where he earned a Bachelor's degree in History in 1969. Jim was a powerful lefty pitcher who played in the minor leagues before an injury led him to obtaining a law degree from Fordham University in 1972. He practiced law as an assistant district attorney in Westchester County, NY, then as a partner at Bauer & Gardner. For 25 years he was a litigation partner with Sedgwick, Detert, Moran and Arnold of New York City, where he handled many high profile products liability cases and was an excellent trial lawyer. Jim was predeceased by his parents and is survived by a daughter, Heather, 22, from his earlier marriage to Barbara Conlon. He leaves behind his wife, Leanne DeShong, of Kansas City, MO. and stepchildren Serena, 12, Zach, 11 and Zoe, 9. He was a devoted husband and family man. Despite his formidable accomplishments, Jim was always a gentle, humble man who was unfailingly kind and generous to everyone. Services: Muehlebach Funeral Home, www.muehlebachchapel.com, where condolences may be left for the family.

BREININ--Goodwin M.,93, died peacefully in New York City on December 14, 2011. Known as Dud, he was a leading ophthalmologist as well as a true renaissance man, who loved literature and the arts as much as medicine and science. Born in New York City, he earned masters and medical degrees from Emory University. Dud served two years in the Army during World War II and achieved the rank of Captain. He did his residency at New York University Medical Center and Bellevue Hospital, ultimately becoming the Kirby Professor and Chairman of the Department of Ophthalmology in 1959, a position he would hold until 2000, and remained a full professor until 2006. Dud not only trained generations of future ophthalmologists and undertook and supported significant medical research, but also became a world-famous surgeon specializing in diseases of the eye muscle. Dud was a leader of many medical organizations, including the American Academy of Ophthalmology and the American Board of Ophthalmology; authored or co-authored several books and over 100 articles in his field; and received numerous awards, including the American Medical Association Knapp Medal for Contributions to Ophthalmology and the Emory Medal, the highest distinction conferred by Emory University. Dud was a member of the Century Association in New York City, and the Cosmos Club in Washington, DC. He was married for 58 years to the late Rose-Helen Breinin, an art historian. A beloved father and grandfather, Dud is survived by his children Bartley J. Breinin, of Rye, New York, and Constance Paton, of Basking Ridge, New Jersey, their spouses Rachel Breinin and Nigel Paton, and four grandchildren, Alexander, Sarah, Caroline and Emma. Services will be held at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City on Sunday, December 18 at 10:30am.

Mark Goldweber, who was a leading classical dancer with the Joffrey Ballet in the 1970s and '80s and who won wide acclaim as the Blue Skater in Frederick Ashton's ballet ''Patineurs,'' died on Dec. 9 in Salt Lake City. He was 53. The cause was lymphoma, said Adam Sklute, the artistic director of Ballet West in Salt Lake City, where Mr. Goldweber was the ballet master.

8 P.M. (HBO) RED RIDING HOOD (2011) Amanda Seyfried, above, boogieing down in a bacchanal that's more Burning Man than Bruegel, portrays the young woman in the red cloak as a natural-born killer in this adult adaptation of the fairy tale, directed by Catherine Hardwicke. Julie Christie is Red's grandmother, rocking the screen in dreadlocks. And Gary Oldman is Father Solomon, a religious zealot summoned to vanquish the computer-generated wolf. ''The suggestion that Red Riding Hood might be as much predator as prey isn't new,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''She may be the intended victim, but she's also the one who (after sizing up the wolf in bed) ends triumphant. It's this blurring between the antagonists as well as the flexibility of the story's morals and meanings that make it work well for different readers and writers.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton reports on the choir of St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minn., which for 100 years has presented a Christmas festival. Kate Olson profiles Martin S. Laird of Villanova University, an Augustinian priest who teaches the Christian practice of contemplation and begins his classes with 15 minutes of silence.
Xavier the Magician does not think rabbits are exciting. ''I want people to go ooh and aah,'' he said. ''Maybe when I was in fifth grade a rabbit was exciting. I did go aah for a rabbit once.''

An article and a headline on Friday about a report on corruption and abuse by local police forces in Afghanistan misidentified the originator of the report. It was the United States Forces-Afghanistan, not NATO.

Friday was a busy day for UEFA in Nyon, Switzerland, as the draws for the next rounds of the Champions and Europa leagues were held. With the group stage of the Europa League, the secondary continental tournament, completed only on Thursday, the sport's European governing body put aside preparations for this summer's Euro 2012 to set up the first knockout stages of the two tournaments.

LOOMIS--Philip Clark, 85, died December 16, 2011, after an extended illness. He is survived by Greta, his wife of 42 years; son Philip C. from his first marriage and brother Lynn Mather Loomis. After Navy service, Mr. Loomis graduated from Yale in 1949, Wharton in 1950. During his Wall Street career he was known as an innovative and ethical director of equities research. A late comer to New York City, he loved living in Manhattan and served as his co-op's Treasurer for 15 years. Talented pianist, opera devotee, intrepid traveler, stalwart Obama supporter. As he requested, no services.

Because of an editing error, an obituary in some copies on Friday about the writer Christopher Hitchens referred incorrectly to the circumstances of his death. While he did die at the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, he had not entered hospice care there, and he had not stopped treatment. The obituary also misstated the source of a remark by Mr. Hitchens, an avowed atheist, about the possibility of a deathbed conversion. It came from a 2010 interview with The Atlantic, not with The New York Times. And the obituary also misstated the frequency of ''Minority Report,'' the column Mr. Hitchens wrote for The Nation. It appeared biweekly, not bimonthly.

Stephen Schlossberg, a onetime garment workers' organizer who rose to become general counsel of the United Automobile Workers and a top official in the Labor Department under President Ronald Reagan, died on Dec. 10 at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 90. The cause was congestive heart failure, said his wife, Nancy.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - Today's constructor, Richard Chisholm, has not been seen around these parts for almost a year, but he's actually a fairly prolific puzzle maker. Mr. Chisholm has had crosswords published in The New York Times on all days of the week except for those most difficult days, Friday and Saturday. Come on, Mr. Chisholm; hit for the cycle already. Not that that makes a good constructor; hitting for the cycle is not really any more important than producing a puzzle that happens to be a pangram. It would just be fun to add another constructor to the list of those who have already done so.

Among the tributes coming in after the death of Vaclav Havel, the playwright who helped found the Czech Republic and was its president for a decade, are several from the theater world. "There is less morality in politics with his death," Natalia Koliada, a co-founder of the Belarus Free Theater, which had a supporter in Mr. Havel, wrote on her Twitter feed. (The company's play "Being Harold Pinter" made Ben Brantley's list of the best shows of 2011.) The Public Theater, which produced the American premieres of several of Mr. Havel's plays, wrote on Twitter: "We are saddened by the death of Vaclav Havel."

New Yorkers will have a chance to see the Sydney Theater Company's celebrated production of "Uncle Vanya" with Cate Blanchett and Hugo Weaving next summer. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, will be presented at City Center from July 19 through July 28 as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, a festival spokeswoman, Eileen McMahon, said. Ms. Blanchett plays Yelena, and Mr. Weaving plays Astrov in the farcical-yet-heartbreaking production, which was staged by the Hungarian director Tamas Ascher. Ms. Blanchett's husband, Andrew Upton, provided the actors a new English translation of Chekov's in 1897 play in Russian.

Hedy Lamarr, the beautiful Hollywood star of the 1930s and '40s, was an inventor of technology that years later would be used in things like cellphones, Bluetooth and GPS devices. A new book by Richard Rhodes tells her story and touches on deeper themes like the gender biases against beautiful and intelligent women. Read the entire book review in The New York Times.

Bells are ringing in Hollywood, but they're not the Christmas kind. Two big sequels, "Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows" and "Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked," delivered shaky results over the weekend, alarming studios about a continued downturn at the North American box office. "A Game of Shadows" (Warner Brothers) was No. 1 with about $40 million in ticket sales. Analysts had expected that film, which cost $125 million to make, to take in over $50 million; the first installment in this franchise opened with $62 million in 2009. "Chipwrecked" (20th Century Fox) was second, taking in about $23.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. That result was 52 percent below the opening weekend total for the last Chipmunks movie in 2009. "Chip-Wrecked" cost an estimated $80 million to make. A variety of factors could have dented interest: sequel fatigue, family film overload, higher ticket prices, a lack of overall momentum at the box office. Elsewhere, Tom Cruise's "Mission: Impossible -- Ghost Protocol" (Paramount) was a powerful third, taking in about $13 million in limited release on 425 Imax screens. That result set an Imax record and positioned "Ghost Protocol" as a potential blockbuster and career rebound for Mr. Cruise as it expands nationwide on Wednesday. "New Year's Eve" (Warner) was fourth with about $7.4 million in ticket sales, lifting its two-week total to $24.8 million. "The Sitter" (Fox) was fifth, taking in an estimated $4.4 million for a two-week total of $17.7 million.

Chris Mullin made plenty of basketball news this year despite the N.B.A. lockout. He was elected to the Naismith Memorial Hall of Fame and the National Collegiate Basketball Hall of Fame, and honored by the Buoniconti Fund to Cure Paralysis for his charity work.

BLUM--Donald J. 87, died December 12, 2011. Son of Madelaine & Joseph K. Blum. Lifelong resident of Scarsdale, NY. WWII veteran, survivor of the sinking of the USS Indianapolis. Member of the Old Guard. Skier, sailor, golfer, mechanical engineer. Celebrated 60 years of marriage to Sandra. Children Linda, James, Thomas & grandchildren: Aza, Aviva, Henry, Tiina, Aenea, Eric, Annie, Mark & Lauren. Also survived by sister Elizabeth Landauer and brother Roger G. Blum. Donations to Human Development Services of Westchester or Rails-to-Trails.
The Makers column on Dec. 4, about the credit card, misstated part of the title of an 1888 novel by Edward Bellamy that used the term ''credits cards.'' It is ''Looking Backward,'' not ''Backwards.''

SEVIN--Geraldine. Mom, I miss you so much - I am not ashamed you were a great mother to all of us- I tried to do everything, everything I could during the 5 years your were ill. You were an iconic woman who had integrity, charm, and brilliance (in many ways). I thought by now - (its over six months since you left us) - that I would have adjusted better. Mother you and Daddy set very high standards! I will and always have tried to reach them. I am caring forth the best way I can. I am so sad. We will meet again. I love you so, so much. Think of you every moment of everyday. Happy Birthday! Love always your son, Seth

A picture caption in some editions last Sunday with an article about Navy's 27-21 victory over Army misidentified the Army player carrying the American flag before the game. He is Kingsley Ehie, not Stephen Fraser.

Redskins (4-9) at Giants (7-6), 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox Matchup to Watch: Giants linebackers vs. running back Roy Helu The Giants held Tim Hightower, the starting running back at the time, to 72 yards rushing in the season-opening loss to Washington, but Helu has excellent speed to the outside and will require some discipline from the Giants' linebackers. Overpursuing will be punished, and the Giants must contain Helu if they hope to keep him from continuing his streak of three games with 100 or more yards. Number to Watch: 33 That's how many touchbacks kicker Lawrence Tynes has recorded this season with three games remaining. Tynes's previous career high? Eight. Tynes acknowledged that the N.F.L.'s moving up the kickoff spot 5 yards had contributed to the touchbacks, but he also noted that he had three off-season operations (one for a hernia, two on his feet) and feels healthier than he has in years.

OAKFORD--Barbara Woolworth, New Canaan, CT, died on December 12, 2011. Survived by her five children: Richard W. Oakford, Malcolm Douglas Oakford, Scott I. Oakford, Lynn O. Reilly, William B. Oakford, 13 grandchildren and one great-grandson. Predeceased by her husband, Malcolm Isdale Oakford. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Darien, CT on December 20th at 11am.

To the Editor: On my way to an emergency visit to the dentist this morning, to see if I need to have a tooth pulled, I read the Sunday Styles article by Bruce Feiler, ''Curtain Up on Act II for the Tooth Fairy'' (This Life, Dec. 11). How ironic that at 6, children await the reward that comes from a visit from the tooth fairy, celebrating their first loss.

LOOMIS--Philip Clark, 85, died December 16, 2011, after an extended illness. He is survived by Greta, his wife of 42 years; son Philip C. from his first marriage and brother Lynn Mather Loomis. After Navy service, Mr. Loomis graduated from Yale in 1949, Wharton in 1950. During his Wall Street career he was known as an innovative and ethical director of equities research. A late comer to New York City, he loved living in Manhattan and served as his co-op's Treasurer for 15 years. Talented pianist, opera devotee, intrepid traveler, stalwart Obama supporter. As he requested, no services.

With the multitudes flocking to London next year for the Olympic Games, some of Britain's other offerings may get overlooked. The British Heritage Cities Web site provides a reminder in the form of eight new themed itineraries to Bath, Carlisle, Chester, Oxford, Stratford and York. Five plans are designed for visitors arriving at Heathrow. They include the theater-based ''Treading the Boards'' tour that goes through sleepy villages and market towns of the Cotswolds, and ''Girls Getaway,'' which visits an herbal healing garden and the ancient Roman Baths, a temple and bathing complex built around Britain's only hot spring that still flows with natural hot water.

ROD--Robert L.,Ph.D (1920-2011). Engineer, Inventor, Environmentalist, Entrepreneur, YPOer. Loved and cherished by wife, Shirley and children, Patricia (Tim) Jennings and Dean (Rani Paul) Rod. Our Hero!

CONLON--James Thomas, 64, of Kansas City, MO, passed away unexpectedly on December 10, 2011. Jim was born May 20, 1947 to Jim and Carolyn Conlon in New York. Jim was an outstanding baseball player at St. Sebastian School (graduated 1965) and at Holy Cross, where he earned a Bachelor's degree in History in 1969. Jim was a powerful lefty pitcher who played in the minor leagues before an injury led him to obtaining a law degree from Fordham University in 1972. He practiced law as an assistant district attorney in Westchester County, NY, then as a partner at Bauer & Gardner. For 25 years he was a litigation partner with Sedgwick, Detert, Moran and Arnold of New York City, where he handled many high profile products liability cases and was an excellent trial lawyer. Jim was predeceased by his parents and is survived by a daughter, Heather, 22, from his earlier marriage to Barbara Conlon. He leaves behind his wife, Leanne DeShong, of Kansas City, MO. and stepchildren Serena, 12, Zach, 11 and Zoe, 9. He was a devoted husband and family man. Despite his formidable accomplishments, Jim was always a gentle, humble man who was unfailingly kind and generous to everyone. Services: Muehlebach Funeral Home, www.muehlebachchapel.com, where condolences may be left for the family.

UNSCHULD--Fay, on December 15, 2011. Beloved wife of Ben, devoted mother of Ira, cherished sister of Lorraine Zam, dear aunt of Edward, Adele, Henry and Allison. She will always be with us. Service Sunday, 11:15am, at "The Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

ARMSTRONG--Noel, of Lexington, VA died on November 24, 2011. Born September 6, 1918, raised at Danskammer Farm, Newburgh, NY. Son of Anne Corbin Harper and Noel Armstrong. Retired Second Lieutenant in the U.S. Army 10th Light Division (Alpine) in Camp Hale, CO. during WWII. Loving father of Noel, Katherine and Corbin; ten grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.

IN March, Justin Mott photographed the temples and pagodas in and around Bagan, Myanmar, just as deeply flawed elections in that country led to a new president and the possible easing of travel restrictions. Myanmar has been under military rule in one form or another since 1962, but since the elections, tourists have begun to trickle in, eager to be among the first few to explore the country as it opens. ''The country is a traveler's paradise with all the treasures of Southeast Asia but without all the tourists,'' Mr. Mott wrote. ''For the early riser, novice monks with their saffron robes are there to see, in perfect composition for a photographer. Wherever you go you will rarely have a smile unreturned. It's easy to forget that the country's beloved Nobel Peace Prize recipient Daw Aung San Suu Kyi was under house arrest for the better part of the past two decades before her release in November.'' See more of Justin Mott's photographs at nytimes.com/travel.
BERMAN--Marc Joseph December 18, 1980. If not for you, couldn't hear the robin sing.

An opinion essay on Dec. 11 about anti-Catholic prejudice during the 1928 presidential campaign of Alfred E. Smith, the first Roman Catholic governor of New York State, referred imprecisely to Hugh L. Carey, a later governor. While Mr. Carey, who served from 1975 to 1982, was the second Catholic to be elected governor of New York, he was not the second Catholic to hold the position. (The second Catholic governor was Malcolm Wilson, who succeeded to the office when Nelson A. Rockefeller resigned in 1973, and lost to Mr. Carey in the 1974 election.)

TEUFEL--Peggy (Marjorie), 91, of Huntington, NY, on December 14, 2011. Longtime civic activist and "professional volunteer" having held many offices and fulfilled many positions in the non-profit sector. Named Outstanding Volunteer Fundraiser by the National Society of Fundraising Executives in 1992. Peg will be remembered for strength and independence, her liberal views and her dedication to the needs of others. She believed that the purpose of life is to do good deeds - and she did. In lieu of a funeral, a memorial celebration in recognition of Peggy's life is being planned. For more information on this event, please e-mail: neteufel@aol.com. Contributions in memory of Peggy can be made to any of the following: The Harborfields Public Library; The Greenlawn - Centerport Historical Association; The Guide Dog Foundation of Smithtown. Peggy will be missed, but not forgotten.

An article last Sunday about the aftermath of Bernard L. Madoff's Ponzi scheme misstated the role of Howard Siegel, a victim of the scheme, in a fund that had invested with Mr. Madoff. Although Mr. Siegel invested in that fund and is now a member of its investment committee, he never ran the fund.

BREININ--Goodwin M.,93, died peacefully in New York City on December 14, 2011. Known as Dud, he was a leading ophthalmologist as well as a true renaissance man, who loved literature and the arts as much as medicine and science. Born in New York City, he earned masters and medical degrees from Emory University. Dud served two years in the Army during World War II and achieved the rank of Captain. He did his residency at New York University Medical Center and Bellevue Hospital, ultimately becoming the Kirby Professor and Chairman of the Department of Ophthalmology in 1959, a position he would hold until 2000, and remained a full professor until 2006. Dud not only trained generations of future ophthalmologists and undertook and supported significant medical research, but also became a world-famous surgeon specializing in diseases of the eye muscle. Dud was a leader of many medical organizations, including the American Academy of Ophthalmology and the American Board of Ophthalmology; authored or co-authored several books and over 100 articles in his field; and received numerous awards, including the American Medical Association Knapp Medal for Contributions to Ophthalmology and the Emory Medal, the highest distinction conferred by Emory University. Dud was a member of the Century Association in New York City, and the Cosmos Club in Washington, DC. He was married for 58 years to the late Rose-Helen Breinin, an art historian. A beloved father and grandfather, Dud is survived by his children Bartley J. Breinin, of Rye, New York, and Constance Paton, of Basking Ridge, New Jersey, their spouses Rachel Breinin and Nigel Paton, and four grandchildren, Alexander, Sarah, Caroline and Emma. Services will be held at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City on Sunday, December 18 at 10:30am.

MORGAN--Robert R.,on December 10, 2011, of New York City passed away peacefully after a hard fought battle with Merkel cell cancer. He was born in Beverly, MA to Sterlyn R. and A. Louise (Smith) Morgan. His lifelong fascination with all forms of classical music was sparked by the fact that both his father and grandfather were musicians. Entering Columbia College in 1956 proved a transforming experience through all the college and New York offered. Mr. Morgan taught social studies in the City's junior high school system for over thirty years, learning from his students as he taught them. Upon his retirement, he pursued his interest in painting, primarily at the National Academy Museum and School under Ms. Michele Licalsi and the Art Student League, most recently with Mr. William Scharf. He also enjoyed a long association with the Ward-Nasse Gallery on Prince Street. An avid traveler, he covered many miles in forty eight states and six continents, missing only Australia. An engaging person with wide ranging interests, he was blessed with many circles of friends. Mr. Morgan is survived by two sisters - Nancy Morgan of Danvers, MA (currently here), and Faye (Morgan) Rees of Halfmoon, NY - and a cousin Robert Smith of Ipswich, MA. A celebration of his life will be held in late January. For those who wish, donations in his honor can be made to your favorite charity or to Goddard Riverside Community Center, 593 Columbus Avenue, New York, NY 10024 Attn: Development Office or online www.goddard.org.

WIENER--Milton, died peacefully on December 5, 2011, at the age of 92. He was the beloved husband of Eleanor for 70 years; the cherished father of Alan Wiener and his wife Frances; daughters Karen (Alston) and Robin Wiener; and the proud Pop of Matthew and his wife Jennifer, David, Elizabeth and her husband Julian; Santi and his wife Rachel; and great-grandfather of Madelyn, Amelia, Ayva and Hazel. He was a Veteran of WWII and a devoted Yankees fan. Milton will be deeply missed by his family and friends. A memorial gathering to be announced. Donations in his memory may be made to Sunsounds, 2323 W. 14th St, Tempe, AZ 85281 or ReMIND, Bob Woodruff Foundation, PO Box 955, Bristow, VA 20136.

ERIK ANDERSON and Josh Habiger, the executive chefs at the Catbird Seat, Nashville's hottest new restaurant, embrace what many food purists discourage -- namely, direct contact with the chef, dietary restrictions and boisterous chatter. Rather than being tucked away, the kitchen is out in the open and cradled by a bar where people eat, drink and watch every culinary move. ''We think that in a normal restaurant setting, the chef plays such a removed role from experience of the diner,'' Mr. Anderson said. ''Our relationship with the person eating doesn't stop when we are done plating the food.'' The two greet the guests and cook and serve artful dishes like pressed duck leg coupled with savory granola and 72-hour slow-cooked wagyu beef dusted with a blackened kale ash. The theme of unexpected whimsy carries through dessert: soft bits of vanilla cake with smoked-oak ice cream and bourbon bullets -- little beads that pop in your mouth like caviar. The Catbird Seat, 1711 Division Street, Nashville; thecatbirdseatrestaurant.com. Open Wednesday to Saturday from 5:30 to 10 p.m. Prix fixe, $100; optional beverage pairing, $35 or $75. Reservations are required. KATIE CHANG
Pop Nate Chinen

An article on Nov. 20 about fracking, the process of extracting gas from shale, in western Pennsylvania referred imprecisely to the history of an area there. The Native American village Annawanna exists in oral tradition and in the journal of a descendant of colonial settlers, but can be found in no other official documentation.
