The Vows column last Sunday, about the wedding of Mary Boyle and Matthew Long, misstated part of the name of the organization for which the bridegroom is a spokesman. It is the New York Blood Center, not the New York Blood Bank. The column also misstated part of the name of the military institution at which the bride's father had served as president. It is the United States Naval War College, not the United States Naval War Academy.

The ''Block by Block'' column on Nov. 13, about DeKalb Avenue in Brooklyn, misstated the age and address of Darrell Cooper, a longtime resident there and board president of his co-op, the 181-183 DeKalb Owners Corporation. He is 46, not 42; and he bought units in No. 183, not 181. The article also described Mr. Cooper's job in the legal field incorrectly. It is in electronic discovery, not electronic recovery.

CHAITKIN--David. b. New York 1938, d. Willow, NY, December 15, 2011. Composer, pianist and longtime New York resident. The cause was cancer. He followed early experience as a jazz musician with studies at Pomona College and UC Berkeley, where he received the Ladd Prix de Paris. He composed symphonic, chamber and vocal works. His commissions and awards included the Guggenheim Foundation, the NEA, Chamber Music America, and the American Academy of Arts and Letters. He taught at Reed College, NYU, and Brooklyn College. He is survived by his wife Carol, son Nathaniel, two grandchildren, two sisters and a brother. Donations can be made to the Music Division of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts.

Here's a reader's comment on Ben Brantley's column about Hugh Jackman and his one-man show on Broadway. ''Ben Brantley is a great critic, always thoughtful, always able to put his finger on the one thing lacking that might have put a show over the top. But in this case Brantley's longing for the tragedy of a Judy Garland or Liza Minnelli is understandable but misguided. Their sadness resonated with audiences, particularly gay men, who could never be who they were in their time or place, the same sadness as the blues before the civil rights movement. Hugh Jackman's joy, and what resonates with audiences is, in fact, the opposite. Hugh Jackman could be gay -- it wouldn't matter. And that is what he is trying to say.''

PARIS THE wreaths, the sprays and the clusters of creamy white flowers -- even an elegant boot fashioned out of rose petals -- made a fitting backdrop at l'Église Saint-Roch for the departure of François Lesage, the artist of embroidery, mourned on Dec. 7 in the world of Paris couture.

AS an alternative to the sentimental letter-stamped gold coins that have been dangling from necklaces long and short in recent years, the jewelry designer Jennifer Fisher created these great street-inspired gothic script charms. ''They remind me of the skate and Latino cultures in Santa Barbara, Calif., where I grew up,'' Ms. Fisher said. ''The Black Letter type style was the predominant font for skin art and tattoos.'' Each letter in the alphabet comes in yellow gold, rose gold and diamond pavé, and is sold separately so you can customize your chain. Consider the message shown above a not-so-subtle hint. Jennifer Fisher large gothic letters, $125. Go to jenniferfisherjewelry.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

MOTHER MARY MAGDALENE had a dilemma. She had started a new Roman Catholic order, the Community of Compassion, in Fort Worth, and she needed something for the sisters to wear. ''You can't just go to the store and buy a habit,'' she said. ''Every order has to have a distinct one, and you're not supposed to copy anyone else.'' Not only that, many old habits (some of them gorgeous) have been lost forever when their order died out. Mother Mary's research led her to the Web site of Julia Sherman, a New York artist who had photographed the nun dolls at Cross in the Woods museum in Indian Wells, Mich. One thing led to another, and before she knew it, Ms. Sherman, who is Jewish, was designing a habit for the Sisters of Compassion (with the only requirements being modesty and the use of natural materials). She also persuaded her friend Jesse Finkelstein, one of the owners of JF & Son, to manufacture the sisters' habits along with a collection of lay garments, like the beaded collar ($288) and tunic ($312), right, inspired by it. Go to jfandson.com. RIMA SUQI

Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy). Cam Newton (CAR) vs. Houston - Newton, who went undrafted in most leagues, has surprisingly carried the many fantasy teams that were lucky enough to grab him off the waiver wire early this season. But just when you need him the most, if you're in one of the many leagues starting their fantasy playoffs this week, he gets his toughest matchup (statistically) of the season in Week 15. The Texans stop the run and pass almost equally well, ranking fourth in the league against the ground game and third against the pass. No quarterback has posted more than 20 fantasy points on them since Drew Brees back in Week 3.

To the Editor:

FUR is a much more common sight in Russia than it is in the United States -- clearly, groups like People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals haven't been able to make as many inroads. In December, ads for fur shows can be seen throughout Moscow. A typical mink coat sells for $3,000, while a sable coat can go for around $30,000. Some of the coats are made in Russia, but many brands have moved production to countries like China, where labor is cheaper. Regardless of their coats' source, Russians have shown little sign of loosening their hold on a fashion born of harsh weather and long tradition.

The sand dunes of Glamis, Calif., are a majestic expanse of pristine sand and sky. Until the dune buggies arrive, that is. On weekends, thousands of them -- as well as motorcycles and pickups and pretty much anything with wheels -- descend on this barren stretch 150 miles east of San Diego. Glamis has been a mecca for sand racing since the 1950s. But these are not the dune buggies of ''Scooby-Doo.'' These vehicles -- some of them customized at a cost of $200,000 -- can go 120 m.p.h. The weekend after Thanksgiving is traditionally one of the most popular; this year, 142,000 people showed up: professional drivers, thrill-seekers, families watching the races and deep-frying turkeys under giant umbrellas. There's no prize money, and no one is really in charge. After sundown, things tend to get a little debauched, according to Phil Pendergist, a Glamis regular. ''You're out in the middle of the desert,'' he said. ''People like to cut loose.'' area of glamis dunes: 200 Square miles

An article on Page 36 this weekend about Benton Harbor, Mich., misstates the title of an official in a neighboring city and refers incorrectly to the concern he expressed about the rising number of Benton Harbor's requests for help from his department. The official, who was not quoted by name, is the fire chief of St. Joseph, not the police chief, and Benton Harbor has been requesting help for its firefighters, not its police force.

An article on Dec. 4 about the history of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science misstated the role of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences in awarding Nobel prizes. Although it bestows the prizes in physics, chemistry and economics, it does not award them in other Nobel categories.

SantaCon, the annual street happening in which nearly 5,000 costumed participants join in a day of good cheer, eating and drinking, was last Saturday. The event, founded in 1994 in San Francisco, is now held in Washington, Los Angeles, Philadelphia and New York, among many other places. This year's more or less impromptu event started at the yacht basin of the World Financial Center and moved through the 19th-century cow-path streets of the financial district to South Street Seaport, eventually ending up at Grand Central Terminal.

FANNON--Betty Spencer, of Bronxville, New York, died on July 25th, after a very brief illness. Born on August 18, 1923 in Providence, RI to Everett L. and Irene Hurley Spencer, and raised in Barrington, RI, and later Providence, by her mother and stepfather, Dr. Francis H. Beckett, Betty attended the Lincoln School and Bradford College. She married Marcy B. Fannon on June 14, 1945 and they lived in RI until Marcy completed his service in the US Navy in late 1945. He predeceased her in 1997 after 52 years of marriage. After World War II, Betty and Marcy lived in Hempstead, NY, then Wilmington, DE and then settled for ten years in Kansas City, KS and MO. They moved to Bronxville in 1959 and spent summers in Saunderstown, RI. In Bronxville, Betty was an active volunteer in school and community organizations. She was a member of the Junior League of Bronxville and served as president of the Bronxville chapter of the American Field Service student exchange program and of the Adoption Service of Westchester County. She also enjoyed a forty-year real estate career, eventually co-owning William H. Watson Realtors and retiring from Houlihan Lawrence in 2010. Betty is survived and deeply missed by her five children, Jeffrey (and his wife, Patricia), Peter, S. Kent (and his wife Diane), Elizabeth (and her husband, William O'Leary) and Anne (and her husband, John Appleby). She is also survived by her seven grandchildren, her sister-in-law, Patricia Marshall Beckett, four nephews and one niece. Her brothers, Francis H. Beckett II and Robert M. Beckett, her sister, Evelyn Spencer Goff, and her nephew, Robert M. Beckett Jr., preceded her in death. Donations in memory of Betty may be made to the Lincoln School, 301 Butler Ave, Providence, RI 02906.

Frank Hudak Jr.: There are 70,000 bulbs, and that's not counting the ones on my coat. I spent two months crawling around on the ground doing this. I get out there by about 9 or 10 in the morning, and I'll work until sundown. I have people coming by here two weeks before, circling until the time comes to turn the lights on. We turned them on Friday night, Dec. 2 at 6 p.m. I was the deputy sheriff, but I am retired now. I've been doing this for 37 years, and I am known affectionately in parts of North America as ''Mr. Christmas.'' This really is a vision of how I feel at the holidays -- merry and bright and sometimes blinky. I work on the design layouts mostly in my head, and I go out there and do it like any artist.

WESSEL--John C. John C. Wessel, formerly of NYC, died at home on December 9 in Pennsylvania from ALS. Born in St. Louis in 1941, a Graduate of the Goodman School of the Art Institute of Chicago, he spent five seasons at the St. Louis Municipal Opera and two seasons on Broadway with Phoenix Rep. He served in the Peace Corps in Venezuela 1966-68, worked for the Arts & Education Council of St. Louis, as Director of the Staten Island Council on the Arts, at the New York State Council on the Arts, and as regional representative for the National Endowment for the Arts from 1977-84. In 1979, he met William C. O'Connor, his joy, strength, and love for the next 33 years. They were married in 2008. They moved to Rome, Italy in 1985 and opened the Wessel O'Connor Gallery, then relocated to New York by 1987. In addition to his husband, survived by siblings Ginger (and John) Williams of Chicago, Tom (and Susan) Wessel of Ironton, MO, Jerry (and Joan) Wessel of Poplar Bluff, MO, and Edward Jr. (and Babette) Wessel of St. Louis, by numerous nephews and nieces, and eight O'Connor siblings. Memorial Mass January 21 at St. Francis Xavier Church 46 W. 16 St., NYC at 10:30am. Donations in his honor may be made to La Mama ETC, 74A East 4th St., New York 10003

WILSON--Donald M. June 27, 1925 - November 29, 2011. Donald M. Wilson, 86, died Tuesday, November 29 at his home in Princeton, NJ, from a stroke following years of struggle with Alzheimer's Disease. Wilson was born in Montclair, NJ in 1925, and graduated from Deerfield Academy in 1943. He enlisted in the US Army Air Corps and was commissioned a second lieutenant as a B-17 navigator. After graduating from Yale in 1949, he started at Life Magazine as a reporter working in New York and Detroit, then became a foreign correspondent, covering the Korean War and French Indochina War. In 1956 he was named Life's Washington bureau chief. Wilson joined John F. Kennedy's presidential campaign in 1960, and was appointed deputy director of the United States Information Agency (USIA) in 1961. He was the last surviving member of the Executive Committee of the National Security Council (ExCOMM), a specially-created policy group that advised President Kennedy during the Cuban Missile Crisis in October 1962. Wilson advocated releasing reconnaissance photographs of Soviet missile sites being built in Cuba, secretly taken by an American U-2 spy plane. Publication of the classified photos was approved by ExCOMM and credited with turning the tide of British press opinion decisively in favor of the US. He left USIA in 1965 to became general manager of Time-Life International. In 1968, Wilson worked briefly on Robert F. Kennedy's presidential campaign, and in 1970 was named Time Inc. Corporate Vice President for Public Affairs, from which he tired in 1989. In 1987, Wilson and former Time magazine business editor George Taber, launched NJBIZ, a paper covering business in New Jersey. NJBIZ was acquired in 2005 by Journal Publications Inc. of Harrisburg, PA. After Communism's collapse in the Soviet Union and its client countries, Wilson and James L. Greenfield co-founded the Independent Journalism Foundation in 1991, which operates training programs for journalists in Eastern Europe and Southeast Asia. Wilson is survived by his wife of 54 years, the former Susan M. Neuberger, a son, Dwight M. Wilson of Berkeley, CA, two daughters, Katherine L. Wilson of Newton, MA, and Penelope Wilson of The Bronx, NY, and five grandchildren. A Service of Remembrance will be held on Saturday, January 28, 2012 at the Presbyterian Church of Lawrenceville in Lawrenceville, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Donald M. Wilson Fellowship, of the Robert F. Kennedy Center for Justice and Human Rights, in Washington, D.C.

About a year ago Clara Vannucci hopped on a yellow school bus as it went around the city picking up children, mothers, sisters and brothers. The destination was at the end of a long bridge in Queens - a holiday party for women jailed at Rikers Island. Ms. Vannucci, an Italian photojournalist, has been making the trip to Rikers several times a year since 2009, capturing images of these women in relaxed moments in a place that is hardly casual. They are participating in a program that offers counseling and activities for women who have been victims of domestic violence and arrested on charges related to their abuse.

Edsel B. Ford II, the great-grandson of Henry Ford, left his audience at Sardi's restaurant on Tuesday with little doubt about what he wanted from them. ''I need your help,'' Mr. Ford said amid tinkling coffee cups and dessert forks. ''I'd like you to tell all your friends that Ford has lost the punch bowl, and we want it back.''

A review on Dec. 4 about ''Rome,'' by Robert Hughes, referred incorrectly to the Renaissance architect Filippo Brunelleschi. While he intensively studied the ancient monuments in Rome, he was not one of ''the city's important architects'' -- his principal works are in Florence.

Jets (8-5) at Eagles (5-8), 4:15 p.m. Eastern, CBS Matchup to Watch: Brodney Pool and Eric Smith vs. Philadelphia's offense Into the void created by Jim Leonhard's season-ending knee injury slides Pool, whose first test teaming with Smith at safety - as it was last season - is a doozy. The Eagles are loaded with big-play threats at every skill position, and that includes tight end, the Jets' bugaboo. How Pool and Smith handle the increased responsibilities - making in-game adjustments and calls in the secondary - will play a major role in deciding whether the Jets' defense flourishes.
Art Robin Pogrebin

A four-bedroom four-bath apartment on Riverside Boulevard on the Upper West Side was the biggest sale of the week, at $6.1 million, according to city records. After several weeks of penthouses with sweeping views, ornate verandas and prime locations dominating the top of the sales lists in the city, the apartment, on the 19th floor of the Heritage at Trump Place, seems modest. It sold for significantly less than its original asking price of $7.25 million, according to Streeteasy.com.

There's nothing like stepping into the arrivals area after a long flight and seeing friends and relatives greet you with a banner welcoming you home. At Schipol Airport in Amsterdam, a new machine offers your reception party a convenient way to convey an effusive greeting: a banner-making vending machine. Since its debut last month, BannerXpress, created by Oliver Janssen and Thibaud Bruna, has been churning out about 50 banners a day, Mr. Bruna said.

To those who bemoan the lack of better choices in presidential elections, third-party fantasies come easily at this stage in a campaign. End hyper-partisanship and Washington dysfunction: Vote Bloomberg-Petraeus in 2012! Those dreams are even more vivid than usual this time around, and not just because polls show striking levels of discontent within both parties about politics as usual.

World-renowned in the fields of strabismus and ocular electromyography, Dr. Breinin will also be remembered for his erudition, creativity and wit. We extend our condolences to his family and friends. Jack Dodick, MD Professor and Chairman

Van Gogh is one of those artists people want to get close to. They want to taste his intense colors, psychoanalyze his thick and passionate brush strokes, parse the letters to his brother Theo. With his extreme close-ups in over 40 paintings, including ''Road Menders at Saint Rémy'' (above), ''Van Gogh Up Close,'' at the Philadelphia Museum of Art from Feb. 1 through May 6, will partly satisfy that desire (philamuseum.org).

Older Americans have always had a hand in rearing grandchildren. But more and more, their roles have expanded beyond dispensing advice and the occasional treat, because Grandma and Grandpa's house is home. In 2010, seven million grandparents in the United States were living with grandchildren under the age of 18, according to census data. About 2.7 million of those grandparents were the primary caregivers of one or more grandchildren. Of the primary guardians, 63 percent were female.

BREININ--Goodwin M. The trustees, faculty and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of Goodwin Breinin, MD, former chair of the Department of Ophthalmology at NYU School of Medicine. In a distinguished career lasting more than 55 years, Dr. Breinin assembled and led a pre-eminent group of research scientists and clinicians, trained generations of future ophthalmologists, and undertook significant medical research. He was a renowned surgeon specializing in diseases of the eye muscle, and his contributions to our medical school and the field of ophthalmology will live on. Kenneth G. Langone, Chair, Board of Trustees, and Robert I. Grossman, MD, Dean and CEO at NYU Langone Medical Center.

THE scent has long since faded from Cinnamon Gardens, in the Sri Lankan capital of Colombo, just blocks from the Indian Ocean. During the South Asian nation's long civil war, even Colombo's toniest residential neighborhood suffered. Fanciful colonial mansions deteriorated along once grand avenues. Abandoned storefronts, too, were among the war's collateral economic damage here. Since securing victory over the Tamil Tigers in 2009, though, President Mahinda Rajapaksa has applied his still strong arm to beautifying Colombo's streets, beginning with those in this district. Sri Lankan fashion designers and artists have followed, many returning from abroad, while boutique hotels, like the 10-room Tintagel, and chic restaurants and cafes, like Coco Veranda (at center right), breathe new life into old haunts. CYNTHIA ROSENFELD
An article last Sunday about Mitt Romney's wealth described incorrectly the horses Mr. Romney bought for his wife, Ann. They are warmblood horses, not thoroughbreds.

Citing unnamed sources, a recent report in the German business magazine WirtschaftsWoche said that General Motors and BMW would collaborate on hydrogen fuel-cell technology for passenger cars. Specifically, BMW would contribute toward research costs in exchange for the technology developed by G.M. While neither automaker would confirm the German magazine's report, each said that talks of a collaboration were continuing.

Cowboys (7-6) at Buccaneers (4-9) Saturday, 8:20 p.m. Line: Cowboys by 7 Two of the league's most idiosyncratic late-game tacticians face off in a game destined to turn into toddler chess (''my horsy got magic powers and blow'd up all your pointy guys'') in the final minutes. Jason Garrett's late-game over-complications have become the stuff of legend, but let's listen in on Raheem Morris's clock-management dissertation after the Buccaneers' loss to the Titans a few weeks ago: ''We spike the ball after every first down you get. You pick up a first down, you have to go spike it, you have no timeouts left. Every first down after that point has got to be a spiked ball.'' Somewhere, Herm Edwards, and only Herm Edwards, is nodding in approval. Clock-management issues have become increasingly moot during the Buccaneers' seven-game losing streak as 37-9 and 41-14 losses have piled up. Josh Freeman has been battling both inconsistency and shoulder and finger injuries, and the Buccaneers' defense often caves in at the red zone, having allowed 14 touchdowns in their opponents' last 17 trips inside the 20. With Freeman spraying passes and the Bucs waving opponents into the end zone like parking lot attendants, Garrett can enjoy a consequence-free last-second timeout spree if he chooses. Pick: Cowboys

HAYES--Selbra Lee, of Manhattan, New York on December 12, 2011. Ms. Hayes, a former model, was a successful businesswoman who owned Selbra's Midway Lounge in Harlem, a must stop for black entertainers, sports figures and others in the 1960's and 70's. She leaves behind many loving friends who cherished her intelligence and most importantly her unconditional love, a reflection of her lifetime practice of Christian Science. She was an open heart to all she met and will be dearly missed. A memorial service will be held for Ms. Hayes in early 2012.

AT first glance it's hard to find a common thread running through Valentino's spring capsule collection, Timestrings. The studded peep-toe booties, satin flats and bow-embellished kitten heels carry many of the brand's signatures but share none of them collectively. What all of the shoes do share is a handwritten stamp -- a numerical record of the amount of time it took to make each pair. For example, a pair of plexiglass and velvet wedges marked 38H costs $34 an hour, at $1,295. Worth every penny. The shoes below, $1,995. At Valentino Boutique. (212) 772-6969. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

HART--Suzanne Louise, 41, was killed in an elevator accident on Wednesday, December 14, 2011 in New York, New York. Suzanne was born on August 25, 1970, in Columbus, Ohio. She grew up in Central Ohio, suburban Chicago, and Palos Verdes Estates, California, a suburb of Los Angeles. Suzanne graduated from Palos Verdes High School and earned a degree in Fine Art and International Relations from Knox College in Galesburg, Illinois. Suzanne began her career as a printmaker in SoHo and entered the advertising business as a graphic artist. She proved to be a quick study and found that she had a strong affinity for leading teams, developing ad concepts and campaigns, and pitching them to clients and prospects. Suzanne was a natural connector of people, both personally and professionally, and she derived great satisfaction from bringing together people from very different disciplines and backgrounds to create something that none of them could have created on their own. She was a tireless and dedicated worker, and she maintained her cheerful disposition, optimistic outlook, and playful sense of humor in even the most stressful of times. Suzanne was equally energetic outside of the office. She was particularly interested in landscape architecture and design, and she recently completed a two year landscape design program through the New York Botanical Garden in her spare time. She was particularly proud of the work she did in the backyard of the Brooklyn Heights home she shared with Christian Dickson, an associate with Robert A.M. Stern Architects (RAMSA) in New York. In addition to Chris, the love of her life, Suzanne also leaves behind a large and loving family: her father, Alex W. "Pete" Hart and stepmother Mary Templeton Hart, of Naples, FL; brother Alex Paul Hart, his wife Desiree Joy Hart, and their children Alex W. and Lauren Hart of Atlanta, Georgia; brother Michael Howard Hart, his wife Patti Zogheb Hart, and their children Hannah, Emma, and Michael G. Hart of Chappaqua, New York; brother Gregory Edward Hart and his girlfriend Tara Cadenelli of Portland, Oregon; and stepsister Kiersten Wolf Petrucci, her husband Andrew Petrucci, and their son Collin Petrucci of Alexandria, Virginia. Suzanne was preceded in death by her mother, Fyanne Edwards Hart, in 1992, and, despite her young age, became the glue that held the family together for the past 19 years. Like her mother before her, Suzanne had a genuine affection for people that led to the development of a wide circle of friends. And despite growing up in the Midwest and on the West Coast, she loved New York and the friends and colleagues she became close to during the last 15 years of her tragically shortened life. Suzanne was a ray of sunshine wherever she went, and though she has left us in body, her spirit will live on through the many people she loved and who loved her so deeply. A memorial service celebrating Suzanne's life will be held on Monday, December 19th, 2011, at 10:30am eastern standard time, at 300 Madison Avenue in New York City. Please enter through the private entrance at Madison and 41st Street. A private burial will be held in her parent's hometown, Lancaster, Ohio, at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent to either the New York Botanical Society (www.nybg.org) or the Suzanne L. Hart Memorial Scholarship Fund at Knox College (please contact Beverly Holmes at bholmes@knox.edu or 309 341-7755 for more information).

An entry on the hardcover fiction list last Sunday for ''Micro,'' by Michael Crichton and Richard Preston, misstated the height of the main characters after they are miniaturized by an evil entrepreneur. They are half an inch tall, not six inches.

An article on Dec. 4 about Bentonville, Ark., and its new Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, the project of Alice Walton, the daughter of Wal-Mart's founder, Sam Walton, misstated her relationship to Christy Walton. Christy Walton is Alice Walton's sister-in-law; she is not Alice's sister.

COOK--Ladda B. August 22, 1935 -- December 13, 2011. He was a devoted husband to Jessie for 53 years and father to Anita and Deborah. Services December 19, 2011, 10am, Siloam Church, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, pls send donations to Siloam Church, Claflin University or Johnson C. Smith University.

WESTLEY--Dr. John William, 75, died December 12, 2011, at his home in Petaluma, California, after a brave and lengthy battle with pancreatic cancer. Dr. Westley was born on February 5, 1936, in Sawston, Cambridgeshire, England. He received his B.Sc. degree and Ph.D. degree in 1961 in Chemistry from the University of Nottingham. That year, he moved to Palo Alto, California with his wife Angela and one-year old son Nicholas, to pursue post-doctorate studies at Stanford University. In 1964, a second son, Peter, was born. In 1968 the family moved to New Jersey. During the course of his career as a research chemist at Hoffman La-Roche and SKB, Dr. Westley published 110 scientific papers and was awarded 32 patents. In 1996, John moved back to California with Camille Dixon. The two were married in 2003. Dr. Westley is survived by his wife, his brother Ivan, his two sons, their wives, Monica and Lisa, and his four grandchildren, Aidan, Allison, Sydney, and Alexandra.

A review on Nov. 27 about ''Thinking, Fast and Slow'' erroneously attributed a distinction to the book's author, Daniel Kahneman, who won the Nobel in economic science in 2002. His being a psychologist was indeed unusual but did not make his award ''unique in the history of the prize.'' Another psychologist, Herbert A. Simon, won the award in 1978. (Simon, a polymath and interdisciplinarian, was also an economist, a political scientist and a sociologist.)

THE best way to save money in Midtown is to spend more time downtown -- advice many a New Yorker has foisted upon visiting friends. But I spend enough time in other people's cities to know that certain zones get tagged as tourist traps for a reason: they have attractions worth seeing. Such is the case in the heart of Manhattan. Midtown is so full of marketing come-ons and overpriced souvenirs that many New Yorkers try to avoid it entirely. (Yes, I like comedy, but no, I don't need to get asked as much by eight guys promoting clubs.) Being frugal in Midtown calls for more than a laundry list of $10 meals, strategies for cheap theater tickets, tricks to find affordable hotels and advice on discount passes (though those will help, too). It calls for a strategy.

LARSON--Sue Howard, 79, died December 7, 2011 of injuries from a taxi cab accident on Riverside Drive. Professor emerita of Philosophy at Barnard College and Columbia University Graduate School, where she taught for over 30 years. Beloved teacher, noted Wittgenstein scholar, and ardent feminist, Sue obtained her BA and PhD from Stanford University and before her tenure at Barnard, taught at Mills College, Stanford University, and Princeton University. Sue is survived by nephews George Gatter of New York City and Brian Gatter and his daughter Gracie, of San Francisco, and by Elizabeth Koob and her daughter Hana of New York City. Donations to Amnesty International made in her memory would be appreciated (www.amnesty.org). A memorial service will be held on January 23, 2012 at 4pm at Barnard College, Broadway at 117th Street. For additional information call E. Koob 212-781-3049.

Africa and safari vacations may go hand-in-hand, but it's possible to go on a wildlife excursion without leaving the United States. Spring Creek Ranch, a 1,000-acre resort in Jackson Hole, Wyo., for example, leads safaris all year round. The newest tour is to Yellowstone National Park, which is closed to cars from mid-December to mid-March but is open to snow coaches and bombardiers - vehicles with tracks that can navigate through snow. Visitors can ride through the park on a five-day excursion for spotting wolves (right), bison, moose and bald eagles and stay at two lodges, one at Old Faithful and one near Mammoth (prices start at $1,450 a person).

An article on Page 30 this weekend about the artist Shea Hembrey misspells the surname of a Times critic who commented on the 2011 Documenta art fair in Germany, which Hembrey attended. He is Holland Cotter, not Carter.

In mid-November, Brendan Shanahan, the N.H.L. vice president for player safety, reported that concussions were down almost 50 percent from the same period in 2010, a ''significant improvement'' he attributed to increased player awareness about the kinds of hits that cause head trauma and the enforcement of new rules against such hits. But now the N.H.L. has a concussion outbreak on its hands. By late Friday, 23 players were on the sidelines, all listed with concussions or concussion symptoms.

MONAGLE--Marjorie (Savarese) Died, December 6, 2011. Born August 18, 1933 in Brooklyn (Flatbush) to the late Humbert and Marjorie Savarese. Survived by sister, Anne K. Blum, of Belle Harbor, NY; sons John (Bridget), James (Kelly) and Michael Monagle, and many nieces and nephews in California and New York. Wife of the late John F. Monagle. Sister of St. Joseph (Sr. Paul-Christie) for 20 years. M.A., Fordham, Ph.D., St. Louis University. Taught English for 30+ years. Funny, faithful and full of love to the end. Memorial Service at St. Francis De Sales Church, Belle Harbor, Friday December 23, at 5:30pm.

THE raucous Houston Street hot spot for hush puppies and jerk chicken, Miss Lily's, has put authentic Caribbean food in fashion's favor in recent months. Now the restaurant is opening a carefully edited record-shop-cum-radio-station with a juice bar next door named Variety. Serge Becker, who designed the space to serve the city's community of artists, designers, writers and musicians inspired by Caribbean culture, sees it as a place to ''talk Jamaica'' and enjoy a juice and patty. Expect to catch underground notables like Brazil's hottest rapper, Criolo, or the Chinese-Jamaican music producer Clive Chin taking to the turntables or perusing the shop's selection of rare vinyl, apparel and limited-edition art. Miss Lily's fine-looking staff (pictured here in the juice bar wearing the resort collections' most optimistic prints and colors) only help to make the hangout rock-steady. Variety, 130 West Houston Street. KATHRYN BRANCH

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about an international climate conference in Durban, South Africa, misstated the day on which the conference ended. It was Sunday, not Saturday, Dec. 10.

KNOX--Alison Douglas, of Philadelphia, 78, retired lawyer and widow of Philip Rieff, died December 12, 2011, after a long illness. She was born in New York on October 21, 1933, daughter of John Andrew and Lucy Randall Knox. She is survived by her sister, Ellen Knox Roston, her brother, John R. Knox, and six nephews and nieces. She graduated from The Masters School, McGill University and St. Hilda's College of Oxford University where she earned the graduate degree of BPhil in Philosophy in 1959. She then taught philosophy at Columbia University, Bryn Mawr College and Brooklyn College. She was graduated from the Law School of the University of Pennsylvania in 1977 and became an associate of Montgomery, McCracken, Walker and Rhoads, LLP, Philadelphia, until she established her own practice in 1984 concentrating on bankruptcy and intellectual property litigation. She will be remembered for her unusual brilliance, great wit, and her delightful company. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Friends of St. Hilda's College, c/o Hemenway & Barnes LLP, 60 State Street, Boston, MA 02109, Attn: Brenda Taylor.

SIEGEL--Eleanore, 86, passed away on December 17, 2011. Wife of the late Jack, adoring mother of Stephen, and beloved sister, aunt, and cousin to many. Family graveside service at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Sunday 1pm followed by Shiva at the residence.

LANGDON--George D.,Jr. George D. Langdon, Jr., former President of both Colgate University and the American Museum of Natural History, died Sunday, December 11th, at the age of 78. George's distinguished career was marked by leadership, intellect, and wisdom. He served as Colgate's president from 1978 to 1988 and oversaw a period in which Colgate solidified both its reputation for academic excellence and its financial standing. He co-founded the Colonial League for football, which later expanded to become the Patriot League. Prior to Colgate, George was the Deputy Provost and lecturer in history at Yale University. He had taught history and American studies at Yale and at the California Institute of Technology. He also taught at Vassar College where he served as special assistant to the president. George left Colgate to become the ninth president of the American Museum of Natural History and served there until 1993. He served on the board of The Kresge Foundation and was a member of Harvard's Board of Overseers from 1982-1988. George was born in Putnam, CT, on May 20, 1933. He attended the Indian Mountain School in Salisbury, CT and graduated from the Pomfret School. He earned his BA in history at Harvard College in 1954, a MA at Amherst College, and doctorate at Yale, as a Coe Fellow. He also spent two years as a lieutenant in the army. George leaves behind his second wife Agnes Langdon; sister Mary Anne Almquist; two sons, George and Campbell; stepdaughter Mary Charlotte Domandi, and five grandchildren: James, Rory, Bryce, Campbell, and Langdon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the George D. Langdon Jr. Endowed Professorship of History at Colgate University. A memorial service will be held at St Andrew's by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Little Compton, RI on June 16, 2012.

TUESDAY'S PUZZLE - Today is Tuesday, which means we have an entertaining crossword puzzle to talk about, but before we discuss that I wanted to ask those of you who are reading this whether or not you like to do the Second Sunday or Variety puzzles. I've asked this before; however, commentary drops off markedly on those days (I don't know how many people actually are doing the puzzles and just not commenting on the blog) and for the life of me, I don't know why. I was not a Variety puzzle solver when I started this job, and now I'm absolutely hooked on them. They're worth a try, and if you want to read a particularly good explanation on what it takes to construct these puzzles by my partners-in-noir-fiction, Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, read Jim Horne's new post here. Then come back and try one of these devilish masterpieces of construction. You might find yourself similarly hooked.

Suddenly, everybody is talking about turning Medicare into a voucher program. It's not a new idea. It's been two decades since wonks first started talking seriously about "premium support" and the idea of replacing Medicare with a competitive marketplace in which older people could shop for health insurance. But the idea got new life last week when Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon, a Democrat with a long record on health care, joined Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Budget Committee, in suggesting that such a scheme was the best way to cut health care spending while providing for the medical needs of the elderly. The plan resembles a proposal that Alice Rivlin, who was budget director under President Clinton, and Pete Domenici, a longtime Republican senator, have also recently been promoting.

I.B.M. just issued its annual list of five predictions of developments in technology that it thinks will come true in the next five years. Like lots of predictive lists, particularly those that come around New Year's, this is something of a pseudo-event that serves as an advertisement for the predictor's own product or service. I.B.M.'s is no different in that regard, but it is worth looking at, both for the pedigree of who is doing the predicting, and what I.B.M.'s choices say about itself.

In her latest Personal Best column, Gina Kolata explores an all too common problem for runners who use GPS watches to track their distance and pace. Thanks to festivals like Under the Radar and Coil, January is a busy month for devotees of international theater in New York. But things promise to be even more active than usual next month, when a new event called the Times Square International Theater Festival makes its debut.

Union leaders and management at New York City Opera met with a federal mediator on Monday morning in an effort to resolve a labor dispute that threatens the company's season. One of the unions said the mediator, Allison Beck, the deputy director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, first met with both sides together and then separately. The union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, said in a statement that it agreed to return to negotiations on Jan. 3, just days before rehearsals are supposed to begin. The guild represents chorus members, stage managers and assistant directors. The orchestra's union is also negotiating with the company's management, which declined to comment on Monday, citing a news blackout requested by the mediator.

Darwin called it the "abominable mystery": the reason for a sudden explosion of diverse flowering plants in the fossil record. Biologists have pondered the issue for years but were hampered by the absence of full studies of some plants and a lack of sophisticated tools for analyzing large genetic data sets. But now, thanks to a method called "functional phylogenomics," scientists have resolved some of the enigmatic relationships of plant families, potentially opening the way for advances in agriculture.

Among the perennial tools of battlefield underdogs, the 107-millimeter rocket has a secure place. Like the assault rifle, the rocket-propelled grenade and the makeshift bomb, this class of weapon, first fielded by China and known as a Type 63, has been a consistent presence in recent wars, used by Palestinians against Israel, by Pakistani and Afghan fighters against Western and Afghan-government troops, by Iraqi insurgents and by both sides of the bitter contest this year for Libya. And that is only a partial list.

Not unlike the ending of a certain hit movie that found the Muppets mobbed by fans they didn't realize they had, the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, has learned that a lot of people really like Jim Henson's creations - enough that it is extending the retrospective on that artist and puppeteer by almost two months. On Monday, the museum said that "Jim Henson's Fantastic World," the traveling Smithsonian exhibition on the life and work of the Muppets creator, will now run through March 4; it was originally scheduled to close on Jan. 16.

(The show reached 10.7 million viewers, up from 7.6 million.)

Stepping into the Gant Rugger store on Prince Street in Nolita feels a bit like walking into the kind of fusty thrift store one might find in a small alpine village. Rumpled chinos are squeezed into little drawers, shirts are rolled and shoved into cabinets, and mannequins in tweedy outfits hang alongside an enormous Christmas tree whose blazing hot lights threaten spontaneous combustion at any moment. But I wouldn't have it any other way: Rugger is the formerly American, then Swedish, now Swiss-owned brand's answer to every label that sits on the fence between Americana heritage and British country - which makes it precisely my type of clothing.

We just published an important article from Jack Healy in Baghdad:

The deaths of Vaclav Havel and Kim Jong Il within a 24-hour span are more than a reminder of the extremes of heroism and iniquity that coexist in human affairs. They're a reminder of how much successful political heroism depends, in the end, on the ability to prick the conscience of iniquity, and to remind even the worst regimes and most compromised authorities that there are moral absolutes which they transgress at their peril. The great success of the Velvet Revolution, like the successes of Gandhi and Mandela and Martin Luther King and so many other icons of peaceful revolution, was achieved by public argument as well as by public protest, and by the fact that the bureaucrats and apparatchiks and generals the revolutionaries were confronting weren't willing to take the most absolute and unthinkable steps to retain their privileges and defend their power. (In David Chappell's "A Stone of Hope," a history of religion and the civil rights movement, there's a fascinating account of how this worked in the white South - the way that the Christian appeals of King and Ralph Abernathy and Co. persuaded many white Christians that they had a moral obligation to stand by and let the revolution happen, rather than defend Jim Crow to the end.) When civil disobedience works, it does so by reminding the inhumane of their inhumanity, and by finding the vulnerabilities in what seem like permanently hardened hearts. In this sense, there's a circular quality to any successful peaceful revolt: No De Klerk without Mandela but also no Mandela (as we know Mandela) without De Klerk; no Gorbachev without Sakharov and Walesa and Havel, but no Havel and Walesa (as we know them) without Gorbachev.

An article on Tuesday about thousands of Indians in California who have been kicked out of their tribes in recent years overstated the federal government's involvement in regulating tribes. The government recognizes the right of tribes to determine their own membership; it does not grant that power. The article also misstated the month in which the Chukchansi Indians held tribal elections. They were in early December, not in early November.

HART--Suzanne Louise, 41, was killed in an elevator accident on Wednesday, December 14, 2011 in New York, New York. Suzanne was born on August 25, 1970, in Columbus, Ohio. She grew up in Central Ohio, suburban Chicago, and Palos Verdes Estates, California, a suburb of Los Angeles. Suzanne graduated from Palos Verdes High School and earned a degree in Fine Art and International Relations from Knox College in Galesburg, Illinois. Suzanne began her career as a printmaker in SoHo and entered the advertising business as a graphic artist. She proved to be a quick study and found that she had a strong affinity for leading teams, developing ad concepts and campaigns, and pitching them to clients and prospects. Suzanne was a natural connector of people, both personally and professionally, and she derived great satisfaction from bringing together people from very different disciplines and backgrounds to create something that none of them could have created on their own. She was a tireless and dedicated worker, and she maintained her cheerful disposition, optimistic outlook, and playful sense of humor in even the most stressful of times. Suzanne was equally energetic outside of the office. She was particularly interested in landscape architecture and design, and she recently completed a two year landscape design program through the New York Botanical Garden in her spare time. She was particularly proud of the work she did in the backyard of the Brooklyn Heights home she shared with Christian Dickson, an associate with Robert A.M. Stern Architects (RAMSA) in New York. In addition to Chris, the love of her life, Suzanne also leaves behind a large and loving family: her father, Alex W. "Pete" Hart and stepmother Mary Templeton Hart, of Naples, FL; brother Alex Paul Hart, his wife Desiree Joy Hart, and their children Alex W. and Lauren Hart of Atlanta, Georgia; brother Michael Howard Hart, his wife Patti Zogheb Hart, and their children Hannah, Emma, and Michael G. Hart of Chappaqua, New York; brother Gregory Edward Hart and his girlfriend Tara Cadenelli of Portland, Oregon; and stepsister Kiersten Wolf Petrucci, her husband Andrew Petrucci, and their son Collin Petrucci of Alexandria, Virginia. Suzanne was preceded in death by her mother, Fyanne Edwards Hart, in 1992, and, despite her young age, became the glue that held the family together for the past 19 years. Like her mother before her, Suzanne had a genuine affection for people that led to the development of a wide circle of friends. And despite growing up in the Midwest and on the West Coast, she loved New York and the friends and colleagues she became close to during the last 15 years of her tragically shortened life. Suzanne was a ray of sunshine wherever she went, and though she has left us in body, her spirit will live on through the many people she loved and who loved her so deeply. A memorial service celebrating Suzanne's life will be held on Monday, December 19th, 2011, at 10:30am eastern standard time, at 300 Madison Avenue in New York City. Please enter through the private entrance at Madison and 41st Street. A private burial will be held in her parent's hometown, Lancaster, Ohio, at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent to either the New York Botanical Society (www.nybg.org) or the Suzanne L. Hart Memorial Scholarship Fund at Knox College (please contact Beverly Holmes at bholmes@knox.edu or 309 341-7755 for more information).

A capsule look at the Jets' 45-19 loss to the Eagles on Sunday: Key Play The Jets had scored 13 straight points and had the Eagles pinned deep in their territory early in the third quarter before Brent Celek rumbled 73 yards on a catch-and-run to the Jets' 1, preceding a 1-yard touchdown by LeSean McCoy. Celek exploited the Jets' ineptitude at covering tight ends by repeatedly gaining separation over the middle, catching five passes for 156 yards - the most against the Jets all season and the most by a Philadelphia tight end since Pete Retzlaff in 1965.

A capsule look at the Giants' 23-10 loss to the Redskins on Sunday: Key Play In a sequence that summed up the Giants' day, Eli Manning completed what he thought was a 4-yard touchdown pass to D. J. Ware with about nine minutes remaining, only to see the call reversed on replay. On the next play, a third down from the Washington 2, Manning hit Hakeem Nicks for a touchdown pass, which was called back because of a holding penalty. Then, on fourth down, Manning was sacked and the Giants turned the ball over on downs.

California has long led the nation in technological innovation. A lesser-known fact: It also leads the country in cybercrime. The state has the most identity theft complaints and the third-highest number per capita, according to the Federal Trade Commission. Over a million Californians are victims of identity theft every year. Taken together, the F.T.C. estimates that their losses exceeded $46 million last year.

10 P.M. (13, 49) CHARLES & RAY EAMES: THE ARCHITECT AND THE PAINTER From the 1940s through the late '70s the Eameses, above -- he was trained as an architect; she was an artist -- ran a design studio in Venice, Calif., that made history. Best known for their beautiful, functional and inexpensive furniture, most notably their signature molded plywood ''Eames chair,'' the couple influenced movements in post-World War II American life, from the development of Modernism to the rise of the computer age. Their motto was ''the best for the least for the most,'' a representation of their utopian ideal of capitalist mass production. In this ''American Masters'' presentation Jason Cohn and Bill Jersey parse the lives of Charles and Ray Eames, not least their eccentricity, the loyalty they inspired in young designers, his infidelity and a partnership ultimately weakened by a loss of common creative purpose. ''All of which is to say that they were human, and the most gratifying thing about 'Eames' is that it shows, in marvelous detail, how their work was an extension of themselves and how their distinct personalities melded into a unique and protean force,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times when the documentary was released theatrically last month. ''The film is also appropriately busy and abundant: full of objects, information, stories and people, organized with hectic elegance.'' 11:15 A.M. (HBO Signature) GREENBERG (2010) Ben Stiller, left, plays Roger Greenberg, a 40-year-old former musician who, after a mental breakdown, house-sits in the large Los Angeles home of his vacationing brother in this film from Noah Baumbach. Greta Gerwig portrays Florence Marr, the brother's 25-year-old assistant and Roger's on-again, off-again love interest in his quest to recapture his youth. ''Mr. Stiller, suppressing his well-honed sketch comedian's urge to wink at the audience, turns Roger into a walking challenge to the Hollywood axiom that a movie's protagonist must be likable,'' Mr. Scott wrote in The Times. Only at the end does Mr. Baumbach reveal that the film has been ''a romantic comedy all along,'' he added. ''And suddenly a movie about a man who is defiantly difficult to like becomes very hard not to love.''

RAMALLAH, West Bank -- Israel released about 550 Palestinian prisoners on Sunday night in the second half of a swap that freed one of its soldiers, Gilad Shalit, who had been held by Hamas in Gaza for more than five years. The prisoners left Ofer Prison in Israel by bus shortly after 10 p.m., with a dozen buses going to the West Bank and one to Gaza. Some prisoners were also going to East Jerusalem and Jordan.

Technology often has a way of fixing the problems it creates. Here's one that needs solving. The invention of the smartphone has created a world where millions of people stroll through life constantly staring into a mobile device, like Narcissus at the edge of a pond.

Are people suffering from gadget overload? Are they exhausted by the consumer equivalent of the brain fatigue -- information overload -- that is caused by a constant updates of devices and online media? Underwriters Laboratories, the venerable nonprofit product testing and certification organization, issued a study last week that found about half of consumers, 48 percent, ''feel high-tech manufacturers bring new products to market faster than people need them.''

On the syndicated public television show ''Vine Talk,'' the actor Stanley Tucci leads a changing cast of chefs and celebrities in a convivial round of wine tasting. But off-camera, many of the show's participants are battling over money still owed to them. The show, produced by Jersey Wooly Productions and broadcast on stations nationwide since April, rented WNET's new Lincoln Center studio to tape a first season last winter. But the New York City public broadcaster, which has already weathered a couple of tough financial years, has not been paid about $500,000, according to several people briefed on the matter who would not discuss it publicly.

Bells are ringing in Hollywood, but they're not the Christmas kind. Two big sequels, ''Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows'' and ''Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked,'' delivered shaky results over the weekend, alarming studios about a continued downturn at the North American box office. ''A Game of Shadows'' (Warner Brothers) was No. 1 with about $40 million in ticket sales. Analysts had expected that film, which cost $125 million to make, to take in over $50 million; the first installment in this franchise opened with $62 million in 2009. ''Chipwrecked'' (20th Century Fox) was second, taking in about $23.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. That result was 52 percent below the opening weekend total for the last Chipmunks movie in 2009. ''Chip-Wrecked'' cost an estimated $80 million to make. A variety of factors could have dented interest: sequel fatigue, family film overload, higher ticket prices, a lack of overall momentum at the box office. Elsewhere, Tom Cruise's ''Mission: Impossible -- Ghost Protocol'' (Paramount) was a powerful third, taking in about $13 million in limited release on 425 Imax screens. That result set an Imax record and positioned ''Ghost Protocol'' as a potential blockbuster and career rebound for Mr. Cruise as it expands nationwide on Wednesday. ''New Year's Eve'' (Warner) was fourth with about $7.4 million in ticket sales, lifting its two-week total to $24.8 million. ''The Sitter'' (Fox) was fifth, taking in an estimated $4.4 million for a two-week total of $17.7 million. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

LARSON--Sue Howard, 79, died December 7, 2011 of injuries from a taxi cab accident on Riverside Drive. Professor emerita of Philosophy at Barnard College and Columbia University Graduate School, where she taught for over 30 years. Beloved teacher, noted Wittgenstein scholar, and ardent feminist, Sue obtained her BA and PhD from Stanford University and before her tenure at Barnard, taught at Mills College, Stanford University, and Princeton University. Sue is survived by nephews George Gatter of New York City and Brian Gatter and his daughter Gracie, of San Francisco, and by Elizabeth Koob and her daughter Hana of New York City. Donations to Amnesty International made in her memory would be appreciated (www.amnesty.org). A memorial service will be held on January 23, 2012 at 4pm at Barnard College, Broadway at 117th Street. For additional information call E. Koob 212-781-3049.

My article in The New York Times on Monday citing high levels of dissatisfaction with Amazon's new tablet generated a torrential response, much of it from people who said they loved their Kindle Fires. The wilder commentators suggested that the whole article somehow came from Apple, which, in their view, was trying to get people to hock grandma's jewels to buy $500 iPads. None of those conspiracy theorists explained why so many original users of the Fire put mixed to negative reviews on Amazon's own site. The uproar underlined yet again how people have deep-seated but contradictory feelings about their devices. In one sense, they demand a lot; in another, they are very forgiving. No one would put up with a new car that did not drive well, but people expect technology to be balky, at least in the beginning. One commentator, Victor from Texas, captured this charity in one sentence: ''Though I am not thrilled with this initial version of Fire, I have no intention of returning it since it works well for me.''

An article last Monday about an international climate conference in Durban, South Africa, misstated the position of the United States on the Kyoto Protocol, a 1997 agreement on reining in greenhouse gas emissions. The United States signed the accord but never ratified it; it did not decline to sign it.

VAN BIEMA--Gerhard, died peacefully on December 13 in Sleepy Hollow, NY, at 91. He was the beloved husband of the late Mary, father of David and Michael, and grandfather of Joshua, Alexander and Julian. He was born to Erna and Hermann van Biema in 1920 in Hannover, Germany. His parents sent him to live in safety with relatives in the U.S in 1936, and were able to join him only years later. He thrived in the face of this adversity, attaining an M.S. in chemical engineering at Purdue University, with the help of a scholarship from the Sigma Alpha Mu fraternity. He traveled frequently and with pleasure, including puddle-jumping to remote tapioca factories in Brazil for General Foods Corp. He went on to manage the import and export of fine chemicals for several firms. In 1951, Gerhard married Mary Epstein, his life partner and best friend for 49 years. Settling in Tenafly, NJ, he volunteered to improve public education, as a Board of Education member and President, and as leader of the Citizens Education Council. He loved his family, art and music, strolling out-doors, a spirited debate around the kitchen table, and the occasional bad pun. He was a wonderful, dedicated son, father, husband, and citizen; a wise and analytical advisor; and terrific company. He was quietly and deeply passionate about many things he believed in and cared about, including the country that took him in, and his grandchildren, who made his eyes light up through his last days. He will be terribly missed.

From my seat on the aisle in the orchestra section at the Metropolitan Opera House I saw only one family get up and leave during the third act of Engelbert Humperdinck's ''Hansel and Gretel'' at its season premiere on Friday night. That seemed noteworthy because onstage, in a kitchen filled with lost children baked into gingerbread, a frumpy, gluttonous witch was compelling a little girl to help fatten her brother for the oven, between unsubtle hints that the girl was destined for the same fate. Brrr. Grimm's fairy tales are hardly kids' stuff: a point that Humperdinck's buoyantly luscious music, Adelheid Wette's slightly softened libretto and David Pountney's quippy English translation don't disguise. Richard Jones, the director, cleverly based his imaginative 2007 production around the relatable notion of gnawing hunger; two acts set in kitchens frame a central scene set in a haunted forest that magically transforms into a whimsical dining room.

Twenty-five years later, this is the legacy of a racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens: One of the victims died in the attack and is memorialized in a Brooklyn street sign, another died five years later, and the third is in jail in Virginia for unrelated crimes. The three teenagers convicted of manslaughter were released from prison and are family men in their 40s. A leader of the attack, who became the key prosecution witness and dreamed of following in his father's footsteps in law enforcement, never did become a police officer.

LOS ANGELES -The Orson Welles Oscar went to the highest-and unidentified -- bidder for $861,542, the Nate D. Sanders auction house said Tuesday evening. Welles received the Oscar in 1942 for his work on the script for "Citizen Kane." It was thought to be lost and later replaced. But eventually the original turned up in the hands of a cinematographer who said he had received it from Welles as a gift, and, after a court fight, it was turned over to Welles's daughter Beatrice. When the original first went on the block, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences went to court to try to stop the sale, but lost. Sotheby's later tried to sell it, but ended that effort when an undisclosed reserve price was not met. And, now, finally the Oscar has been sold in an auction that, according to Sanders, included an underbid from the magician David Copperfield. "I'm proud to have represented this fantastic award to the cinema collecting community," Nate D. Sanders, the auction house owner, said in a statement that was circulated late Tuesday.

Americans spend less time cooking than anyone, and the amount we "cook" - some people count microwaving a pizza - has been on a long, slow decline. The reasons for this decline are varied and complex, but an increase in the average of both hours worked and television watched, coupled with the marketing of "convenience" foods, have turned cooking from a sometimes-pleasurable necessity into, for many people, an ominous-seeming choice.

The measures would make it easier for property owners to add insulation to exterior walls and install awnings, skylights, green roofs, solar panels and greenhouses, among other features. With only an oven, Giulio Adriani established his reputation as a pizzaiolo in Italy and at Olio Pizza e Più in Greenwich Village. Now, at Forcella, Mr. Adriani has a fryer, too. With it, he creates his montanara pizza, a margherita with a crust flash-fried before being finished in a wood-burning oven. The crust has a crisp airiness, not to mention a thin coat of oil that has the naughty pleasure of street food; the oven gives it color and adds a little smoke. Other pizzas on the menu aren't up to the montanara's caliber, but you'll do well with the classics.

After the last diamond-encrusted bauble had been snatched up, the last item of Dior couture sold, the last Fendi handbag handed on to a new owner, the sale of Elizabeth Taylor's vast collections netted $156.8 million. The four days of sales at Christie's became the most valuable private jewelry sale in history ($137.2 million) and the most valuable private collection of fashion ever sold ($5.5 million). The first online-only Christie's sale drew 57,000 bids and reaped $9.5 million. The complete collection sold out, a testament to both the star's magnetism and the quality of the merchandise. All the proceeds benefit the Elizabeth Taylor Trust, which manages the Taylor estate.  Taylor was well-known in her later years for her fund-raising and activism for AIDS research. A portion of the profit generated by Christie's sale of exhibition tickets (58,000 people saw the exhibit in its international travels), event  sponsorship and the ongoing sales of "select publications," will be donated to the Elizabeth Taylor AIDS Foundation. The auction house also raised $170,00 through the sale of a deluxe limited edition boxed set of the catalogs on the first evening of the auction, which will also go to the foundation.  Some highlights from the later sales: those Vuitton trunks, with the violet-colored tags reading "Mine!" sold for $245,500, the top figure for the accessories sale. The Andy Warhol lithograph signed and dedicated by the artist went for $662,000. A (quite hideous) beaded Versace bolero jacket featuring rhinestone images of Taylor in some of her famous roles fetched $128,500. Even rocks Taylor never actually wore went for big sums: a large gray "scholar's rock" netted $386,500, more than 30 times its estimate of $8,000 to $12,000. Christie's will complete the dispersal of the Taylor collections in the new year with sales of her Old Master paintings (Jan. 25 in New York), including a Frans Hals portrait (not of Taylor), and her Impressionist and modern art collection (London, Feb. 7 and 8). Chris Wilding, Taylor's son and a trustee of the foundation, said, "My mother always acknowledged that she was merely the temporary custodian of the incredible things she owned. Today, I think she would be happy to know that her collections will continue to enrich the lives of those who have acquired pieces."

New voting rules for the Academy Awards could help the movie "Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close," which will be released in Los Angeles and New York on Christmas and won't play around the country until next year, Michael Cieply writes. The movie was shut out by Golden Globes voters, who were shown a screening at the beginning of the month; the voters said in interviews with Mr. Cieply that they were sharply divided on the movie, with some hating it, some loving it. That kind of polarity didn't work at the Golden Globes, but it might now prove an advantage in the Oscar contest after changes in balloting for best picture have put a premium on first-place votes.

Patent battles have engulfed the cellphone industry for years, reflecting the heated competition. The wages of sin is death. It says so right there in Romans 6:23, questionable grammar and all. Death may be a tad harsh for most sins. In his look at the the film "Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close" and the challenges of an Oscar campaign on its behalf, the Bagger's colleague Michael Cieply notes that the divisive reaction toward it -- it was overlooked in the Golden Globes nominations -- may actually be a benefit. That's because a handful of passionate fans can make a difference under Academy rules changes that now "put a premium on first-place votes" for best picture, he writes, citing the work of Steve Pond of TheWrap.com. A few first-place votes can count more than second- or third-place votes. How few? Under the Academy's bylaws, 5 percent of the first-place votes can create a nominee, or some 250 of the 5,000 votes typically cast in a year. Read more »

Not unlike the ending of a certain hit movie that found the Muppets mobbed by fans they didn't realize they had, the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, has learned that a lot of people really like Jim Henson's creations -- enough that it is extending the retrospective on that artist and puppeteer by almost two months. On Monday the museum said that ''Jim Henson's Fantastic World,'' the traveling Smithsonian exhibition on the life and work of the Muppets creator, would run through March 4, rather than Jan. 16. It features artwork, props and puppets from Henson's work on films and television shows like ''Sesame Street,'' ''The Dark Crystal'' and ''Fraggle Rock,'' and has hosted guests like Henson's colleague Frank Oz; family members Brian and Cheryl Henson; and Kevin Clash, who performs Elmo. It has drawn nearly 90,000 visitors since opening on July 16, the museum said, and is expected to have more than 100,000 visitors by the time it closes.

Rahber tracks Brian's quest to marry Amber by converting to Islam and winning over her family.

The Yeshiva University community is deeply saddened by the passing of Rabbi Sheldon Rudoff, a devoted alumnus of Yeshiva College and RIETS, who together with his beloved wife, Hedda, was a Yeshiva University Guardian who brought honor to his alma mater as a distinguished attorney and through his leadership roles in the Jewish community. He was the cherished father of Sara and Ira Olshin, Simone and Mark Semer, and the late Shaindy Rudoff, and brother of Evelyn Rochlin. May his entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Rabbi Norman Lamm Chancellor and Rosh HaYeshiva
