Kim Jong-il, the reclusive dictator who kept North Korea at the edge of starvation and collapse, banished to gulags citizens deemed disloyal and turned the country into a nuclear weapons state, died Saturday morning, the North's official news media announced on Monday. He was reported to be 69. He had been in ill health since a reported stroke in 2008.

Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia has taken a $300 million stake in the social media start-up Twitter, adding an emerging brand name to an international investment portfolio that largely includes established giants like Apple, Citigroup and Walt Disney. Although the billionaire investor has long been known for taking stakes in stalwarts, the Twitter deal focuses on the next generation of blue-chip companies.

The American premiere of Tom Stoppard's adaptation of Luigi Pirandello's ''Henry IV'' may be running for one night only, but now more people will be able to see it. The Red Bull Theater Company announced that its staged reading of the play on Jan. 9, directed by Jack O'Brien (Mr. Stoppard's ''Coast of Utopia''), would be held on the main stage at Playwrights Horizons on West 42nd Street in Manhattan, instead of the troupe's regular quarters at the Theater at St. Clement's on West 46th Street. Among those taking part in the reading are Jennifer Ehle (a Tony winner for Mr. Stoppard's ''Real Thing''), Paxton Whitehead and Mamie Gummer. The Stoppard adaptation, which was fully staged in London in 2004, is part of the company's Obie-winning ''Revelation Readings'' series. Coming performances include Gogol's ''Government Inspector'' (with Stephen Spinella and Marsha Mason) on Monday; Beaumont and Fletcher's Jacobean tragicomedy ''A King and No King'' (with Matthew Rauch) on Jan. 23; and ''The Balcony'' and ''The Screens,'' both by Jean Genet, on March 19 and 26. JENNIFER SCHUESSLER

Union leaders and management at New York City Opera met with a federal mediator on Monday morning in an effort to resolve a labor dispute that threatens the company's season. One of the opera's unions said the mediator, Allison Beck, the deputy director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, met with both sides together and then separately. The union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, said in a statement that its members agreed to return to negotiations on Jan. 3, just days before rehearsals are supposed to begin. The guild represents chorus members, stage managers and assistant directors. The orchestra's union is also negotiating with the company's management, which declined to comment Monday, citing a news blackout requested by the mediator. Talks on a new contract broke down on Nov. 30. The company moved out of its Lincoln Center home to save money this season and is to perform four operas on a drastically reduced budget in several locations around New York. DANIEL J. WAKIN

Mitt Romney is coming to a television screen near you. Mr. Romney's media blitz, which began in earnest last week with a series of print and television interviews, picked up Monday with renewed vigor. On Monday night, Mr. Romney was to appear on Bill O'Reilly's Fox News show, on Charlie Rose's PBS program and on ''The Late Show With David Letterman,'' where he was scheduled to read a Top Ten list. He is also scheduled for an appearance on MSNBC's ''Morning Joe'' on Tuesday.

WISHNER--Maynard. American Jewish Committee (AJC) is deeply saddened by the passing of Maynard Wishner, a past leader of the global advocacy organization, and a longtime Jewish activist in Chicago and worldwide. He served as AJC National President from 1980 to 1983. Wishner led AJC efforts in his native Chicago to nurture enduring relationships with, among others, the Polish, Greek and Catholic communities. He also traveled to many countries on behalf of AJC to advance the well-being of Jewish communities and Israel, and to strengthen respect for democratic values. We will miss Maynard's love of the Jewish people, and incredible sense of humor. If ever there was a true mensch, it was he! We extend deepest condolences to his wife Elaine, his three daughters, Ellen, Jane and Mimi, his sister, three sons-in-law, eight grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. May his memory forever be for a blessing and an inspiration. Robert Elman, President David Harris, Exec. Dir.

One of the enduring questions in the history of pop music is how two teenagers from Liverpool with a background in skiffle and rock 'n' roll became among the most inventive songwriters of the last 50 years, producing an enormous variety of tunes that broke new ground for pop music both melodically and harmonically. Those songwriters, of course, were John Lennon and Paul McCartney of the Beatles, above. Now Mr. McCartney, at 69, says he is putting out an album of standards from his youth, calling them ''the songs which inspired the songs.'' The album also includes two original songs in the style of pre-rock standards. Mr. McCartney announced on Monday that he would release the new album on Feb. 7, saying it was time ''the songs me and John based quite a few of our things on'' received the attention they deserve. ''When I kind of got into songwriting, I realized how well structured these songs were, and I think I took a lot of my lessons from them,'' Mr. McCartney said in the announcement. The song list for the album has yet to be released. Mr. McCartney said it includes classic American compositions by songwriters like Cole Porter and Harold Arlen, many of which he heard his father, a jazz musician, play on the piano in their home. He said he recorded the songs over the last year at the Capitol studios in Los Angeles with Diana Krall and her band. He did the vocals himself but, for the first time in his long career, left all the instrumental work to others. Eric Clapton and Stevie Wonder play on the two original songs, he said. JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

An obituary in some editions on Monday about the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il reversed, in some copies, the second and third columns of type. The correct version can be found at nytimes.com/international. The obituary also referred incompletely to comments by Hwang Jang-yop, a former aide to the Kim regime, who was quoted describing Mr. Kim's rise to power. The comment was from a 2006 memoir of Mr. Kim; it was not a current observation. (Mr. Hwang died in 2010.)

INGRAHAM--Laura Jennings, of Hanover, NH died on December 18, 2011, at the age of 93. A longtime resident of NYC, Cold Spring Harbor and Northport, NY and Lyme, NH she was survived by Alice I. (Dr. John Anthony K.) Davies, of Weston, MA, Frederic B. Ingraham of Cold Spring Harbor and John W. (Judith Berry) Ingraham of Tulsa, OK and eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Her husband David Ingraham, a partner at Cahill Gordon & Reindel, and their son David Jr. predeceased her in 1978 and 2006 respectively. She was the daughter of Percy Hall Jennings and Elizabeth Auchincloss Jennings of NYC and Cold Spring Harbor. Educated at Brearley, Shipley, Bryn Mawr, she was a graduate of Bennington College located on what had been her family's farm and Cornell University. She was a microbiologist at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory where she worked for many years with Dr. Alfred D. Hershey the Nobel laureate.

HOCHMAN--David, MD, died at home peacefully on Monday, December 19, 2011, age 99. Survived by his loving daughters Joan and Marcia, sons-in-law Chris and Joel whom he considered to be his sons, and grandchildren Ian, Emma, Annie, Kate. Pre-deceased by his loving wife Anita. Attended medical school at the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons, Edinburgh, Scotland. Practiced medicine privately in New York City for over 50 years. Retired at age 89 as medical director of a Beth Israel methadone maintenance clinic. As a captain and flight surgeon in the US Army Air Corps during World War II, survived the Bataan Death March and 2 ++ years as a Japanese prisoner of war, heroically caring for his fellow captives and saving many lives. Funeral services on Tuesday, December 20 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. at 11:30am. Interment to follow at Temple Israel Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Doctors Without Borders. May his memory be for a blessing.

It would lead us to become a banana republic, in which administrations would become regimes and each regime would feel it perfectly appropriate to disregard decisions of courts staffed by previous regimes. That's not what we are. MICHAEL B. MUKASEY, President George W. Bush's attorney general, on Newt Gingrich's statement that the elected branches should be free to ignore judicial decisions. [A24]

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a spat between French and British officials as tensions mount over the possibility of a downgrade of France's sovereign debt misstated a credit downgrade for another country. Moody's Investors Service downgraded Belgium on Friday to Aa3 -- not to Aa1.

A federal agency ruled on Monday that a set of important features commonly found in smartphones are protected by an Apple patent, a decision that could force changes in how Google's Android phones function. The ruling, by the United States International Trade Commission, is one of the most significant so far in a growing array of closely watched patent battles being waged around the globe by nearly all of the major players in the mobile industry. These fights reflect the heated competition among the companies, especially as Android phones gain market share.

ST. GEORGE--Rev. John P.,S.J., on December 18, 2011. Beloved brother of Mary Diorio of Barnegat, NJ. Fr. St. George taught chemistry at St. Peter's College, Jersey City for over 30 years. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY on Tuesday from 3-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday 11:30am at the Jesuit Community Chapel. Interment at Jesuit Martyrs' Shrine, Auriesville, NY. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors (718)654-0500.
The New Old Age Paula Span posted to nytimes.com/newoldage:

WOLMAN--William. December 14, 1927 - December 5, 2011. Died peacefully at home after an extended illness. Raised in Montreal, Canada, he attended McGill University and went on to Stanford University to complete a Ph.D. in economics before he joined the economics staff at Business Week Magazine in 1960. Five years later he was promoted to economics editor and continued on at the magazine - with some breaks - until he retired in 2001 as chief economist. He also worked at CNBC during the 1990's as chief economist. He is survived by his wife, Anne Colamosca, and his children, Ann Elizabeth, John and Flor. We will miss his quick wit, amazing vitality and intellectual curiosity. He loved his family (and two grandchildren, Luis and Laila) and was always excited about working on his next journalistic project.

The poet Maya Angelou, above left, said she was ''surprised and disappointed'' to find that a track she appears on in a coming album by the rapper Common, above, frequently uses a racial epithet, The New York Post reported. Ms. Angelou, a National Medal of Arts winner and the author of the memoir ''I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings,'' is heard reciting a poem that she wrote on Common's song ''The Dreamer,'' from his album ''The Dreamer/The Believer.'' In her verses, she says: Dare to let your dreams reach beyond you

Jimmy Rollins made his major league debut with the Philadelphia Phillies in 2000. That season, the Phillies lost 97 games, finished last in the National League East and traded their best pitcher,Curt Schilling. Two years later, on their way to another losing season, they traded their best offensive player, Scott Rolen. Look at them now. Rollins officially re-signed Monday for three years and $33 million, which could extend his time in red pinstripes to 2015, if he meets the requirements of a vesting option. The Phillies have won five N.L. East titles in a row - with a World Series crown mixed in - and have found a way to keep their best players.

ROSENBERG--Abraham, 88, of Boynton Beach, FL, died Sunday, December 18, 2011. Mr. Rosenberg was born in Brooklyn and had lived in Long Island before moving to Boynton Beach, FL 20 years ago. He was predeceased in death by his daughter-in-law Carol Rosenberg and son-in-law Mel Schnell. He is survived by his wife of 69 years, Lillian (nee Farberman), his daughter Rochelle Lipton and her husband Hal, and sons Steven and Richard and his wife Barbara. He also leaves behind to cherish his memory seven grandchildren Emily, Cheryl, Josh, Scott, Melissa, Maxwell and Blythe and five great-grandchildren Matt, Benjy, Tess, Mason and Mariel. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer. Graveside services will be held on Tuesday, December 20, 2011 at 10:00am at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Services are being handled by The Goldstein Funeral Chapel, Inc., Edison, NJ.

FLEISCHNER--Ruth. 90, died at home on December 9. Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Proud graduate of Hunter High School and Hunter College; admired and devoted co-owner of Camp Scatico; much loved mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, and great-aunt. We will all miss her. Services Thursday, 9:30am, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam. Shiva Thursday, 4:30-7:00pm, at her home.

CASCELLA--Claire Crisona, suddenly on December 18, 2011, in her sleep. Adoring wife of the late Ralph, beautiful beloved mother of Elizabeth Auran and Nancy Cascella, cherished sister of Cynthia Crisona, proud and beaming grandmother of Catherine and Emilv Auran and Robert and James Flatow, loving mother-in-law of James Auran, dear companion of William Bruce. She was the devoted daughter of the late James and Claire Crisona. Generous, loving friend to so many. Her family and friends were her life. She will be forever missed. Visiting Frank Campbell, 81st and Madison Avenue, Tuesday, December 20th 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of the Resurrection St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 84th and Park Avenue, Wednesday, December 21st, 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Scleroderma Foundation. 300 Rosewood Drive, Suite 108, Danvers, MA 01923.

BUSINESS DAY An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about the move of Brown University's medical school to a renovated factory building in Providence, R.I., described a previous use of the building incorrectly. It once housed Brier Manufacturing, a costume jewelry maker; it was not the home of a watchband factory. (Brown owns a nearby building that was the home of Speidel, which makes the Twist-O-Flex watchband.)

The Books of The Times review on Friday, about ''Blue Notes in Black and White: Photography and Jazz,'' by Benjamin Cawthra, misstated the name of a photojournalist who took many pictures of jazz musicians. He was W. Eugene Smith, not Eugene W. Smith.

Three years after the financial crisis, the Grinch still hovers over Wall Street. In the precrisis era, big banks were renowned for their extravagant holiday parties. Goldman Sachs once rented out huge halls for its end-of-year galas, which featured appearances by performers such as Harry Connick Jr. and Bette Midler. In 2007, Morgan Stanley took over several floors of Lotus, then a popular Manhattan nightclub.

The New York Times Company said on Monday it was in advanced talks to sell 16 regional newspapers, another indication the company was divesting itself of assets to concentrate on its core newspaper business. Halifax Media Holdings of Daytona Beach, Fla., is currently negotiating the purchase of the Times Company's Regional Media Group, a division that includes newspapers across the country like The Sarasota Herald-Tribune in Florida; The Press Democrat in Santa Rosa, Calif.; The Star-News in Wilmington, N.C.; The Gainesville Sun, also in Florida; and The Tuscaloosa News in Alabama.

Bi-Lo agreed on Monday to buy Winn-Dixie Stores for about $560 million, uniting two of the South's better-known regional supermarket operators. Under the terms of the deal, the privately held Bi-Lo will pay $9.50 a share in cash, 75 percent more than Winn-Dixie's closing price on Friday.

After months of trying to stay in business, the owner of Saab Automobile filed for bankruptcy on Monday when hopes of a life-saving investment from Chinese investors collapsed in the face of opposition from General Motors. Saab and two subsidiaries filed with the District Court in Vanersborg, Sweden, according to Saab's parent company, Swedish Automobile. The parent company said it ''does not expect to realize any value from its shares in Saab Automobile,'' and that it ''will write off its interest in Saab Automobile completely.''

GAGE--Suzanne, 92, passed quietly Sunday, December 18, 2011 in New York City. She was born and raised in "fun city," the city she loved. She was the daughter of the late Walter Reade, the movie theater mogul and Gertrude Blumberg Reade, wife of the late Edwin "Peter" Gage and sister of the late Walter Reade, Jr. She is survived by her children Linda (Tim) and Tom and grandchildren Andrew (Geri), Jessica, Peter and Laura, In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

In comic books, superheroes always seem to have tragic origins. I believe most sports fans can relate to that. Cheering on a team when it is doing well and winning big games does not demonstrate loyalty. Instead, it is doing so during the lows that proves devotion.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about Bonnie Hammer, the head of NBCUniversal's cable unit, misstated the name of the USA Network show in which Gabriel Macht and Gina Torres appear. It is ''Suits'' -- not ''Dirty Little Secrets,'' which is the name of the episode in which the scene shown in the picture took place.

LONDON -- The British government plans stricter banking regulations that would force banks to separate their investment banking operations from those businesses that take deposits. The chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, said on Monday that the government would seek to pass laws by 2015 to strengthen financial regulation as proposed by an independent commission led by John Vickers, a former Bank of England chief economist. The new laws would then apply by 2019 the latest.

6:53 p.m. | Updated More than a year after HBO began introducing its online streaming service HBO Go, the two cable holdouts, Time Warner Cable and Cablevision, are about to turn it on for their customers. Cablevision, which mainly serves the New York metropolitan area, said on Monday that it had reached a deal with HBO to allow its customers to stream HBO's films and shows via the Internet. The announcement came three days after Time Warner Cable, which serves most of the rest of the New York area as well as other markets, said it had reached a similar deal.

I learned what it was to be a Giants fan at my father's side. During the 1960s and '70s, we spent parts of our Sunday afternoons together watching mostly bad football. My dad, a former all-city fullback and nose tackle, would sit down to watch the game on TV each week, and invariably wind up muttering about the incompetent defense the Giants were playing before wandering out to the garage to putter around. Another in a line of many Giants losses that made for completely lost Sundays.

Bob Brookmeyer, who left a distinctive mark on jazz as a musician, composer, arranger and educator whose students included many of today's leading jazz arrangers and bandleaders, died on Thursday in New London, N.H., four days before his 82nd birthday. The cause was cardiopulmonary arrest, said his wife, Janet.

Jerome Isaac entered the courtroom in handcuffs and a white Tyvek suit, bearing what appeared to be the aftereffects of a horrific crime. Red, glistening blotches dotted his cheek and neck; his lip and left eye were badly swollen. The injuries, Kenneth M. Taub, a prosecutor, said Monday, were evidence of Mr. Isaac's role in one of the more brutal killings in recent memory in New York City: the methodical immolation of Deloris Gillespie, 73, in the elevator of her apartment building in Brooklyn.

The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would devote three days in late March to hearing arguments in challenges to the 2010 health care overhaul law. A decision in the case is expected by the end of June. The court agreed to hear the case on Nov. 14, saying it would put aside five and half hours for arguments and specifying how much time it would devote to each of four issues. Monday's announcement assigned those issues to particular days, giving a sense of the logical sequence in which the justices will approach them.

GREENBURGH, N.Y. - There was bad news and good news for the Rangers' injury-riddled defensive corps Monday. The bad news: Steve Eminger will be out 8 to 10 weeks while recuperating from a separated right shoulder sustained in Saturday's 3-2 victory in Phoenix. More bad news: Jeff Woywitka was unable to practice Monday after being struck in the ankle with a shot later in that game and may not be ready to face the Devils on Tuesday in Newark.

LEVINE--Herbert, 87, died December 17, 2011 in Florida after a brief illness. Born in Newark, NJ and served proudly in the Army in World War II, earning a Purple Heart. Graduate of NJIT. Successfully created and operated Paige Electric Corporation which became a public company under his leadership. Adored husband of the late Selma (Kornhauser) Levine and beloved father of Vicki Friedman and Janice Levine. Proud grandfather of Jesse (Melissa) Friedman and Michael Friedman. Longtime resident of The Ocean Reef Club in Key Largo, FL where he became an avid fisherman. Funeral service to be held at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman in Livingston, NJ on Wednesday, December 21 at noon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Medical Center at Ocean Reef by calling 305-367-2600 for information. We love you forever and always Dad. You will be greatly missed by all of those who knew and loved you.
WILLNER--Alvin. Greatly beloved. You are missed and ever in our thoughts. Jane (Harold), Jay (Jeanne), Stella.

There was a lot of back slapping at Morgan Stanley when Zynga went public on Friday. But it should hold the self-congratulatory applause. Morgan Stanley scored the coveted position of lead underwriter for Zynga's initial public offering. The offering was considered a lucrative win for the bank: it was paid more than $10 million for marketing and distributing shares of the new stock. In total, Zynga paid out $32.5 million in fees to its underwriters. They included a laundry list of other Wall Street heavyweights too, like Goldman Sachs (which took in about $8.7 million).

STOCK SLIDE Zynga, the online game company, which closed below its offering price on Friday, continued to slide on Monday. Shares of Zynga, which was co-founded by Mark Pincus, fell nearly 5 percent, closing at a little more than $9 a share, about 10 percent below its offering price. But there were winners in the I.P.O. Zynga's underwriters, led by Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, collected $32.5 million in fees for the offering, the largest for an American Internet company since Google's debut in 2004. EVELYN M. RUSLI

An article on Thursday about a speech by President Obama to mark the end of the Iraq war misstated the significance of the burgundy berets worn by some soldiers who attended the event in Fort Bragg, N.C. The burgundy berets signify that soldiers are attached to air-borne units, not simply that they are on active duty.

AT&T on Monday ended its effort to buy T-Mobile USA, acknowledging that it could not overcome stiff opposition by the Obama administration to form the nation's biggest cellphone service provider. The decision to scrap the $39 billion takeover - which would have been the biggest deal of the year - is a major setback for AT&T, which had pinned its hopes for growth on the acquisition. The company wanted T-Mobile's cellular airwaves, or spectrum, to relieve its congested network and offer faster service for data-hungry devices like the iPhone.

ARLINGTON, Va. -- Newt Gingrich threw down a "debate me in Iowa'' challenge to his chief Republican rival, Mitt Romney, on Wednesday night, hours after Mr. Romney said in a television interview that Mr. Gingrich should stop complaining about negative advertising."I've challenged Governor Romney to meet me for 90 minutes in Iowa next week, anywhere, anytime, timekeeper, no moderator,'' Mr. Gingrich told supporters during a quick pep talk at a Marriott Hotel here.He went on: "And we'll bring all of his negative ads and show them for free and he can explain them, and we'll find out tomorrow whether he likes the heat and wants to come in the kitchen, or whether he is just another normal national politician with clever consultants and a lot of money and no willingness to stand up and tell the truth.''

11:52 a.m. | Updated A court in Amsterdam on Thursday sentenced the man who ran onto the field and attacked the AZ goalkeeper Esteban Alvarado to six months in jail, The Associated Press reported. Because of privacy laws in the Netherlands, the attacker was identified only as Wesley van W. (kind of catchy, don't you think?). Prosecutors had been seeking a 10-month jail term. Under terms of the deal van W., 19, will also be required to report to the police during all Ajax, AZ and Dutch national team games for two years. The match, which was suspended when AZ players were instructed to leave the field, will be replayed in full next month.

Thirteen years before he became famous as one of television's great slobs, Oscar Madison on "The Odd Couple," Jack Klugman had his breakout role in the 1957 film "12 Angry Men" as Juror 5. He played a hardened young man who brought street smarts to the jury deliberations in a murder trial in a cast that also included Henry Fonda (as the main character Juror 8), Lee J. Cobb, and Martin Balsam. Mr. Klugman is now the only surviving actor who was on the jury - a detail much on his mind Wednesday as he spoke about his latest career move. George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J., announced that Mr. Klugman - who is 89 - will play Juror 9 in a production of the stage adaption "Twelve Angry Men" there March 13-April 8, 2012.

Early in my career as a critic at The New York Times, I began receiving nuisance calls from a ghost. This was before I had caller ID (or an unlisted number), and for a week or so I would pick up my phone only to hear an angry actress berating me for not singling out her performance in my review of an Off Broadway show in which she appeared as a specter.

I was recently asked to create a specialty cocktail for a big holiday bash. I knew I wanted it to be something special and seasonal, but the constraints posed by the party (it was held at the Center for Fiction, a lovely place, but one not equipped with a full bar or full kitchen) demanded that I keep it simple. Not a worry, as I'm inclined to keep it simple where cocktails are concerned. The classic rye Manhattan was my starting point. What if I replaced the sweet vermouth with ginger syrup? That worked fine, but something was missing. I was testing the drink in a friend's kitchen in New Hampshire over Thanksgiving weekend. A bowlful of clementines (one of my favorite winter treats) sat on the counter. Freshly squeezed clementine juice - and a generous dousing of Angostura bitters - brought the whole thing together. It's easy to make ginger syrup: I prepare a basic sugar-and-water simple syrup, in which I steep peeled, fresh ginger long enough that its strong, spicy bite really comes through. But you can skip this step altogether and buy the excellent ready-made ginger syrup from Brooklyn's Morris Kitchen. As a nod to the bitters and the clementine, I christened the drink the Bitter Darling. It was a hit. And even though I invented it especially for one party, I'm sure it'll be a mainstay of my winter-cocktail repertory.

Strolling along the Rue de Paris in Le Havre at dusk on an early winter day, I was mystified by the faint rosy glow of the concrete buildings around me. It couldn't be the sun, since the sky was shrouded with low pewter clouds scuttling in off of the English Channel. Maybe the briny sea air was causing some kind of chemical reaction with the lime in the cement? I'd have to ask my friend Arnaud when I met him a few minutes later for dinner. One way or another, this gentle color blunted the brute angles of these perplexing post-war buildings. One minute, I found them harshly beautiful; the next, cold and alien.

In recent years, some of the Whitney Museum of American Art's Biennials have featured over-the-top spectacle, while others have been lower key. On Wednesday, the museum announced an eclectic lineup for the 76th edition of its survey of contemporary American art, which opens March 1. The list includes Dennis Cooper, who plans to install a speaking "robot"; Andrea Fraser, who once posed as a museum tour guide as part of a performance piece; Kate Levant, who will have a hanging-fabric sculpture on display; and Nick Mauss, who is installing a velvet room. Also represented will be the experimental theatrical director and playwright Richard Maxwell; the filmmakers Vincent Gallo, Werner Herzog and Frederick Wiseman; the dancer and choreographer Michael Clark; and the rock band Red Krayola.

As someone whose life was upended by the Cultural Revolution, the Chinese director Zhang Yimou, 60, has every reason to be wary of politics. But his new film, "The Flowers of War," which opens Wednesday, is China's submission for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film and has already picked up a Golden Globe nomination. (It's the subject of an article in the Arts & Leisure section here.) It deals with one of the most horrific episodes in modern Chinese history: the Nanjing Massacre of December 1937, in which Japanese troops overran China's capital, killing more than 200,000 people and raping as many as 80,000 women.

The National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity has asked two journals, Science and Nature, to keep out details of certain research from articles they plan to publish about the spread of a deadly flu virus. The virus normally doesn't travel from person to person, but scientists managed to make a highly transmissible form (at least in ferrets, which provide a good model of what viruses will do in people). The government board fears the information could be used by terrorists to create deadly viruses and touch off epidemics.

Want more information about the items scattered around the Mac OS X desktop, like the number of items inside a folder or the resolution of an image? Just click the desktop background and go to the View menu in the Mac's Finder. Choose Show View Options from the menu and turn on the checkbox next to "Show item info." The desktop icons now display that additional data. If you decide that the Mac might be showing you too much information, just repeat the steps and remove the check from the box next to "Show item info."

A plurality of New York voters said Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo broke campaign promises to oppose tax increases and bring an end to Albany's tradition of secret deal-making when he overhauled the state's tax code earlier this month, according to a new poll released on Tuesday. The poll, conducted by Quinnipiac University, found that a large majority of voters nonetheless approved of Mr. Cuomo's job performance. Many of them also appeared uncertain about how the agreement to change the state's personal income tax would affect them.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about the lineup for the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival next summer referred incorrectly to performances scheduled during a weeklong homage to the choreography of the festival's founder, Ted Shawn. A rotating cast will perform original choreography, not Mr. Shawn's work. The report also referred incorrectly to the scheduled world premiere of a work by the Swedish choreographer and dancer Pontus Lidberg. It is not yet titled; ''Morphoses'' is the name of the company that will perform it, not the name of the work.

If the idea of Christina Ricci joining Bebe Neuwirth in Classic Stage Company's coming production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' isn't sufficiently tantalizing on its face value, think of it as the coming together of extended members of the Addams Family. The company said on Tuesday that Ms. Ricci would appear in that fairy-dusted Shakespeare play as Hermia, the diminutive but excitable Athenian, of whom her friend Helena says: ''She was a vixen when she went to school; And though she be but little, she is fierce.'' Ms. Neuwirth was previously announced to star as the fairy queen, Titania.

Shares of the Jefferies Group surged nearly 23 percent on Tuesday as stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter results helped restore confidence in the investment bank after it had been whipsawed in recent months by worries over its exposure to Europe. The firm also noted that it had shrunk its balance sheet by nearly a quarter and reduced leverage, further comforting investors.

(CBS) A HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS WITH MARTINA McBRIDE Ms. McBride, above, hosts this annual concert dedicated to promoting adoption and telling uplifting stories about children who found families. Between musical performances from Mary J. Blige, Justin Bieber, Gavin DeGraw and others, families that have adopted discuss the experience. One story is from the Hendersons of Helena, Ala., who were inspired to adopt their daughter Brittney after watching a previous presentation of ''A Home for the Holidays.'' Denise Richards, who adopted her daughter Eloise, will also reflect on her decision. 4 P.M. (Showtime2) DORIAN GRAY (2009) Claiming his inheritance, Dorian Gray (Ben Barnes) moves into a home in Victorian London, where he meets the aristocrat and dissolute hedonist Lord Henry Wotton (Colin Firth), who corrupts the newcomer into joining his lifestyle of wild abandon. To keep the good times from stopping, Dorian wishes to preserve his youthful looks forever, so he makes a deal with the devil: for the price of his soul he will show no signs of aging, but a painted portrait of him will reflect the toll of time and a life of indulgence. The portrait becomes as grotesque as his excesses, and when Dorian falls in love with a woman, he must keep the painting a secret. The movie is based on a novel by Oscar Wilde.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Dec. 13 about the discovery of two old episodes from the BBC's ''Doctor Who'' television series that were believed to be lost misstated the series' history. It began nearly 50 years ago, not 40.

Several newly opened Broadway musicals struggled to sell tickets last week, according to box office data released on Monday, as holiday tourists and others appeared to favor long-running hits like ''The Lion King'' and star-driven productions like Hugh Jackman's one-man concert. The musical ''Lysistrata Jones,'' which had a popular downtown run last spring and opened Wednesday on Broadway to some strong reviews, continued to be one of the poorest-selling musicals in recent history: The show grossed only $123,750 for eight performances last week, or about 15 percent of the maximum possible amount. (Most musicals need to gross about 55 percent of the maximum just to pay weekly running costs.)

Brian Bassett is the founder of SNY's The Jets Blog. You can follow him on Twitter at @Brian--Bassett. He and Ed Valentine of Big Blue View will be writing about the Jets and the Giants in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday. It is indisputable that the Giants are the firstborns of football in the New York area. Big Blue existed before even Joe Namath or Y. A. Tittle roamed the earth. As early members of the N.F.L., the Giants are steeped in tradition. Their legacy cannot be questioned.

An obituary on Thursday about George Whitman, the longtime owner of the Shakespeare & Company bookstore in Paris, referred incorrectly to a quotation written on a wall of his store. The words ''Be not inhospitable to strangers, lest they be angels in disguise'' are a variation on a passage from the Bible; although Mr. Whitman himself attributed them to the poet W.B. Yeats, they were not written by Yeats.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Israel's release of Palestinian prisoners on Sunday, the second half of a swap in which a captive Israeli soldier, Gilad Shalit, was returned to Israel from Gaza in October, misstated the location of Ofer Prison, the departure point of the released prisoners. It is in the West Bank, not in Israel. The article also misstated the number of prisoners released in the first part of the swap, in October. It was 477 -- not 1,027, which was the total number released over both phases of the swap. And the article misstated Israeli charges against one of the freed prisoners, Izzedine Abu Sneineh, who had been arrested three years ago at age 15. Israel had accused him of weapons training, attempted murder and possession of explosives -- not throwing stones and hanging Palestinian flags from telephone poles.

She has captivated New Yorkers for 16 years, the daughter of Manhattan academics convicted in Peru of aiding a leftist terrorist group, famous for a fist-waving rant to television cameras that cemented her reputation among Peruvians as a dangerous radical. On Tuesday, as the woman, Lori Berenson, touched down on American soil for the first time since her arrest, nothing about her recalled that image as she pushed a luggage cart across the shiny floor of Newark Liberty International Airport, her 2-year-old son, Salvador, trotting beside her.

A television review on Saturday about ''Method to the Madness of Jerry Lewis,'' on Encore, referred incorrectly to an invention by Mr. Lewis, called video assist, that enabled him to see a scene he had just shot while still on the set. It used a form of videotape; it was not created ''long before videotape.''

The Obama administration's surprise announcement Friday that it planned to give states broad leeway to pick the benefits offered under the federal health care law offers yet another example of a gradualist approach to carrying out its signal domestic policy achievement. Facing vociferous Republican opposition, a looming Supreme Court decision on the constitutionality of the law and the practical challenges of overhauling the vast health insurance market for small businesses and individuals, federal officials are choosing to avoid some crucial choices until well after the 2012 elections. While critics accuse the administration of political expediency, the officials insist the decisions have been based on sound policy judgments.

Santa had a few minutes to kill before a holiday party the other evening, so he pulled up his sleeves and showed off some of his tattoos: a dragon, a sailboat and, inked across the nape of his neck, the phrase ''Meat Is Murder.'' The man in red, played by Justin Brannan, was sitting in the Brooklyn office of his boss, City Councilman Vincent J. Gentile, whose district includes Bay Ridge and Dyker Heights. Mr. Brannan, 33, is the councilman's director of communications and legislative affairs.

Norman Krim, an electronics visionary who played a pivotal role in the industry's transition from the bulky electron vacuum tube, which once lined the innards of radios and televisions, to the tiny, far more powerful transistor, died on Dec. 14 in a retirement home in Newton, Mass. He was 98. The cause was congestive heart failure, his son Robert said.

An obituary on Tuesday about Warren Hellman, the Wall Street investor and patron of bluegrass music, misspelled the name of the mayonnaise company that some mistakenly assumed his family founded. It is Hellmann's, not Hellman's.

DE WITT, Iowa - Rick Santorum, who was the first Republican presidential hopeful to visit all 99 Iowa counties in a quest to gain traction for the party's nomination, received a lift on Tuesday by collecting a highly coveted endorsement from Bob Vander Plaats, one of the most visible leaders of the Christian conservative movement. Two weeks before the Iowa caucuses open the Republican nominating contest, many of the state's evangelical voters have yet to unify behind one candidate. Tensions among influential groups have split the support of Christian conservatives, but Mr. Vander Plaats urged party activists to support Mr. Santorum.

LONDON - Goldman Sachs, Vodafone and other big businesses were treated too favorably by British tax officials, potentially costing the nation billions in lost revenue, according to a government report released Tuesday. The report did not say how much the deals, often struck at expensive restaurants, cost the government. But the government said there were 2,700 unresolved cases with big companies, with potential taxes of 25 billion ($39 billion) as of March 31.

Federal authorities investigating the collapse of MF Global have uncovered e-mails that detail the transfers of money in the firm's last days, including transfers that contained customer money, according to people close to the investigation. One e-mail chain refers to the transfer of roughly $200 million that MF Global owed JPMorgan Chase on Oct. 28 - the firm's last business day before it filed for bankruptcy. In that chain, a senior official in the firm's Chicago office was told to make the transfer, said the people close to the investigation who requested anonymity because the inquiry was still open.

We often think of the Super Bowl winner as a dominant team that had an inevitable rise to power, but that's not often the case. In fact, last season, the Packers surprised everybody -- well, almost everybody -- by winning the Super Bowl as a No. 6 seed. Who wasn't surprised? In November, Toni Monkovic noted that the Packers were a sleeper because of their great points differential. Before the playoffs, Jason Lisk predicted that the sixth-seeded Packers would go to the Super Bowl for similar reasons. History tells us that it's not always the team with the best record that wins the Super Bowl. In the A.F.C., four teams have clinched the playoffs, while Denver and the Jets would be in with two wins, or one win and some help. (There's a mathematical possibility that the Jets could lose the tiebreaker even if they win both games, but it's remote.) In the N.F.C., three teams have clinched a playoff spot, and the Falcons and the Lions are just one win (or no wins and some help) away from earning a playoff berth. The final spot goes to the N.F.C. East winner, and if the Giants or Cowboys win their final two games, the division is theirs.

Thanks to festivals like Under the Radar and Coil, January is a busy month for devotees of international theater in New York. But things promise to be even more active than usual next month, when a new event called the Times Square International Theater Festival makes its debut. The event, which will run Jan. 16 to 22, will feature nearly a score of works from three continents at the Times Square Arts Center on West 43rd Street. The festival is being organized by Roy Arias, an actor who has worked in both English and Spanish, and Alfred Preisser, who was the founding director of the Classical Theater of Harlem and is starting a new theater company next year.

IF the past is a foreign country, then Christmas is its capital city. We can't help but remember it the way we saw it and tasted it. The glow of lights. The scent of pine needles. The snap of a cookie. That first bite of morning bacon. Christmas is all about memories that can never quite be recaptured, although year after year we try to summon them.

When Gov. Rick Perry of Texas entered the Republican presidential race four months ago, his bumper-sticker message (and the slogan painted on his bus) was ''Get America Working Again.'' Two weeks before the Iowa caucuses, his campaign bus, parked outside the historic Decker Hotel in Maquoketa, Iowa, on Tuesday, reflected how faith was central to his closing argument. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

OFFER REBUFFED Talbots, the women's fashion retailer, rejected an unsolicited buyout offer from a private equity firm as too low. The company said on Tuesday that it would instead explore strategic alternatives, essentially putting itself on the block. The bid of $3 a share from Sycamore Partners, made on Dec. 6, valued the retailer at about $212 million. The bid was seen as a lifeline to Talbots, which has struggled with below-average sales. Talbots' chief executive, Trudy F. Sullivan, above, is planning to step down. KEVIN ROOSE

An article on Tuesday about a federal trade ruling that some features in smartphones that use Google's Android software infringe on an Apple patent misidentified the operating system of the HTC Titan, a product of the HTC Corporation. The Titan runs on Windows Phone software, not on Android.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa - A day after Newt Gingrich forcefully denounced the proliferation of outside money into the Republican presidential race, one of his longtime aides announced that he was joining a group to help Mr. Gingrich win the party's nomination. Rick Tyler, who had been at Mr. Gingrich's side for years before stepping down this summer as the campaign was on the cusp of imploding, said that he was joining Winning Our Future, a Super PAC created to aid the Gingrich candidacy.

The financially troubled Mets announced Tuesday that they were eliminating their minor league team in the Class A Gulf Coast League. That move could save them between $750,000 and $800,000, according to executives with other franchises who are familiar with the cost of running those teams. According to Jim Duquette, who was the Mets' farm director and their general manager and now is an analyst on Sirius XM's MLB Network Radio, the move saves money but may also reflect a new drafting philosophy. The Gulf Coast League is usually for draftees out of high school and for international signees. Most college draftees go straight to the New York-Penn League or the Florida State League, where the Mets retain affiliates.

The Communists were big winners in recent parliamentary elections, capturing nearly 20 percent of the popular vote and cementing their place as the most formidable opposition bloc, as voters began to express their exhaustion with United Russia, the governing party of Prime Minister Vladimir V. THERE came a point when we started celebrating Christmas in the warm humidity of a South Florida winter. There was family down there, retired and happy. Our children, tiny and burbling, were content to lie with them in the condo living room, in mottled sun and a soft breeze off Estero Bay. I remember the smell of Christmas morning toast, slathered in butter and marmalade, set against the scent of mangrove and mud flat. I remember soft scrambled eggs against Dean Martin singing ''Silver Bells.''

Michael Kors Holdings not only sells fashion that people crave, it has also offered shares that were a hit with investors. BRENNER--Dr. Egon. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Dr. Egon Brenner, former Deputy Chancellor and Vice Chancellor for Academic Affairs. A 1944 alumnus of The City College, he joined the faculty in 1946 and later served as the College's Provost and Dean of its School of Engineering. Dr. Brenner was deeply committed to the University's mission to offer access to quality higher education. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson, Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

The whimsical secret of Audrey Hepburn's royal status may be the heart of William Wyler's ''Roman Holiday,'' but for years the romantic comedy concealed another more troubling truth: the film was missing the screenwriting credit of Dalton Trumbo, the blacklisted writer and its original author, and instead attributed his work to Ian McLellan Hunter. Now, nearly 60 years after the 1953 release of ''Roman Holiday,'' the Writers Guild of America, West said it had restored Trumbo's credit following the efforts of Trumbo's and Hunter's sons. Trumbo, who died in 1976, was one of 10 filmmakers - the so-called Hollywood Ten - who were cited for contempt of Congress in 1947 when they refused to testify about their political beliefs before the House Un-American Activities Committee; he served 11 months in prison and was effectively unable to continue working in the film industry. After Trumbo wrote the screenplay for ''Roman Holiday'' in exile in Mexico, Hunter, who was later blacklisted himself, served as a front writer, receiving the payment for the work (which he passed along to Trumbo) as well as the writing credit (which he shared with another writer, John Dighton).

In the classic Monty Python sketch ''Upper-Class Twit of the Year,'' a group of bumbling aristocrats compete on an obstacle course full of challenges both athletic (leaping over books of matches) and misanthropic (kicking beggars, insulting waiters). The competitor Oliver St. John-Mollusc, ''thought by many to be this year's outstanding twit,'' somehow runs himself over with a convertible midway through the race. John Cleese, as the play-by-play announcer, later says of Oliver, ''He's dead, but he's not necessarily out of it.'' Oliver's fate neatly sums up the current state of the Philadelphia Eagles. They were thought by many to be this year's outstanding twit, and they possessed a remarkable capacity for running themselves over. Yet they are not necessarily out of it.

HELLMAN--F. Warren. The Officers of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourn the passing of philanthropist, business leader, civic mediator, preeminent citizen, and revered Academy Fellow F. Warren Hellman. Founder of Hellman & Friedman, his interests and expertise ranged from the future of the American scientific enterprise to the preservation of the nation's musical heritage. We were blessed to have worked closely with him and his staff to create the Hellman Fellowship in Science and Technology Policy and the Commission on the Humanities and Social Sciences. Warren, a member of the Academy Trust, was a man of warmth, wit and wisdom and will be deeply missed. We extend our condolences to his wife Chris, his children, and his staff. Louis W. Cabot, Chair of the Board Leslie C. Berlowitz, President

A pair of Golden Globe nominations for the HBO comedy ''Enlightened'' may have helped it earn a second season, but three other shows on that channel - ''Hung,''''Bored to Death'' and ''How to Make It in America'' - will not be ascending to another plane and have been canceled. On Tuesday, HBO said it had picked up a new season of ''Enlightened,'' a series created by Laura Dern and Mike White and starring Ms. Dern as a woman who returns to her job after a breakdown and a personal reawakening. The series has struggled in building an audience, drawing 200,000 viewers or fewer for new episodes, but has earned critical acclaim and last week received Golden Globe nominations for a comedy or musical series and for actress in a comedy or musical (Ms. Dern).

FLEISCHNER--Ruth. 90, died at home on December 19. Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Proud graduate of Hunter High School and Hunter College; admired and devoted co-owner of Camp Scatico; much loved mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, and great-aunt. We will all miss her. Services Thursday, 9:30am, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam. Shiva Thursday, 4:30-7:00pm, at her home.

GOLDMAN--Jacob E.,90, died Tuesday. The funeral will be held Thursday at 10:30am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel. A former executive at Xerox and founder of the famed Palo Alto Research Center (PARC), Goldman was a dynamic leader and ardent supporter of innovative technologies. He was a lifelong Zionist, and supporter of the Weitzman Institute and Technion. He is survived by his wife Rhoda Miller Goldman, sister Judy Crystal, children Melvin, Edith, and Beth, step-sons Shalom, Ari, and Dov, eight grandchildren, and eight great-grandchildren.

In a statement on its Web site, the F.A. said it had found ''a charge of misconduct against Luis Suarez proven.'' Although the first season of "The X Factor" was never the 20-million-viewer juggernaut that Simon Cowell, its creator-producer-judge, had promised, the singing competition has still been a success for Fox, with an average of 10.9 million viewers tuning in live for each episode. (Factoring in the audiences that watched the show on DVR in the following seven days, that number grows to 12.4 million.) But network executives are probably a little concerned with the lack of ratings momentum heading into the finale, which was evident on Wednesday night, when the final performance show was essentially flat when compared to last week, despite almost no original competition from the other networks. The 90-minute episode averaged 11.1 million total viewers, up slightly from 10.7 million last Wednesday, but down just as slightly in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic segment.

There are any number of things I'd rather be doing 72 hours before Christmas than writing about the payroll tax debate, but it's an important window into the continuing policy dysfunction afflicting the Republican Party. The problem, to be clear, doesn't lie in the particular stance that the House Republicans have taken over the last week, insisting on a full-year extension of the payroll tax cut rather than two-month extension agreed to in the Senate. (On the merits, the House is right to want a full-year extension, the Senate's punt was an embarrassment, and the compromise that may be in the offing looks like better policy than a purely short-term deal.) Rather, it lies in the fact that we've been having drawn-out negotiations about the issue at all. Republicans should have just taken yes for answer, embraced a bipartisan tax cut, declared victory and gone home for Christmas. Instead, a Republican Party that blithely voted to extend the Bush tax cuts without any offsets suddenly became very, very concerned about "paying for" a far more modest measure, and a G.O.P. that's supposedly committed to the lowest possible middle class tax burden decided that it needed to extract concessions from a Democratic president in exchange for supporting ... a middle class tax cut.

Though we like to think of ourselves as a humble people who disdain ostentatious display, there are those occasions that encourage, nay, demand the chest-thumping, post-touchdown hubris inherent in our species. One of these is the presentation of a frosty bottle of Champagne. It's like a convoluted Myers-Briggs test for personalities. Many people open such a gift, even on New Year's Eve, with the gravity of a monk, showing the respect and discretion due a vinous masterwork. But there are those more excitable oenophiles, whose personal standard - "What Would Pirates Do?" - dictates freeing the bubbly soul by lopping off the bottle's neck with a saber.

The diamond pattern on this hand-carved rock crystal and white gold "Power" ring ($14,000) may look like a snowflake, but it actually represents the sun. "The energy of the sun is the most powerful force on earth," says the New York-based jeweler Visnja Brdar. "I wanted to create a piece that reflected that energy. When I wear it, I radiate and feel that anything is possible." Known for graphic simplicity and fastidious pavé work, all of Brdar's pieces have uplifting themes like Love, Courage, Freedom and Faith. She may as well have called this one Perseverance, since it took two years to make. "I finally found a way for the crystal to appear as if it is floating on the finger. It is perfect."

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

Not long after the pioneering optical brand L.A. Eyeworks set up shop in 1979, in a tiny storefront on Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles, its founders, Barbara McReynolds and Gai Gherardi, had an audacious idea. Andy Warhol's Interview Magazine was considered "the" magazine for all things hip and cool. McReynolds and Gherardi, who were generating buzz with the bold colors and modern shapes of their eyeglass frames, decided to advertise in Interview. The idea of a small shop taking out a full-page ad in a prominent national magazine was a little outrageous, but it led to the advertising campaign that has defined L.A. Eyeworks for nearly 30 years.

Jacob E. Goldman, a physicist who as Xerox's chief scientist founded the company's vaunted Palo Alto Research Center, which invented the modern personal computer, died on Tuesday in Westport, Conn. He was 90. Read the obituary by John Markoff in Thursday's New York Times.

It's been a busy year for Carine Roitfeld, who was replaced last December as the powerful editor of French Vogue by a former friend, Emmanuelle Alt. There have been wild parties she has hosted, fashion magazines and ads she has collaborated on, and talk of starting a new magazine. Ms. Roitfeld, Eric Wilson writes, "has taken every opportunity to demonstrate the value of her brand, post-Vogue," and concludes: "Rarely has the stock price of a fashion figure shown such resilience, after taking a severe blow to the side, since Lady Duff-Gordon survived the sinking of the Titanic."

In Thursday's New York Times, Julie Scelfo writes about how Skype, an eight-year-old technology, is being used in new ways in growing numbers of American homes. The Darvick family of Birmingham, Mich., for example, celebrates what they call "Skypanukkah," to observe the Jewish holiday; with family members spread out in three different cities, they light the Hanukkah candles together through video chat.

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has released its annual report and our colleague Michael Cieply reports that the organization is flush with cash. Total revenue amounted to $115 million. That's up about 15 percent over the previous year's take -- partly because of the Oscars telecast, but a 52 percent rise in investment income really helped. Expenses increased only about 2 percent. Can anyone guess the biggest cost? That's right: Academy Awards-related activities. Read more »

Texans at Colts Thursday, 8:20 Line: Texans by 5 1/2. It only took one loss to for the euphoria of the Texans' first-ever division title to fade into pessimism about their playoff chances. The Texans are relying on third-string quarterback T.J. Yates to remain viable, top receiver Andre Johnson's recovery from a pulled hamstring has been slow (he has been ruled out for Sunday), top pass rusher Mario Williams (torn pectoral muscle) is long gone, defensive coordinator Wade Philips is recovering from surgery, and Arian Foster has fumbled three times in four games as the strain of carrying the offense has taken its toll. A first-round playoff bye does not appear likely, though Ravens and Steelers losses kept the possibility alive, and a wild-card round battle with either of those teams (or the Jets) probably means an early exit for a team whose freshman quarterback is not ready to read graduate-level defenses. The Texans used all of their fuel to this altitude and have nothing left to navigate a soft landing.

Albert A. Foer, the president of the American Antitrust Institute, was enjoying a restful Sunday last March when news broke that AT&T was seeking to buy T-Mobile USA. Dismayed by the possible blockbuster cellphone merger, Mr. Foer rushed to the institute's global headquarters -- the first-floor study of his Washington home -- and swung into action.

Want more information about the items scattered around the Mac OS X desktop, like the number of items inside a folder or the resolution of an image? Just click the desktop background and go to the View menu in the Mac's Finder. Choose Show View Options from the menu and turn on the checkbox next to ''Show item info.'' The desktop icons now display that additional data. If you decide that the Mac might be showing you too much information, just repeat the steps and remove the check from the box next to ''Show item info.'' Personal Tech invites questions about computer-based technology to QandA@ nytimes.com. This column will answer questions of general interest, but letters cannot be answered individually.nThis is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Saturday with an article about the deteriorating relations between Occupy Wall Street protesters and the Trinity Wall Street church over a gravel lot near Canal Street and Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan that demonstrators want to use as an alternate campsite referred incorrectly in some editions to the lot's proximity to the New York Stock Exchange. It is about a mile from the exchange, not ''barely one block'' away. (As the article correctly noted, the church is about a block from the exchange.)

A chart on Tuesday with an article about threats to long-distance migrations by wildlife, using data from a study on such migrations, misstated the distance of the calliope hummingbird's annual trip from southern Canada and the northern United States to Mexico. As the article correctly noted, the round-trip distance -- not the one-way distance -- is 4,000 to 5,000 miles.

3:06 p.m. | Updated Daniel J. Socolow, the director since 1997 of the MacArthur Foundation fellowship program known as the ''genius'' awards, will retire sometime in the next several months, foundation officials are expected to announce Thursday. While he wielded influence in the selection process and delighted in making the telephone calls to the winners, he did not directly choose them. Some 850 people in fields from poetry to physics have been named fellows since 1981. Those lucky winners not only had the prestige of the so-called ''genius'' awards (a term the foundation discourages), they also receive a no-strings-attached $500,000 fellowship from the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation in Chicago. The idea of the program was to liberate creative people in a broad swath of fields - from the well-known to the little-known - to do their work without worrying about resources.

The federal court monitor charged with diversifying the city's Fire Department is allowing black firefighters to go door to door to persuade black applicants to join the department, over objections from city lawyers. As part of a pilot program that was described in papers filed on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, members of the Vulcan Society, an organization of black firefighters that sued the city for discrimination, will be provided with a list of black applicants whose applications are incomplete, so that Vulcan members can visit their homes and encourage them to follow up.

WUKAN, China -- Leaders in the fishing village of Wukan, in Guangdong Province, said Wednesday afternoon that they were halting the public protests against what they have called illegal land sales by local officials. The announcement was made in the village square, at a rally of more than 1,000 residents, by two men who had led the protests, Lin Zuluan and Yang Semao. Afterward, villagers took down white protest banners that had been hung around the square. Villagers had kept Communist Party officials and the police out of Wukan for 11 days, erecting barricades made of tree trunks at roads into the village.

PESSINA CREMONESE, Italy -- Alongside family names like Ferrari and Galli, the telephone directories in Cremona Province have been listing an increasingly common surname: Singh. For 20 years, Indian immigrants from Punjab have been settling in Italy's agricultural heartland to work, primarily on farms and often as bergamini, as dairy workers are known.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the concern of some economists that a failure to extend the payroll tax cut could undercut the country's fragile economic recovery described incorrectly the increase in taxes that would occur without such Congressional action. Taxes on the payroll income of America's 160 million wage earners would increase to 6.2 percent from 4.2 percent; the change would not amount to a 2 percent tax increase.
SAVADA--Lila. The partners, associates and employees of Adams & Co. offer their heartfelt sympathy to the family of Lila Savada, the matriarch of the Savada family, long time partners of our firm.

Thirteen years before he became famous as one of television's great slobs, Oscar Madison on ''The Odd Couple,'' Jack Klugman had his breakout role in the 1957 film ''12 Angry Men'' as Juror 5. He played a hardened young man who brought street smarts to the jury deliberations in a murder trial in a cast that also included Henry Fonda (as the main character Juror 8), Lee J. Cobb, and Martin Balsam. Mr. Klugman is now the only surviving actor who was on the jury - a detail much on his mind Wednesday as he spoke about his latest career move. George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J., announced that Mr. Klugman - who is 89 - will play Juror 9 in a production of the stage adaption ''Twelve Angry Men'' there March 13-April 8, 2012. ''Working with Fonda and the director Sidney Lumet was like a dream for me, because I could tell they appreciated me and my work and I felt very, very good then about deciding to become an actor,'' Mr. Klugman said by telephone, his voice now raspy and scratchy after throat cancer surgery two decades ago. (He plans to wear a microphone and have his lines memorized for the production.) ''It'll be an honor to appear in the play - I'll be thinking of all those guys from the film.''

For a couple of weeks in November, the story captivated even the casual college football follower, perhaps because it did not concern allegations of child sexual abuse or recruiting violations. Yale's senior quarterback, Patrick Witt, the most productive passer in the program's history, was wrestling with a decision that generated national attention and debate. Should he play in the Harvard-Yale game one more, final time, or should he attend an interview in Atlanta as a finalist for a Rhodes scholarship? Because of the schedule of the events, he could not do both.

Ben Greenberg plays guitar in the Brooklyn band Zs, but he is also the monocrat of Hubble, a project of one. He performed a short set at Zebulon in Brooklyn's Williamsburg neighborhood on Tuesday; so did Diamond Terrifier, alias the saxophonist Sam Hillmer, also from Zs. Individually, they're working on related forms of minimalism, an old idea, but they're post-genre people, interested in the dirty magic of warping and transforming sounds and languages you might already know. Hubble makes music about small phrases and layered rhythms and tiny melodic variations: adding or bending some notes in a chain. (You can hear it on a strong new album, ''Hubble Drums,'' released last month by Northern Spy.) Mr. Greenberg sounds as though he's starting from the usual 20th-century source material, Terry Riley in particular, and seeing where his own skill and nervous system can take it.

The South Street Seaport Museum will reopen on Jan. 26, the institution announced on Wednesday. The museum, which has been plagued by financial problems, was provisionally taken over by the Museum of the City of New York in September, with help from a $2 million grant from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. When it reopens, the museum will use 16 of its 21 galleries; the rest will be used for school programs, Susan Henshaw Jones, the City Museum's director, said in a telephone interview. ''For the first time in the history of the Seaport Museum, we are activating the whole place,'' she said.

Two stores, on Staten Island and in Chinatown, have agreed to stop selling roll-your-own cigarettes after New York City accused them of being fronts for evading cigarette taxes. The owners of the stores, both called Island Smokes, agreed to close them by February as part of a consent decree filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, according to the city's Law Department. They also agreed that no one associated with the businesses would operate a similar enterprise in New York City; stores had already been planned for the East Village and Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

An article on Wednesday about a plunge in the value of Iran's currency, the rial, caused in part by reports that Iran had suspended trade relations with the United Arab Emirates, quoted incorrectly from a statement by Iran's vice president, Mohammad-Reza Rahimi, in which he warned the United Arab Emirates against supporting American sanctions against Iran. Mr. Rahimi said such support ''does not hurt Iran but hurts itself.'' He did not say ''does not hurt the U.S. but hurts itself.''

DUVETICA, a young Italian outerwear label, is a stylish new choice for light-as-air puffers and vests. The company was founded in 2004 by Giampiero Vagliano and Stefano Rovoletto, a former president and brand manager of Moncler. The coats, first introduced, to great success, in Japan, are cut slim, filled with French down (90 percent gray goose down and 10 percent small feather, to be precise) and, relatively speaking, less expensive than Moncler. They also come in chic and unexpected color combinations. Styles for women, including packable hooded jackets in colors like granite with a purple lining and shiny black knee-length coats with teal zippers, are at Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale's. For men, glossy hooded jackets and vests, like this wine-colored style with a navy blue lining, are up on Mr Porter.

WASHINGTON - The Environmental Protection Agency unveiled new standards on Wednesday sharply limiting emissions of mercury and other toxic pollutants from the nation's coal- and oil-burning power plants.

An article on Wednesday about a British government report that found that tax officials treated Goldman Sachs and other big businesses too favorably misidentified the employer of a whistle-blower who was the source of some of the information. He is an employee of the British revenue office, Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs; he is not employed by Goldman Sachs.

In recent years, some of the Whitney Museum of American Art's Biennials have featured over-the-top spectacle, while others have been lower key. On Wednesday, the museum announced an eclectic lineup for the 76th edition of its survey of contemporary American art, which opens March 1. The list includes Dennis Cooper, who plans to install a speaking ''robot''; Andrea Fraser, who once posed as a museum tour guide as part of a performance piece; Kate Levant, who will have a hanging-fabric sculpture on display; and Nick Mauss, who is installing a velvet room. Also represented will be the experimental theatrical director and playwright Richard Maxwell; the filmmakers Vincent Gallo, Werner Herzog and Frederick Wiseman; the dancer and choreographer Michael Clark; and the rock band Red Krayola. An earlier version of this post misstated the edition of the biennial. It is the 76th, not the 75th.

Dance companies are supposed to be shrinking, not starting up in these recessionary times. Not so at the Dance Theater of Harlem, which closed its company in 2004. Theater officials on Wednesday announced the start of auditions to create a new stripped down troupe of 18 dancers, which will begin rehearsing in August and touring in October and aims to return to a New York stage by April 2013. Foundations and others have contributed about $2.5 million toward the company's start-up plan, said Laveen Naidu, the executive director. But next season depends on whether the theater can raise more money - enough to help finance a $5 million budget. Mr. Naidu said Dance Theater of Harlem plans to tour for 12 weeks and is negotiating with theaters. ''There's a hunger for this company,'' he said. Touring will bring in much-needed revenue too, he added.

6:46 p.m. | Updated Newt Gingrich's mad dash to get on the ballot in Virginia, seen as a test of his ability to go the distance, seems to have paid off, as Mr. Gingrich said Wednesday that his campaign had gathered more than enough signatures to qualify. ''We'll be on the ballot in Virginia,'' Mr. Gingrich said while campaigning here, adding that he planned to deliver the signatures to the state offices in Virginia on Thursday. ''I'll personally deliver them.''

Daniel H. Mudd, who faces accusations that he misled investors while he was the top executive of Fannie Mae, is taking a leave of absence from his role as chief executive of Fortress Investment Group. Last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission sued Mr. Mudd and five other former executives at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two mortgage-finance giants that helped feed the housing bubble and then faltered when it burst. In one of the most significant federal actions taken against crucial players in the mortgage crisis, the S.E.C. accused Mr. Mudd of playing down Fannie Mae's exposure to risky loans.

HERE'S a bit of good news for 11th-hour shoppers: Creatures of Comfort, the year-old NoLIta boutique by way of Los Angeles, has added silk pajamas to its private label for the holidays. ''I remember looking for these pajamas and not finding them except when I visited Asia,'' said Jade Lai, the owner. ''So last year I made my holiday wish list for things to stock this season, and silk pajamas were on the top of the list.'' The luxurious unisex pajamas come in eight different color combinations, including navy blue with red piping, as well as black, white, lavender and emerald green, all with contrasting piping. Silky pj's from Creatures of Comfort? Sounds right.

Still stuck for a gift to give your household shutterbug? Here are some of my favorite photo products from this year-as well as some perennial favorites-at a variety of prices. Canon PowerShot S100 - Even if you favor an SLR, every dedicated photographer should have a high-quality camera they can slip in a pocket; one like the Canon PowerShot S100 ($430). Thanks to a light sensor larger than what's normally found in cameras of its class, paired with a light-grabbing f2 lens, the Canon can get photos in low light that others can't. Its 5X optical zoom also works when you are shooting video. Shoot fully automated or manual, and the S100 has a handy ring around the lens that can be assigned any function, so you can use it to control shutter speed, aperture or even focus.

10:53 p.m. | Updated A new company with a strong focus on digital media has agreed to buy The Chicago Sun-Times and more than 40 other media properties from Sun-Times Media Holdings, the new company said Wednesday. The announcement was made in a news release late Wednesday night after numerous reports that The Sun-Times would be sold.

LOS ANGELES -The Orson Welles Oscar went to the highest-and unidentified -- bidder for $861,542, the Nate D. Sanders auction house said Tuesday evening. Welles received the Oscar in 1942 for his work on the script for ''Citizen Kane.'' It was thought to be lost and later replaced. But eventually the original turned up in the hands of a cinematographer who said he had received it from Welles as a gift, and, after a court fight, it was turned over to Welles's daughter Beatrice. When the original first went on the block, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences went to court to try to stop the sale, but lost. Sotheby's later tried to sell it, but ended that effort when an undisclosed reserve price was not met. And, now, finally the Oscar has been sold in an auction that, according to Sanders, included an underbid from the magician David Copperfield. ''I'm proud to have represented this fantastic award to the cinema collecting community,'' Nate D. Sanders, the auction house owner, said in a statement that was circulated late Tuesday. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

When Tyson Chandler was a rookie in Chicago, tall and skinny and months out of high school, he and his aspiring front-line co-star, Eddy Curry, would be summoned to the office of Jerry Krause, the Bulls' longtime general manager, for a twice-weekly chat. In 2001, in the post-championship Bulls-to-bust years, Krause had staked the team's future on the teenage big men. He shed his best player, forward Elton Brand, to match Curry, a low-post scorer, with Chandler, an athletic shot blocker. Krause envisioned resurrection by high rise.

While American audiences struggle to understand the dialogue in the trailer for Christian Bale's next Batman movie, the Chinese government has expressed itself loud and clear to that ''Dark Knight'' star, saying that Mr. Bale was trying to ''create news'' when he tried to visit a detained lawyer in China last week. Last Thursday, Mr. Bale, who was in China promoting his role in Zhang Yimou's film ''The Flowers of War,'' traveled to Shandong Province to visit with the lawyer, Chen Guangcheng, who is blind and has been confined to his home for 15 months. There, Mr. Bale was assaulted by government-backed guards who have similarly prevented other people from entering Mr. Chen's village, in a scene that was recorded by a CNN camera crew accompanying the actor. Mr. Chen has been a target of the government since taking on the case of thousands of women who were victims of forced sterilizations and abortions.

HONOLULU -- Hawaii should be a happy outpost for the Democratic Party. It has a Democratic governor. Democrats overwhelmingly control the Legislature. It has Barack Obama in the White House and all the prestige that brings, most recently an Asia-Pacific economic summit meeting with the president as its host, packing this city's streets, restaurants and hotels with international leaders. Yet these are hardly happy days for Hawaii Democrats. The governor, Neil Abercrombie, is ending his first year under a storm of criticism; he referred to himself the other evening as ''the most unpopular governor in America.'' Mr. Obama's struggles in Washington have cast a bit of a pall here.
